DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia's Ambassador To Washington Has Leukemia
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia's new ambassador to the United States has an early form of leukemia and is trying to decide whether to remain in this country or return to her own, The Washington Post said in its Wednesday editions. ``It's not that we don't have good doctors at home,'' Ambassador Rita Klimova told the newspaper. ``But we don't have the ability to protect patients from infection. That requires a high degree of sophistication in the hospitals.'' The ambassador, who assumed her diplomatic post five months ago, said her government will pay her medical bills, but she is concerned about the finances and does not want to run up a big tab. She said her decision on whether to stay in the United States will depend on finding treatment that ``fits in with someone's research plans.'' Ms. Klimova became ill in May, but the leukemia diagnosis is recent, the newspaper said. Leukemia is a form of cancer of the blood-cell forming system. Though the disease once was considered invariably fatal, treatment has improved dramatically in recent decades and years, and complete remissions may be obtained for some types.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Radio Personality Suffers Fatal Stroke On Air
DOC.TEXT: A 60-year-old public radio personality suffered a stroke while hosting his classical music show Tuesday morning and died a few hours later. Listeners to WETA-FM heard four minutes of empty air after announcer Bill Cerri began garbling his words and left his open microphone about 9 a.m. Long pauses are not unusual for classical music stations, but listeners sensed something was amiss and started calling the station, said Joe Davis, chief engineer for WETA. ``Our listeners were right on top of the situation,'' Davis said. ``Gosh, they knew that something was wrong with Bill. They were calling immediately.'' Cerri was taken to National Hospital for Orthopaedics and Rehabilitation in Arlington, Va., where he died at 1:38 p.m. He had a number of health problems, including Parkinson's disease, and had planned to take a disability retirement next month.

DOC.HEAD: Launching Commercial Satellites is a High-Risk Industry
DOC.TEXT: Imagine you paid a company to move your belongings from California to New York. In Kansas, the truck breaks down. You end up paying someone else to haul your stuff the rest of the way _ but it takes another couple of years. To add insult to injury, the first mover goes to court to forestall any attempt to get your money back. Farfetched? Well, that's about what is happening in the nervous, competitive, megabucks business of launching satellites for profit. And the moving company in this case _ the giant Martin Marietta Corp. _ claims it may have to get out of the commercial launching business if it loses in court. Martin Marietta is one of only three major American companies in that infant of private enterprise and the only one lifting the heaviest satellites. Should Martin Marietta's prediction come true, the European consortium Arianespace, the Chinese, the Soviets _ and someday the Japanese _ all will be waiting, rockets at the ready. Here is what happened: For $111.5 million, Martin Marietta agreed to launch a satellite for Intelsat, the international communications consortium. The satellite, valued at $157 million, lifted off from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on March 14 aboard Martin Marietta's Titan 3 rocket. Once in orbit, the satellite and the spent Titan were to separate and a much smaller booster attached to the Intelsat 6 was to take it on the next 22,000 miles of its journey to its work station. But Martin Marietta had miswired the rocket, the separation didn't take place and the satellite was trapped in a useless orbit. Engineers were finally able to split the two and Intelsat 6 is awaiting a 1992 visit by NASA astronauts who will attach a new booster rocket and send the satellite on its way. This will cost Intelsat another $90 million. According to a suit filed by Bethesda, Md.-based Martin Marietta in federal court in Baltimore, Intelsat demanded damages. Martin Marietta called that ``unlawfully coercive demands.'' The launch firm said its contract called only for a replacement launch at an undisclosed price ``in the event the Titan 3 mission fails for any reason.'' Intelsat could have bought insurance but didn't. ``I don't want to call it a pre-emptive strike,'' said Martin Marietta corporate spokesman Elliott H. Miller. ``We did this because it became clear they were going to file a civil damage suit. We are asking the court to essentially declare that the provisions of our contract are enforceable.'' A question at the heart of the suit filed by Martin Marietta is what constitutes a launch. Miller says that under terms of the contract with Intelsat ``when the engines are fired, that constituted a launch.'' Intelsat has until Sept. 4 to file an answer. A spokesman, Tony Trujillo, said the dispute is unfortunate because ``we don't have an ax to grind.'' He would not comment on the suit. In its complaint, Martin Marietta said that if it is forced to pay damages on the failed launch it may have to raise prices to an uncompetitive level or ``terminate its commercial launch business.'' To date, Martin Marietta has sold only four launches on the Titan 3 and its competitors say privately that the company might be getting out of the commercial launch business anyway. It has plenty of military customers. ``It's been a very competitive business,'' said spokesman Miller. ``One of the differences in competition has been the entry of foreign _ really government-owned and supported _ competitors such as China and now the Soviet Union.'' To put that competition on a level playing field, President Bush this week is expected to sign a new space policy setting forth conditions under which other countries can enter U.S. launch markets. The president also is expected to sign an agreement under which a subsidiary of United Technologies Corp. will be allowed to help build a launch facility in Australia that might someday be used by the Soviets. Such technical assistance requires an export license, and that has led to erroneous reports that the United States will be agreeing to send up American-built satellites on Soviet rockets. ``The real competition in launching heavyweight satellites is between ourselves and General Dynamics,'' said Douglas Heydon, president of Arianespace's American subsidiary. General Dynamics markets the Atlas. Spokesman Trujillo said Intelsat would have no hesitancy in purchasing launches from China or the Soviet Union. ``A diversity of suppliers is a situation we like to encourage,'' he said. Intelsat is a cooperative of 119 nations, including China. The Soviets are not members, but they use Intelsat's services.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Entertainment Chief on the Defensive Over Foul Language
DOC.TEXT: It can't be easy being Jeff Sagansky these days. Six months on the job, in charge of entertainment for the bottom-rated TV network, and everyone looking to you for a failsafe way to rocket out of last place. So there he stood before the nation's TV critics at their annual press tour this past weekend, proudly hyping CBS' new fall shows. The reporters wanted to talk about sex. And morality. And questionable dialogue uttered by children during peak, prime-time family viewing hours. Specifically, the reporters wanted to know why a 6-year-old girl will be delivering lines such as ``you suck'' at 8 p.m. on Mondays. The show in question is ``Uncle Buck,'' a fall TV spinoff of the John Candy film. In the pilot, the blond, cherubic child star also explains the crankiness of a female family member by saying ``she's ovulating.'' Some of the reporters at the Century Plaza Hotel news conference Sunday appeared righteously indignant. ``How can you say, Mr. Sagansky, that the networks are more sensitive now when you do have programs like `Uncle Buck' coming on the air?'' demanded one critic. Looking a bit uneasy, Sagansky replied, ``I'll tell you something, believe it or not, kids say that in homes all over America. And I don't think we can go and put on shows which have no relationship to reality.'' Besides, Sagansky added, the child is immediately reprimanded for such talk, and future episodes do not consistently contain that kind of dialogue. The reporters were unappeased and the 37-year-old, Harvard-educated programming executive spent much of the 45-minute press conference defending his network's standards. Or lack thereof, as some critics grumbled. Although a lot of time was spent dissecting the social value of ``Uncle Buck,'' many questions also concerned Sagansky's strategy for boosting ratings. Sagansky admitted his work is cut out for him. Part of his game plan for enhancing CBS' schedule has focused on wooing top writers and producers. That included giving carte blanche to Linda Bloodworth-Thomason and Harry Thomason, creators of the network's hit ``Designing Women.'' What the Thomasons came up with was ``Evening Shade,'' a comedy about life in a small Arkansas town that debuts with a one-hour pilot on Sept. 21. Starring Burt Reynolds, ``Evening Shade'' was one of three shows that Sagansky touted as having the fall schedule's ``most unique voice.'' The others were ``WIOU,'' a drama about a TV news operation in Chicago, and ``Lenny,'' a blue-collar situation comedy starring stand-up comic Lenny Clarke, a former Boston janitor. Sagansky also was asked about the wisdom of putting ``The Flash'' _ a new fantasy action thriller about a man who moves so fast his feet nearly catch fire _ on Thursdays at 8 p.m. The time period has been dominated for years by NBC's top-rated ``The Cosby Show,'' and Fox Broadcasting Co. recently announced a gutsy decision to move the phenomenally successful ``Simpsons'' family to the same half-hour slot. ``I knew that we had a great idea when we went in Thursday at 8,'' Sagansky said. ``Unfortunately, we weren't the only ones who had that idea.'' Fox has admitted that if ``The Simpsons'' bomb in their new time period, they will probably be sent back to Sunday nights, Sagansky said. ``So I don't want to run away from them, particularly if they're not going to be there.'' On the subject of the street-smart alternative network, Sagansky was asked if Fox could ever beat one of the big three in the overall Nielsen ratings. ``Not during my watch,'' Sagansky replied. ``Absolutely not.'' Another crucial aspect of Sagansky's vision, he said, is to lure younger viewers to CBS. ``When we talk about younger viewers for CBS, we're talking about people, you know, less than 60,'' he told reporters, who erupted in laughter. ``Look, for CBS, I'M a younger viewer.''

DOC.HEAD: Here's How $100 Billion Spending Cut Would Work
With PM-Budget Deficit; also moved for ams
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at how a $100 billion spending cut would be triggered by the Gramm-Rudman law, and what it would mean: HOW IT WORKS: The White House's Office of Management and Budget estimated Monday that the fiscal 1991 deficit will hit $168.8 billion, or $231.4 billion if the savings and loan bailout is counted. Between now and Oct. 1 _ the start of the new fiscal year _ OMB will monitor any new laws that affect spending or government revenue collections and take them into account. If the projected deficit exceeds $74 billion on Oct. 1 _ $10 billion above the target _ spending is cut temporarily by whatever amount is needed to reduce the shortfall to $64 billion. The cuts take effect permanently on Oct. 15. Savings and loan rescue spending is included in the deficit calculations under current law, but many in Congress and the Bush administration want to exclude those costs. DISTRIBUTION OF CUTS: 50 percent to defense, 50 percent to domestic programs. But portions are exempt in full or in part. _ Defense: About one-third of the $300 billion defense budget is exempt from Gramm-Rudman cuts because it has already been committed to long-term contracts. Of the remaining amount, the law allows the president to exempt personnel costs, such as salaries. He chose not to exempt personnel last year. If he made the same choice this time, according to OMB, this could mean dismissal of about 1 million troops, about half of the active-duty force; layoffs or dismissals of up to half the military's 1.1 million civilian employees, and a cut in weapon acquisition programs, such as reducing the request for major new naval ships from 15 to 11. If personnel costs were exempted, remaining programs would be slashed by 41.3 percent. This would mean that the amount of flight time for aircraft and steaming time for ships would be cut by half and about 80 percent of the military's civilian workers could lose their jobs. _ Domestic: Completely exempt from cuts are interest on the national debt; Social Security and several federal retirement and disability programs; several low-income programs including food stamps, Medicaid and child nutrition aid, and many veterans' programs. Several other programs can be cut only partially. Cuts in Medicare and some health programs for veterans and migrants are limited to 2 percent reductions. There are also special rules for support payments to farmers and for Guaranteed Student Loans. Spending on those programs subject to the full brunt of the cuts would be reduced by 38.4 percent. According to OMB, that could mean a one-year delay in hazardous waste cleanups at Energy Department sites; elimination of vaccines for polio, measles and other diseases for 1 million children; a 20 percent cut for FBI investigations into organized crime, and prevention of government plans to upgrade airline security overseas. DURATION OF CUTS: By law, they remain in effect for the entire fiscal year once Oct. 15 passes. But ``permanent'' Gramm-Rudman cuts have been rolled back before, most recently just last fall.

DOC.HEAD: Veto Threatened if Senate Crop Supports Enacted
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is threatening a veto of the 1990 farm bill if the crop support programs in the version expected to be debated this week in the Senate reaches the White House. The announcement came in a letter Monday to the Senate from Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, who said the programs were too costly at a time when the government is trying to cut the budget deficit. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Agriculture Committee, immediately criticized the letter as an ``eleventh-hour threat'' aimed at killing the five-year bill as part of an international trade negotiating strategy being pursued by President Bush and Yeutter. Senate leaders have said they would try to begin debate on the bill by Wednesday. Leahy's committee has estimated that the commodity programs in the bill would cost $55 billion over five years, but Yeutter said its spending requirements amount to $59 billion. This compares with an estimated $79.4 billion spent over the last five years under the 1985 law that expires this year. The veto threat follows efforts by Bush at the seven-nation economic summit in Houston last week to get the Europeans to reduce subsidies on farm products that the United States considers distorting to the international marketplace. A five-year farm bill could be viewed as limiting the promises negotiators could make to the other countries about U.S. policy. But members of the Senate and House agriculture committees have said they would make necessary adjustments based on the outcome of the ongoing talks over the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in Geneva, Switzerland. The administration has indicated support for a one-year extension of the current farm law. Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas said on Friday he would offer such legislation if the spending in the bill going to the floor is not reduced. ``The administration's veto threat is a thinly veiled effort to kill the farm bill so the administration can cut a back-room deal in Geneva, out of sight of the American farmer,'' said Leahy. Yeutter didn't mention the trade talks in his letter. He dwelled instead on the budget implications of the Senate's farm bill, criticizing every subsidy program in the legislation. ``From a budget standpoint, the cost of the bill is excessive,'' he said. Yeutter said that if the bill is sent to the president before budget talks with Congress are completed and without substantial savings and a change in the price and income support programs, ``the secretary of agriculture and the president's other senior advisers would recommend that he (Bush) veto the bill.'' The government subsidizes farmers who produce wheat, corn, rice, cotton, soybeans, sugar, dairy products, wool and mohair, honey and peanuts either by direct payment or manipulation of the marketplace. Leahy said the administration had ``cooked up new numbers'' in estimating the bill's impact on the budget. ``The reality is that the Senate farm bill is over $6 billion less than what the president proposed in January for current services,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pastry Chefs Say Let Them Eat Cake
DOC.TEXT: Whether Marie Antoinette ever really said, ``Let them eat cake'' remains in doubt, but 17 pastry chefs have created in wondrous constructions of chocolate and marzipan the cake she might have had in mind. Cakes that no peasant in pre-Revolutionary France likely ever got to taste surrounded a life-size ice sculpture of a guillotine and two cannons at the Plaza Hotel on Monday. Pastry chef Martin Howard of the Hudson River Club in New York designed three necklaces of chocolate jewels spilling out of chocolate jewel boxes. Pascal Scirrotto of Restaurant Deja-Vu in Philadelphia made a croquembouche, a towering, traditional wedding cake then and now in France. There even was a cake of three kinds of caviar, cream cheeses and Scotch salmon from Bruce Sobol of Caviarteria in New York. The fifth annual Bastille Day celebration, though two days late, ended with the selection of three of the chefs as the U.S. team for the International World Cup Pastry Competition next January in Lyon, France. One of them, Mary Cech from Jackson at Montgomery in San Francisco, prepared a fanciful tea party in chocolate, with a teapot of chocolate, elaborate place mats and lace napkins of white chocolate, and a cake of chocolate and strawberry. ``I went for a theme that was light and frilly,'' Cech said as she handed out tastes of her cake for judges and guests. The two other chefs going to France are Gil Renusson, executive pastry chef at the Amway Grand Plaza in Grand Rapids, Mich., and pastry chef Eric Bedoucha of the restaurant Adrienne at the Peninsula Hotel in New York. In a second competition, celebrity judges were given sheets to score their favorites. Some of the judges attracted as much attention as the cakes. A crowd pressed around judge Ivana Trump, the estranged wife of Donald Trump, wherever she stopped. Other judges included designer Mary McFadden and Robin Leach of ``Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous.'' Perhaps the plainest Jane cake was a chocolate sheet cake presented by pastry chef Chad Gilchrist of the Plaza Hotel. He had made a 2-foot-high replica of Versailles, with Marie Antoinette throwing cake to a crowd. But earlier in the day a door hit Gilchrist, and the cake went flying. It was destroyed. ``It was most disappointing,'' he said. ``Two days of work ended on a sour note.'' The event was a benefit for the Pierre Franey Scholarship Fund at Johnson & Wales University in Rhode Island. Pastry fans paid $50 a ticket.

DOC.HEAD: Multi-ethnic Melange On the Brink of Disintegration
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: While most of Europe is on the threshold of unification, Yugoslavia's deeply divided states cannot agree on how to remain together. The troubled Balkan country is on the brink of disintegration. Some politicians maintain that Yugoslavia has already falle apart. ``Yugoslavia no longer exists,'' said Dimitrij Rupel, foreign minister of Slovenia, the republic leading the rebellion against Yugoslavia as the world has known it for the last 70 years. The country was formed as a joint kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes in the aftermath of World War I. After being occupied and dismembered by the Germans in 1941, it re-emerged as a Communist-style federation of six ``peoples' republics'' with Macedonia, Montenegro and Bosnia-Hercegovina added to the three pre-war states under Yugoslavia's Communist founder Josip Broz Tito. During the Cold War, Tito's nationalist politics were useful to the West, which provided significant financial and other support to non-aligned Yugoslavia as a check on Soviet influence in the sensitive Balkans. This in turn helped Tito impose unity and the rule of a Communist Party that ostensibly rose above Yugoslavia's traditional ethnic rivalries. But traditional ethnic and regional rivalries began to bubble after Tito's death in 1980. And the message of greater democracy and human rights that spurred last year's revolutions in Eastern Europe also worked against the old-style centralized rule from Belgrade. On July 2, Slovenia proclaimed its full sovereignty, establishing an independent legal system and asserting the right to control all armed forces stationed on its territory. On the same day, ethnic Albanian deputies of the volatile southern province of Kosovo announced plans to secede from Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics. Croatia, the second-largest republic, has already demanded radical reshaping of the federal system bequeathed by Tito. President Franjo Tudjman's center-right party won a landslide victory in the republic's free elections this spring. Slovenia's freely elected president, Milan Kucan, said this month that his republic will secede, either alone or with Croatia, if the country does not swiftly become a loose confederation of fully independent states. ``The only thing that could keep us together is constant and brutal repression,'' Rupel said _ an apparent reference to repeated warnings by the Communist-run armed forces that the ``battle for Yugoslavia will not be fought without the military.'' In contrast, the Communist leaders of Serbia want a federal system with a strong central authority and they oppose free elections. Slobodan Milosevic, Serbia's president, has effectively ruled out confederation. He has said Serbia would agree only if its present borders are revised to include the estimated 2 million Serbs in Croatia and the central region of Bosnia-Hercegovina. Retaining Kosovo, an ancient Serbian heartland now dominated by ethnic Albanians, and the assertion of Serbian nationalism appear to take precedence over ties with Slovenia and traditional rival Croatia. Many Yugoslavs fear that Milosevic's demands, which brought him wide popularity among the Serbs, could trigger ethnic violence. Rupel described Milosevic's aspirations as ``lunatic.'' Behind the ethnic divisions lurk other clashes over introducing democacy and integrating Yugoslavia with Western Europe. Slovenia and Croatia want to join the integration processes going on throughout Europe. In July, their officials held exploratory talks with the European Community on eventually joining the grouping. The EC and the United States, however, view Yugoslavia as a single country and would like it to remain that way. It is difficult to see how the Yugoslavs can reconcile their deep differences to meet Western demands for unity and for an improved human rights record. Amnesty International and the European Parliament repeatedly have condemned what they see as gross human rights violations by Serbia against Kosovo's ethnic Albanians. At least 60 Kosovo Albanians, who demand full autonomy and free elections, have died in clashes with Serbian security forces since March 1989, when Serbia virtually abolished the region's self-government. Thousands have spent time in jail, and Serbia has muzzled ethnic Albanian media. For many Yugoslavs, federal premier Ante Markovic remains the only integrating factor among the feuding republics. Markovic won widespread admiration for a remarkably swift economic turnaround, and his market-oriented programs have received wide support from Western governments and financial institutions. But optimism only a month ago that Markovic could translate his economic success into political clout and use it to form a new party has evaporated in the face of Slovenia's declaration of sovereignty and Serbia's reaction. Even Yugoslavia's collective presidency, nominally in charge of the country, seems unwilling or unable to stop the disintegration. Borisav Jovic, the Serb now heading the country's collective presidency, has suggested a referendum to determine whether individual nationalities want to remain united in one country.

DOC.HEAD: In Albanian City, Residents Dream of Leaving Communism
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Forty miles and a half-century away from Italy, citizens of this Albanian coastal city dream about a life without communism. ``We all dream of Italy,'' sighed a waiter at a government-run restaurant. Residents interviewed Monday by a reporter on a one-day ferry trip from Italy all expressed a desire to go abroad. Some appeared to want to live better. Others longed to escape the grip of Europe's last hard-line Communist government. Their quick, whispered comments suggested that the discontent that drove thousands of Albanians to seek refuge this month in embassies in the capital city of Tirana is no isolated phenomemon in this tiny Balkan nation. ``There's nothing in this country to live for,'' a young economist said angrily. Like the others interviewed, he spoke on condition of anonymity. Albanians can receive harsh punishments for contacts with foreigners. Vlore, 60 miles southwest of Tirana and just 40 miles across the Adriatic Sea from Italy, provides a glimpse of life in Europe's poorest and most isolated country. Most of the 70,000 residents live in five-story apartment buildings lined up like matchboxes. Laundry flaps from the balconies. In the rocky, white dirt lots around the buildings, thin children in patched clothes and rubber thongs play in a baking sun. Asked whether residents had problems getting enough food, a mechanic looked around to see if anyone was listening, then nodded. A silence hangs over the city because of an absence of cars, which individuals are not allowed to own. On the broad, palm-lined road to the Vlore port, horses and wagons rattle past bicyclists. But nearly every building has a television antenna, allowing residents to watch Italian television. Several residents, spotting a group of Italian tourists on Monday, called out the names of Italian soccer players. A few debated the merits of Italian pop stars. One student, a member of the Roman Catholic minority, said he liked to watch Pope John Paul II on Italian television. Until recently, religious observances were banned in Albania. ``When I see him, I cry,'' he said. It was through Italian TV that many Albanians learned about the revolutions in Eastern Europe last year, as well as the boatlift that carried about 4,500 Albanian asylum-seekers to Italy and France last week. Many had spent more than a week packed into embassies in the capital before the government decided to let them leave under the supervision of foreign diplomats. Those interviewed Monday spoke of widespread discontent in the country of 3 million people. But they said they did not expect a revolution like the ones that overtook other Eastern European countries. ``There are so many simple people here,'' said the economist. A university student said that most people would be content once the Communist government carried out the limited reforms it has announced since spring. They include giving everyone over 16 the right to a passport and foreign travel. Albanians have not had such a privilege for 45 years. Limited reform seemed unlikely, however, to appease a group of factory workers standing outside their plant. Asked about living conditions, they laughed bitterly and one uttered an expletive. Then they asked about the possibility of jobs in Italy. Most of those interviewed spoke quietly and looked around nervously, showing the widespread fear of the powerful Sigurimi secret police. At one point, a van of police pulled up at the government-run restaurant. All but one of a group of youths talking to a Western reporter shrank away. ``I haven't done anything wrong,'' declared the youth, as police glared at him. A moment later, several officers approached and ordered him off. He slunk down the road to a tree, from which he watched the foreigners and apparently continued to ponder life across the sea.

DOC.HEAD: Men Won't Take Bath on Big Water Bills
DOC.TEXT: A pair of neighbors feared they would be taking a bath on bills for more than 140,000 gallons of water, but the local water company says it wasn't trying to soak them. The Lemont Water Co. billed Eugene Emerick for 79,000 gallons of water during the second quarter of 1989. For John Paul Devereaux, it was a 64,000-gallon question. ``I was wondering what I did with all that water,'' Emerick said. ``I think I'd have to bathe three times a day and drink water all day to use that much.'' When Devereaux got his bill, ``The first thing I did was go downstairs and look at the cellar to see if it was flooded.'' Devereaux said his normal water bill totaled $17 per quarter. The inaccurate bill he received this month was for $70.15. Emerick said his bill was $80 before the mistake was caught. His real bill totaled $17.54. Cindy Rose, a spokeswoman for the 2,000-customer water company, said computer errors were responsible. ``There were too many zeroes on there,'' Rose said. What made the bills even harder to understand was that Centre County had 12.42 inches of rain during the April-June period covered by the bill _ 9.8 percent above normal. Devereaux did win three swimming events at the Centre County Senior Games this summer, but he said he didn't have a pool to account for his big bill. ``With this rain, we haven't even watered the garden,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Camarena Case Jury Begins Deliberations
DOC.TEXT: The jury weighing the case of four defendants charged with complicity in the slaying of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena began their deliberations Monday. The jury began weighing two months of evidence presented them during trial. After meeting for several hours, they retired without reaching a verdict. Deliberations were set to resume Tuesday. Closing arguments ended Friday and U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie gave the jurors their instructions Monday morning. On trial are Ruben Zuno Arce, Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros and Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez and Javier Vasquez Velasco. The group is charged with conspiring in 1985 Camarena's kidnap and murder near Guadalajara, Mexico. The killing strained U.S. relations with its southern neighbor. Bernabe also is charged with the murder of Camarena's pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. The beaten and tortured bodies of Camarena and his pilot were found in March 1985. Prosecutors contend the men killed Camarena and Zavala in retaliation for the drug agent's pursuit and crackdown of cocaine and marijuana traffickers in Guadalajara. Vasquez is charged with helping kill Americans John Walker and Alberto Radelat. The two walked into a restaurant in Guadalajara a week before Camarena was abducted and were mistaken for DEA agents. In all, 22 people have been charged in Los Angeles in connection with the murders.

DOC.HEAD: Forced Sales of Farmland Show Downturn
DOC.TEXT: An annual market survey by the Agriculture Department shows the rate of farmland sales through financial failure declined last year. Nationally, voluntary and estate sales accounted for 70 percent of the farmland transfers in the latter part of 1989, compared with 66 percent in the same period of 1988. Sales or transfers among family members accounted for 16 percent of the land transactions, about the same as the preceding year, the department's Economic Research Service said. ``Another 11 percent represented foreclosure, bankruptcy and condemnation sales and transfers (against 15 percent in 1988), while 3 percent fell into the `other' sales and transfers category (the same as in 1988),'' the report said. Officials said the survey included information on nearly 6,600 farmland sales involving more than 2 million acres. The research agency's annual farmland market survey was described in a new Agricultural Resources outlook report elaborating on figures announced in April that showed U.S. farmland prices rose 4 percent in 1989. A further gain of between 3 percent and 4 percent is forecast for 1990, based upon the current economic outlook. The report said other farmers continue to buy most of the land sold during the year, accounting for 59 percent of the purchases last year, compared with 57 percent in 1988. Tenants made 12 percent of the purchases, compared with 11 percent the previous year. Non-farmers accounted for 27 percent, down from 29 percent in 1988, and retired farmers, 2 percent, unchanged. ``Shares among buyer groups have been fairly stable over the past several years,'' the report said. ``Ten years ago, owner-operators were involved in 50 percent of the reported purchases, with tenants (15 percent), retired farmers (2 percent), and non-farmers (33 percent) accounting for the rest.'' The report also noted that nearly 41 percent of all U.S. farmland operated in 1989 was rented, according to another survey on farm costs and returns. ``Leasing was most widespread in the Corn Belt, Northern Plains, Southern Plains and (Mississippi) Delta states, where 50 to 55 percent of all land operated was leased,'' the report said. ``In other regions, the proportion of leasing ranged from 28 percent in the Southeast to 35 percent in the Mountain region.'' Tenants most often leased land on a cash-rent basis, accounting for 66 percent of all rented land last year. Thirty percent was rented for shares of production and 4 percent was rent-free.

The structure and volume of Japan's agricultural trade has changed substantially over the long haul, despite a popular perception of inflexibility, according to an Agriculture Department analyst. Rapidly changing economies in then Soviet Union and Eastern Europe have dominated the world's attention, says William Coyle of USDA's Economic Research Service. ``Japan, by contrast, often appears reluctant to change because of persistent and large trade surpluses, an inhospitable attitude about foreign investment and imports, and a political system dominated for 35 years by one party,'' he said. But changes do occur in Japan, but they sometimes go unnoticed because they are slow and incremental. Bulk commodities such as grain, soybeans, cotton and tobacco still make up most of Japan's agricultural imports, but Coyle said value-added products are accounting for a growing share. Tariff reductions, deregulation of foreign cigarette imports and more beef and citrus since 1985 helped push Japan's value-added imports to $12 billion in 1988, up 20 percent from 1970. In 1988, when Japan's agricultural imports were valued at $27.2 billion, bulk commodities made up 55.4 percent of the total. In 1970, when they were worth $4.2 billion, grains and other bulk items accounted for 79.8 percent. Coyle, writing in a new outlook report on world agriculture, said the changes have meant more meat, less imported grain; more cigarettes, less leaf tobacco; more finished textile products, less raw fibers; and more pasta and less wheat.

A package of queen honeybees from a 90-year-old monk in England is being added to the Agriculture Department's weaponry against the destructive tracheal mite. The 15 queen bees from Brother Adam in Buckfastleigh, England, will be used by scientists at the department's bee laboratory in Baton Rouge, La., to breed mite-resistant strains. Ralph A. Bram of the department's Agricultural Research Service said the breeding program will take two or three years. If successful, new queens will be distributed to bee breeders. Parasitic tracheal mites clog the breathing tubes of bees, killing 80 percent or more of a hive. Brother Adam, a resident of the abbey since 1910, began keeping bees at age 16, the agency said. He has written reports that his bees withstand mite attacks ``even when in identical environments other races and crosses collapsed mid-season.''

DOC.HEAD: South African Reminded of Past at Rally in Mozambique
DOC.TEXT: At a rally in his honor, Nelson Mandela received a souvenir from the past _ a framed copy of an arrest warrant issued for him in 1962 by the Portuguese colonial rulers of Mozambique. Amid much laughter from the crowd, President Joaquim Chissano presented the memento to Mandela on Monday. The South African black nationalist leader is on the last stop of a 14-nation tour of Africa, Europe and North America. The warrant described Mandela as a ``black agitator'' in South Africa last seen ``wearing a long beard and a chauffeur's uniform, with a peaked cap,'' the national news agency AIM reported. The warrant said Mandela, the underground leader of a newly organized guerrilla campaign at the time, could be on his way to Mozambique, South Africa's eastern neighbor. Mandela was captured by South African authorities in 1962 and sentenced to life in prison for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white-led government. He was released in February. Mozambique gained independence from Portugal in 1975 and has been governed for the last 15 years by the leftist FRELIMO party, which supports Mandela's African National Congress. The ANC is the leading black opposition group in South Africa and the guerrilla movement is an arm of the group. ``The struggle of the ANC is our struggle,'' said Chissano, who described Mandela as ``a man of peace.'' Mandela said he would seek to end the violence in South Africa. ANC supporters have been locked in a power struggle with Inkatha, a relatively conservative Zulu organization. Four years of factional fighting in the eastern province of Natal has claimed more than 4,000 lives. Also, right-wing whites have claimed responsibility for a recent series of bomb attacks aimed at blacks and whites who oppose apartheid. The violence threatens efforts by South African President F.W. de Klerk to end white domination and negotiate a new constitution that would give political rights to the country's 30 million black majority. Mandela is to return to South Africa on Wednesday, his 72nd birthday, and is expected to meet de Klerk soon afterward. Mandela's tour has raised millions of dollars for the ANC, which is trying to establish itself as a major force inside South Africa after being banned from 1960 until February. He also has helped convince foreign leaders to maintain economic sanctions against South Africa despite de Klerk's reforms. Mozambique has been devastated by a 13-year-old civil war pitting the government and against guerrillas who have been accused of widespread atrocities. The South African government openly supported the Mozambican guerrillas until the nations signed a peace pact in 1984. The war has left Mozambique one of the world's poorest nations. Annual per capita income is about $200 and almost half of the country's 15 million people require some level of food assistance.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Deciding Whether to Force Vote on Civil Rights Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Cloture vote expected mid-afternoon EDT; lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: The Senate is deciding whether to force a vote on civil rights legislation with critics still warning that it would inevitably lead to racial and ethnic hiring quotas. Bargaining among the White House, bill sponsors and conservative senators stretched into the early evening Monday but failed to produce an agreement on the embattled civil rights bill. Provisions of the measure range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to punitive damages for victims of discrimination. The most controversy has surrounded a provision that would require employers to end practices shown to be statistically discriminatory or prove in court that they were justified by business necessity. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said talks over the last three weeks have produced many areas of ``common ground between the administration and the bill's proponents here in Congress.'' ``But this common ground is shaky ground, and it will collapse if the bill's proponents do not show some willingness to address _ in very meaningful ways _ some very legitimate concerns raised by the president and his advisers,'' Dole added. He said he favored a civil rights bill but could not accept the version currently under debate. Meanwhile, Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, laid the groundwork for a vote today on whether to limit debate to 30 hours. It would take 60 votes to succeed in such a move. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., and other sponsors have been holding off on trying to force a vote while negotiating with the administration. It appeared Friday that Kennedy and the administration might be close to an agreement Friday and the Massachusetts senator said one was likely this week. Before leaving for his Camp David retreat Friday, President Bush said he was encouraged by the turn the talks had taken. The bill is aimed at reversing five Supreme Court decisions last year that civil rights forces say represented a severe setback for their cause. Before last year's decision in the case of Wards Cove vs. Antonio, involving hiring at a Salmon cannery in Alaska, it was up to the employer to prove in court that a practice shown to be discriminatory was a matter of business necessity and therefore justified. The Wards Cove decision reversed that and said those filing discrimination suits must prove that the practices involved were not matters of business necessity. Kennedy's bill would place the burden back on the employer. But critics say it would make it even easier to win a job discrimination suit than before the Wards Cove decision. They say employers would be guaranteed to turn to the use of quotas to protect themselves from such suits. Business groups also are upset over a provision of the bill that would allow courts to award punitive damages to victims of bias in the workplace. Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., on Monday introduced a proposed compromise that appeared likely to gain support from lawmakers holding out against the Kennedy version but wanting to prove that they were not opponents of civil rights. Kassebaum said in a statement that her measure would reinstate the legal language in use before the Wards Cove decision. She said that provision ``forms an appropriate balance between the concerns voiced on both sides _ avoiding quotas and excessive litigation versus ensuring equal opportunity in the workplace.'' She said her measure was designed ``to restore our civil rights laws to the same strength and clarity that existed before a series of Supreme Court decisions last year.'' ``Those decisions have significantly increased the difficulty of proving discrimination, and if they are allowed to stand, they will weaken our civil rights laws,'' she said. She said the other goal of her bill was to ``maintain the balance first struck by the 1964 Civil Rights Act and to preserve the basic philosophy of conciliation, cooperation and equitable relief that are the foundation of all of our civil rights laws.''

DOC.HEAD: Backsides Go Numb In Huge Dress Rehearsal
DOC.TEXT: Asian Games organizers holding a huge dress rehearsal for the September competition found many small problems with the new stadiums and a few unusual ones, including a vibrating press box. Nearly 9,000 athletes, referees, police and officials took part in the weekend rehearsal at all the games venues around Beijing. Scoreboards, telephones, toilets, lights, air conditioning, parking, drug-testing facilities and emergency and security procedures were tested as athletes held make-believe contests. Sixteen of the 36 sporting venues are newly built, and 11 others have been renovated for the Sept. 22-Oct. 7 games. It will be China's first major international sporting event. China Sports News said the basketball stadium leaked during heavy weekend rainstorms, but did not say how serious the problem was. At the Ditan Stadium, the paper said in its Monday editions, journalists found their press box vibrated throughout the try-out. ``After half a day, their rear ends were numb, if not shaken to pieces,'' the paper said. It turned out the stadium's air conditioning equipment was installed under the press box. ``If the air conditioning is turned on (during the games),'' the paper wrote, ``what will the foreign guests think?'' Chinese reporters arriving at another stadium said none of the guards could tell them where the press box was, and when they found it, discovered there were no telephones. Other stadiums discovered they had too few entries and exits, the paper said _ not commenting on how such a basic problem would be resolved.

DOC.HEAD: TV, Radio Stations Asked to Prove Compliance With FCC Political Rules
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission will examine information from 30 major market television and radio stations asked to show that they are offering political candidates the lowest possible advertising rates. The FCC on Monday began its first-ever audits of broadcasters, prompted by what an agency news release called an ``obligation to assure that broadcast stations are complying with political programming laws and rules, especially in an election year.'' The audits were not the result of any complaint, said Milton Graves, chief of the FCC's political division. ``This is just a part of overseeing how the stations are complying,'' he said. ``We want to know what their practices are.'' The FCC sent field inspectors to stations in Cincinnati, Dallas-Ft. Worth, Philadelphia, San Francisco and Portland, Ore. In each city, they visited four television stations, an AM radio station and an FM radio station. ``These cities were selected because they are geographically diverse and also because, in some instances, the stations serve more than one state,'' the FCC said. Inspectors asked the stations for political files for the 1990 elections, rate cards for political and commercial advertisers, commercial invoices, program logs and statements from the stations regarding pricing structures and methods of calculating ``lowest unit'' charges for political candidates. They were given 20 days to send the FCC data on rates for non-political advertisers but were asked to provide the political information immediately, Graves said. He said auditors in the agency's Washington office will ``examine all the information that's provided to us.'' Under FCC regulations, the lowest unit charge is available to political candidates 45 days before primary balloting and six days before a general election. Candidates may purchase single broadcast advertisements for the same price as commercial advertisers who buy a number of spots in the same time period. Graves said most of the field auditors completed their work Monday but that their jobs were ``just the beginning'' of the auditing process. Spokeswoman Briana Gowing said the action was an unusual one. ``Apparently the FCC has never before done anything like this before,'' she said. The stations are: _Cincinnati: WCPO-TV, WKRC-TV, WLWL-TV, WIII-TV, WCKY-AM and WWNK-FM. _Dallas: KDFW-TV, KXAS-TV, WFAA-TV, KTXA-TV, KRLD-AM and KPLX-FM. _Philadelphia: KYW-TV, WCAU-TV, WPVI-TV, WGBS-TV, WPEN-AM and WWDB-FM. _Portland: KATU-TV, KGW-TV, KOIN-TV, KPTV-TV, KWJJ-AM and KKSN-FM. _San Francisco: KGO-TV, KRON-TV, KTVU-TV, KOFY-TV, KNBR-AM and KABL-FM.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Agency Halts Relief Food Distribution In Uganda
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. relief agency has halted delivery of emergency food in northeastern Uganda after unidentified gunmen ambushed its convoy and killed a driver. Lee Tommi, the World Food Program representative in Uganda, said the Rome-based organization would resume deliveries if the government provides armed escorts into the arid region, where people are reported dying of starvation. ``The situation is serious,'' Tommi said Monday. ``We talked to the authorities and elders in Moroto and Kotido who reported that at least 300 people have died of starvation in the past couple of weeks.'' Moroto and Kotido are trading towns about 310 miles from Uganda's capital, Kampala. An estimated 220,000 people are threatened with famine caused by drought, Tommi said. He said a driver was killed and two people hired as truck loaders were injured in the July 7 ambush. New Vision newspaper described the gunmen as ``about 70 shabbily dressed bandits.'' They stole the corn and burned two trucks. A third truck escaped. Tommi said President Yoweri Museveni's government had not officially appealed for emergency food, but that the World Food Program decided to deliver 5,000 tons of corn. The operation began in May and about 3,000 tons of the grain have since been delivered, he said. ``This is a drop in the bucket,'' he said. ``It is hardly enough. People are going without food for days.'' In 1980, starvation caused by a severe drought killed thousands of people in the same region, known as Karamonja. The region is also home to remnants of insurgencies that took up arms against Museveni after he took power early 1986.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Tells Manufacturers to Stop Making Health Claims
DOC.TEXT: Fish oil sellers are under orders from the Food and Drug Administration to stop claiming their capsules can help lower cholesterol and the chance of heart attacks. FDA spokesman Bill Grigg said the agency concluded after consulting with the National Institutes of Health that, although some studies have suggested fish oil might be useful for cholesterol lowering, ``there wasn't sufficient evidence for them to make these claims'' regarding the amount found in capsules. The letters sent to 60 fish oil capsule makers Monday are an extension of an earlier FDA warning for them to stop claiming the capsules were good for arthritis and other disorders. The companies agreed with that, but argued that the cardiovascular benefits were well-enough established to justify the claim. Several studies in recent years have suggested that fish oils containing a component called omega-3, such as those from mackerel and herring, can lower blood pressure and cholesterol, reduce damage from inflammatory processes such as arthritis and lower the chances of other problems such as diabetes and heart attacks. Grigg said the FDA agrees that ``there are studies that show fish diets may be helpful. ``We said it's quite conceivable'' that further research might justify an assertion that the capsules provide health benefits, Grigg said. But such results are several months ``if not more'' down the road, he added. It is the assertion of a health benefit that brings fish oil capsules under stringent drug regulation rules. The manufacturers can continue selling their capsules as foods without health claims if the FAA accepts them as ``generally recognized as safe,'' Grigg said. This might be a simple matter for some products, because ``for cod-liver oil and some of the others, there is a good record,'' Grigg said.

DOC.HEAD: Pittsburgh Lab Criticized by FDA Inspectors
DOC.TEXT: All but two of 13 studies conducted for generic drug manufacturers by a Pittsburgh lab violated Food and Drug Administration regulations or fell short of accepted laboratory practice, the agency says. The lab, Biodecision Laboratories, promised to correct the flaws. FDA headquarters is analyzing the inspection reports to see whether they affect any drugs recently approved or waiting for approval, spokesman Don McLearn said Monday. He said he did not know what drugs were involved but noted that ``this is not a product issue, but how a lab conducts its business.'' Biodecision is one of the more heavily used laboratories in the generic drug industry, McLearn said. The studies were so-called ``bioequivalence'' studies aimed at showing that a candidate generic drug reaches the same concentration in the bloodstream as the patented drug for which it will be sold as a substitute. McLearn said an example of violation of standards of good practice would be starting an analysis before validation of the method being used. The agency can refuse to accept data from labs it deems unreliable, but McLearn said the company ``is not in that kind of jeopardy at this point.'' The inspection was conducted in January and the company reported its plans for corrective action in March. At some point, FDA probably will approve or disapprove those plans, McLearn said. The agency has been wrestling with problems in the generic drug industry for more than a year, with some drug manufacturers having been found to have cheated on their lab tests and bribed FDA officials. In Pittsburgh, a man answering the company's telephone who identified himself as a guard said no one was available to comment. In Tuesday editions, The Washington Post quoted the company president, Robert Lecher, as saying, ``We view the entire process as very constructive and have taken it extremely seriously. We don't take issue or disagree with any of the observations.''

DOC.HEAD: Strong Quake Hits Philippines; At Least 193 Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to ADD details on Hyatt. Picks up 4th pvs, `Baguio radio ...' To CORRECT relation of Cabanatuan to epicenter, SUB 12th graf, `Hundreds of ... the epicenter.' ^LaserPhotos MLA2,3,5, LaserColor MOSB6
DOC.TEXT: A major earthquake jolted Manila and surrounding Luzon island on Monday, killing at least 193 people. Hundreds more were reported trapped in collapsed buildings. The death toll, compiled by the Office of Civil Defense, included some 80 people killed in the mountain resort of Baguio, where four hotels were heavily damaged. Reports said nearly 1,000 people were believed trapped in damaged buildings in the resort 110 miles north of Manila. Most of the Baguio victims, about 50, were at the Hyatt Hotel. Aerial footage taken early Tuesday by private television station GMA showed that the entire front section of the Hyatt, the city's plushest hotel, had collapsed. It appeared that floors containing guest rooms had crashed down onto the lobby, which includes the main restaurant, bar and shops. Baguio radio station DZWT said 23 people were killed when the commerce building at the University of Baguio collapsed. Aftershocks continued Tuesday, and reporters in Baguio said most of the 119,000 residents slept outdoors on the streets after the quake, which struck about 4:30 p.m. and measured 7.7 on the Richter scale. Officials said the worst affected areas were Nueva Ecija province, which includes Cabanatuan, 60 miles north of Manila; Baguio area; and Dagupan on Lingayen Gulf, about 100 miles north of Manila. Manila TV stations said local officials were woefully short of blood, medicine and rescue equipment in the nation's worst earthquake in 14 years. President Corazon Aquino was meeting senators in her office when the quake hit and she took cover under a table, said her spokesman, Adolf Azcuna. She ordered the military to begin rescue operations and closed schools throughout the area Tuesday. She flew early Tuesday to Cabanatuan to inspect damage and console relatives of a school disaster. Early Tuesday, hospitals said 35 people were killed in the Cabanatuan area and 154 injured. Most casualties came from the collapse of the six-story Philippine Christian College school in the city of 80,000, but officials had no accurate breakdown because of administrative confusion. Hundreds of students and staff were trapped in the collapse of the school, which taught students from the first grade to senior year in college. Cabanatuan is about 20 miles southeast of the epicenter. The U.S. Embassy said Tuesday an official of the U.S. Agency for International Development is missing and feared dead after the quake heavily damaged the Nevada Hotel in Baguio, where he and others were attending a symposium. The embassy refused to give his name. U.S. officials said the Baguio injured were being transported to American military hospitals at nearby Camp John Hay and Clark Air Base. The State Department said earlier in Washington it was investigating reports of deaths or injuries to American government officials. Rescue efforts were hampered by poor communications and lack of equipment. Landslides blocked roads to Baguio and the airport was closed due to poor visibility and damage to the runway, officials said. The Philippine Institute of Vulcanology and Seismology recorded 70 aftershocks, measuring up to 3 on the Richter scale. Only 11 were felt by the public, the last at 5 a.m. Tuesday. The June 21 earthquake in Iran registered 7.3 to 7.7 and killed at least 40,000 people. At least 150 people were believed trapped in the Hyatt Hotel in Baguio, a favorite with foreign tourists. The military said 800 more were believed trapped in a government building in the Baguio Export Processing Zone. The Pentagon said it provided an Air Force C-141 transport plane to carry 16 civilian search and rescue personnel, four dogs and support equipment to assist in the hunt for survivors. In Manila, which together with surrounding areas has a population of about 8 million, numerous buildings were slightly damaged and one fire broke out in the city's Santa Cruz district. Two people were killed. Thousands were sent fleeing into the streets. Filipinos prayed or made signs of the cross. The temblor cracked walls and broke windows in many buildings, including the downtown ticket office of Philippine Airlines and The Manila Hotel, a luxury hotel on Manila Bay from which hundreds of guests were evacuated. Much of the city was without power Monday night. Stop lights were knocked out of service, causing huge traffic jams. Most of the casualties were reported in the densely populated areas north of the capital in central Luzon, the country's agricultural heartland. One 14-year-old survivor at Cabanatuan, Loida Gabwat, a high school sophomore, screamed after being pulled from the rubble: ``Mommy, mommy, come here! I can't go through this alone! My friends are dead inside!'' Hours after the quake, hundreds of relatives and friends watched as volunteer rescuers dug through the wreckage; hope for survivors faded. Ms. Gabwat, 14, said her class had just finished a math exam when the quake struck. ``We were kidding each other, we were saying the test was so easy,'' she said. ``Then suddenly, the walls trembled, the ceiling collapsed and there was total darkness. We embraced each other. We were very scared.'' A 7.8 quake struck the Philippines in 1976, killing 8,000 people. Most died in a tidal wave that struck Mindanao.

DOC.HEAD: Former Senator Tower Heads Revamped Intelligence Board
DOC.TEXT: Former Sen. John Tower of Texas is the new chairman of his Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board. As part of a major overhaul Monday, President Bush also replaced all Reagan-era members of the panel, except Tower, and cut its size from 15 to six. Tower, who was nominated by Bush as secretary of defense last year but not confirmed, was the only holdover member of the board. He now works as a consultant in Dallas. Among those removed were chairman Anne L. Armstrong, the former ambassador to Britain; former Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger; former Attorney General William French Smith; Zbigniew Brezinski, who was national security adviser for President Carter; former United Nations Ambassador Jeane Kirkpatrick and former Tennessee senator and White House chief of staff Howard Baker. The new board, composed entirely of defense and foreign policy experts, consists of: Lew Allen Jr., former chief of staff of the Air Force and now vice president of the California Institute of Technology; John M. Deutch, provost of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and onetime undersecretary of energy; William G. Hyland, editor of Foreign Affairs, the quarterly publication of the Council on Foreign Relations. Also, Bobby Ray Inman, onetime deputy director of the CIA and now a consultant in Austin, Texas; William J. Perry, former Pentagon research chief and now chairman and chief executive officer of Technology Strategies and Alliances in Menlo Park, Calif. The board is charged with assessing the quality, quantity and adequacy of intelligence collection, analysis and estimates. It also evaluates counter-intelligence work.
DOC.HEAD: Auto Safety Group Asks For Chrysler Recall
DOC.TEXT: An auto safety group wants the government to investigate and recall 5.5 million Chrysler cars and vans after 76 reports of vehicles moving into gear while their transmissions were in park. The Center for Auto Safety said in a letter to National Highway Traffic Safety Administrator Jerry Curry on Monday that two people had been killed and 20 injured in accidents involving the problem with several Chrysler models from 1981 to 1989. NHTSA spokesman Tim Hurd said the agency had just received the letter and would review it before deciding whether to open an investigation. James Kenyon, spokesman for Chrysler Corp., said the company was not aware of any problem with the models cited in the petition. He said the company had not seen the complaint, which was sent first to members of the news media. The center, which describes itself as an independent consumer group formed in 1970 to improve vehicle and highway safety, said its petition covers 1981-89 Dodge Aries and Plymouth Reliants; 1982-87 Dodge 400s and Chrysler LeBarons; 1983-88 Dodge 600s, Plymouth Caravelles and Chrysler New Yorkers; and 1984-89 Dodge Caravans and Plymouth Voyagers.
DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Threat Not Considered Credible
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration informed airlines of a threat against Pan Am in Europe but did not consider the threat credible, an FAA spokesman says. ``The FAA routinely issues information to U.S. carriers to put into perspective rumors, news reports and other information that may be based on erroneous information or speculation,'' spokesman Fred Farrar said Monday. Such a circular was issued July 12, he said, without describing its contents. A London newspaper, the Sunday Correspondent, reported Sunday that U.S. authorities had warned airlines of a threat to blow up a Pan Am jet on a flight from West Germany in the next 10 days. The supposed threat involved a female student with a Canadian passport who was to be duped into carrying a suitcase containing a bomb on a Pan Am flight from either Frankfurt or Berlin. Farrar said information about the threat had been circulating for several months among news organizations in Europe. The FAA cautioned that doubts existed about the information and advised airlines that the agency did not consider it a credible threat, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Stigma of Mass Child Sex Abuse in Rural Coal Country Won't Go Away
DOC.TEXT: This impoverished town in the eastern Kentucky coalfields was shocked when 23 men and women were indicted four years ago for sexually and physically abusing more than two dozen children. Four trials have come and gone and a fifth opens this week, but the unwelcome spotlight of the nation's media has dimmed. Nevertheless, for some residents the stigma is proving hard to bear. ``We'll never live it down,'' said Sheriff Chalmer Wireman. Investigators concluded that 26 children ranging in age from 1 to 11 had been abused. The accused included their fathers, grandfathers, uncles and mothers, and charges ranged from rape and sodomy to torture with burning cigarettes. Nineteen of the defendants were members of an extended family supported largely by work as low-income laborers. One defendant was convicted, eight others pleaded guilty and five won acquittals. None of the victimized children was returned home and 10 have either been adopted by new families or have adoptions pending. Impoverished living conditions common in an area with 20 percent unemployment came to light at the recent trial of Herbert ``Hub'' Gipson when his 12-year-old son testified that he fabricated tales of abuse ``because I wanted to live in a better place.'' Gipson was acquitted. Despite the five acquittals, Assistant Attorney General Barbara Whaley says she thinks prosecutors have excelled because winning convictions in child sexual abuse cases is among the hardest of legal tasks. Medical evidence and witnesses to confirm child allegations are frequently lacking, and the pressures of court testimony on alleged child victims makes pursuing such cases difficult, said Ms. Whaley, a special prosecutor assigned to the case. Children recanted in Gipson's trial, she said, because ``it's almost impossible to ask those kids to come in here.'' Gipson, an unemployed former tobacco farmer with a seventh-grade education, had been charged with eight felony counts for allegedly sexually abusing three of his children and a cousin. Gipson thinks the acquittal will enable him to clear his name, but said the 3{-year wait for trial was an ordeal. ``It hurts and everything ... getting jobs and things like that,'' he said. The investigation began in August 1986 when state police and social workers interviewed a young incest victim. The case snowballed when the child said other youngsters had been molested. Seventeen of the original 23 cases have been resolved. Brack Nickles, 64, of Mason's Creek, received the maximum sentence of 20 years after being found guilty last summer of rape and sodomy. The eight defendants who pleaded guilty to various misdemeanor and felony counts have all received probation. Three cases ended when one man died, one woman's charges were dismissed, and prosecutors realized that one person named didn't actually exist. In the next trial, scheduled to begin Thursday, 27-year-old Della Adkins is charged with three felony child abuse counts for allegedly acting as an accomplice in the molestations of two girls and a boy. Some local residents defended the accused and about 50 rallied in front of the county courthouse in November 1986 to demand charges be dropped and that children be returned to their families. But now many are eager to forget. ``I'd say it's just fading away, except for the damage that's done to a few kids,'' said Jim Wadges, an unemployed millwright.

DOC.HEAD: New Astronauts Optimistic About NASA's Future
DOC.TEXT: A new astronaut on track to becoming NASA's first female shuttle commander said she welcomes the Bush administration's scrutiny of the beleaguered agency. The administration on Monday ordered a review by outside experts of the nation's long-term space goals, the same day the astronaut candidate class of 1990 reported to work for the first time. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has endured a spate of recent embarrassments, including trouble with the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope and hydrogen leaks that have grounded the space shuttle fleet. Air Force Maj. Eileen Collins, one of 23 new astronauts selected earlier this year, told reporters she is not unnerved by problems with sophisticated machines. The new astronauts were chosen from more than 2,000 applicants. ``There are high points and low points in any airplane or weapon system,'' Ms. Collins said Monday. ``You learn to get through the bad times.'' ``If our president feels it's something that needs to be done, it needs to be done,'' she said. If all goes according to plan, Ms. Collins would become the first woman to command a shuttle mission. She said she hopes to be flying shuttle missions to help construct the planned space station Freedom. The candidates will become full-fledged astronauts a year from now, after undergoing advanced training and evaluation. In the history of the program, only one candidate has dropped out during this last leg, officials said. An assignment on a space shuttle would probably take at least two years after that. Besides the seven pilots, the 1990 class includes 16 mission specialists. Eleven of the 23 are civilians and 12 are military pilots. Of the five women selected, three are military officers, including Ms. Collins. The class also includes Ellen Ochoa, of Los Altos, Calif., the first Hispanic woman to be selected.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 33,172.28, up 150.55 points, or 0.46 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: School Choice Program Slowed by Legal Battles
DOC.TEXT: The nation's first program allocating state money to poor parents so their children can attend private schools is nearing its autumn startup, but critics are planning a last-ditch effort to block it. The school choice plan, which has drawn praise from the Bush administration and Republican Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, faces a court hearing this month that could determine its immediate fate. The hearing is the result of a lawsuit, urged by state School Superintendent Herbert Grover and filed by opponents of the plan, that challenges the constitutionality of using state money for private schools. The Wisconsin Supreme Court declined to immediately review the lawsuit and referred it to Dane County Circuit Court, which has scheduled a July 28 hearing. If the court blocks the program, it will start a legal battle that will probably delay implementation. ``The arguments they're making amount to grasping at constitutional straws,''said Clint Bolick, spokesman for the Landmark Legal Foundation Center, a Washington-based advocacy group assisting in the fight against the lawsuit. Even if they win the court battle, program organizers still face a battle with Grover over requirements for the 10 private schools that have applied to accept the students. That battle has prompted a second lawsuit challenging Grover's authority. Plans that allow parents more choice over where to send their children to school have gained momentum in the last five years. Minnesota and Iowa were among the first to offer tax credits to parents sending their children to private schools. Wisconsin's voucher system would be the nation's first to directly provide government money for the purpose. The program was approved by the Legislature in April and signed into law by Thompson. It has been hailed by Bush administration officials as a national model for overhauling public education. It provides as much as $2,500 to each of nearly 1,000 poor Milwaukee students to help them leave the public schools and enroll in non-sectarian private schools. The average yearly tuition at the private schools is $3,200. The experiment would affect about the poorest 1 percent of the city's estimated 97,000 students. The money used would be deducted from the city's school budget. Critics such as Grover and the Wisconsin Education Association Council teachers union claim the plan undermines public education and puts students in private schools that aren't fully accountable to the state. Grover devised a series of forms for the schools to complete before they would be allowed to participate. Two of the schools completed the forms. The others refused and filed a lawsuit claiming the forms were too complex and would force the schools to meet numerous requirements not specified in the law. ``None of these schools are capable of providing those kinds of services,'' said attorney William Levit, who represents the private schools. ``The city of Milwaukee doesn't even provide them on a school-by-school basis. The district provides them.''

DOC.HEAD: School Survivor Sobs for Mother _ `My Friends Are Dead Inside'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT to `Miss Gabwat' SUB 4th graf, ```We were ... we wept.'' ^With PM-Philippines-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Loida Gabwat's class had just finished a math test when the earth shook, bringing her six-story school down in crumbling concrete on hundreds of students and teachers. ``We were kidding each other, we were saying the test was so easy,'' said the 14-year-old. ``Then suddenly, the walls trembled, the ceiling collapsed and there was total darkness. We embraced each other. We were very scared.'' Survivors groped for one another in the darkened rubble and prayed aloud. ``We were calling out our classmates' names but they did not respond any more,'' Miss Gabwat told a reporter while being taken to a provincial hospital. ``Then we groped for their hands but felt that they were cold. Each time, we wept. ``We were scared and some were screaming. But then later on, they said they wanted to sleep already and rest. Then there was silence.'' Ms. Gabwat lost so many of her friends. ``Mommy, mommy, come here!'' she had screamed when she was pulled from the rubble of the Christian College of the Philippines after Monday's quake. ``I can't go through this alone! My friends are dead inside!'' Mayor Honorato Perez said about 50 people remained buried today in the rubble of the school _ which included first grade through the senior year of college _ but fewer than half were believed still alive. The quake was centered 20 miles northwest of Cabanatuan, a city of 80,000 people. The rescue efforts that followed were undertaken largely by local volunteers. There was little sign of experienced supervision. President Corazon Aquino flew to Cabanatuan from Manila early today to console families and visit survivors. While she was present, a rescuer crawled from the rubble and told reporters he found four boys, all alive. But he said one was pinned under the ruins, in such pain he amputated his own leg with a jagged piece of concrete. Lt. Benbol Moralde, part of an army contingent sent from nearby Fort Magsaysay, said he believed few remained alive beneath the debris. Moralde said victims' cries grew fainter and fainter and that he could see bodies and parts of bodies when he surveyed the destruction. Hours after the temblor, hundreds of family members and friends watched and prayed as rescuers dug through the school rubble. Each time someone was brought out alive, relatives crowded around the survivor, begging for news of those still missing. ``They told me she's still alive,'' said Rosa de los Reyes, who was waiting word of her daughter, Maria Lisa, 14. ``I'm very happy but if it turns out she has died, I think I'm going to die too.'' Throughout the night, boys as young as seven scrambled between slabs of concrete carrying water to victims still trapped. Sixteen-year-old Florencio Alano crawled through the wreckage looking for his 13-year-old brother, Cesario _ only to find out he was dead. Florencio, who eventually led three survivors to safety, said: ``At first I couldn't believe that he was already dead. So I crawled through the passageway. I saw his face and felt him. What else can one feel but just accept it.'' Rescuers could hear the anguished screams during the night of those buried under tons of debris. Most begged for water. One girl shrieked for rescuers to ``cut off my legs'' to free her. Cenando Memping, whose 14th birthday was Monday, said he had just invited his three best friends to join him after class at a restaurant when the quake hit. Cenando and his friends were trapped beneath tons of rubble. He said there were 54 students in his class. More than 10 hours after the quake, he was the only one of them who had been rescued. ``I prayed to God that if I survive, I'll hear Mass every day,'' he said from his hospital bed. He said his friend Michael Nuevo joked that he would never go to a ``high'' school again. Moments later, Michael died, Cenando said. ``We were kidding each other, comforting each other,'' Cenando said softly. ``Then suddenly, he stopped breathing. He said, `Praise the Lord. Our Father, Our Father, Our Father.' Then he was silent.''

DOC.HEAD: Faulty Speaker System Adds To Confusion In Empire State Building Fire
DOC.TEXT: The speaker system at the Empire State Building may have been faulty when a smoky fire erupted halfway up the 102-story landmark, forcing many of the 1,000 people inside to seek their own way out. ``Some people said they heard the alarms, others said they didn't. But we get that in every fire,'' said Fire Department spokesman John Mulligan. ``There's a speaker system and we are investigating to see how well it worked.'' At least four civilians and 34 firefighters were hurt, mostly from inhaling smoke, in the Monday evening fire, Mulligan said. The blaze was confined to four unoccupied offices on the 51st floor, but smoke spread throughout the upper floors. Sixteen people were sent to hospitals for treatment. A firefighter who suffered minor burns was the only one to be hospitalized. About 1,000 people evacuated the building down the stairways and elevators, said Fire Department Capt. Charles Kasper. Although 10,000 people work in the building, more than 80 percent of them leave the building at 5 p.m., officials said. The cause of the fire was not immediately known. ``We are trying to find out now who was the last person in the room,'' Mulligan said. ``There were nothing but tourists up there and there were no announcements,'' said Josephine Danielson of New York, who was on the observation deck with five friends from Spain. ``No one really knew what was going on, not even the employees.'' ``We started smelling smoke and we saw on the east side of the building dense black smoke coming from below the tower,'' said Danielson, a Pan Am stewardess. ``Whoever runs the observation deck is tremendously unorganized. You would think they would have had some kind of recorded announcement.'' Paula Schnorbus of Hoboken, N.J., who was on the observation deck with her boyfriend Stephen Giradi, also complained that ``there was no one up there to tell us where to go.'' Tourists who stayed on the observation deck were eventually evacuated, by elevator, 15 at a time. The last civilian came out at about 10:20 p.m., Mulligan said. The fire was reported at 6:30 p.m., and by 8:45 p.m., the blaze was out and the danger passed, fire officials said. Nabila Al Riyami, a tourist from Oman, emerged from the building at about 9:15 p.m. with her husband and five children. ``Some people were crying and having nervous, trembling fits,'' she said. Her husband, Said, added: ``We were praying to God that he would help us. We are safe and we thank the fire department of the municipality.'' Fire Department officials reported heavy fire damage on the 51st floor, water damage on lower floors and smoke damage above. Dan Kaplan, a spokesman for Helmsley-Spear, the company that runs the building, said it would be open for tenants and visitors as usual today.

DOC.HEAD: Lucy and Desi Talent Search: Hollywood With a Henna Rinse
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Lucy and Desi wanna-bes, hoping to play the comedy duo in a television movie, flooded CBS Television City with red hair and broken English as a nationwide casting search began. The Desi Arnaz warning, ``you gotta lotta splainin' to do,'' got a workout Monday before a producer and a casting director who smiled cheerfully through some painfully amateurish readings. One truth seemed evident: The more the performers looked like Lucy and Desi, the worse their acting was. Some women dyed their hair red for their slim chance to be in ``Lucy and Desi: Before the Laughter.'' A few men wore white suits. Most every fake Lucy wore a 1950s-style dress and heels. Several looked just like the zany comedian, while others bore more of a resemblance to Carol Burnett. One couple danced the rumba while waiting for their names to be called. ``What are my chances? Not great. There are like tons of people here,'' said Randy Aguirre, an engineer who missed a staff meeting to audition for the part of the Cuban band leader.
