A woman named Tahoe Castle (``I was born there'') died her hair red and drove 300 miles for a stab at the lead role. ``It's just a rinse so I can wash it right out,'' she said, fingering her tresses. For her shot at stardom, Castle performed a song from the musical ``A Chorus Line'' as Lucy might have interpreted it. ``I feel like I'm really her,'' said Castle, who came from San Martin in Northern California to be one of the first in line. ``I watch all of her old shows.'' Castle also planned a trip to Disneyland as part of her Southern California visit. The CBS movie will cover the late Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz's life from when they met in 1940 while making the movie ``Too Many Girls,'' to 1951, the year television's ``I Love Lucy'' premiered. ``I'd like to play her, but it's so hard to fill her shoes,'' said Dianalynn Pfennig, who drove from her makeover salon in San Jose to perform Lucy's famous drunken sales pitch for the alcohol-laced Vita Meta Vegamin nutritional supplement. In addition to false eyelashes and the heavy makeup she'd been wearing since 2 a.m., Pfennig brought a stage prop: a bottle of multivitamin liquid extract from which she drank during her two-minute monologue. ``This stuff tastes awful,'' she said after her performance. Her audition was scarcely the most offbeat. One Desi gave a stream-of-consciousness monologue, Ricky Ricardo as scripted by Hunter S. Thompson. One actress' audition consisted entirely of her impression on how Lucy would eat a crumb. A few Lucy simulations came from as far away as Dallas and El Paso. The first Lucy in line arrived at 3 a.m. after finishing her shift as a waitress at a late-night restaurant. Tony Rael, who was born in Havana and came to the United States when he was 2, was one of the few the producers wanted to see again. He sang the show's theme song for his tryout. ``I love Desi Arnaz,'' Rael said. ``He's a hero to the Hispanic people.'' Producer Larry Thompson said the television movie, due to be broadcast next February, will be a ``loving but honest portrayal'' of the relationship between Lucy and Desi. He deflected criticism from daughter Lucie Arnaz, who said, ``I believe that the climate is wrong to try and tell my parents' story accurately no matter who tells it.'' CBS Entertainment President Jeff Sagansky said: ``We're not going to desecrate all the wonderful things Lucy and Desi did for CBS.''

DOC.HEAD: Pediatricians Recommend Earlier Vaccinations Against Hemophilus Influenzae
DOC.TEXT: The American Academy of Pediatrics is advising that babies should be vaccinated three months earlier than previously recommended against a disease that causes meningitis and pneumonia. The 39,000-doctor academy is recommending that children be vaccinated at 15 months against the disease hemophilus influenzae type b rather than at 18 months, the academy said in a news release Monday. The academy said its Committee on Infectious Diseases revised the position after reviewing data on 15-month-old children who had been vaccinated. Before immunizations against the disease were introduced, there were about 16,000 cases a year in this country among children 5 years of age or younger. More than 9 percent of the cases occurred among children 15 months to 17 months old. The vaccine recommendation was published in the July issue of the American Academy of Pediatrics News.

DOC.BYLINE: Government Extradites Two Accused Drug Smugglers To U.S. ^By STEVEN GUTKIN
DOC.TEXT: In a move sure to anger cocaine bosses, the Colombian government has extradited to the United States two more men accused of drug trafficking, one a native Texan, police say. Both were sent to the United States on Monday night, bringing to 19 the number of suspects extradited since August, when the government declared war on cocaine traffickers. President-elect Cesar Gaviria promised Monday to fight poverty in Medellin slums, where drug traffickers are hiring teen-agers as assassins in their war to stop extraditions, the fate they fear most. The Texas native extradited was identified as Eduard George Mitchell, a U.S. citizen wanted on drug smuggling charges in Wisconsin. The other suspect, Jose Gil Zapata, is a Colombian charged in a Florida court with cocaine trafficking, a police spokesman said in a telephone interview. Gil Zapata was arrested on Jan. 15 in Medellin, headquarters of the Medellin cocaine cartel, the spokesman said. Mitchell, 44, was arrested in northern Colombia on Jan. 22. No further details were given on the arrests. Eleven other drug smuggling suspects are still in Colombian jails awaiting extradition to the United States. The government of President Virgilio Barco reinstated the nation's extradition policy in August after drug traffickers were blamed for murdering a leading presidential candidate, Luis Carlos Galan. The policy is not popular in Colombia, where many believe sending citizens to be tried in a foreign country is an insult to national pride. Many drug bosses have been able to bribe or threaten their way out of Colombian jails. One of the main cities where the drug traffickers are carrying on their bombing and murder campaign against the government crackdown is Medellin, home of the drug cartel by the same name. Drug barons often hire teen-agers from Medellin's poor neighborhoods to carry out their campaigns of bombings and assassinations, authorities say. An estimated 3,000 people have been murdered in the city this year, including about 1,50 police officers. With 2 million people, Medellin is Colombia's second-largest city after the capital. Gaviria, who becomes Colombia's next president on Aug. 7, said at a news conference in Bogota that the government will have to attack Medellin's poverty if it hopes to make a dent in drug-related violence. ``The country's gravest problem now is violence in Medellin, and this will require special treatment from my government, a treatment that transcends just military, police and public order measures,'' Gaviria said in his first public appearance since returning Sunday from Europe, the United States and Venezuela. He met with President Bush during his trip to Washington last week. He also said the drug raids now taking place in northeastern Colombia have not been a failure, as suggested in many news reports. Last week about 2,000 policemen and soldiers began combing the area in search of Pablo Escobar, reputed head of the Medellin cocaine cartel. Police said they had Escobar surrounded, but the fugitive drug lord managed to slip away for the third time in a year.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Dips, Stocks Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar slipped against the Japanese yen in Tokyo today, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange firmed on arbitrage buying. The dollar closed at 148.20 yen, down 0.23 yen from Monday's close of 148.43 yen. It opened at 147.87 yen and ranged between 147.80 yen and 148.30 yen. Spot transactions totaled $8.568 billion, up from $7.959 billion on Monday. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained 150.55 points, or 0.46 percent, to 33,172.28. The index surged 377.36 points on Monday. Volume on the first section was estimated at 600 million shares, up from Monday's 580 million shares. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond stood at 86.87 points as of 5 p.m., down from Monday's close of 87.06 points. The yield was 7.225 percent, up from 7.185 percent. Currency dealers said movement of the dollar was narrow before the release in Washington of U.S. trade data later in the day. ``Dealers' sentiment here generally favors the dollar to slip further'' because of Friday's cut in the U.S. key federal funds rate, among other factors, said Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer with Bank of Tokyo. On the stock market, traders said share prices moved higher on arbitrage buying in the day's closing minutes of trade. Yoshiro Inoue of Nomura Securities said share prices opened firm, aided by a steep overnight advance on Wall Street, and transactions were brisk in early trading before a rumor hit the market that Japan's central bank would raise its key rate for loans to commercial banks near in the future. Japan's discount rate now stands at 5.25 percent, one of the lowest among industrialized nations. The country has been under pressure from its trading partners to raise the rate to stem the yen's weakness against the dollar and other major currencies. Higher interest rates tend to make a currency more attractive to investors on the one hand, but make security investment less attractive on the other hand. In the last few minutes of the day's trading the benchmark Nikkei index shot up on buying linked to stock-index arbitrage, Inoue said. In the arbitrage, traders bought shares coupled to a short sale of the same securities to profit from a disparity of prices, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Press Ahead With Offensive On Besieged Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: The following is partly based on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia, among them Associated Press correspondent Michael Goldsmith.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ABJ1
DOC.TEXT: Rebels have redoubled their efforts to take the capital, and frightened residents are streaming out of the city on the last open road in search of food and safety, witnesses say. The fighting has cut off food supply routes and public utilities, and the witnesses said Monday that food shortages had worsened. Gunfire was heard in Monrovia, but there were no details on the battles. Heavy fighting was reported Sunday just east of this city of about 400,000. Hundreds of refugees have been fleeing, and on Monday they converged on the only road still reported open. A high government official, who said he had been held captive by the rebels for two weeks, said they were murdering members of President Samuel Doe's Krahn tribe as well as the allied Mandingos. ``It was sheer anarchy,'' the official said of what he had seen during his captivity. ``Every house is opened and looted of the cars and food in it. When they see your house, they chase you out with your family. If you resist, they kill you.'' The official spoke on condition of anonymity. It was not clear how he gained his freedom. He said he understood that the rebel leader, former Doe aide Charles Taylor, was trying to prevent such abuses. Human rights groups have accused both sides of killing hundreds of civilians in the war, which has been fought along largely tribal lines. The government official said the rebels were demanding food and lodging from civilians. He said they were executing those who refused. Witnesses have made similar charges about Doe's forces. The rebel National Patriotic Front of Liberia began its insurgency in December, accusing Doe of corruption and rights violations. Since then, its ranks have swelled from only a few hundred men into the thousands, and the rebels have captured most of the country. Most diplomats believe Doe cannot hold out against the insurgents' 2-week-old onslaught on the capital. The United States has posted 2,000 Marines on ships offshore, saying they might be needed to protect American lives. The government is operating with a skeleton staff, with only four of 21 ministers remaining. Officials acknowledged Monday that the army chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Charles Julu, has fled the country. He was reported to be in the United States. The West African nation has strategic importance for the United States. It is the base for all diplomatic messages to and from U.S. missions in Africa. There is a huge Voice of America transmission station outside Monrovia, and the country also has a powerful transmitter responsible for guiding all U.S. shipping in the Atlantic. Doe took power in a 1980 coup that ousted the elitist descendants of freed American slaves who founded this nation in 1847. Liberia now has 2 million people. The United States has offered to escort Doe from the country. The rebels have said they will not lay down their arms unless he leaves, and peace talks in neighboring Sierre Leone have broken down.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Is it too much to ask that in the wake of these multiple mistakes that President Bush should do what President Reagan did not do after the Challenger tragedy _ give personal attention to the problems at NASA.'' _ Sen. Al Gore, D-Tenn., on the administration's decision to have an outside panel study the nation's long-term space goals following problems with two shuttles and the Hubble Space Telescope.

``There is no subliminal content on the `Stained Class' album ... I say that unequivocally and we will prove that unequivocally.'' _ Defense attorney Suellen Fulstone of the heavy metal group Judas Priest, which is accused of recording an album containing lyrics that led two listeners to commit suicide.

``We were calling out our classmates' names but they did not respond any more ... Then we groped for their hands but felt that they were cold. Each time, we wept.'' _ Loida Gabwat, a 14-year-old student who lost many friends in the Philippines' earthquake.

DOC.HEAD: Drugstore Chain Head Cleared of Bribery Charges
DOC.TEXT: Rite Aid Corp. and its president have been acquitted on charges of bribing a member of Ohio's pharmacy board in an effort to fill his job with someone more favorable to the drugstore chain. Prosecutors contended that Rite Aid President Martin L. Grass, 36, gave Board of Pharmacy member Melvin Wilczynski a $33,000 company check to get him to resign. The company wanted to push its own member into the job, they said. But when the prosecution rested its case Monday, two weeks into the trial, Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Judge Lillian Greene granted a defense motion for acquittal. The judge said prosecution evidence was circumstantial and did not prove any willful intent to bribe. The ruling was met by courtroom applause. Supporters hugged the smiling Grass or shook his hand. ``I never had a doubt. It was a ridiculous prosecution,'' Grass said. Grass and Rite Aid, based in Shiremanstown, Pa., were charged in an indictment unsealed in August with bribery and possession of criminal tools, described as a corporate aircraft. Assistant County Prosecutor William Caine refused to comment. Wilczynski, 61, said he was offered a Rite Aid check for just over $33,000, plus ongoing insurance benefits. Rite Aid's lawyers claimed the payment was a legal buyout of Wilczynski's consulting contract for another drug store company, Lane Drug Co., a division of Peoples Drug Stores Inc. acquired by Rite Aid last year. Wilczynski testified that Grass offered the buyout only if he would step down as a voting member of the board. Prosecutors said Rite Aid had complained that the pharmacy board harassed the company when enforcing state regulations over drugstores. But defense attorneys argued that the board had a vendetta against Rite Aid because the company challenged some rules and decisions that it thought unreasonable. The prosecutors had the jury hear and watch two secretly-made tapes _ a recorded telephone conversation between Wilczynski and Grass on April 26, 1989, and a videotape the following day in a Cleveland hotel room. In the telephone tape, Wilczynski is heard arranging the following-day meeting with Grass at the hotel to discuss the contract buyout. In the videotape, Wilczynski and Grass are seen in the motel room, leafing through papers, some of which Wilczynski signs. Prosecutors said the papers included six undated letters of resignation. Wilczynski remains a voting member of the pharmacy board. The bribery charge carried a maximum 10-year prison sentence and a fine of up to $5,000.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms in North Plains, Great Lakes
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms moved across the northern Plains and Great Lakes region today, but fair weather prevailed over much of the rest of the nation. A disturbance that brought heavy rain to New Mexico and Texas over the weekend was expected to linger over the western Gulf of Mexico. Showers fell over southern Texas early today, and the Atlantic coastline from Florida to the Carolinas was overcast. Thunderstorms rumbled through the Dakotas and northern Michigan, and a cool front was expected to trigger more storms later in the day. Today's forecast also calls for thunderstorms to spread eastward from Texas into Louisiana. Dry weather is expected in the northern Rockies, Pacific Northwest and the central Plains, and warm air moving into the East will ward off the threat of showers between the Ohio Valley and the Northeast. Flash floods were likely in the desert Southwest. The nation's high for Monday was 107 degrees at Yuma, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Generally Lower in Europe, Gold Also Weaker
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was generally lower in calm European trading late this morning as the market waited for the release of two key U.S. indicators for guidance on the currency's next move. Gold prices were weaker in moderate dealings. Traders said U.S. trade figures for May and industrial production figures for June may push the dollar out of its current tight range. The trade deficit is expected to have widened to $7.7 billion in May from $6.94 billion in April, while industrial production is forecast to rise 0.2 percent in June following a 0.6 percent rise in May. If the indicators don't provide a strong clue about the U.S. economy, dealers said the market will be waiting for Wednesday's congressional testimony by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan for a further indication of U.S. monetary policy. The dollar fell after Greenspan's comments last week indicating that a modest easing in U.S. credit policy might be necessary. ``The performance of the dollar in the last few days hasn't been bad when you consider the reaction after the Greenspan comments last week,'' said Jochen Zimmermann, chief trader at Berliner Bank AG in Frankfurt. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.23 yen to a closing 148.20 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 148.17 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _1.6515 West German marks, down from 1.6535 _1.4165 Swiss francs, unchanged _5.5373 French francs, down from 5.5460 _1.8653 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8640 _1,209.50 Italian lire, down from 1,210.75 _1.1573 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1587 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.8075, compared with $1.8040 late Monday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $360.90 a troy ounce and at midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $361.30. Both were down from $362.75 bid late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $361.00, down from $362.70 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.25 to close at a bid $361.86. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $4.85 a troy ounce, from Monday's $4.89.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Israeli Sentenced to 90 Days For Election Violation
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge sentenced a wealthy pro-Israel activist to 90 days in prison for making an illegal $120,000 campaign contribution to aid the re-election of Alan Cranston in the 1986 Senate race. ``You must be made an example,'' U.S. District Judge Ronald S.W. Lew told Michael Goland during sentencing Monday. ``There must be deterrence.'' Goland, 43, was convicted of a misdemeanor charge of making the illegal contribution in the tight race between Cranston and his Republican challenger, Ed Zschau of Los Altos. Goland was accused of paying for a $120,000 television advertisement for American Independent Party candidate Ed Vallen to help split the conservative vote between he and Zschau to aid Cranston, who is considered liberal. Cranston is a long-time supporter of Israel and Goland felt Zschau might be less supportive of continued aid for the Middle East nation. The candidates were not implicated in the case. Cranston beat Zschau by about 100,000 votes. The contribution was illegal because the commercial claimed it was financed by the Vallen for Senate Committee, a group that did not exist, and it failed to note Goland was the actual backer, prosecutors said. Goland was acquitted of three felony counts, including conspiracy and making a false statement to a federal agency.

DOC.HEAD: Activist Braves Foul Long Island Sound to Publicize Water Pollution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Taskforce, 11th graf, and Soundkeeper, 13th graf, are cq.
DOC.TEXT: Long Island Sound is a notoriously dirty waterway, and that's precisely why Skip Storch is making a 150-mile swim across it. Storch dove in Monday and completed the first leg of the weeklong swim that will take him to to the Statue of Liberty. He's braving the pollution and 58-degree water to publicize fouled beaches and environmental damage to underwater habitats. The activist calls himself a ``modern-day Johnny Appleseed.'' ``Instead of planting (tree) seeds, I plant seeds of consciousness,'' Storch said. ``Everybody has to work together. Around the world, efforts are being made to clean up and save our planet.'' Wary of water-born germs, Storch said he had been inoculated against hepatitis. ``There are all kinds of dangers out there,'' he said, adding that he would wear a bodysuit to protect against the cold. Storch, a recreation director from Spring Valley, N.Y., swam to New London, Conn., where he stopped for the night. A boat carrying volunteer supporters will accompany him on the trip. The chilly water ``sapped most of my energy in the first two hours,'' Storch said. He plans to swim about 17 miles a day and end the week at the Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor. Twenty million people live, work or play on or near the sound, swim organizers said. The waterway extends from New York Harbor to the southwestern tip of Rhode Island. Herm Hannah of the Long Island Sound Taskforce said it once was an important commercial fishing area where beachgoers could take a dip without getting a booster shot first. ``Unfortunately, it has also been a dumping ground,'' Hannah said. ``Skip Storch is going to highlight the good things he sees and try to make us very much aware what needs to be done to keep this sound clean and usable.'' Terry Backer of the Long Island Soundkeeper Fund said ignoring cleanup efforts could be costly. ``The coastal environment for Rhode Island, Connecticut and New York is the source of billions of dollars of revenue,'' he said. ``When people feel (the waters are) open sewers ... we're going to lose that revenue.'' It wasn't the first time Storch has embarked on a long swim to heighten awareness about water pollution. Last summer he swam from Atlantic City, N.J., to New York Harbor and the summer before he swam down the Hudson River from Albany, N.Y., to the Statue of Liberty.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS item to correct `whose' to `who' in lead.
DOC.TEXT: Rock 'n' roller Joe Cocker, who lives less than a mile from neighborhoods ravaged by a June fire that destroyed more than 400 homes, will give a benefit performance for fire victims with Pat Benatar. The ``With a Little Help For Our Friends'' concert was scheduled for July 31 at the Santa Barbara County Bowl. ``Many of my neighbors and friends, people I have known for years, have been hurt by this tragedy,'' Cocker said Monday. ``Some of them risked their lives fighting the fire, and I want to return something to them. ... If I can do that with my music, I will.'' Cocker's best-known recordings include ``With a Little Help From My Friends,'' ``The Letter'' and ``Delta Lady.'' One person was killed in the blaze.

DOC.HEAD: `Die Hard 2'' No. 1 Again; `Ghost' Opens Strongly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to correct to `fewer' sted `less'; SUBS 1st item in list to include full name of 20th Century Fox.
DOC.TEXT: ``Die Hard 2'' stayed atop the box office ratings, but ``Ghost'' conjured up more dollars per screen while debuting in less than half as many theaters. ``Die Hard 2'' grossed $14.5 million over the weekend, becoming only the second film this summer, after ``Dick Tracy,'' to lead for two consecutive weeks. The Bruce Willis tough guy-vs.-terrorists flick has now made $60.7 million. ``Ghost,'' a romantic drama starring Demi Moore and Patrick Swayze, was second with receipts of $12.2 million, but the film opened on just 1,101 screens, fewer than half as many as ``Die Hard 2.'' Its ticket sales of $11,073 per screen was the third-best per-theater average of the season, behind the far more expensive and heavily hyped ``Total Recall'' and ``Back to the Future Part III.'' ``Days of Thunder,'' with Tom Cruise as a race-car driver whose smile is as winning as his automobile, was in third place and continuing to do strong business with $8.2 million. The re-release of the 1967 animated film ``Jungle Book'' was fourth on a gross of $7.7 million. ``The Adventures of Ford Fairlane,'' starring raunchy comedian Andrew Dice Clay, was fifth in a somewhat limited release. It collected $6.4 million in its first weekend, or $5,120 per screen in 1,245 theaters. ``Dick Tracy'' was sixth with $4.8 million, followed by Bill Murray's latest, ``Quick Change.'' The comedy about a bank robber grossed $4.7 million in a weak debut. Arnold Schwarzenegger's ``Total Recall'' finished in eighth with a gate of $3.2 million, and ``Another 48 HRS.'' was ninth on $3 million. ``Jetsons: The Movie'' was 10th with collections of $2.9 million. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Rules Against Sharon's Emergency Housing Plan
DOC.TEXT: Israel's Supreme Court today overturned emergency regulations by Housing Minister Ariel Sharon to speed the construction of homes for thousands of Soviet immigrants. The three-judge panel ruled Sharon could have sought approval for the programs from parliament instead of using the emergency powers. It was the first time the court challenged the government's use of such regulations, which date from Israel's 1948 independence war. Up to 150,000 Soviet immigrants are expected to arrive this year. Tent cities are springing up across the country as part of protests by Israelis who say subsidies for immigrants are driving up rents and pricing others out of the housing market. Sharon, who also serves as Cabinet coordinator of immigration, had asked to use emergency regulations to allow the purchase of 3,000 prefabricated homes, either locally or abroad. The Cabinet approved it July 1. ``There is no doubt that this is a revolutionary decision,'' said Moshe Negbi, a legal expert for the Hebrew daily newspaper Hadashot. He said the procedure for emergency powers was introduced during war in 1948 when there was a fear the Knesset, or parliament, could not always be convened because of the fighting. ``For the first time, the Supreme Court clearly says that the government ... must not use these radical powers when there is no problem in convening the parliament,'' Negbi said. ``It must not get around the parliament and adopt its authority.'' Under the emergency regulations, the Cabinet authorized the prefabricated housing units to be set up near nine Israeli towns, most in the Galilee in the north and in the southern Negev desert. Some politicians expressed fear that Sharon would try to take undemocratic actions, assuming powers delegated to planning councils and zoning boards. Sharon was accused as defense minister in 1982 of concealing military plans from the government that led to the army's invasion of Lebanon. The high court panel issued its ruling after a liberal legislator, Abraham Poraz of the Shinui Party, appealed Sharon's use of emergency regulations. In his appeal, Poraz argued Sharon used emergency regulations at a time when the Knesset was debating the housing crisis. Last week, the Knesset passed a law that shortened housing license procedures. ``Emergency regulations are an anti-democratic act ... that should be used only in difficult, exceptional situations, when there is no other choice,'' Poraz said on Israel army radio. The government argued in its court response that emergency regulations were needed to ease the housing crisis created by the mass influx of Soviet Jews. According to figures submitted by the government, Israel's 20,000 available rental apartments will be filled by the end of September.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Iranian Shiites Storm Amal Stronghold, PLO Steps In To Block Advance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with PLO intervention; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Hezbollah fighters dislodged their Amal militia rivals from a key hilltop village in southern Lebanon in fierce fighting, leaving the village square ``littered with bodies,'' police said today. Palestine Liberation Organization fighters moved in to block the fundamentalist Hezbollah's push to expand its territory and later came under mortar fire from Hezbollah, which overran the village of Jarjou. At least eight people were killed and 27 wounded in fighting during the night, police said. That raised the casualty toll since fighting began early Monday to at least 20 killed and 77 wounded. The PLO said it intervened to block the apparent drive by Hezbollah, or Party of God, to the Mediterranean coast. Hezbollah, or Party of God, is a pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem group while Amal is a Syrian-backed group comprised of more secular Shiites. The rival militias have been fighting off and on for three years for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. Police said Hezbollah fighters broke through Amal's defenses around the village of Jajrou and were advancing toward Nabatiyeh, the main town in the central sector of southern Lebanon. Jarjou is five miles north of Nabatiyeh, which has been controlled by Amal since an offensive against Hezbollah two years ago. ``It was close-quarter combat in Jarjou. The village square is littered with bodies that couldn't be evacuated by the Red Cross because of the savage fighting,'' a police spokesman said. Police said several hundred heavily armed guerrillas from Fatah, Yasser Arafat's faction in the PLO, moved in to halt the bloodletting this morning. It deployed along a two-mile front between Amal and Hezbollah along the southwestern edge of the disputed zone in the villages of Sarba and Houmine overlooking Jarjou. Four hours later, Hezbollah fighters shelled the Palestinians in Sarba with 82mm and 120mm mortars, police said. Lt. Col. Anwar Madi, commander of the PLO force in Sarba, reported no casualties in the barrage. The police spokesman said Madi shouted at the Hezbollah fighters through a bullhorn: ``Stop shooting or we'll respond.'' The shelling ``sharply decreased about 15 minutes later,'' the spokesman said. The PLO has about 5,000 fighters in the south based in refugee camps around Sidon. Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps has an estimated 3,000 men deployed in the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon. The guards were moved there in 1982 during Israel's invasion of Lebanon. The PLO fears that Hezbollah's aim is to seize control of Sidon, the southern provincial capital, to gain an outlet to the Mediterranean, a move that would dramatically alter the strategic balance in the region north of Israel. Hezbollah badly needs a coastal outlet because its supply lines from the Bekaa Valley northeast of the battle zone are vulnerable to interdiction by Syria and its Lebanese allies. A PLO source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said if Hezbollah was allowed to control ``any part of the coast, they'll have a port to ship in weapons, ammunition and fighters and establish their own Islamic republic modeled on Iran.'' The PLO also is determined to prevent Iran from establishing control, through Hezbollah, of strategic terrain east of the Palestinian camps in Sidon. The source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Palestinian deployment today was ``personally ordered by Arafat in a message received overnight.'' Shortly after the PLO force was deployed, Israeli warplanes made several low-level passes over the battle zone. ``They're apparently monitoring the Palestinian deployment,'' the police spokesman said. In January, a battalion-size PLO force intervened to separate Amal and Hezbollah units in the region. That halted a Hezbollah advance, saved Amal from a decisive defeat and at the same time enlarged the PLO's area of control. By police count, 1,069 people have been killed and 3,228 wounded in Amal-Hezbollah fighting since late 1986.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Cuban Asylum-Seekers Leave Czechoslovak Embassy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with details, Cuban agency not mentioning a promise to the asylum-seekers. Pick up 8th pvs, `Five of...'
DOC.TEXT: Twelve Cuban asylum-seekers have left the Czechoslovak Embassy in Havana, and one report said the Cuban government promised to help them leave the country. However, Cuba's official news agency reported the release without any mention of a promise to help the Cubans leave. At least eight other would-be emigrants were reported still holed up in diplomatic compounds. The East German news agency ADN, in a dispatch from Havana today, quoted the Cuban Foreign Ministry as saying the asylum-seekers left Monday night after the country's Communist government promised to help them find asylum abroad. Czechoslovak radio also reported the release. A Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry official, Jindrich Opava, said by telephone that he had no details on the circumstances of the asylum-seekers' leaving. The Cuban agency Prensa Latina, also quoting an official statement, said the asylum-seekers would be returned to their homes upon completion of an investigation of the incident. It made no mention of any Cuban promise to the asylum seekers. The Spanish news agency EFE also quoted the Cuban statement as saying 11 of the Cubans ``left the embassy voluntarily (and) unconditionally'' Monday night. The twelfth, according to Czechoslovak sources, was evacuated earlier Monday in an ambulance after his blood pressure went up, EFE said. On Monday evening, the Mexican news agency Notimex quoted the Cuban Foreign Ministry as saying it would not give in to the refugees' demands for safe conduct out of the country. Five of the 12 had arrived on July 9 and apparently remained peaceful. But the other seven, who arrived on Wednesday, took several diplomats hostage on Monday, Notimex reported from Havana. The agency said they threatened to blow up an embassy building unless they were allowed to go to the United States. They were believed to be unarmed. Czechoslovak television reported later that the diplomats had been released. Five refugees remained at the residence of Czechoslovak charge d'affaires Jan Doemoek, ADN said. It said the diplomat has asked Cuban authorities to eject the five from his home, but the Cubans have so far refused. It said Czechoslovakia was refusing to grant asylum to the five because they used violence to break into the diplomat's home. In addition, three would-be emigrants took refuge in the Spanish embassy last week. Madrid lodged a protest after Cuban authorities chased a fourth onto the grounds of the Spanish Embassy and hauled him away Sunday. ADN said ``tumultuous scenes'' occurred at the Czechoslovak Embassy compound Monday, with furniture and other objects being thrown from the windows. The affair has soured Cuba's relations with Czechoslovakia. The countries had been close allies before last fall's ``velvet revolution'' toppled Prague's hard-line Communist leaders. Cuban President Fidel Castro has defied the reformist trend sweeping Eastern Europe, refusing to abandon socialism. Castro, in his first official statement on the affair, called the asylum-seekers ``antisocial elements encouraged by Czechoslovak diplomats,'' the Czechoslovak newspaper Lidova Demokracie said Monday. The newspaper also quoted him as saying that Cuba has no agreement on diplomatic asylum with European countries, and the embassies of these countries have no right to grant asylum. Czechoslovak television quoted Foreign Ministry spokesman Lubos Dobrovsky on Monday as saying a deputy foreign minister would leave for Havana immediately because ``it is necessary to protect the safety of Czechoslovak citizens.'' As the tension over the refugees increased, about 30 Czechoslovaks left Cuba on Sunday on a regular flight, Lidova Demokracie reported Monday. Opava said they included some families of diplomats.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Gets Six Years For Breaking Into `Cagney' Star's Home
DOC.TEXT: An obsessed fan of ``Cagney and Lacey'' star Sharon Gless apologized during her sentencing to six years in prison for a break-in at the performer's home. Joni Leigh Penn, 30, of Garden Grove pleaded no contest to two felony burglary charges Monday in San Fernando Superior Court. ``I just want to apologize to Sharon Gless and her family and any of her friends for all the stress and trouble I've caused,'' said Ms. Penn. ``I want her to feel safe, because she is from me, and I'm really sorry for what I did,'' she said. Gless' brother and attorney, Michael Gless, said that he was glad Ms. Penn would be locked up for a while. ``That might be enough for her to get the help she needs so this won't be a problem any more,'' he said. Police said Penn was carrying an assault rifle when she barricaded herself in Gless' home. Gless, who played a tough police detective on the old ``Cagney and Lacey'' television series, was not at her Studio City home. Police said Ms. Penn told them she was in love with Gless and planned to sexually assault her, then kill herself. At the time, she was under a restraining order instructing her to stay away from the actress.

DOC.HEAD: Writer Susan Sontag, Juggler, Health Activist Win MacArthur Fellowships
RETRANSMITTING a0428 to fix name Sontag in summary line
With PM-MacArthur-List
DOC.TEXT: Writer Susan Sontag may cut back on lecturing. Population studies expert Paul Ehrlich says he will buy part of a rain forest. And public health activist Sidney M. Wolfe plans to continue battling for consumers. All three were contemplating how to deal with sudden wealth as recipients of this year's MacArthur fellowships, grants of up to $375,000 that the 36 winners may spend as they choose. A juggler, a free-lance wildlife illustrator and numerous poets and academicians also received the prestigious grants announced Monday by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation. The grants range from $150,000 to $375,000 over five years, with the largest amounts going to the oldest recipients. ``It's very liberating, and it's also a great honor,'' Sontag of her $340,000 grant. ``It's an incredible relief. It means a lot for my work.'' The 57-year-old essayist and critic, whose works include ``On Photography'' and ``AIDS and its Metaphors,'' said she can now concentrate on writing and cut back on lecturing that was needed ``to help pay the rent.'' Individuals cannot apply for the grants, which must be proposed to the foundation by a group of more than 100 designated nominators nationwide. Nominations are reviewed by a selection committee, and final approval for the fellowships comes from the foundation's board of directors. A total of 319 fellows have been named since the program began in 1981. They have ranged in age from 18 to 82, representing fields including the arts, human rights, mathematics and medicine. Ehrlich, a Stanford University professor whose work also includes environmental preservation, said he will use his $345,000 grant to buy part of an Argentinian rain forest that is rich in bioligical specimens. ``For somebody in my position, (the grant) is the best of all possible worlds,'' Ehrlich said. ``It's just delightful to get recognized by this organization,'' said Wolfe, a 53-year-old physician and director of the Public Citizen Health Research Group, a Washington-based public-interest group whose work has led to government bans or limitation on certain drugs and medical devices. Wolfe received a $320,000 grant, but said, ``The thing that means the most is really recognizing that our way of researching health issues and trying to improve people's health is important.'' Also among this year's recipients are Jacques D'Amboise, founder of the National Dance Institute; Michael Moschen, a juggler who has appeared in several films and on television's ``Sesame Street;'' and Kent Whealy, co-director of the Seed Savers Exchange, a Decorah, Iowa, group that preserves heirloom varieties of crop plants. The MacArthur Foundation is the legacy of John D. MacArthur, founder of Bankers Life and Casualty Co. and a Chicago philanthropist who died in 1978; and his wife, Catherine, who died in 1981. The bulk of the couple's fortune went to the foundation they created, which has awarded more than $800 million in grants since 1978.

DOC.HEAD: Jubilant Kohl Says Pan-German Elections Expected in December
With PM-Soviet-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A jubilant Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that he and Mikhail S. Gorbachev have solved all practical problems in the way of German unification and that elections for an all-German parliament are expected on Dec. 2. Kohl met with reporters a day after returning from a two-day trip to the Soviet Union, where he and the Soviet president announced Gorbachev had dropped his objections to NATO membership for a united Germany. The Soviet objections had been the most significant obstacle to unification. ``The practical problems, which lay before us on the way to German unity, have been solved,'' Kohl said. He said joint German elections were expected Dec. 2, but whether East Germany merges with the West before or after elections had to be decided by East Berlin. He also reiterated his position that the capital of a united Germany must be decided by the new Parliament. East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, who is pushing for Berlin over Bonn as united Germany's capital, has said the capital must be stipulated in a unification treaty now in preparation. Kohl said that during his visit he had offered no specific economic aid to the Soviets, but he emphasized that Gorbachev needs financial help if his program of economic restructuring is to succeed. He said he could envision the West Germans helping the Soviets retrain the thousands of soldiers who would return from East Germany and possibly face unemployment, as well as help in supplying housing but ``not for a certain category of Soviet residents.'' West German officials worry about the political fallout at home of building housing specifically for returning Soviet troops. Kohl ruled out the possibility that West Germany would be the sole source of financial aid to the Soviets, saying the burden would be too great. At the Houston summit of the world's industrial leaders last week, Kohl had pushed for a $15 billion international aid package for the Soviet Union. Instead, the leaders asked the International Monetary Fund to study exactly what kind of aid would be most beneficial. West Germany has already backed a $3 billion bank credit to help the Soviet Union shift its economy to a free market and has agreed to pay $780 million toward the upkeep of Soviet soldiers stationed in East Germany in the second half of this year. Kohl said he hoped a bilateral treaty with the Soviet Union that covered all areas and provided for regular meetings could be ready by next summer. He set the same time frame for a treaty with Poland, and said he wanted it to be wide-ranging, not just focusing on the border question. Poland has been pushing for a formal, written guarantee that Germany will never try to reclaim territory it lost after World War II. One-third of modern day Poland was once German land. Among the Kohl and Gorbachev agreements announced Monday were plans to reduce the size of a united German army to 370,000 soldiers within three to four years after unification. Currently, the two Germanys have about 600,000 soldiers under arms. East German Foreign Minister Markus Meckel today rejected the idea of one German army. He said East Germany should retain its army and its own command structure and called for even deeper cuts in the combined armed forces.

DOC.HEAD: Western Nations Hail Gorbachev Acceptance of Germany in NATO
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for 4th graf pvs, `By dropping...' to UPDATE with Bush, Kohl remarks. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `Gorbachev and...'
DOC.TEXT: Western countries are praising Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decision to allow a united Germany the freedom to join NATO, calling it a turning point in European history. The decision, announced Monday by Gorbachev and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, was ``an extremely positive development in Soviet thinking,'' Britain's Foreign Office said. ``We have throughout argued that a united Germany in NATO would be in the best interests of all those concerned,'' it said in a statement. In Washington, President Bush said Gorbachev's action ``strengthens efforts to build enduring relationships based on cooperation.'' By dropping its objection to NATO membership for a united Germany, the Soviet Union removed the last big obstacle to German unification. A beaming Kohl said today in Bonn that he and Gorbachev have solved all practical problems in the way of unification and that elections for an all-German parliament are expected on Dec. 2. Gorbachev and Kohl announced the agreement in a televised news conference in Gorbachev's home region, Stavropol in the Soviet republic of Russia. The area was one of the deepest points of German penetration during World War II. The announcement capped several months of intense diplomatic maneuvering, during which Germany backed a $3 billion bank loan to Moscow and pushed its allies for a comprehensive plan to bail out the crumbling Soviet economy. The Foreign Office said Gorbachev was evidently swayed by the July 5-6 NATO summit in London at which the 16 leaders of the Western alliance committed themselves to limiting the size of the German army _ a prime Soviet concern. Leaders of North Atlantic Treaty Organization also offered a non-aggression pact to the Soviet Union and other Eastern European countries, and said nuclear arms would only be weapons of ``last resort.'' France, a major West European power that belongs to NATO but keeps its military forces outside the alliance's command, had no immediate comment. Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said he was waiting to hear the news personally from West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. In Rome, an Italian Foreign Ministry spokesman praised Gorbachev's position. ``At first glance we look on it with extreme favor,'' said the spokesman, who declined to be identified. Austria, which is not a member of NATO, said the agreement was ``a historic hour for Europe and for the world.'' ``The long journey of European history in this century has reached a very positive station,'' said Austrian Chancellor Franz Vranitzky. It is ``the foundation for building a peaceful Europe.'' The Soviet Union took the heaviest casualties of any nation in World War II, with some 20 million people killed. In Tokyo, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu today hailed the development as ``big progress.'' Japan is not a NATO member by has expressed its intention to send officials as observers to meetings of both NATO and the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. NATO, in a statement from its Brussels headquarters, said Gorbachev's acceptance of a unified Germany in the Western alliance ``will increase stability for all ... including the Soviet Union.'' In Bonn, the leader of Kohl's governing party said the decision marked a ``new high point'' in German-Soviet relations. ``There is nothing more standing in the way of the reunification of Germany in full sovereignty by the end of the year. The new Europe has taken on a concrete form,'' said Volker Ruehe, general-secretary of Kohl's Christian Democratic Union. East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere told West German television ``the question ... of full sovereignty for a united Germany has been secured.'' In the German view, this includes an end to all remaining rights over the divided nation by the four World War II victors _ the Soviet Union, the United States, France and Britain. The four allies were meeting in Paris today for another round of talks on the international implications of German unity.

DOC.HEAD: Whale Freed From Fisherman's Net
DOC.TEXT: Rescuers perched in dinghies worked for three hours to untangle a whale from a fishing net, then whooped and cheered as the humpback swam free. The rescuers were nearly capsized Monday when they came within inches of the 38-foot whale's breathing hole. The whale named Mallard was discovered earlier in the day thrashing in the Atlantic Ocean, 30 miles from Boston. ``Boy, did these guys have guts,'' said Captain Tom Hill of the Yankee Captains, one of the vessels dispatched to try to save the 5-year-old whale. ``All it would take is one good swipe with a flipper to kill them.'' But with patience and daring, the rescuers untangled the net from Mallard's flippers, mouth and tail. The 25-ton humpback, spouting and breaching, joined a throng of whales that had remained nearby. Once the sight of a helpless whale would have been considered a bounty for sailors who plied the Atlantic in search of whales. Today, the ships that roam this area are filled with people longing for a glimpse of the creatures. Rescue workers attached buoys to the trailing ends of the net wrapped around Mallard and waited for the humpback to tire and rest on the surface. The other whales kept a safe distance, expect for one that came up alongside the entangled mammal and rubbed its head. Leading a crew of four rescuers, Charles ``Stormy'' Mayo, head of the Center for Coastal Studies in Provincetown, Mass., launched two inflatable and motorized dinghies and floated on top of the two whales. When Mallard suddenly reared its head, Mayo's boat nearly overturned. ``Finally, we were able to cut the lines with some of our specialized equipment. Rough weather made this rescue quite difficult,'' Mayo said later. ``The whale seemed to work in harmony with our efforts to free it.'' The rescue mission began after a fisherman radioed that he was awakened in the morning by a whale thrashing next to his boat. The whale, named by whale watchers when it was first recorded in 1986, was identified by scars and coloring on its tail and flukes. Mallard _ sex unknown _ was tangled in one of the quarter-mile-long gill nets set on the lucrative Stellwagen Bank fishing grounds about 17 miles off Gloucester and 25 miles from Provincetown. Whales come to the area to feed on cod, haddock and other fish plentiful this time of year.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Department Releasing Records of Nuclear-Weapons Workers
DOC.TEXT: Records detailing radiation exposure of 50,000 nuclear weapons workers are being sent to researchers who were denied access to the information in the late 1970s after they detected high cancer rates. The federal Energy Department said Monday that the computer tapes containing data on the workers at the Hanford, Wash., nuclear reservation would be in the mail today at the latest. They would have been mailed Monday but for a minor glitch in preparing the tapes, department spokesman Robert Griffin said today. ``It won't be very dramatic, but it's a great moment in history of this research,'' said Alice Stewart, one of three radiation scientists awaiting the records. Last month, after resisting for years, the Energy Department agreed to release the data, in a settlement with a Philadelphia-based group that monitors plant safety, the Three Mile Island Public Health Fund. ``It's been a long struggle and I'm very gratified that we've been successful,'' said Daniel Berger, a lawyer for the group. Researchers Thomas Mancuso of the University of Pittsburgh and Stewart and George Kneale of Birmingham University in England studied Hanford records in the late 1970s for the Energy Department but were discharged after publishing preliminary findings showing high cancer rates. ``We left the story rather abruptly because we produced a risk estimate that was considered impossibly high,'' Stewart recalled. The release is important, she said, because it shows that ``whoever owns the industry must never be totally in charge of health records.'' In Washington, Energy Department spokesman Bob Griffin said officials in Hanford were ``making last-minute adjustments, working feverishly'' to prepare the tapes for delivery. The department agreed to release records of workers at 10 weapons plants in four batches over the next 10 months. All told, the information will cover 200,000 of the 300,000 current and former workers at the plants since World War II. The Energy Department stopped financing the research and denied access to the records, citing patient confidentiality. The Three Mile Island Public Health Fund sued for access and the department agreed to reopen the files. It enabled the resumption of research done more than 10 years ago, Stewart said. ``We're hoping that, say by the end of year, we'll establish some very firm points,'' she said. Stewart estimated cancer rates may be shown to be three to five times higher than most experts previously thought, in line with the preliminary findings of 13 years ago. The next batch of records to be released will over workers from these plants: Rocky Flats, Colo.; Los Alamos National Laboratory, N.M.; Mound Laboratory, Miamisburg, Ohio; and the Pantex facility in Amarillo, Texas. After that, records will be released from plants at Oak Ridge, Tenn. and Savannah River, S.C.; followed by records from the Fernald Feed Plant, Fernald, Ohio; the Mallinckrodt Chemical Works in St. Louis and the K-25 Plant in Oak Ridge.

DOC.HEAD: Georgians Vote As Federal Judge Refuses To Intervene in Primary System
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with judge refusing to intervene, early turnout, picking up at the 8th graf previous, ``I feel better.''
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Young put his bid to become Georgia's first black governor before the voters today, and a federal judge refused to throw out Georgia's runoff election system. Late polls showed Young running slightly behind Lt. Gov. Zell Miller in the five-way Democratic primary with neither of them likely to gain the majority vote required to avoid an Aug. 7 runoff. Black leaders acting without Young's support had filed a lawsuit arguing the runoff system is unfair to blacks, who make up about 22 percent of Georgia's registered voters. They asked U.S. District Judge Richard Freeman to declare today's top finisher the Democratic nominee even if he did not have a majority. But the judge, who held a five-day hearing on the request last week, today refused to interfere, saying he would not issue a temporary restraining order that would have immediately blocked the runoff. He did not set a trial date to consider the issue further. It was cloudy in Atlanta and elsewhere, but there was no rain to discourage voters early today. Election officials predicted that 33 percent of registered voters would cast ballots. Young, the former Atlanta mayor, U.N. ambassador and congressman, predicted Monday he would run more strongly in predominantly white areas today than pollsters and other observers expect. ``A lot of people who say I couldn't get votes in south Georgia have implied there's something backward about south Georgia, and I think they've underestimated south Georgia again,'' he said in Columbus. ``We're going to surprise people in where we get votes.'' Miller and state Sen. Roy Barnes, also expressed optimism as they crisscrossed the state Monday. Both are white. ``I feel better about this campaign and this race than any of the others,'' Miller said at a rally in suburban Atlanta. Barnes refused to concede defeat despite Young's prediction earlier Monday that the state senator would support him in a runoff against Miller. ``Andy and I have deep philosophical differences,'' said Barnes, who portrayed himself as the conservative alternative to ``tax-and-spend liberals.'' Polls have shown state Rep. Johnny Isakson with a strong lead in the four-man Republican gubernatorial race. Gov. Joe Frank Harris, a Democrat, is completing his second term and cannot seek re-election. Despite the closeness of the race, the Democratic campaign has been a gentlemanly affair, free of negative advertising and racial appeals. Even former Gov. Lester Maddox, a longtime segregationist running a longshot campaign, de-emphasized race as an issue. Young said he didn't attribute the positive nature of the campaign to any altruism on the candidates' part. Rather, he said, negative campaigns don't seem to work these days. ``I think they would fire away if they thought it would work,'' he said. Miller, who has made a lottery to raise money for schools his signature issue, attributed the positive atmosphere to ``the character of the candidates.'' ``And I think it has been good for the state of Georgia, racially,'' Miller said. ``You can't get elected in Georgia without a strong coalition of urban and rural and black and white.'' In event of a runoff, Young will be battling for white support. A recent poll by The Atlanta Journal-Constitution showed 36 percent of likely Democratic voters favored Miller, 30 percent Young and 16 percent Barnes. The poll had a margin of error of 3 points. But the poll found that only 14 percent of white voters supported Young, while 45 percent supported Miller. Three seats in the U.S. House also are being contested today, but only one incumbent, Rep. Doug Barnard, has opposition. Barnard, a Democrat from Augusta, is a member of the House Banking Committee and has been accused of being too cozy with savings and loan officials. He faces journalism student Scott A. Starling. J.B. Stoner, a white supremacist who served time for the bombing of a black church in Alabama, is running for lieutenant governor but is considered the longest shot of nine candidates in the Democratic primary.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Kills 234; Rescue Efforts Hampered in Stricken Areas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4 grafs for grafs 7-8 pvs, `The hardest-hit...' to UPDATE with relief effort, description of damage at Hyatt. Pickup 9th pvs, `The quake...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MLA3
DOC.TEXT: Authorities said today that more than 230 people were killed in a major earthquake, and television reports said the worst affected areas were woefully short of blood, medicine and rescue equipment. U.S. military units rushed to two of the worst affected areas with medical supplies and engineering equipment to help clear rubble. Japan and other countries also provided help. President Corazon Aquino today visited the quake-stricken city of Cabanatuan and declaed a state of emergency in the affected areas. Scores of buildings were destroyed by Monday's temblor and the death toll was expected to rise as rescuers pulled more bodies from the rubble. Figures compiled by the Office of Civil Defense and the Philippine Red Cross showed 234 people were killed and more than 600 injured in the quake, which measured 7.7 on the Richter scale and struck the country's main island of Luzon, including Manila. Its epicenter was 60 miles north of the capital. Officials complained that rescue efforts were hampered by a lack of heavy equipment to remove rubble. Reporters said some efforts appeared disorganized with little evidence of government supervision. In Geneva, the International Red Cross today appealed for $357,000 to provide aid _ mostly food and medicines _ to earthquake victims. The hardest-hit area was the mountain resort of Baguio, 110 miles north of Manila, where 22 buildings, including four hotels, were heavily damaged. Officials said as many as 1,000 people were trapped in damaged buildings in Baguio, with the Hyatt Hotel sustaining the worst damage. Officials estimated about 50 people died. The earthquake caused the catwalks that surrounded a five-story indoor atrium to collapse, and parts of adjacent guest rooms fell into the lobby. The quake ripped the city's luxury Nevada Hotel in half, leaving a huge gash in the middle of the structure. Baguio radio station DZWT said 23 people were killed when the commerce building at the University of Baguio collapsed. U.S. officials said four members of the U.S. Agency for International Development were staying at the Nevada and one was missing. A Filipino television reporter who visited Baguio by helicopter described the city as a virtual ``war zone,'' running low on food, water and fuel. An American medical unit from the Subic Bay naval base was flown by helicopter to Baguio, a fashionable summer retreat, today to help in rescue efforts and establish a field hospital. Thirteen aftershocks rumbled across Luzon after the quake and many of Baguio's 119,000 people slept outdoors Monday night. Manila television stations showed clusters of the homeless camped out in a city park. Numerous bridges in central Luzon were heavily damaged and hundreds of motorists were stuck along highways. Roads to Baguio were blocked by landslides, officials said. Officials said the other worst affected areas were Dagupan, 100 miles north of Manila, and Nueva Ecija province, which includes the 80,000-resident city of Cabanatuan, where a six-story school collapsed. Schools were ordered closed indefinitely in Manila and other affected areas as officials inspected classroom buildings for damage. In Cabanatuan, 60 miles north of Manila, hospitals were so jammed with injured that many patients spent Monday night on cots in the hospital's yards. Hospitals said 35 people were killed in the area and 154 injured. Mayor Honorato Perez said up to 30 people were believed still trapped beneath the rubble of the school. U.S. military engineers from Clark Air Base brought in heavy equipment to clear the rubble. Volunteers had been trying to dig through the rubble, sometimes with bare hands. They appeared to be acting with little supervision by local authorities. In Cabanatuan, friends and relatives of the students kept vigil at the ruined school. Each time a survivor was brought out, the crowd rushed forward asking for word of their loved ones. In Dagupan, the civil defense office reported 20 deaths. U.S. officials said some of the Baguio injured were being transported to American military hospitals at nearby Camp John Hay and Clark Air Base. The Pentagon said it provided an Air Force C-141 transport plane to carry 16 civilian search and rescue personnel, four dogs and support equipment to assist in the hunt for survivors. Canada, Thailand, Switzerland and South Korea also offered assistance. Officials said 10 people were killed in the metropolitan Manila. The Philippine Institute of Vulcanology and Seismology recorded more than 70 aftershocks. Monday's quake was the worst to strike the Philippines since 1976, when a 7.8-magnitude quake killed 8,000 people. Most died in a tidal wave that struck Mindanao. The June 21 earthquake in Iran registered 7.3 to 7.7 on the Richter scale and killed at least 40,000 people. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means the ground motion is 10 times greater.

DOC.HEAD: At Least Forty Mountain Climbers Perish in Avalanche
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to correct spelling of coach's name to Shatayev. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: At least 40 mountain climbers, including 13 foreigners, have died in an avalanche set off by an earthquake in the Pamir mountains in Soviet Central Asia, the Tass news agency and climbing officials said today. Three climbers in the group survived when the avalanche Friday engulfed a base camp on Lenin Peak, a climbing coach said. According to Vladimir Shatayev, a coach with the Soviet mountain climbing committee, Alexei Koren of Leningrad suffered a broken arm and an unidentified Czechovakian member of the group broke a leg. A third climber escaped unhurt, he said. The two injured climbers were taken to a hospital in Osh, in the Republic of Kirghizia, he said. Tass said the avalanche struck the base camp, known as ``Frying Pan,'' situated at the 15,900-feet level of Lenin Peak in the Central Asian mountain range 1,800 miles southeast of Moscow. ``There has never been such a tragedy in the history of Soviet mountain climbing,'' Shatayev said in a telephone interview. ``I don't think there has ever been such an accident in the world.'' He said the base camp has been in use since the 1930s. Since 1974, he said, the base camp has been almost permanently occupied by groups of 100 or more mountain climbers. Shatayev said 23 of the victims belonged to the Leningrad mountain climbing team, four came from Israel, six from Czechoslovakia, two from Switzerland and one from Spain. The remainder were from other Soviet clubs. He said none of the bodies have been recovered, but that a team of 100 rescue workers was searching for the remains of the victims. ``Everything is complicated by heavy snow,'' he said. Interfax, the information service of Moscow Radio, said the climbers were preparing to climb to the top of Lenin Peak when the avalanche struck.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Vivisectionist Sentenced to 32 Months, Probation
DOC.TEXT: An animal rights activist who pleaded no contest to trying to bomb the head of a company that uses dogs in medical demonstrations has been sentenced to 32 months in prison. Fran Trutt was accused of planting a pipe bomb near the parking space of Leon C. Hirsch, chairman and chief executive of Norwalk-based U.S. Surgical Corp., in November 1988. The company uses anesthetized live dogs to show surgeons how to use its surgical staplers, used in some cases in places of sutures. Trutt, 35, of New York, pleaded no contest April 16 to charges of attempted murder, possession of explosives and bomb manufacturing in the incident. Stamford Superior Court Judge Joette Katz imposed a sentence of 10 years for each charge, to run concurrently and suspended after 32 months. With credit for time already served, Trutt will be released from prison next March 31. Trutt told Katz that she feels she is a scapegoat. ``Here I am taking the brunt for it. This is unbelievable,'' she said. She had said in interviews that she wanted to scare Hirsch, not kill him. Animal protection groups, citing an abhorrence of violence, did not rally behind Trutt until her attorney, John R. Williams, alleged the company had set her up. According to Williams, Mary Lou Sapone was cent Chevron stake to slightly less than 10 percent. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks edged up .21 to 201.34. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index fell 1.10 to 364.48.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Refuses to Throw Out Georgia Runoffs
With PM-Georgia Governor, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today refused to halt Georgia's Aug. 7 primary runoff despite a challenge by blacks to the state's majority vote rule, saying the opponents had filed too late to disrupt this year's elections. The 16-page ruling, which came as voters were going to the polls to choose Democratic and Republican nominees for governor, allows the state to hold runoffs, if they are needed after today's vote. An attorney for the black plaintiffs said he could not rule out a future court challenge to the outcome of the runoff. Granting an injunction to halt the runoff at this late date would ``significantly disrupt elections at all levels in Georgia,'' U.S. District Judge Richard C. Freeman said in his order. Candidates who signed up for today's primary ``reasonably believed that the majority vote requirement would govern the 1990 elections,'' Freeman said. But he also said the plaintiffs had raised a legitimate point that would have to be decided later. A coalition of black political and community leaders filed a lawsuit in May, seeking to abolish Georgia's majority vote requirement on grounds that it discriminates against black voters. They asked Freeman for a preliminary injunction that would have halted the Aug. 7 runoff. Such a runoff is expected in the Democratic gubernatorial primary, where pre-election polls indicate no one is likely to get an absolute majority. A runoff is considered less likely in the Republican primary. Among the five Democrats in today's governor's race was Andrew Young, the former Atlanta mayor seeking to become Georgia's first black governor. A ruling halting the runoff could have favored Young, most observers believe, although Young did not support the lawsuit. The judge, who held a five-day hearing on the request last week, did not address the merits of the lawsuit itself in his ruling today. But he wrote, ``Given the evidence presently before the court, it appears to be a close question as to whether plaintiffs will ultimately prevail on the merits of their claims.'' Laughlin McDonald, an American Civil Liberties Union attorney who helped file the suit for the black plaintiffs, said the group was not likely to appeal Freeman's decision. But he did not rule out the possibility of a challenge to the results of the runoff when attorneys argue the merits of the case before the judge. Freeman has not set a trial date for the lawsuit. In his ruling, Freeman noted that the group filed the lawsuit only three months before the Aug. 7 runoff and at least five years after state Rep. Tyrone Brooks, the lead plaintiff, said he had viewed the majority vote requirement as racially discriminatory. Brooks testified during the hearing that he had considered the requirement discriminatory since 1984. Freeman said he was sympathetic to testimony that the group was unable to obtain representation earlier, but added, ``The court cannot ignore the timing of the filing of plaintiff's suit in assessing the equities of this case.'' He also said the group had failed to support its contention that the court would have to call a special election and unseat incumbents who were not plurality winners if it later found that the majority vote requirement caused irreparable injury to the plaintiffs. McDonald said he was not disappointed with today's ruling. ``We had two purposes,'' he said. ``One was to try to get an injunction to stop the runoff. The second was to make certain we raised a legally valid objection to the use of the runoff. We accomplished half of that.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Declares Tie in GOP Primary In Which Candidates Divided On Abortion
DOC.TEXT: The declaration of a tie in the Republican primary for in a suburban legislative district has forced a lottery to determine the winner _ and ensured an appeal from the loser. Cook County Circuit Judge Francis Barth declared the March 20 primary race, which pitted a strongly anti-abortion incumbent against a pro-choice challenger, a tie Monday after reviewing a recount. The original primary results showed Mary Mulligan, a paralegal from Des Plaines, had defeated incumbent Rep. Penny Pullen by 31 votes in the 55th District race. Pullen sued for a recount, which Barth ordered July 3. The recount was conducted last week. At Monday's hearing, Barth threw out 39 ballots that had not registered on the electronic computer system used in punch-card voting. Mat Delort, an attorney for Mulligan, said today that with the 39 ballots, Pullen probably would have been ahead. Under Illinois law, the State Board of Elections must hold a lottery to determine the winner of a tied election. The race could be decided by the flip of a coin or by pulling a name from a hat. The Board of Elections was expected to conduct the lottery this week. But the lottery is not likely to be the final step. ``Both sides agree there definitely will be an appeal,'' said Pullen's lawyer, Michael Lavelle. Mulligan's attorney said each candidate is proceeding with campaign plans on the assumption that she will be declared the winner. ``I'm very pleased,'' said Pullen, a seven-term representative. ``We live to fight another day.'' ``I think we have a lot of issues that are appealable in our favor if it (the lottery) shouldn't go the right way,'' Mulligan said in a telephone interview. Lavelle, former chairman of the Chicago Board of Election Commissioners, argued Monday that the three-day recount completed Wednesday at the Cook County warehouse showed Pullen winning by 17 votes. But lawyers for Mulligan contended the recount showed a tie. The victor in the heavily Republican district in Chicago's north suburbs will face Democrat Robert Mucci in the November election.

DOC.HEAD: Zambia Lifts Ban on Opposition Campaigning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd pvs, `Judge Mathew...' to CORRECT first name of magistrate. Pickup 3rd pvs, `Pro-democracy activists...'
DOC.TEXT: The government today lifted a ban on opposition campaigning for a national referendum on one-party rule. Judge Matthew Ngulube, head of the government-appointed referendum commission, said campaigning will be allowed beginning Monday as long as the language used is ``sober and temperate'' and does not defame individuals. Pro-democracy activists have so far been denied access to the media but Ngulube said today opposition groups would be allowed to buy campaign advertisements. The secret ballot scheduled Oct. 17 will ask voters ``if they support the reintroduction of a multiparty system,'' he said. Voters will use one of two symbols to cast their vote. The symbol for a ``yes'' vote will be a hand; the symbol for a ``no'' vote will be a foot. In April, the government announced plans for a referendum on one-party rule and immediately banned public debate on the issue. Opposition activists said, however, the state-controlled media continued to air arguments siding with President Kenneth Kaunda's ruling United National Independence Party, the only legal political organization in this southern African nation of 7.5 million people. Ngulube told Zambians their vote in the referendum will determine the nation's future. ``This is a critical moment in our history...the future of our country is in your hands,'' he said. Kaunda's party has held power unchallenged since 1973. In each district, referendum commission officers will monitor public meetings to ensure both sides of the issue are equally discussed, Ngulube said. He said police will attend meetings to maintain law and order. Last month, student-led protests against food price increases and one-party rule left at least 26 people dead. Voicing widespread political discontent, labor leaders, students, private businesses and churches have said they want to form a broad-based opposition group. Zambia, one of Africa's poorest and most indebted nations, last held a referendum in 1969 and that vote endorsed measures by Kaunda to establish a one-party system. Kaunda has said he will abide by the outcome of the referendum and is confident his party will retain its monopoly on power.

DOC.HEAD: Freed British Nurse Turned Over to High Commissioner
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 10 grafs after 10th pvs, `Iraq later...' to UPDATE with nurse's remarks. Pickup 11th pvs, `Kaunda said...'
DOC.TEXT: President Kenneth Kaunda today turned over to British officials a British nurse freed at his request from an Iraqi prison where she was jailed for helping a journalist who was hanged as a spy. Daphne Parish, 53, was driven to the home of British High Commissioner Peter Henchliffe after spending the night at State House, Kaunda's official residence in the capital, Lusaka. She was freed Monday after pleas from Kaunda. At a brief ceremony, Kaunda prevented Mrs. Parish from answering reporters' questions. But, looking tired and drawn, the soft-spoken nurse thanked Kaunda for his role in her release from Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq. The British nurse was sentenced to 15 years in prison as an accomplice to Farzad Bazoft, an Iranian-born British journalist who worked for The Observer newspaper. Mrs. Parish was arrested in September after driving Bazoft to the Al-Iskandaria military installation outside Baghdad. The Observer said Bazoft, who lived in Britain and traveled on British documents, was trying to check out reports of an explosion. But Iraq said he was a spy and hanged him on March 15. Iraq later confirmed 19 people died in an explosion at a military installation. When asked by reporters about her visit to the military installation with Bazoft, Mrs. Parish said: ``It didn't appear improper at the time. We didn't do anything I considered illegal.'' She said other British journalists had already visited the scene and had climbed over a perimeter fence. ``We didn't climb over any fences,'' she said. ``As we were driving around, we saw what appeared like coal dust on the side of the road.'' Bazoft wanted to collect some of the dust and she gave him a bottle to put it in. ``We did this in full view of cars going up and down. We did nothing secretly,'' she said. Iraq accused Bazoft of collecting soil samples to establish the nature of weapons used at the military installation. Parish said she was told by prison guards of her release midmorning Monday. ``I just laughed,'' she said. She said in the prison, where she shared a cell with four other inmates, prisoners played fortune-telling games by reading tea leaves in each others' cups. ``We said: Oh yes, you'll be released ... this afternoon. It was a joke so I thought this was just another joke.'' Kaunda said he sought Mrs. Parish's release on humanitarian grounds. He did not question the validity of the sentence passed by the Iraqi court. Kaunda said in a letter to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein dated March 11 he also asked for the death sentence passed on Bazoft to be commuted. In his letter, Kaunda said, he referred to `` the deep feelings of love and confidence'' he shared with Hussein and asked for the release of both Mrs. Parish and Bazoft. At his news conference Kaunda also lashed out at the British press for what he termed its ``outrageous coverage'' of Mrs. Parish's release. He claimed the British press reported that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``and myself are using Daphne Parish to cleanse ourselves. Zambia was never dirty. This was a genuine humanitarian appeal.'' Last month, the worst civil unrest since Zambia's independence in 1964 erupted over food prices and calls for a Western-style multiparty democracy. Rioting and a bungled coup attempt by mutinous soldiers June 30 left at least 26 people dead.

DOC.HEAD: White House Says Deficit Balloons, Wall Street Says `Ho Hum'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with morning prices, move up reference to 3,000 mark. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Jerry Jordan...'.
DOC.TEXT: News that the White House boosted its projection of next year's budget deficit caused barely a blip in the bond market, while the stock markets roared ahead to a record-high close a whisper away from the 3,000 mark. The reaction Monday _ or lack of one _ wasn't unusual, corporate economists say, considering the executive branch's horrendous track record on deficit figures. ``Private estimates both on Wall Street and elsewhere have been very large, and the market knew that,'' said James L. Kochan, chief bond market strategist at Merrill Lynch & Co. Kochan said White House budget reports ``have always been viewed with a high degree of skepticism as being somewhat tainted or being overly optimistic.'' The White House increased its forecast of the deficit for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1 to $168.8 billion _ $231.4 billion if savings and loan bailout costs are counted. The figure is $10 billion higher than the Bush administration's informal estimate of a month ago and up sharply from January's $100.5 billion estimate. News of a greater deficit often weakens bond prices because it implies the need for more government borrowing, which in turn can drive up interest rates.
