Higher rates tend to decrease the value of fixed-return investments such as bonds. But bond prices closed virtually unchanged Monday and remained flat this morning. The stock market, meanwhile, continued its rally. The Dow Jones industrial average closed Monday at 2,999.75, up 19.55, and gained an additional 7.43 points in early trading this morning, standing at 3,007.18 as of 11 a.m. Analysts said the stock market was driven by prospects of lower interest rates, as well as by a belief that corporate profits for the second quarter will be higher. Jerry Jordan, chief economist at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles, said Wall Street typically has two reactions to White House projections of budget shortfalls, ``both a yawn for the marke.'' ``If the White House is simply coming up with projections that are in line with what private forecasters have been saying, then it doesn't affect the market,'' he said. ``If it's different than what the consensus is, then we just disregard it because it's politics.'' Besides, ``Everyone knows the White House doesn't have any authority on budgetary matters,'' Jordan said, adding the real work takes place in Congress. Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist for Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co., said the Congressional Budget Office came out with figures in May that are similar to those released Monday by the administration. ``The markets have learned to believe the Congressional Budget Office. They tend to be more accurate,'' he said. The markets view the White House budget report as ``more of a political than economic document,'' Kellner said. For example, he said, the report contains what he called an optimistic rate of economic growth for next fiscal year, along with lower interest rates. ``White House documents always seem to be rosy scenarios,'' he said. Kochan of Merrill Lynch said the bond market in particular has more on its mind these days than the budget shortfall. Chiefly it is concerned with remarks last week by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, who indicated the central bank may ease interest rates to compensate for a perceived credit crunch in the banking system. ``The bond markets have known for some time about how large the budget deficit was going to be,'' Kochan said.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Miss Teen USA, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0502,0245
DOC.HEAD: Oregon Girl Wins `Miss Teen USA' Pageant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to restore dropped time element.
DOC.TEXT: Bridgette LeAnn Wilson of Oregon topped 50 other teen-agers to earn the Miss Teen USA crown in the eighth annual pageant. ``I went in and I was going to give it my best shot, and whatever my best was, I was going to hope for the best,'' said the blonde, brown-eyed teen after her win Monday. The 16-year-old from Gold Beach said she hopes for a career in entertainment. ``There are 51 beautiful girls here. I'm a sincere person, and I believe in myself, and having my family here was a help,'' said Wilson, who was crowned by 1989 Miss Teen USA Brandi Sherwood of Idaho Falls, Idaho. Miss Alaska, Mar La Johnson, 18, of Anchorage was first runner-up, and Miss Georgia, Holly Roehl, 17, of Griffin was second runner-up. Sandy Duncan and Former Miss Teen finalist Leeza Gibbons, of ``Entertainment This Week,'' were co-hosts of the two-hour pageant held at the Mississippi Coast Coliseum and televised nationwide. Wilson will receive more than $150,000 in cash and prizes, including a car. Contestants competed in interviews, evening gown and swimsuit events. Finalists also competed in an impromptu interview. Wilson said she was unsure of what her year would include. ``I don't know. This is pretty good so far. If it gets better, I can hardly wait.''

DOC.HEAD: Van Hits Group of Children, Injuring 8
DOC.TEXT: A van went out of control in the driveway of a day-care center and plowed into a group of young children, critically injuring a 2-year-old girl and injuring seven others, police said. The driver had been working on the van's brakes in the driveway of ABC-123 Day Care Center in west Philadelphia. He started the van, put it in gear, and drove through a gate and hit the children, said police Lt. John Rohrbach. The driver was not charged while police investigate Monday's accident. ``He lost control of the van, but we don't yet know the reason,'' said Rohrbach, adding that the van will be checked for mechanical failure. The injured girl, Tyree Davis, was in critical condition today at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia with a broken pelvis and internal injuries. Three other children were hospitalized, and the others were treated and released.

DOC.HEAD: New Baby Cushion Recall Announced
DOC.TEXT: Infant bean bag cushions called ``Baby Comfy Cushions'' sold by New Orleans-based Kalencom Corp. are being recalled voluntarily because of a risk babies could suffocate, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today. Kalencom had sold about 8,000 of its fabric-covered, polystyrene pellet-filled cushion since 1988. No reported deaths have been linked to the Baby Comfy Cushions, but the commission said it has received 29 reports that infants were found dead lying face-down on similar cushions made by other manufacturers. Kalencom is the 11th company to recall infant bean bag cushions, but the commission said it was concerned that only 11.5 percent of such cushions that were sold have been accounted for. Baby Comfy Cushions can be returned for refund to the stores where they were purchased, or buyers can return them directly to Kalencom for an exchange for another baby product. To return the Baby Comfy Cushion to Kalencom, cut a six-inch square from the product's cover and return it with the sewn-in labels, including the manufacturer's name, to: The Kalencom Corp. 740 Clouet Street New Orleans, La. 70117 Consumers with questions can call Kalencom at (504) 943-0123 or the CPSC's toll-free Hotline: 1-800-638-2772.

DOC.HEAD: Five Soldiers Killed, 10 Wounded In Training Accident
DOC.TEXT: A stray artillery shell accidentally exploded today near a group of soldiers on a training exercise, killing five and wounding 10, the army command said. Three of the wounded suffered serious injuries, the military said. The accident occurred this morning when a reserve unit was conducting an exercise involving the capture of a position at a training base in southern Israel, it said. The military command released no further details. Army officials who spoke on condition of anonymity said the accident was at a military base near Tzeelim in the southern Negev desert, 15 miles from the Egyptian border. Defense Minister Moshe Arens and Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron rushed to the scene to receive reports on the accident, the military said. The injured soldiers were evacuated by helicopter to Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem and Soroka Hospital in nearby Beersheba. Dr. Haim Granot, head of Hadassah's emergency ward, said there were six injured soldiers at the hospital, including one in serious condition, one moderately wounded and four with slight injuries. Soroka officials told Israel army radio that the hospital was treating two soldiers who suffered serious wounds and one trooper in moderate condition. One soldier was released after treatment. The army said that head of its ground forces, Maj. Gen. Uri Saguy, who was present at the exercise, appointed an investigation committee headed by senior officers. Army officials said all those injured in the accident were reserve soldiers. Israeli men under the age of 55 serve up to a month each year on reserve duty, in addition to a compulsory three years in the army starting at age 18. It was the most serious training accident in the Israeli army since April 23, when seven airmen were killed as their transport helicopters collided during a flight over the occupied West Bank.

DOC.HEAD: Hitting the Water, Think Ahead
DOC.TEXT: Olympic diving champion Greg Louganis sets a good athletic example for many youngsters. For starters, he cautions that they not just plunge in, but think ahead. ``Know the water depth before you dive,'' tops the list of Louganis' diving tips. That sounds simple, and in pools the water depth may be marked on the sid. But just looking into the water can be deceptive, and in lakes and ponds care is especially important. Rocks, partly sunken logs and other hidden obstructions can lurk beneath the surface. And the water may simply not be as deep as people think. Never dive where you don't know the depth or where there may be obstructions. Once a dive is started there is no time to change or think. Remember, when diving down into water, steer up with hands. Never dive into an above-ground pool or into the shallow end of any pool _ nine out of 10 diving injuries occur when people dive into water less than six feet deep, according to the National Swimming Pool Foundation. Often injuries follow when inexperienced people do back dives, dive through objects such as inner tubes or try fancy dives. One crucial warning: never dive or swim alone. Anyone can get into trouble in the water and the best insurance policy is a friend to pull you out if necessary. Children are particularly vulnerable, according to the National Spa and Pool Institute. But the safety measure that best protects them is simple, a watchful adult on hand at all times. Nothing can replace a watchful parent, grandparent, neighbor or baby-sitter when it comes to make sure a child is safe in the water. It's easy for horseplay to get out of hand, so the American Academy of Pediatrics urges setting rules around water. Running, pushing and similar roughhousing should be banned. Be sure everyone leaves the water and finds a safe shelter in the event of a thunderstorm also. Good fences make safe pools, ensuring that people can't get to the pool, fall in and drown when no one is available to save them. Many communities have laws setting minimum sizes for pool fences. At the least the Spa and Pool Institute recommends a barrier tall enough to prevent youngsters from climbing over. And don't place tables, chairs and other items nearby that could be used to climb over the fence. Doors, gates and other entry points need secure latches. Finally, post the number for emergency assistance near the telephone and learn to administer cardiopulmonary resuscitation just in case. In fact, make sure anyone who supervises the pool knows CPR.

DOC.HEAD: Evicted Protester Sets Up New Camp Near Lorraine Motel; May Be Moved Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with police saying summons issued. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `The motel...'.
DOC.TEXT: Evicted from her two-year campsite, protester Jacqueline Smith has set up a new sidewalk residence near the Memphis motel where Martin Luther King Jr. was murdered. But authorities said today that she may be evicted from there, too. Police Inspector David Dugger said police have issued a summons accusing Ms. Smith of blocking a city sidewalk. Ms. Smith will have a court hearing Sept. 5 and the city will seek an order for her removal if she is found guilty, he said. Before the summons was announced, Ms. Smith had said she was setting up a new camp because ``this protest must continue.'' On Monday, sheriff's deputies enforcing a court order evicted Ms. Smith from the construction site of a museum being built at the Lorraine Motel. The construction company obtained the order last week after convincing a judge that she was in the way. She had camped in front of the Lorraine since deputies evicted her from the motel itself on March 2, 1988. The motel was shut down in January 1988 to make way for the National Civil Rights Center, scheduled to open July 4, 1991. Ms. Smith, 39, contends that King's memory would be better served if the Lorraine were used as housing for the homeless or other social purpose, rather than as a museum. A half-dozen sheriff's deputies waded through about 50 gawkers, news reporters and supporters of Ms. Smith to pluck her from a lawn chair at her camp. Two female carried her across the street and deposited her at the curb there. She did not resist and no one was arrested. Tom Marshall, a deputy chief with the Shelby County Sheriff's Department, said the court order required only that she leave the construction site. Construction workers moved her tent and other belongings into the street and closed in a chain-link fence behind her. Shortly after the eviction, Ms. Smith re-established her camp but on the opposite side of the small side street which runs in front of the Lorraine. The Lorraine was crumbling in disrepair in 1982 when a group of citizens brought it at a foreclosure auction. They spent the next several years persuading the state, county and city governments to built the museum.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Express Support for Iran Opposition Movement
DOC.TEXT: More than 160 members of Congress expressed support Tuesday for Iran's opposition movement, criticizing what they called Tehran's ``medieval dictatorship.'' Rep. Mervyn M. Dymally, D-Calif., initiated the letter to Massoud Rajavi, leader of the Iraqi-based People's Mujahedeen of Iran. It was signed by 100 House Democrats and 62 Republicans. The lawmakers offered condolences to Rajavi over the April machine-gun killing of his brother Kazem Rajavi by an Iranian squad in Switzerland. Swiss police have said that one or more Iranian government services were involved in the assassination, but are continuing the investigation. Rajavi's widow, Michelle, met here last week with Dymally and other members of Congress to discuss allegations of the Iranian government's involvement in the killing. ``Dr. Rajavi's assassination is but more proof of Tehran's continuing insistence to use terrorism as the principal and indispensable pillar of its foreign policy,'' the letter said. ``Decisiveness is required to confront Tehran's medieval dictatorship.'' The lawmakers asked Rajavi ``to assure your countrymen that we support their peaceful and democratic aims'' of replacing the government. The U.S. administration has had occasional contacts with the Mujahedeen, partly in an effort to obtain information about events in Iran. But it has refused to officially endorse the organization or any other opposition group despite its acrimonious relationship with the government in Tehran. Diplomatic ties with Iran were severed after the U.S. Embassy staff was taken hostage in 1979 by the Islamic revolutionaries who overthrew the pro-Western government of the late Shah Reza Pahlavi. Since then, the relationship has been confined to U.S. efforts to obtain the release of American hostages held by Tehran-sponsored Moslem Shiite extremists in Lebanon. U.S. officials have been disappointed that the death of Iran's revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, has not seemed to moderate the enmity toward the United States. The United States joined other countries in providing supplies to help victims of the earthquake that killed an estimated 40,000 people last month. But Iranian officials said the U.S. help, while appreciated, would not improve overall ties. ``One year after the death of Khomeini, the Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani has proven that he is as immoderate as Khomeini, by continuing the repressive and terrorist policies of his mentor,'' the lawmakers wrote. They also denounced a report issued last year by a special U.N. envoy sent to investigate accusations of gross human rights violations by the Iranian government. The team's findings were described in the letter as ``a whitewash and a disgrace to the United Nations.'' Among those who signed the letter were Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia, and Reps. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., Edward Feighan, D-Ohio, and Jan Meyers, R-Kan.

DOC.HEAD: Ninety-One More Drug Addicts Found Infected With AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Ninety-one more Chinese drug addicts living near the drug-producing Golden Triangle have been diagnosed as infected with the AIDS virus, the China Daily newspaper said Tuesday. The report comes five months after shocked Chinese officials discovered 146 AIDS-infected drug addicts, the first in the nation, also living in southwest China's Yunnan province near the Burma border. China Daily quoted He Jiesheng, vice minister of public health, as saying the 91 were infected through ``communal use of contaminated syringes for intravenous injections.'' She spoke at a national telephone conference on epidemic control, held Monday, the newspaper said. The report gave no other details of the new AIDS cases, such as whether any of the infected persons had symptoms of the disease. None of the previously discovered 146 people had any symptoms, authorities have said. Before the first group of drug addicts were discovered, China said only seven of its nationals were known to have become infected with the virus. Of these, two died. In addition, China periodically reports the expulsion of foreigners found to be infected. So far, China has discovered 305 people infected with the virus, including foreigners and Chinese, the newspaper said. All foreigners studying or working in China must take AIDS tests, and any foreigner applying to marry a Chinese citizen also must be tested. Chinese students studying abroad also are tested when they return home.

DOC.HEAD: 111 People Die of Meningitis
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 people died of meningitis this year but the disease has not assumed epidemic proportions, a senior Health Ministry official said Tuesday. Dr. Sadek Mahjoub, director of the ministry's epidemics department, said his office registered 1,012 cases of meningitis since the beginning of the year. So far, 111 people have died. In 1988, about 32,000 people contracted meningitis and 2,000 of them died. This prompted the government to launch a nationwide vaccination drive. ``Most of the cases this year occurred in displaced persons camps and remote areas that were not covered by the vaccination program,'' Mahjoub told the state-owned newspaper Al-Inkaz Al-Watani. The refugee problem was created by a 7-year-old civil war in the south. Rebels have been fighting for greater autonomy and a larger share of the country's economic benefits. More than half the 6 million inhabitants of the southern regions of Bahr el-Ghazal, Equatoria and Upper Nile have been displaced by the fighting and famine.

DOC.HEAD: Forest Fire Rages Across Greek Tourist Island
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers and civilians battled a forest fire on this tourist island Tuesday but strong wind fanned the blaze for a second day, police said. No injuries were reported. Olympic Airways, the national carrier, ordered one of its planes to turn back from the eastern Aegean island after wind and smoke made landing impossible, an airport spokesman said. Flights continued after the wind changed direction, the spokesman said. The fire, which began Monday afternoon, had destroyed more than 750 acres of pine forest and scrub and two unoccupied cottages by noon Tuesday, a police official said. ``No places frequented by tourists are under threat and no evacuations have been ordered,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``But we have no chance of containing the fire unless the wind drops.'' Samos Prefect Thanasis Himaras told state television that a local farmworker had been arrested on suspicion of causing the fire by throwing a lighted cigarette into the brush.

DOC.HEAD: International Police Operation Nets Major Drug Bust
DOC.TEXT: A police operation involving French, Dutch and British officers has netted Britain's largest haul of amphetamine sulphate, the drug known as ``speed,'' police said Tuesday. Eleven men were arrested Monday when police and customs officers raided a boat at the mouth of the Thames River, 40 miles east of London, Kent police said. Police fired a stun grenade but no one was injured in the raid, which recovered 132 pounds of the drug worth up to $18 million, said Kent police Chief Inspector Alan Butterfield. Five of the men were arrested as they unloaded the motor cruiser, Merulius, which had sailed from Holland on Friday under surveillance by coast guard vessels, police said. Customs officers and police arrested six other people in London. The arrests capped a three-month investigation, code-named Operation Tributary. Butterfield called it the largest seizure ever in Great Britain.

DOC.HEAD: After 66 Years, Ex-Prisoner Reunited With Family
DOC.TEXT: An 86-year-old Tunisian was reunited with his family this week, 66 years after he was sent to a colonial prison in French Guiana, a newspaper reported Tuesday. Mekki Ben Brahim Touati was sentenced to an 18-year prison term by French authorities in 1924 and remained in French Guiana, on the northeast shoulder of South America, after his release, said Assabah, a Tunis daily. He was reunited with relatives in the northern region of Bizerte following the intercession of an Algerian businessman who met Touati in French Guiana and later took up the matter with Tunisian diplomats in Paris, the newspaper said. The account gave no details about Touati's criminal record or his family.

DOC.HEAD: Now on Sale: The Winnie Mandela Doll
LaserPhoto JOH1
DOC.TEXT: In the heart of the white suburbs, Winnie Mandela is a hit. Not as a fiery activist, but as a stuffed doll. Priced at $38, the two-foot high Winnie doll comes complete with headdress, gold-colored hoop earrings, an African print dress and lots of jewelry. Mrs. Mandela, wife of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, has been a controversial anti-apartheid activist known for her provocative statements and flashy outfits. Capitalizing on Mrs. Mandela's notoriety, two young white design students have been handmaking the Winnie dolls and selling them at an upscale shopping mall in the affluent white suburbs of Johannesburg. Mrs. Mandela, once called ``Mother of the Nation'' by her black supporters, was expelled from the anti-apartheid movement last year after her bodyguards were accused of waging a ``reign of terror'' in the Soweto township outside Johannesburg. She has been re-accepted by anti-apartheid groups since her husband was released from prison in February.

DOC.HEAD: Station Reinstates Show Host Who Banned Black Callers
DOC.TEXT: A radio talk show host who was suspended for banning black callers returned to the air Tuesday after his station manager said his action was not malicious. Tim Lennox, suspended Thursday, returned to the air on WERC-AM. But station manager Berkley Fraser said Lennox was removed from his job as news director and will be on probation for a year. Lennox also will be required to develop, produce and serve as host of a special series for the station on the topic ``Birmingham faces the future,'' focusing on race relations in the city. Lennox said early in his two-hour talk show on July 11 that he would take no calls from blacks that day. Lennox imposed the ban after three employees saw a black youth break into an fellow employee's car and take her purse. Lennox, 40, said later he made ``an emotional spur-of-the-moment decision.'' He and Fraser issued on-air apologies. On Thursday's pre-suspension show, Lennox fielded listener reactions without commenting on them. Fraser said Monday his investigation showed that Lennox's black ban was ``not based in malice and his 14-year career was without incidence of any racial prejudice.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises Gorbachev, Kohl on Reunified Germany
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with Bush comments; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today said that both Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl showed ``exceptional qualifies of leadership'' in agreeing that a reunified Germany can join NATO. Bush, who had lengthy telephone conversations with both leaders this morning, also took credit for spurring the process that led to Monday's announcement from the Soviet Union. ``The United States has been in the forefront in suggesting that the best way to achieve stabilization and peace would be a united Germany, a unified Germany as a full fledged member of NATO,'' Bush said a day after Kohl and Gorbachev took center stage for an announcement that many U.S. officials had not expected until months down the road. ``Both Kohl and Gorbachev have displayed, I think, exceptional qualities of leadership during this challenging period,'' Bush told a gathering of the Magazine Publishers of America who visited the White House. The president said he had telephoned both Kohl and Gorbachev this morning for ``fairly long conversations'' of 30 to 40 minutes each. ``I feel that the agreement that was announced yesterday between Gorbachev and Kohl was very, very significant and very important,'' he said of the announcement that Moscow would not oppose a unified Germany in NATO. Bush said also that he commended Gorbachev on the outcome of the recent stormy Communist Party congress in Moscow. ``You talk about a guy getting hit from all sides,'' Bush said in reference to attacks on the Soviet president from both left and right and the splintering of the party. Bush said it made him feel `totally relaxed about what's happening in this country.'' He recalled his meetings with Kohl, and with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, French President Francois Mitterrand as well as with Gorbachev as laying the groundwork and reaching consensus on the German reunification question. ``I take pride in the way Europe is moving into this new era of freedom,'' Bush said. ``We've still got some very important problems that lie out there ahead of us.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Satellite Woes
DOC.TEXT: Here is a quick glance at the major players in the commercial satellite industry:

Titan 3, Martin Marietta, can lift 31,000 pounds to low Earth orbit (LEO) or 11,000 pounds to 22,300 miles, the geosynchronous altitude (GTO) where communications satellites operate. Four built, two launched successfully, one failed, one set for 1992. Atlas 2, General Dynamics, 14,500 pounds to LEO, 8,000 to GTO. 23 on order commercially, eight under option, 10 sold to Air Force. Delta 2, McDonnell Douglas, 11,000 pounds to LEO, 4,000 to GTO. Has launched four of 11 rockets under contract.
Long March rocket, 19,000 pounds to LEO, 7,000 to GTO. China has launched one American-made satellite, has contracts for two others in 1991 and 1992.

Energia, heaviest-lift vehicle in the world, can lift 220,000 pounds to LEO, has flown only once. Soviets are anxious to market their launchers but have won no American contracts. The Bush administration has announced its intention to give them the right to some technical information that may eventually lead to launches of American satellites.

Arianespace, the most aggressive competitor to American launch companies, launched 24 satellites the last 24 months on 16 rockets. Arianespace's order book is bulging with 39 launch contracts, four of them this year and nine the next.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Gives NASA Administrator Vote of Confidence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs with editing. ^By HARRY F. ROSENTHAL
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today gave NASA Administrator Richard Truly a vote of confidence for running the troubled agency. Truly predicted space shuttle flights will resume within a month now that scientists have identified unrelated hydrogen leaks on two of the vehicles. ``I have great confidence in Dick Truly ... so lay that part of the question to rest,'' Bush said, explaining the administration's decision to have a panel of outside experts look at NASA's long-range plans. ``I have confidence in NASA,'' Bush added. ``It's a perilous business, I guess, anytime you put people up there into space, but the record has been very good.'' Bush spoke at a question-and-answer session with magazine publishers. Separately, Truly appeared on ABC's ``Good Morning America'' and discussed problems leading to the grounding of the space shuttles. The president said he ``went semi-ballistic'' when he read weekend news reports suggesting there would be an investigation of NASA. ``What we are doing is asking him (Truly) to form an outside committee of the best minds he can find to look at the future _ not go try to assign blame because a mission is delayed getting off the ground,'' Bush said. ``These shots are highly complex,'' the president added. ``We have been the leaders in space and I want to see us continue to be the leaders in space.'' Truly said recent problems with the space shuttle turned out to be less complicated than originally feared. ``As it turned out, it was just the terrible coincidence of two separate, specific leaks. We have found them both and now, since it did involve two orbiters and two payloads, we're now just looking at schedules to see what is the most effective way to get back to flight.'' He said a new flight schedule probably will be announced later today or tomorrow, and predicted that flights will resume by mid-August or the first of September. ``The system didn't go down for three years like it did after Challenger, it went down for three or four weeks,'' he said. NASA grounded the space shuttle fleet after a hydrogen leak was found in Columbia in May and another leak was found on Atlantis last month. Columbia, which had been poised for launch on an astronomy mission, was rolled back to the hanger and partially dismantled. The part that was leaking has now been replaced. Atlantis remains on the pad and NASA officials said its leak may be repaired without taking the shuttle back to the hangar. Truly acknowledged that problems with the shuttle and the Hubble telescope could prompt the public to question NASA's competence, but said a management review panel announced Monday is intended to look at long-range plans rather than second-guess recent problems. He said Vice President Dan Quayle ``fully understands that these recent events have been separate events that didn't have anything to do with each other.'' ``What we talked about most was the future, where we're going in future years and how a NASA of the future might be structured and how we could get advice on where it would move to,'' said Truly. ``We agreed to do something we both thought was the right thing to do and that is get in a few people that have some real top experience in both government and industry management and report to me and take a look at where we might go in the future.'' However, the Bush administration's decision to have an outside panel study the nation's long-term space goals is getting a cool reception from some lawmakers. ``After a weekend of rumors that the administration was going to ask some fundamental questions about NASA, we now find it will create yet another group,'' said Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., chairman of a subcommittee that oversees the space program. The panel, which is being appointed in response to a spate of recent embarrassments to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, will report to Quayle, head of the National Space Council. ``Is it too much to ask that in the wake of these multiple mistakes that President Bush should do what President Reagan did not do after the Challenger tragedy _ give personal attention to the problems at NASA,'' Gore sad. Rep. Michael Andrews, D-Texas, also said strong leadership, not another study, is needed to solve the problems in the space program. Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., chairwoman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee that has oversight responsibility for NASA, summoned Truly and former space agency Administrator James Beggs to a hearing Wednesday. NASA needs congressional support to continue the $32 billion space station scheduled for a critical design review this year, a planned Earth study called ``Mission to Planet Earth,'' and the president's announced goal of a permanent manned base on the moon and an expedition to Mars. The agency's setbacks in recent months included the finding that one or both of the mirrors on the Hubble Space Telescope were ground incorrectly, making a precise focus of the telescope impossible. In addition, the space shuttle fleet has been grounded while engineers pursue leaks that were discovered when two of the three orbiters were being fueled. There were reports last weekend that Bush planned to restructure the agency. But the decision announced by Quayle's office was far less sweeping: a study by experts who have not yet been named. ``Contrary to some published reports, there is no White House investigation of NASA,'' the statement said. It said the administration was calling for the outside study because ``we all want the best ideas on how we can move into the next century maintaining our leadership in space.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: FBI Claims New Evidence On Gotti
DOC.TEXT: The FBI has gathered tape-recorded evidence against John Gotti that could bring the reputed mob boss up against federal prosecutors in Brooklyn, according to a report published today. The FBI has amassed ``mountains of evidence'' against Gotti and the Gambino crime family hierarchy, including conversations that link Gotti to the 1985 slaying of former Gambino boss Paul Castellano, the Daily News reported. The new evidence includes taped conversations of Gotti and his associates made by a hidden microphone during an two-year long investigation, the News quoted unidentified sources as saying. The sources did not indicate where the bugs were placed or to give details of the conversations, the newspaper said. Gotti has been under investigation in the death of rival mob boss Castellano since the Dec. 16, 1985, killing outside of a Manhattan steakhouse. Gotti, known to tabloid readers as the ``Dapper Don'' because of his fondness for expensive suits, was found innocent in February of state charges related to the shooting of a union official. It was the third time in that he had been acquitted in recent years of major state or federal charges.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Voters Consider Young's Bid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close at 7 p.m. EDT; material below the dash will stand
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AX2; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Young, bidding to become Georgia's first black governor, competed Tuesday in a genteel five-way Democratic primary that seemed likely to send him into a runoff against Lt. Gov. Zell Miller. Young, a one-time aide to Martin Luther King Jr. who went on to be a congressman, ambassador to the United Nations and mayor of Atlanta, hoped to follow in the footseps of L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia. Wilder last year became the nation's first elected black governor. Early indications Tuesday pointed to a moderate turnout. Election officials had predicted about a third of the state's registered voters would take part in the primary. The campaign was notably short on mudslinging or negative advertising. Race was mentioned far less than such issues as abortion, legalized gambling and the economy. Recent polls showed Young running slightly behind Miller, a moderate who has enjoyed black support in his 16 years in the state's No. 2 job. Georgia law provides for an Aug. 7 runoff between the top two candidates, unless one wins a majority in the primary. Young predicted Monday he would run more strongly in predominantly white areas than pollsters and other observers expected. ``A lot of people who say I couldn't get votes in south Georgia have implied there's something backward about south Georgia, and I think they've underestimated south Georgia again,'' he said in Columbus. ``We're going to surprise people in where we get votes.'' About 25 percent of Georgia's voting age population is black. Miller, 58, made himself the principal advocate of an issue of growing popularity in the state _ legalization of a state lottery. Young, also 58, stressed his experience traveling the world to bring business to Atlanta and said economic development was a cause that could bring blacks and whites together. On Monday, Young suggested that Miller was too combative to get his lottery proposal through the Legislature. Young said he would persuade the Legislature to let voters decide the idea, although he personally opposes it. Young and Miller supported abortion rights. State Sen. Roy Barnes, 42, third in opinion polls, advocated restrictions on abortion and called Young and Miller ``tax and spend liberals.'' The Democratic field also included state Rep. Lauren ``Bubba'' McDonald, 51, and former Gov. Lester Maddox, the 74-year-old one-time arch segregationist. Black officials, supported by the American Civil Liberties Union but not by Young, had sued to block a runoff, complaining that it discriminated against blacks. But U.S. District Judge Richard Freeman on Tuesday rejected their request to halt runoffs until the lawsuit is decided. In the Republican primary, state Rep. Johnny Isakson, 45, a real estate executive from the north Atlanta suburbs, was a heavy favorite against three challengers. The well-financed Isakson is regarded as the most serious Republican threat in years to the Democratic lock on the governor's mansion. The only congressional incumbent with primary opposition was Rep. Doug Barnard, a Democrat from Augusta, who serves on the House Banking Committee and was accused by opponents of being too cozy with savings and loan officials. Barnard was opposed by journalism student Scott A. Starling of Athens. Two Republicans sought to oppose him in November. J.B. Stoner, a white supremacist who served time in prison for the bombing of a black church in Alabama, ran for the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor, but he was not regarded as a serious contender. Eight other Democrats were in the race.

Democratic Gov. Joe Frank Harris is completing the state limit of two four-year terms, and remained neutral in the primary. Young, borrowing from Wilder's strategy in Virginia, linked himself strongly to the pro-choice cause, using television ads late in the campaign to go after votes of abortion rights supporters. Miller, too, staked out a pro-choice position, as did McDonald. Only Maddox and Barnes positioned themselves against abortion rights. Barnes attacked Miller with a ``Willie Horton'' tactic. He accused the lieutenant governor of voting 16 years ago, as a member of the state clemency board, to free a prisoner who later committed murder. Miller said he acted on 4,000 cases and didn't remember that one. Horton, a convicted murderer in Massachusetts who fled while on a weekend furlough and later was accused of rape, was used by Republicans during the 1988 presidential campaign to depict Gov. Michael Dukakis as soft on crime.

DOC.HEAD: Six Indicted in Marijuana Distribution Ring
DOC.TEXT: A motel maid's discovery of $42,000 led to the investigation of a marijuana trafficking operation and the indictment of six men, authorities said. The Boulder-based organization allegedly imported nearly 100,000 pounds of marijuana into the United States between 1978 and 1988. ``It is an incredibly large, well-financed, terrorist-oriented organization,'' said U.S. Attorney Mike Norton in announcing the federal indictment Monday. ``This case rivals any marijuana case in the country'' in size and scope, said FBI agent Chuck Evans. About $10 million in cash, gold, art works, rare coins and other valuables have been impounded from the group, authorities said. The assets were seized from storage lockers in Colorado and Arizona. The indictment under the Racketeer Influenced Corrupt Organizations statute accuses Robert A. Mackesy, 40, and five others of operating a continuing criminal enterprise. They also are charged with possession with intent to distribute marijuana. According to the indictment, Mackesy headed an organization that bought marijuana from Miguel Angel Caro-Quintero, younger brother of Mexican drug lord Rafael Caro-Quintero. The elder Caro-Quintero is charged in the 1985 torture and slaying of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena. The man alleged to be a distributor of the marijuana, Douglas McPheron, left $42,000 in a Boulder motel room while he ran errands, Norton said. A maid came across the money and turned it over to police in July 1988. Four of the six men indicted are in custody. Perry said he has been in touch with U.S. Drug Enforcement Agency agents in Mexico who will work with the Mexican government to apprehend Miguel Caro-Quintero, who was named in the indictment.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Says She Gave Barry Cocaine Week Or Two Before The Vista Sting
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; edits throughout to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A woman testified today at Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial that she started giving cocaine to the mayor in 1983 and last provided it to him a week or two before his Jan. 18 arrest in an FBI sting operation. The reluctant prosecution witness, Bettye Smith, flew to Washington earlier in the day by order of a U.S. magistrate in Chattanooga, Tenn., where she had been undergoing treatment for stress at a psychiatric hospital. Testifying under a court order, Smith told the jury at Barry's trial that she and the mayor snorted cocaine powder at her residence on Capitol Hill ``maybe five times'' in 1983 and up to half a dozen times in each succeeding year. But she said ``we skipped'' the latter part of 1987 and all of 1988 after press coverage surrounding a Thanksgiving 1987 trip Barry made to the Bahamas. Smith was in the Bahamas with Barry and other friends. ``I didn't see him for a while after that trip,'' she said. In the earlier years, she said, Barry used cocaine in front of her in her home. Starting in 1986, she said, the mayor took it into the bathroom alone. Early this January was the last time she offered cocaine to him, she said. The mayor took a package of cocaine into the bathroom and after a short time came out again and handed the package back to her, she said. On Jan. 18, former model Rasheeda Moore persuaded Barry to come to her room at the Vista Hotel, where the mayor was arrested after being videotaped smoking crack cocaine. Moore was a former girlfriend of Barry's. Smith said that she and Barry were close friends, but that their relationship was ``not a sexual friendship.'' On cross-examination by Barry's lawyers, sh said she never saw Barry use or have possession of cocaine in the Bahamas. And she said she never provided the mayor with crack, a particular form of cocaine. Smith's attorney had asked that the magistrate delay her transfer to Washington. He presented a letter from her doctor stating that travel might be dangerous because of her mental and emotional state. In Washington, U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson on Monday ordered the execution of a bench warrant for Smith, who had been scheduled to testify last week until she was hospitalized in Chattanooga. Testimony by the woman, a friend of Barry, would relate to one of the 14 criminal charges against Barry, that he possessed cocaine between Jan. 1 and Jan. 18 of this year. Barry is accused of 10 cocaine possession counts, one count of conspiracy and three counts of lying to a grand jury. The first 11 are misdemeanors, the last three felonies. Prosecutors say they will end their case with the testimony of Smith and Doris Crenshaw, another friend of the mayor. The defense is preparing to open its case Wednesday and plans testimony from 10 to 15 witnesses, said Mundy. Attorneys outside the case said the only effective way to defend the mayor is to focus on the aggressive tactics the government used to prosecute him. Several said emphatically that Barry himself should not take the stand. The defense should emphasize the contention that ``if he weren't the mayor they wouldn't have come after him,'' said G. Allen Dale, a private attorney who handles drug cases. Former U.S. Attorney Joseph diGenova, who pursued several criminal investigations of Barry, said the mayor ``would be destroyed'' on cross-examination if put on the witness stand in his own defense. DiGenova now is a lawyer in private practice. Barry's attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, said no decision has been made on whether Barry will testify.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Pledges Aid to Fight Deadly Fly in Libya
DOC.TEXT: The United States on Tuesday pledged $3 million to help Libya fight a deadly fly infestation that is a potential threat to wildlife and livestock in much of Africa. The United States led other nations in committing funds, but the fund-raising effort fell far short of the money needed to carry out the eradication, U.N. officials said. So far, the screw-worm fly has not spread beyond northern Libya, where it was first spotted in July 1988. But experts say it could spread quickly. A conference had aimed at raising $91.7 million, according to its organizers, the U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization and the International Fund for Agricultural Development. But only $31 million was pledged at the conference, which was attended by representatives from 26 nations, a statement by the two Rome-based agencies said. In addition to the money sought by the conference, Libya will provide $25 million, organizers said. The eradication plan calls for unleashing tens of millions of sterilized screw-worm flies in Libya. Matings then will yield no offspring and the insect, which eats away at the flesh of its victims, will die out. Despite the failure to raise all the funds, the sterile fly release is expected to get under way in September, a FAO official said. U.S. sanctions against Libya, including a ban on American travel there, complicated planning to wipe out the fly. U.S. technology is needed to carry out the program, and supervision by American experts was considered essential to its success. After delicate discussions, Washington agreed to allow both the technology and personnel to go to Libya. U.S. officials said they agreed to help for humanitarian reasons and because an international organization will carry it out. West Germany pledged the equivalent of $2.7 million, followed by Britain, with a $1.8-million pledge.

DOC.HEAD: Jogger Testifies at Trial of Youths Charged with Attacking Her
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with morning testimony. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `Assistant District...'.
DOC.TEXT: A woman who was nearly killed in an attack in Central Park climbed unsteadily onto the witness stand to describe the lasting effects of an assault she does not remember. The 30-year-old investment banker testified Monday that her battered body gives her constant reminders of the attack 15 months ago. As the trial continued today, a detective testified that one of the defendants admitted participating but said he did not rape the woman. The woman, whose identify is not being disclosed by the media because of the nature of the assault, was making her first public appearance at the trial of three teen-agers accused of taking part in the so-called ``wilding'' attack. On the witness stand, she listed lingering physical problems, including impaired balance, loss of her sense of smell and vision troubles. Despite plastic surgery, she has long, jagged scar on the side of her face where she was beaten into submission. Antron McCray, Raymond Santana and Yusef Salaam, all 16, are charged with attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, assault, robbery and riot in separate attacks on the woman and two men who were jogging through the park on the night of April 19, 1989. Today, Police Detective Humberto Arroyo testified that he took a statement from Santana in the presence of his grandmother the day after the attack. Santana said that Kevin Richardson threw the jogger to the ground and had sex with her, and that Steven Lopez beat her with a brick. Richardson and Lopez are among three youths who are to be tried later. ``When she was on the floor, I grabbed her (breasts),'' Santana said in the statement. ``I did not have sex with her,'' In the statement as recounted by Arroyo, Santana told how he and other youths convened northeast of Central Park the evening of the attack, with the plan of robbing joggers and cyclists. In cross-examination, the defense said the boy should not have been questioned only in the presence of his grandmother because she does not speak English well. But Arroyo said he read Santana his rights in Spanish as well as English. As the woman testified Monday, the defendants looked at their hands, fiddled with pens or stared into space. She was on the stand about 10 minutes. Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer showed the woman the T-shirt she was wearing when she was attacked. It is now almost completely brown with dried blood. ``That's the shirt that I used to wear,'' the woman said. Police have testified that the T-shirt was used to bind and gag the woman while she was raped and bludgeoned. The woman has recovered enough to return to work at Salomon Brothers Inc. State Judge Thomas B. Galligan told the sketch artists in court not to portray the woman clearly. He said her worries about being identified from sketches were justified. She said she did not remember entering the park to run the night she was assaulted and her first memory afterward was waking up in the hospital on Memorial Day weekend. Defense attorneys did not cross-examine the woman. ``In the long run, I think her testimony helps us, the fact that she came in and couldn't identify any of the defendants, and could not even (remember) going to the park,'' Santana's lawyer, Peter Rivera, said outside court. The three youths are being tried in an adult court, but if convicted they will be sentenced as juvenile offenders to up to 10 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Forests Burning Across Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of reinforcements poured into the rugged backcountry of the Boise National Forest in Idaho today as stiff wind and low humidity fanned forest fires across the Northwest. Forests also burned in Oregon, Washington, Montana and Wyoming. In west-central Idaho, the Mormon Creek Fire had leaped fire lines in steep terrain and quadrupled in size since Monday to 450 acres. It flared up Sunday from embers left from a lightning strike last week. ``Everything we had built yesterday we lost,'' Boise forest spokeswoman Jennifer Callan said. ``It was pretty gusty up there today.'' An additional 200 firefighters were sent to join the more than 100 already at work on the blaze. Two air tankers bombarded the blaze with flame retardant and helicopters dumped water. Wind blowing at 20 mph was blamed for swelling the Gird Point fire in the Bitterroot National Forest in southwestern Montana to 2,500 acres this morning, five times its size Monday night. Because of the fire near Hamilton, officials closed a highway and evacuated twqo campgrounds. Some 450 firefighters were on the lines today in rugged terrain. The fire was started Friday by a lightning strike. Smaller fires were reported northeast of Missoula and in the Kootenai National Forest of northwestern Montana. Stiff wind and low humidity also were reported in Oregon, where fires triggered by lightning last week had charred more than 4,000 acres and some were still spreading, authorities said. The Spring Butte fire near La Pine, Ore., grew to 935 acres Monday while smoldering brush on the Warm Springs Indian Reservation re-ignited and burned about 145 acres. The Corral Basin blaze near John Day, Ore., had destroyed 900 acres, according to state and federal fire managers. About 430 firefighters battled the Spring Butte blaze and 780 were at work on the Corral Basin fire, with an additional 240 called in, officials said. ``Weather forecasts indicate a shift to southwest wind with increasing velocity. This will cause major problems for firefighters,'' said Jennifer Harris of the Malheur National Forest. About 65 fires, most small and set by lightning, were burning across Washington state in the Wenatchee and Okanogan national forests. The largest had covered about 300 acres in a wilderness area of the Wenatchee forest. Firefighters in Yellowstone National Park in Wyoming were still trying today to contain a 15-acre fire north of Yellowstone Lake. And two firefighters were sent to battle the park's 14th fire of the season, a 40-foot-diameter blaze started by lightning Monday night. Elsewhere, while nearly a week of rain in Alaska's interior gave firefighters a needed break, the return of warm and dry conditions has state and federal lands officials warily watching the weather. Despite the rain, 115 fires continue to burn in Alaska, down from a high of more than 200 last week, said Sue Mitchell, a spokeswoman for the federal Bureau of Land Management. On Sunday, more than 670,000 acres of Alaska were burning, she said. Near San Jose, Calif., fire officials declared a 2,140-acre brush and grass fire 100 percent contained today and estimated that it would be completely out by the end of the day.

DOC.HEAD: Court Widens Jurisdiction of Prosecutor in HUD Probe
DOC.TEXT: The court that oversees independent counsels today widened the jurisdiction of the special prosecutor investigating allegations of political favoritism by former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. The jurisdiction of independent counsel Arlin M. Adams was widened to include Pierce's administration of the Urban Development Action Grant Program and the Secretary's Discretionary Fund for technical assistance and special projects. Adams was appointed March 1 to investigate allegations that Pierce and top aides conspired to defraud the government by showing political favoritism in the operation of the Moderate Rehabilitation Program. The court's order made public today expanded Adams' jurisdiction along the lines requested by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to include the operation of the two other programs. Thornburgh sought the expanded jurisdiction after the Justice Department reviewed the congressional testimony of DuBois L. Gilliam, a former assistant HUD secretary who told lawmakers that politics was an important criteria for awarding grants through UDAG and the discretionary fund. The court said in a statement that it had also ``moderately expanded'' Adams' jurisdiction to investigate the Moderate Rehabilitation Program. The statement did not specify how that jurisdiction was changed. Pierce, who headed the Department of Housing and Urban Development under President Reagan, has denied any wrongdoing in the award of grants or rent subsidies. But Gilliam and other witnesses told a House Government Operations subcommittee that grants went to politically connected developers.

DOC.HEAD: Calculator-Equipped Grocery Carts Cruising the Aisles in Florida
DOC.TEXT: No more adding in your head, trying to figure whether that last $10 bill will cover five frozen dinners and a bag of dog food. Supermarkets in three states have been testing grocery carts equipped with calculators to help coupon-clipping consumers keep within their budgets. That is, if they can get the gadgets to work. Publix, which owns 370 Florida supermarkets, bolted 200 calculators to cart handles at a new store in Lakeland and 156 others to baskets at an established Clearwater store near a sprawling retirement complex. The sites were picked for their diverse customers, said Bob McDermott, spokesman for Publix, the nation's eighth-largest supermarket chain. In a random sampling of some 30 shoppers at the Clearwater store, people said they liked the idea, but often found the gadget a hassle. Some shoppers didn't know how to use the checkbook-size device, which has a keypad and display window on one side and advertising space on the other. Others got it to work, but with mixed results. ``I tried using it,'' said Vicki Bartholomew, an insurance worker with six items in her basket: a melon, cat food, potatoes, grapes, coffee and cottage cheese. ``My total came up to $109.30, and I run a computer at work,'' she said. Julie Snider, a retiree who moved to Florida from Denver 10 years ago, said ``they'd be great if they worked properly.'' ``Three times I started the darn thing and something screws up and it's back to zero,'' she said. ``They shouldn't do that to aggravate the old people.'' But coupon shopper Gail Schueren is a believer. ``I love them,'' she said. ``I don't have to worry about whether I have a scrap of paper and a pencil to keep track of the discounts. And so far in a couple of weeks I've only run into one that didn't work right.'' The shopper calculator is marketed by ADDvantage Media Group of Tulsa, Okla., which during the past two years has tested the device in Oklahoma and Alaska. The Florida tests began about two months ago. The retailer pays from $13 to $25 for each calculator, depending on how many it buys. The advertising space is meant to make up for the cost. The calculators being tested in Florida are already obsolete and upgraded ones should arrive in August or September, said Mike Brennan, vice president of ADDvantage. ``We've researched it and we also have to have instructional posters to help people understand what to do,'' he said. ``We've made significant changes. The new ones have a new keypad, new chip and new design.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Captain Assassinated; Military Blames Leftists
DOC.TEXT: An army captain was shot to death and his wife was wounded Tuesday in an ambush that the military blamed on leftist guerrillas. Capt. Ramon Aristides Reyes Hernandez was gunned down in the town of Santa Tecla, seven miles from the capital, as he was getting into a car, the armed forces press office said. His wife, Cecilia Sandoval de Reyes, was treated at a San Salvador hospital for gunshot wounds to the left leg and right arm, the armed forces said. Witnesses told The Associated Press that two men on a motorcycle fired on the couple and fled. The armed forces press office blamed the attack on guerrillas from the leftist Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, which has been at war with a series of U.S.-backed governments for the past decade. More than 70,000 people have died in the conflict. Reyes Hernandez, an instructor at the national military school, was the second army officer to be assassinated this month. On July 9, Mayor Carlos Figueroa Morales, the head of the high command's legal staff, was slain in an attack also blamed on the leftist guerrillas. The armed forces said in a statement that the attacks will not contribute to the search for peace. The government and the guerrillas have scheduled another round of peace talks later this week in San Jose, Costa Rica.

DOC.HEAD: Army Conducting Espionage Investigation of 6 AWOL Soldiers; No Charges Filed
DOC.TEXT: Six Army soldiers missing from their posts with an intelligence unit in West Germany have been apprehended in Florida as a result of a traffic violation and are under investigation, authorities said. ``Due to the fact they had access to classified materials within the last six months a counter-intelligence investigation has been initiated,'' Maj. Joe Padilla, an Army spokesman at the Pentagon, said Monday. Bob Hall, a spokesman for Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, said the counterintelligence investigation was routine, in the sense that it is required in cases involving people with access to classified information. He said he could not comment beyond saying: ``The Army says this does not appear to be an espionage case.'' No charges had yet been filed against the six soldiers, Padilla said. He said no decision had been made on whether the absent-without-authorization allegation would encompass absent without leave or the more serious charge of desertion. All six were from the 701st Military Intelligence Brigade at Augsburg, West Germany. Padilla said he could not say exactly what jobs they performed at the 701st, but said their training was in analyzing foreign communications. Hall said the disappearance of the six ``came to our attention'' on July 9. He would not say whether that was when they left West Germany. He and Padilla both said they did not know how the six got to Florida from West Germany or what they were doing in Gulf Breeze. Padilla said the six are believed to belong to an organization called ``The End of the World,'' but he said he had no information about the group and could not say if it had any significance in the investigation. The soldiers were taken to the stockade at Fort Benning, Ga., said Padilla. A police officer in this Florida Panhandle city stopped a van late Friday because its tail lights were not working, said police Chief Jerry Brown. The driver of the van had no driver's license, and warrants showed he was listed Thursday as wanted for desertion from the Army, Brown said. After officers called the Pensacola Naval Air Station police to have the man picked up, the Navy called back to say he was traveling with five other Army soldiers _ four men and a woman _ who also were wanted, Brown said. Soon after, representatives of the FBI, the CIA and the National Security Agency also called, Brown said. Police learned that the five might be at a Gulf Breeze couple's home, where the four men were arrested Saturday. Police then learned that the woman was staying at a campground on the Gulf Island National Seashore near Fort Pickens, where she was arrested, Brown said.

DOC.HEAD: L.A. School Board Appoints New Superintendent
DOC.TEXT: The school board has appointed William Anton, a longtime administrator, as superintendent. He is the first Latino to head the nation's second-largest school district. At a closed meeting Monday, the board also approved spending an estimated $225,000 to buy out the remaining 11 months of Superintendent Leonard Britton's contract. Britton, 59, announced last week he was quitting the $164,555-a-year job. He said he would leave as of June 30, 1991. The buyout would include salary and unused vacation time. Anton, a 65-year-old deputy superintendent, accepted a three-year contract, and will take over Friday. ``I believe he has good leadership skills, and that is important,'' said Mark Slavkin, one of six board members who voted for Anton. ``If anyone can bring this district together at this critical time, Bill is the one to do that.'' Julie Korenstein was the lone board member to vote against the appointment. ``It was simply railroaded through,'' she said. ``The board did not do any interviewing, except for one person. I think the process stunk.'' The district also should not have bought out Britton's contract during the current budget crisis, she said. The board recently cut $220 million from its 1990-91 budget. Britton, who previously was superintendent of the Dade County, Fla. school system, was the first superintendent to be hired from outside the Los Angeles district in 40 years. Anton, who began his career in the district as a teacher in 1952, was passed up as superintendent in favor of Britton three years ago. In November, Anton announced he was retiring, but withdrew the letter at the urging of many district workers, teachers, parents and community members. As superintendent, he will have to contend with the budget, an ethnically diverse student population, overcrowded schools, and calls to break up the 610,000-student district into smaller units. ``One of my big challenges is to be sure it doesn't happen,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Subliminal Messages Blamed in Lawsuit Against Heavy Metal Group
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 7th graf pvs, `The non-jury...'., to UDPATE with quotes from mother testifying today. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `Previously, in...'.
DOC.TEXT: Subliminal messages such as ``try suicide,'' ``let's be dead'' and ``do it'' in a song by the heavy metal band Judas Priest led two young men to shoot themselves in a suicide pact, their parents' lawyers say. Members of the British rock group deny any such messages were hidden in their music. They and CBS Records are being sued by parents of the men, Raymond Belknap and James Vance. The parents contend the young men hatched the suicide plot as they drank, smoked marijuana and listened to the album ``Stained Class'' _ and particularly the song ``Better By You, Better Than Me'' _ in 1985. ``What pushed the boys over the edge to eternity was the subliminal push,'' Vivian Lynch, the Vance family's attorney, said during opening arguments Monday. ``This was not a suicide. This was an adventure _ a journey to a better place. What they planned was good, because Judas Priest said it was good.'' ``There is no subliminal content on the `Stained Class' album,'' countered defense attorney Suellen Fulstone. ``I say that unequivocally and we will prove that unequivocally.'' The non-jury trial is being heard by state District Judge Jerry Carr Whitehead. Vance's mother, Phyllis, testified today that her son found religion in 1983 at a Christian camp and threw away his collection of rock albums. But she said he turned belligerent when he again began listening to Judas Priest's music. ``He'd attack me like a dog'' when she tried to turn off the music, which he played so loud it could be heard down the street, she said. ``I was embarrassed,'' she said. ``I told him I thought it was garbage.'' Previously, in similar lawsuits across the country, judges have dismissed cases after ruling that artistic messages are protected by the First Amendment. But those cases did not involve alleged subliminal messages, which are said to influence people not even aware they heard them. Whitehead has ruled that freedom of speech protections would not apply to subliminal messages. He said he was not convinced the hidden messages actually exist on the album but left the argument to attorneys. The lawsuit is proceeding as a products liability case, with the band and record company accused of negligence and reckless conduct. The plaintiffs are seeking unspecified damages. Two days before Christmas 1985, Belknap, 18, held a sawed-off shotgun to his chin and died instantly from a single blast. Vance, 20, blew away the lower portion of his face. He died three years later of complications from his injuries and a reaction to medication. Ken McKenna, the Belknaps' attorney, said Vance and Belknap were chanting ``do it, do it'' before heading for the church playground where the shooting took place and that Vance again chanted it moments before he pulled the trigger. The defense contends the young men shot themselves because they were deeply troubled and that alcohol and drug abuse contributed to their suicide pact. ```Do it' is not a suicide message,'' Ms. Fulstone said. `` `Better By You, Better Than Me' is not a suicide song. There are no suicide songs on this album.'' She said that the two young men did not have time to listen to the album repeatedly as claimed and that Belknap initiated the shooting because he was depressed over losing his job. Judas Priest lead singer Rob Halford was in court and later told reporters the allegations were ``completely false and untrue.'' He said he and other band members were disturbed by the deaths but could not be held responsible.

DOC.HEAD: No Charges To Be Filed Against Earth First! Activists, Lawyer Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Earth First! is cq per group's preference.
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors will not file charges against two Earth First! activists arrested in connection with a pipe bomb explosion that injured them two months ago, a defense lawyer said today. Douglas Horngrad, a lawyer for Darryl Cherney, said Alameda County Deputy District Attorney Chris Carpenter told him in a telephone conversation that no charges would be filed against either Cherney or Judi Bari. ``I can't speak for the prosecutors, but we view their action as confirmation of Judi and Darryl's innocence,'' Horngrad said. ``We believe the Oakland Police Department never had the evidence against them.'' A spokeswoman for Carpenter said the prosecutor would not comment until later today. Bari and Cherney have contended that the car bomb explosion May 24 in Oakland was in retaliation for their work in organizing ``Redwood Summer'' protests against the lumber industry. Authorities had suggested that, to the contrary, it had been their own bomb that accidentally went off while they were driving, and Cherney and Bari were initially arrested for investigation of explosives possession. ``From the moment the bomb went off under Judi's seat, the Oakland Police Department launched an investigation directed at them solely because they are political activists,'' according to a joint statement issued by Horngrad and Susan Jordan, a lawyer representing Bari. ``The Oakland Police Department has conducted an unprecedented and outrageous smear campaign in an attempt to discredit Earth First! and Redwood Summer,'' the statement said. Bari, who suffered a broken pelvis in the explosion, was released from Oakland's Highland hospital last week but is receiving medical treatment at an undisclosed ``medical facility,'' a hospital spokeswoman said Tuesday. Horngrad said he has not been able to reach Cherney with the news. ``I hope he's heard the news. He should be gratified but not relieved because the person who put the bomb in the car is still at large,'' Horngrad said. Authorities have not publicly identified any other suspects. Mike Roselle, a founder of the environmental group, said he understood the prosecution decided against filing charges because nails used to construct the homemade bomb did not match those found in Bari's house. ``He did not say that was the only reason,'' Roselle said.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Panel Counsel Emphasizes Statements of Durenberger Associates
DOC.TEXT: A confidential report on Sen. Dave Durenberger, submitted to the Ethics Committee by its special counsel, gives substantial weight to statements by his close associates in concluding he should be denounced for financial misconduct. Key documents highlighted in the report by Robert S. Bennett were described to The Associated Press by sources who had read it. The sources commented only on condition of anonymity. The report is expected to figure prominently in the six-member committee's deliberations on Durenberger, R-Minn. ``We're meeting Wednesday _ stay tuned,'' committee Vice Chairman Warren B. Rudman, R-N.H., said Tuesday. Durenberger, commenting meanwhile on WCCO radio in Minneapolis, said the committee ``ought to do what I've done ... acknowledge that I've done wrong and they ought to characterize it for people so that it can guide others' conduct in the future.'' Bennett's report supports an oral presentation he gave the committee last month, when he said Durenberger had broken Senate rules and should be denounced. If the committee finds that Durenberger broke Senate rules or federal law, it could rebuke him in a letter or recommend that the full Senate do so in a formal vote. Such a move by the Senate would have no surface effect on his duties, but could generate severe political damage back home. The Ethics Committee also could recommend to Durenberger's Republican colleagues in the Senate that they strip him of ``seniority or positions of responsibility'' such as key committee assignments. According to those who have seen the lengthy report, key statements cited by Bennett include those of: Charles Kahn III, Durenberger's legislative assistant for health policy; Anne Kelly Planning, the former personal secretary and scheduler; Michael C. Mahoney, his personal attorney, and Paul Overgaard, his onetime campaign manager. Bennett also focused on statements from a Tobacco Institute representative _ former Republican Sen. Marlow Cook of Kentucky _ and other trade association representatives who invited Durenberger to speak for a fee, according to the sources. The investigation centers on allegations that Durenberger violated Senate rules and federal law by disguising regular fee speeches as promotions for his two books, accepting free limousine rides in excess of gift limits, accepting reimbursements for staying in a Minneapolis condominium that he partly owned and later arranging a bogus sale of the condo unit. Durenberger has acknowledged breaking some rules but said he never intended to do so and asked that any punishment be light. Ms. Planning, the former secretary and scheduler, said she did not recall any group inviting the senator to give a book promotion speech. She said she placed all speaking invitations into the same folder and the senator would ``indicate whether the speech was to be treated as an honorarium speech or a Piranha Press speech.'' Piranha Press published Durenberger's books. Bennett also cited an affidavit from Cook, who as a Tobacco Institute representative invited Durenberger to one of the first appearances after the book promotion deal became operational. ``There was no discussion of the senator's books or publisher during the conversation,'' Cook said, adding that Durenberger never mentioned or displayed the books during the address. Bennett mentioned Kahn, the former health policy aide, for saying he didn't ``recall any group inviting the senator to promote his books'' and was ``not aware of the criteria used to differentiate'' between a book promotion and a speech for honoraria. Honoraria speeches are subject to the limits that Durenberger is accused of exceeding. Legitimate book-promotion appearances would be exempt. In several appearances before health care groups, Kahn told the committee, Durenberger had to acknowledge he hadn't even completed the health care book he was supposed to be promoting. He told the organizations that his earlier book on defense policy was for sale. In concluding that Durenberger deceived the Senate to protect his condominium reimbursements, Bennett cited statements by Mahoney, acting as the senator's attorney; by Overgaard, whose company bought the condominium; and Durenberger's own writings. Bennett noted that Mahoney told the committee he cautioned Durenberger in 1986 that he ``couldn't find any support'' for reimbursements the lawmaker had been receiving from the Senate since 1983. Durenberger at the time owned the condominium with a friend. Bennett also noted that in July 1987, Durenberger himself confided to two friends in a letter than he believed he had relied on ``shaky or misleading'' legal advice in establishing the condominium arrangement. Bennett cited statements by Overgaard to conclude that the 1987 sale of the condominium was a sham concocted to let the payments continue. Overgaard said the sale became effective in April 1987 through an oral agreement between himself and the senator. But Bennett included documents showing the legal papers completing the deal weren't signed for another 2{ years. One document showed that Overgaard was so frustrated with Durenberger's delays in sending him the papers to finalize the deal that he threatened to pull out of the sale. In a September 1989 letter to the senator, Overgaard wrote, ``The last thing I need is to get involved in your ethics investigation and be accused of participating in a sham transaction by which you collect per diem ... on a residence you actually own.''

DOC.HEAD: Many Soviets Unaware Gorbachev Agreed to Germany in NATO
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet media left many citizens in the dark Tuesday about President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's agreement to allow a united Germany to join NATO. Muscovites interviewed in a city park who were aware of the development said they approved, but admitted to doubts about the nation they fought during World War II. ``It's good for stabilizing the situation in Europe,'' said a 72-year-old retired engineer. ``But on the other hand, if I am to speak openly, I fought for five years, and I fear the Germans.'' Despite a recent press law banning censorship, most newspapers limited their coverage to a sketchy report by the official Tass news agency. Tass reported that West Germany had agreed that troops would be cut following the reunification of East Germany and West Germany, but did not mention Gorbachev's reversal on the thorny issue of a unified Germany's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The government newspaper Izvestia published the bare-bones Tass report. But it also printed an article by its own Berlin correspondent titled: ``The route to unification is open.'' The dispatch quoted West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl as saying the Soviet Union had given the long-awaited green light for a united Germany's membership in NATO. The joint news conference at which Kohl announced the breakthrough was televised live. But subsequent television reports about the Monday meeting between Gorbachev and Kohl were no more informative than most of Tuesday's newspapers. State television broadcast an interview with Kohl and Gorbachev offering optimistic comments just before their final session. Both were comfortably clad in sweaters _ unusual informality for Gorbachev. The lengthy report then showed the two leaders walking in a mountain meadow, driving to a news conference, and saying goodbye at the airport. The announcer said results of their negotiations were revealed at the news conference, which had been broadcast live earlier. But the announcer left those who had not seen the conference guessing about what had happened. ``I heard only that they met, and then went for a walk,'' said a 23-year-old woman, enjoying the sunshine between rainstorms Tuesday afternoon. ``But what they said on the walk _ it's not known to anybody.'' Radio Moscow's English broadcast did say: ``The united Germany will be able to decide what blocs or alliances it wants to belong to,'' and admitted that it would likely be NATO. The emphasis in all Soviet media was on sections of the agreement that promise a reduction in German troops, and a future non-aggression pact between NATO and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact military alliance. A commentary Tuesday by Tass, signed by Alexander Antsiferov, noted the Soviet change of heart and said it came only after NATO and the Warsaw Pact took steps away from confrontation. Last week, NATO issued a declaration that it was ready to sign a non-aggression pact and no longer regarded the Soviet Union as an adversary. The change also came just a few days after Gorbachev defeated Communist Party hard-liners, who had accused him of undermining the country's security by relaxing controls on Eastern Europe. At a party congress, which ended last week, Gorbachev succeeded in replacing nearly the entire party leadership. Some Muscovites expressed doubts about a reunited Germany. Twenty million Soviets died in World War II, according to official Soviet counts. The war, in which the Red Army repelled a German invasion that brought Nazi troops hundreds of miles inside the Soviet Union, is known in the Soviet Union as the Great Patriotic War. ``Although the leaders of modern Germany are not aggressive _ well, today it's fine, but tomorrow a second Hitler could appear, and it could start again,'' said the 72-year-old engineer, who refused to give his name. For a 77-year-old Moscow woman who still has the letters her husband wrote to her before disapearing on a World War II battlefield, the thought of German membership in NATO is ``terrifying.'' But still, she did not object. ``I think that a war will not happen. We'll trade and we'll help each other,'' she said. ``I hope everything will be all right.''

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Rejects Sharon's Plan to House Soviet Jews
DOC.TEXT: Israel's Supreme Court on Tuesday overturned Housing Minister Ariel Sharon's use of emergency regulations to speed up construction of housing for thousands of Soviet immigrants. Sharon was also dealt another blow as Tourism Minister Gideon Patt opposed a second crash program for the immigrants, under which the Soviet Jews would live temporarily in hotels and youth hostels. The three-judge Supreme Court panel ruled Sharon could have sought approval from the parliament, or Knesset, instead of using emergency powers. Tent camps are springing up across the country as a protest by Israelis who say subsidies for immigrants are driving up rents and pricing others out of the housing market.
