More than 63,000 Soviet Jews have arrived since 1989, and the total this year is expected to reach 150,000. Sharon, who is also Cabinet coordinator for immigration, led the government to approve emergency regulations July 1 that allow the purchase and establishment of 3,000 prefabricated units in Israel. Some politicians criticized the move, saying Sharon might take undemocratic steps and assume powers delegated to planning councils and zoning boards. Sharon was accused as defense minister in 1982 of concealing military plans from the government during the army's invasion of Lebanon. The Supreme Court decision followed an appeal by a liberal legislator, Abraham Poraz of the Shinui Party. Poraz argued that Sharon used emergency regulations at a time when the Knesset was debating the housing crisis. Last week, it passed a law shortening housing license procedures. ``Emergency regulations are an anti-democratic act ... that should be used only in difficult, exceptional situations, when there is no other choice,'' Poraz said on Israel army radio. The Housing Ministry said in a short statement it will respect the court's decision. It was the first time the court challenged the government's use of emergency powers, which date from Israel's 1948 war for independence. The procedure was introduced because there was fear that the Knesset could not always be convened because of the fighting. ``There is no doubt that this is a revolutionary decision,'' said Moshe Negbi, a legal expert for the Hebrew daily newspaper Hadashot. ``For the first time, the Supreme Court clearly says that the government ... must not use these radical powers when there is no problem in convening the parliament.'' ``The importance of this decision is that is again stresses the superiority of the Knesset over the government,'' Negbi said. The government argued that emergency regulations were needed to ease the housing crisis, and stated Israel's 20,000 available rental apartments will be filled by the end of September. Sharon's other emergency plan was approved Sunday by the government's ministerial immigration committee headed by him. That plan would direct Soviet immigrants to low-rate hotels and youth hostels, where they would rent rooms but would not get the customary hotel service. But Patt told reporters Tuesday that the plan, devised without prior consultations with the Tourism Ministry, was ``doomed to fail.'' He said the program would get Sharon ``a few rooms here and there,'' perhaps 400 to 500. The government says it needs 7,000 to 8,000 units each month to house the immigrants.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Blow Up House Where Explosive Found
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with chemical exploded; damage confined to house, and to DELETE reference to blasting cap; in fact, explosive cord was used. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Oakley Gover...'. ADDS one graf with background on man who was charged.
DOC.TEXT: Authorities set off a blast today in a house where a powerful explosive was found, saying the substance was too dangerous to move. The house was described as heavily damaged but no surrounding buildings were affected. At least 2,000 people had been evacuated from the area after an undetermined amount of nitroglycerin was found in a home Monday. There were no injuries. ``There was definitely nitroglycerin exploded in the basement,'' said FBI spokesman Ed Boldt. ``The house, even though it doesn't look like it (from the outside), has been pretty heavily damaged. Apparently there wasn't as much nitro as we feared there might be.'' Tests had indicated that a shot glass and syringe found in the basement of the one-story frame house Monday contained nitroglycerin, a flammable oil used in medicine and explosives, said police Chief Donald White. Authorities had feared larger containers nearby might contain the same substance. Authorities charged a man who had lived in the house until recently. Before the chemical was set off with a time-delay blast, the containers were surrounded by sandbags, windows in the house were opened, and surrounding homes were boarded up, authorities said. The blast was set off shortly after 1:30 p.m.; within a half-hour, evacuees began returning home. Boldt said it was the first time he knew of in his 11 years with the FBI that authorities resorted to exploding a home. Officials decided not to try to move the materials because they considered that even more dangerous, he said. They had considered taking the containers to a gravel pit. Authorities found the liquid Monday while responding to a report of a domestic dispute in this city of 20,000 about 30 miles north of Dayton. Residents in a 12-block area around the home and along the three-mile route to the gravel pit were urged to leave their homes. Before exploding the substance today, authorities extended the evacuation area by two blocks as a further precaution. Before that decision, city spokesman Michael Hemm had estimated that 2,000 people were out of their homes. Oakley Gover and his wife left their home after police told them there was danger of an explosion. ``We took them at their word, grabbed our dog and left,'' Gover said. Steve Jackson of the American Red Cross' Miami Valley chapter said about 12 people stayed overnight at an elementary school. Workers boarded up homes in the immediate area, shut off utility service and marked the ground where natural-gas lines were buried. According to Hemm and White, Dana Taylor, 25, was charged with possessing dangerous ordnance and was being held in the Miami County Jail in Troy. ``We do know that the ingredients to make nitro are there,'' White said. ``(And) we know from other sources that he (Taylor) has been setting off explosives in town or in the area.'' White said Taylor had maintained that there were no explosives in the house and that he knew little or nothing about explosives. But Hemm said police have received information that Taylor has experimented with explosives in the past. White declined to say what triggered the domestic dispute, only that Taylor and his wife had been involved in an argument. He said Taylor had recently moved out of the house.

DOC.HEAD: Discontinued Baby Formula Is Greatest Birthday Gift
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Raymond Dunn Jr. turned 16 Tuesday, but the profoundly retarded birthday boy feasted not on cake, to which he is allergic, but on the day's greatest gift: the bland, brown infant formula that keeps him alive. Gerber Products Co., which stopped making the meat-based formula in 1985, resumed production two months ago after Raymond's doctors said he would die without it. Gerber employees volunteered to make a batch on their own time, and on June 26 the Dunns received a two-year supply, free of charge. ``Gerber says `Babies are our business,' but Raymond's their business, too,'' said Carol Dunn, who spent five years trying to get the company to retool for a market of one. The Dunns celebrate Raymond's birthdays quietly yet thankfully, because each is one more than they were told to expect after Raymond was born with a broken skull and a brain that had been deprived of oxygen. At 16, Raymond is getting mail from Navy recruiters and college admissions offices, but he rarely leaves his house in this village in the Catskills. As he sits in his wheelchair or lies on his special floor mat, Raymond moves only with the help of others, and sees only shadows. His expression ranges from a painful grimace to a slight smile. He snorts, gurgles, wheezes and occasionally burps. He weighs 32 pounds, and his twisted, cramped body is 4 feet long. He suffers 15 to 20 major seizures a day and sleeps two or three hours a night, if at all. His asthma makes each breath a struggle; phlegm plugs repeatedly hospitalize him and threaten to kill him. Raymond, the Dunns' only child, also is allergic to the foods that help most children grow. But he always was sustained by Gerber's MBF (meat-based formula). When Gerber decided to drop the product five years ago, Mrs. Dunn was unable to find or create any substitute that did not make Raymond sick. Frantic, she hunted down every can she could find, and Gerber kept passing along its own backlog. By July 1988, Gerber ran out of MBF, leaving Raymond with less than two years' supply. Supported by the state Association for Retarded Children, Mrs. Dunn begged Gerber to make more MBF, and began a mail campaign asking others to pressure the company. Finally, the company's research director gave in. Since the nation learned of how a mother's devotion moved a large corporation, Mrs. Dunn and her husband, Raymond Sr., a car salesman, have received a shopping bag full of mail. A Sunday school class sent a check for $28. A dealer in rare baseball cards offered Raymond any card he wanted. The Rev. Raymond Dunn, no relation, told Mrs. Dunn that when her son finally dies, ``You will have a saint in heaven.'' Meanwhile, at Gerber, volunteers in the research division put their own projects on hold, hauled out old equipment and devoted several thousand square feet and several days of production space and time to Raymond's supply of MBF. It arrived in Yankee Lake just in time. The Dunns had about two dozen cans of the old formula, enough to last through the end of July. Each July 17, Mrs. Dunn worries that this birthday will be Raymond's last, so she follows the same ritual. She takes last year's birthday number candles from the tea cup over the sink and burns them down. Then she takes the candle numbers from this year's cake and places them in the cup, where they sit for the next 12 months. Raymond wears the same gold cardboard king's crown, with each year marked on a point on the crown. But even these rituals are touched by sadness. There are only two points left on the crown, and Mrs. Dunn has not had to let it out in many years because Raymond's head grows very little. What is most remarkable about Raymond is not his condition, but the care he receives. His mother and a platoon of teachers and helpers caress him almost constantly. They feed him seven times daily, and brush his teeth after each feeding. Raymond sleeps in his parents' bed, often between them. He receives about a dozen different medications, some several times a day. His mother's calendar has no luncheon dates or hairdresser's appointments; it is devoted entirely to charting the times and dosages of just one asthma remedy. But the Dunns say his birthday reminds them that life at its most marginal, at its most precarious, is life at its most meaningful. When Raymond was an infant they were urged to institutionalize him, told that keeping him home would burn them out and ruin their marriage. ``We knew we'd have to pay a price, and the price has been hard,'' Mrs. Dunn says. ``I've given up a normal life. But Raymond gives me a lot of joy. Does it outweigh the sorrow? No. But he is my son, and if I had put Raymond away, the price would have been even higher.''

DOC.HEAD: Britain and Germany: Did Sharp Words Reveal an Identity Crisis?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf, `In The ...' to CORRECT first name of Ascherson from Neil to Neal. Pickup 17th pvs, `He said...'
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: In a memorable episode of the British TV sitcom ``Fawlty Towers,'' a bumbling hotel owner goes to absurd lengths ``not to mention the war'' to his German guests, then proceeds to do just that _ over and over. That episode from the 1970s, which had actor John Cleese goose-stepping and heil-Hitlering in hilarious fashion, is being recalled these days as British commentators wrestle anew with the complexities of Anglo-German relations. First there was Nicholas Ridley, trade secretary and close confidant of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, sounding off last week about ``uppity'' Germans trying to take over Europe. Then came publication Sunday of the summary of a secret seminar hosted by Mrs. Thatcher, in which leading academics put Germany on the psychiatrist's couch, analyzing such stereotypical traits as bullying, angst and sentimentality. Ridley resigned, and Mrs. Thatcher's office vowed to find out who leaked the summary to the press. But as most observers agreed, the two episodes served to bring a delicate issue into the open. The issue is the mix of suspicion, envy and scholarly fascination that characterizes Britain's attitude to Germany, steeped in memories of World War II. Today, whatever hostility remains is usually expressed in jokes, about early-rising German holidaymakers grabbing the best beaches, or Basil Fawlty screaming at his staff: ``Whatever you do, don't mention the war!'' But lately, things have gotten serious. Germany is a formidable economic power, and after it reunites, the deutschmark looks certain to dominate the European Community. Thus, argue supporters of Ridley and Mrs. Thatcher, surely a small island nation like Britain with chronic economic problems has the right to ask what sort of Europe it is going into. The trouble, as in Fawlty's case, is in the presentation. Ridley expressed a genuine popular concern which is shared by Mrs. Thatcher. But his references to the EC bureaucracy as Hitler, and to Britain ``being bossed by a German,'' were widely criticized. The seminar was a free-ranging session covering many opinions. According to participants, it only looked controversial when it was boiled down to a 2,000-word summary by Mrs. Thatcher's private secretary for foreign affairs, Charles Powell. ``If Chancellor Kohl himself had sat in on that meeting, he would have agreed with, or at least accepted as fair comment, 90 percent of what was said,'' Timothy Garton Ash, a German affairs scholar who attended the seminar, wrote in The Independent. Opposition Labor Party lawmakers accused Powell of slanting the summary to match Mrs. Thatcher, and got no straight answer when they asked her whether she repudiated Ridley's remarks. Some German commentators find the uproar symptomatic of a British identity crisis, rooted in memories of its lost empire and World War II, when it stood alone but united against Hitler. In The Independent on Sunday, Neal Ascherson noted a German tendency to regard Britain as a twilight world on the fringes of Europe, ``a raft being pulled away into the sunset by a mad queen whose shouts grow gradually fainter.'' He said that when he lived in Germany 20 years ago, attacks like Ridley's would have provoked ``panic-stricken self-questioning about why the `ugly Germans' were still so ugly. Now they are just laughing at us.'' British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd was also critical of his nation's tendency ``just to draw down the blinds, shut out the real world, swear at the present world and pretend that we can go on just living in the past.'' He pointed out that Germany had prospered by working hard, producing manufactured goods, holding down inflation _ ``all the things we failed to do.'' Garton Ash blamed history and geography. ``America,'' he wrote, ``is far enough away, and still big and powerful enough, to be quite relaxed about the re-emergence of Germany as a great power in central Europe. France (let alone Poland) is too small and too relatively weak to be anything but deadly serious about it. ``But Britain is somewhere in between: close enough to be worried and weak enough to be resentful (`Who won the war, anyway?'), yet also far enough away, and still self-confident enough, to be outspoken and outrageous.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Marcus Eliason is news editor of the AP London bureau.

DOC.HEAD: DEA Says Traffickers Finding Cocaine in Short Supply
DOC.TEXT: Drug traffickers are finding cocaine in short supply nearly everywhere in the United States, a top U.S. drug official said Tuesday. Ronald Caffrey told the Senate Judiciary Committee that the shortage was the ``first positive development in domestic wholesale cocaine availability and prices since the onset of the cocaine epidemic.'' Caffrey, the Drug Enforcement Administration's deputy assistant administrator for operations, said cocaine prices had reached their highest level since mid-1985 and that purity levels had dropped. The combination of high prices and low purity generally indicates a shortage in the drug, he said. Some of the shortages, Caffrey said, may be due to stockpiling by cocaine traffickers and price gouging by those playing on fears of a shortage. He said law enforcement efforts at home and in Latin America have had a major impact on the drug's availability, but acknowledged that it could be temporary. One way the DEA knew shortages existed was because of its undercover agents' dealings with drug traffickers. ``Normally, when we do our undercover work, we go out and we buy drugs at certain prices that are quoted to us,'' Caffrey said. ``When the market starts to dry up a little bit, suddenly people are asking us to sell them drugs, and then sting operations occur.'' Caffrey said wholesale price increased in Los Angeles, New York City, Houston, Chicago and Miami between December and June. In New York, for example, prices ranged from $14,000 to $20,000 per kilo in December but increased to $21,000 to $35,000 per kilo by June. However, Caffrey said prices remain far below the $55,000 to $65,000 price per kilo in 1982. At the same time, the level of cocaine purity has dropped steadily since 1988, he said. The agency found that purity at the kilo level decreased from 90 percent two years ago to 74 percent in June. At the gram, or street-buy level, purity dropped from 70 percent two years ago to 55 percent last month, the DEA said. Asked outside the hearing about the results of an unreleased cocaine price and purity survey of all 19 DEA field offices, Caffrey said the trend toward increased prices and decreased purity of wholesale quantities of cocaine was ``almost nationwide.'' ``Florida is a little bit different in the sense that, yeah, prices have gone up since last year at this time, but I would say that it is still fairly stable,'' he said. That, he said, ``would indicate to us that at least in Florida, there is a fair amount of wholesale cocaine available.'' Until Tuesday, the DEA had been unwilling to say there was a shortage in wholesale level cocaine in most of the United States despite information on price and purity changes. National drug policy director William J. Bennett had hailed those changes as indications of a shortage.

DOC.HEAD: Nurse Says She Was Innocent, Journalist Was Not A Spy
DOC.TEXT: A British nurse on her first full day of freedom from an Iraqi jail professed her innocence Tuesday and said she did not believe executed journalist Farzad Bazoft was a spy. Daphne Parish, 53, acknowledged that she drove Bazoft to the site of an explosion near an Iraqi military installation and saw no wrong in their action. ``It didn't appear improper at the time. We didn't do anything I considered illegal,'' she told reporters in the Zambian capital, Lusaka. Earlier Tuesday, President Kenneth Kaunda handed Mrs. Parish over to British officials in Lusaka. Kaunda, who secured Mrs. Parish's release on humanitarian grounds, said he blamed British press coverage of events in Iraq and official British hostility toward Iraqi President Saddam Hussein for Bazoft's death. He said an appeal sent by him before Bazoft's execution on May 15 also sought the Iranian-born reporter's release. If it were not for what he described as Britain's vicious attitude to Iraq ``that man might have lived, might have been here with Daphne,'' he said. The British Foreign Office declined to comment on Kaunda's remarks. In London, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher sent personal messages of thanks to Kaunda and Saddam, her office said Tuesday. Bazoft, who traveled on British documents but did not have British nationality, was on assignment for the London Sunday newspaper, The Observer, at the time of his arrest. His colleagues have insisted he was not a spy but merely an enthusiastic reporter. Speaking with reporters at the Lusaka home of British High Commissioner Peter Henchcliffe, Mrs. Parish said she drove Bazoft to the Al-Iskandaria military complex on her day off. Other British journalists had already visited the complex and some climbed over a perimeter fence. ``We didn't climb over any fences,'' she said. ``As we were driving around, we saw what appeared like coal dust on the side of the road.'' Bazoft wanted to collect some of the dust and Mrs. Parish said she gave him a bottle to put it in. ``We did this in full view of cars going up and down. We did nothing secretly. It was all out in the open.'' Iraq has denied using chemical weapons, and it accused Bazoft of collecting soil samples to establish the nature of weapons housed at the military base. Mrs. Parish, sentenced to 15 years in jail as an accomplice of Bazoft, said she was told of her release by guards at Abu Ghraud prison mid-morning Monday and thought it was a joke. ``I just laughed,'' she said. She was jailed last September and convicted in March. Mrs. Parish said she kept physically trim in jail by doing aerobics. In a cell with four other women, she also kept her mind occupied by making playing cards and chess, with pieces out of old newspaper. Mrs. Parish planned to leave Zambia on a scheduled British Airways flight to London late Tuesday, accompanied by a Lusaka-based British diplomat.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Up Despite Boost in U.S. Exports
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit widened to $7.73 billion in May as a big jump in imports of oil and foreign cars offset the second-highest level of exports on record, the Commerce Department reported Tuesday. The May deficit was 5.8 percent higher than a revised April trade gap of $7.31 billion, but most economists discounted the report as a small worsening of the deficit. They pointed out U.S. export sales remained strong and they predicted the trend would continue as economic growth overseas helps prop up a sluggish American market. ``Thank goodness for trade. It remains the brightest spot in the economy,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``The small increase in the May deficit is not of concern because we believe that strong growth overseas will keep U.S. exports rising.'' Many analysts believe export sales are the only thing keeping the country out of a recession. In the first three months of the year, fully half of total economic growth was supplied by the rise in overseas sales. In a separate report Tuesday, the Federal Reserve said industrial output rose by 0.4 percent in June, helping push the operating rate at the nation's factories, mines and utilities to 83.5 percent of capacity, the highest level this year. Much of the June increase reflected a spurt in auto production in advance of a possible strike this fall and a heat wave which boosted utility demand. But analysts said a growing portion of U.S. manufacturing output is being shipped to overseas markets. The Bush administration, which is counting on strong foreign demand to continue propping up the economy, was pleased with the May trade report. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher noted the U.S. trade deficit for the first five months of the year was almost $6 billion less than the same period a year ago. ``We can be encouraged by our continuing steady export growth of 8 percent this year, which is more than double the overall growth of imports,'' Mosbacher said. However, Lawrence Chimerine, a senior economic adviser at DRI-McGraw Hill Inc., said import demand has been depressed by the sluggish U.S. economy. He said once the economy picks up, the trade deficit would resume climbing, especially given America's growing dependence on foreign oil. So far this year, the merchandise trade deficit has been running at an annual rate of $97.68 billion, surprising many analysts who had predicted little change from the 1989 deficit of $109.4 billion. Bruce Steinberg, senior economist at Merrill Lynch, said that deficit for all of 1990 should end up between $90 billion and $95 billion, marking the first time since 1983 the country has had a deficit below $100 billion. For May, imports climbed by 2.9 percent to $40.52 billion offsetting a 2.3 percent rise in U.S. exports, which totaled $32.79 billion. The trade deficit is the difference between imports and exports. The export level, second highest in history after a March figure of $33.3 billion, was bolstered by gains in various areas including automotive parts, capital goods and consumer products. Close to half of the total import increase came from a 15.2 percent increase in oil shipments during May. America's foreign oil bill totaled $4.32 billion during the month as the volume rose to 8.95 million barrels a day, up from 7.55 million barrels daily in April. The price per barrel dropped by $1 to $15.57 in May. Analysts said that with domestic oil production dropping to its lowest level in more than a quarter of a century, the dependence on foreign oil is certain to rise even higher in coming months. Much of the rest of the increase in imports in May came from a 10 percent jump in shipments of foreign motor vehicles and parts, which climbed to $6.22 billion. The United States continued to enjoy a trade surplus with the countries of Western Europe of $812 million in May. The biggest deficit was, as usual, with Japan _ a $2.97 billion imbalance, down from an April gap of $3.95 billion.

DOC.HEAD: UPI Names Chief Operating Officer
DOC.TEXT: John Berentson, a top official of Infotechnology Inc., the parent company of United Press International, was named vice chairman and chief operating officer of the wire service on Tuesday. Berentson, 50, will keep his post as senior executive vice president and chief operating officer of Infotechnology Inc. which owns UPI as well as 47 percent of Financial News Network Inc. At the news agency, he replaces Joseph K. Taussig, who is leaving to pursue other business interests, UPI said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Two Top Economic Advisers Resign, Giving Way to Proponents of `Shock' Plan
DOC.TEXT: Two of President-elect Alberto Fujimori's top economic advisers have resigned, raising speculation the new government is planning an economic ``shock'' program to fix Peru's battered economy. Fujimori vigorously denied he would create such a program during his campaign, but the resignations Monday of Adolfo Figueroa and Santiago Roca leave Fujimori's advisers dominated by proponents of a ``shock'' plan. Fujimori has been meeting in private for the last week with the advisers to iron out policies and form a Cabinet. They have been meeting at a military base in Lima for security reasons and have not disclosed details of their meetings. In a joint resignation letter, Roca and Figueroa said they wanted to allow Fujimori ``complete freedom to make the appropriate decisions for the country's best interests.'' Political analyst Manuel D`Ornellas, writing in newspaper Expreso on Tuesday, said: ``Fujimori no longer has internal opposition to his adjustment program. But outside he'll face a mountain of it.'' Fujimori's opponent in the election, novelist Mario Vargas Llosa, bluntly proposed the need for drastic changes to revive Peru's economy, burdened by 3,000 percent annual inflation and high unemployment. Analysts and pollsters said much of Fujimori's support came from poorer people who feared Vargas Llosa's austerity plans. Many now attack Fujimori for abandoning his supporters by adopting some of Vargas Llosa's ideas. Since his election June 10, Fujimori has emphasized his desire to re-establish relations with international lending agencies such as the International Monetary Fund. The IMF and other lending organizations cut off credit to Peru after President Alan Garcia stopped foreign debt repayments in 1986. In late June, Fujimori met in New York with leaders of the IMF, the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank. He expressed his willingness to cooperate on economic policies to secure new loans to help Peru cope with its $20 billion foreign debt. Many interpreted that as his acceptance of the need for more serious measures to stop inflation and promote growth. Since his trip, in which he also visited Japan, his ancestral homeland, Fujimori has said he will dismantle price subsidy programs and exchange rate controls. Many blame the weak economy on Garcia's populist programs of deficit spending and price controls on basic goods and services. Prices for water, electricity and telephone service are among the lowest in the region. Gasoline costs the equivalent of 20 U.S. cents for a gallon, less than what the government oil company pays to produce it. Many state-owned companies are broke, and press reports say the Central Bank is $129 million in the red. Roca and Figueroa were not the first to depart from Fujimori's economic team over policy differences. Oscar Ugarteche, who served on a commission studying the foreign debt problem, resigned because of disagreements over debt policies and rejoining the IMF. Fujimori is scheduled to take office July 28, his 52nd birthday.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Votes to Restrict Growth of Textile, Apparel Imports
DOC.TEXT: The Senate brushed aside veto threats by President Bush and voted Tuesday to restrict the growth of U.S. imports of textiles and apparel to 1 percent a year and freeze imports of shoes at 1989 levels. By a potentially veto-overriding 68-32 vote, the Senate approved a textile-import bill nearly identical to measures passed by Congress in 1985 and 1988 but successfully vetoed by then-President Reagan. ``They do not want to do anything for the textile industry,'' Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., said of the Bush administration. ``If we do nothing, it is safe to predict the demise of the industry is at hand.'' Since 1980, the U.S. trade deficit on textiles and apparel has jumped from $4.7 billion to $26.5 billion, making it the second largest component of the nation's trade deficit behind oil. Over the same time, more than 1,800 textile and apparel plants have closed and employment has dropped by 400,000 to just over 1.9 million jobs _ despite an $18 billion modernization effort. Opponents claimed the bill would cost consumers $25 billion to $27 billion a year in higher prices. ``You do not notice it much,'' said Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore. ``Just 50 cents a shirt here; a dollar, ... two dollars a pair of shoes. But add that up by 250 million consumers in this country. That is a lot of money.'' Bush rejected a last-minute appeal Tuesday from senators from textile-producing states to back off his threatened veto. ``I can't do that,'' he said. ``I can't say that I think the answer to the problem of textiles is further protection.'' The administration contended any further restrictions placed by the United States on textile imports would ``virtually destroy any chance of a successful conclusion'' by the end of this year to the 4-year-old Uruguay Round of 100-nation trade negotiations in Geneva. But lawmakers from textile-, apparel- and shoe-producing states said they fear the administration will sacrifice textile concerns in those talks to win concessions from trading partners on protecting U.S. copyrights and patents and to secure a lowering of those countries' barriers to American farm exports and service suppliers. Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., said the major U.S. trading partners have shown no willingness to yield on the major issues in the Geneva negotiations on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). ``We are about to lose our shirt,'' he predicted. ``They will not yield on agriculture in Europe. They will not yield on intellectual property rights and computers in South America.'' The Senate's vote was well beyond the two-thirds needed to override a veto and more lopsided than the 59-36 vote by which the Senate approved nearly identical legislation a year ago. A similar bill in the House is being sponsored by 234 of its 435 members but faces some difficulty because of opposition from Rep. Sam Gibbons, D-Fla., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee's subcommittee on trade. The bill would establish nation-by-nation quotas on U.S. imports of textiles, apparel and non-rubber footwear beginning this year, except for certain products from Canada and Israel, which have free-trade agreements with the United States. Textile and apparel imports, which have tripled in the last decade, would be allowed to grow only 1 percent a year while shoe imports would be frozen at their 1989 level. However, to reduce opposition from farm interests who fear retaliation, the bill would provide increases in quotas to countries that increase their purchases of U.S. agricultural products. Several attempts to weaken the bill through amendments were defeated by better than 2-to-1 margins.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Blocks Hezbollah Advance In Southern Lebanon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with 52 killed, Arafat letter to Iranian president to help stop the intra-Shiite fighting. Pickup 12th pvs, `The PLO...' ^By MOHAMMED SALAM
DOC.TEXT: Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas moved in Tuesday to block pro-Iranian fundamentalists' attack on a rival faction in south Lebanon. Police said 52 people were killed and 167 wounded. A police spokesman said Yasser Arafat's guerrillas intervened after Hezbollah, or Party of God, overran the village of Jarjou Monday night. That stripped the Syrian-backed Shiite Moslem Amal of its main stronghold in Iqlim al-Tuffah, or the Apple Province. A police spokesman called it the bloodiest battle in six months in the mountainous regions above Sidon, provincial capital of south Lebanon. Jarjou is 10 miles southeast of Sidon. The spokesman, who could not be named in line with standing regulations, said that in the final push that ended just before midnight, 40 people were killed and 117 wounded. Twelve people were killed and 50 wounded in clashes earlier in the day. ``It was close-quarter combat. The village square is littered with bodies that couldn't be evacuated by the Red Cross because of the savage fighting,'' the spokesman said. He said the fatalities included 30 Amal fighters and 10 from Hezbollah. An estimated 600 PLO fighters entered Iqlim al-Tuffah at 4 a.m. on orders from Arafat. Their deployment blocked Hezbollah's advance toward Nabatiyeh, the main Shiite town in south Lebanon, some five miles south of Jarjou. It also left the fundamentalists bottled up in a mountain enclave with no access west to the Mediterrnean coast, or south toward the major Shiite cities and towns. A Hezbollah official in Sidon, provincial capital of south Lebanon, rejected what he described as Palestinian ``expansion,'' and vowed to ``confront it.'' The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Palestinian move would lead to ``large-scale violence,'' but he refused to say what Hezbollah planned to do about it. Zeid Wehbe, the PLO's representative in Lebanon, said Arafat appealed to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani to ``throw his weight behind the PLO intervention to stop the intra-Shiite bloodshed.'' The PLO has about 5,000 hardcore fighters based in refugee camps around Sidon. It fears Hezbollah might try to seize control of Sidon to gain an outlet to the Mediterranean, a move that would dramatically alter the strategic balance in the region north of Israel. Hezbollah needs a coastal outlet because its supply lines from the Bekaa Valley northeast of the battle zone are vulnerable to interdiction by Syria and its Lebanese allies. A PLO source said that if Hezbollah controlled ``any part of the coast, they'll have a port to ship in weapons, ammunition and fighters and establish their own Islamic republic modeled on Iran. ``This cannot be permitted. ... No one wants Iran to become a key partner to the Middle East conflict,'' he explained. The source, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Palestinian deployment Tuesday was ``personally ordered by Arafat in a message received overnight.'' Shortly after the PLO move, Israeli warplanes made several low-level passes over the battle zone. They repeatedly broke the sound barrier, but did not open fire. Amal and Hezbollah have been fighting off and on for three years for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. By police count, 1,069 people have been killed and 3,228 wounded in the conflict.

DOC.HEAD: Rockers And Rappers Hunt Down Deals at Huge Convention
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `The convention ...' to CORRECT spelling of `Marriott'
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of rockers, rappers and producers from as far away as the Soviet Union chased down record contracts at one of the country's biggest music conventions, which graduated the likes of Madonna and Run DMC. The 11th-annual New Music Seminar, drawing 8,000 people worldwide this year, combines an exhibition hall of blasting stereos hawking the wares, 85 panel discussions, and shows by more than 300 bands. The first convention was held in a rehearsal studio with 200 participants in 1979. It caters mainly to performers looking for their big break and to ``indies,'' independent record producers who seek ``unsigned'' artists _ musicians without a record contract. ``We have an ideology that makes us fireproof in terms of obsolescence, because the program brings together the neophyte and insurgent elements,'' said Mark Jacobsen, 32, executive director of New Music Seminar. During the five-day convention, which ends Wednesday, panel discussions covered distribution, publishing, stage presence, video production and social issues. Environmental attorney Robert Kennedy Jr. and ex-Go Go Jane Wiedlin pushed Earth concerns. Singer Dionne Warwick called for more AIDS education by the industry. Even separatist political movements were apparent at the convention _ the Estonian delegation taped over the USSR on their name tags. The convention was a hectic, surreal scene of rockers in leather and tattoos and rappers in gold and chiseled haircuts talking business in the luxurious glass, steel and marble halls of the Marriott Marquis on Times Square. Their convention tags bore such names as Bashun Beat, Freeze, Neutron, Coyote Shivers and Dave Rave. ``It's the one time you can talk to label executives and they'll give you the time of day,'' said Robert Oss of Lunar Music in Hamilton, Ontario. ``You also get a kind of beat on what's going on.'' Many carried briefcases and lined up at public phones to fill orders or arrange other meetings. ``I need 200 more of each record; how soon can I get them?'' a rocker-businessman in a T-shirt said over the phone. More than 100 booths filled the exhibition hall, with stereos blasting rock and rap. Booths featured the latest talent from Germany, Italy, Australia, Spain and France, music magazines, suppliers and social groups like ``Ban the Box,'' which campaigns against the use of oversize CD packaging, criticized as a waste of trees. One panel discussion Monday was led by the Earth Communications Office, a Los Angeles-based group that urges entertainment companies and artists to help get the public more aware of the environment. Because young people more often look up to rock stars than politicians, ``you have a major responsibility. If you don't use it, we'll be living in a very different world,'' said Kennedy, who sat on the panel. The convention reflected the intertwining of business and music. ``I do spend more time doing business than writing songs,'' said Page Hamilton, lead singer of the avant-garde noise band Helmet. ``I'm busy doing album covers and promotion like advance cassettes, press packets, photos, T-shirts.'' Jody Kurilla, in charge of booking the convention's more than 300 acts, said she auditioned more than 10,000 tapes from around the world. She said there was no single trend but various currents of funk, rock, rap, world beat, industrial dance, Latin and the hippy-psychedelic style from Manchester, England. Performers who played in previous years included Madonna, New Order, Run DMC and the B-52s, organizers said. Record industry officials say they are unable to chart how big a chunk the independents own of the $6.5 billion music industry. But an advantage of independent labels is they can sell 2,000 to 3,000 records or tapes and break even, while the larger companies require sales in the tens of thousands, said Kramer, 31-year-old owner of Shimmy-Disc Records in New York. He uses only one name.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl: All German Elections Likely in December
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Bush comment, details from East Germany, Paris talks. Edits to trim. No pickup. Stands as Germany-Unification roundup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BON7
DOC.TEXT: A jubilant Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Tuesday that all major obstacles to German unification had been swept aside and said elections for a united German parliament were likely in December. Speaking to reporters the day after he returned from the Soviet Union with guarantees that a united Germany was free to join NATO, Kohl also said he hoped bilateral treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland could be concluded by early next summer. ``The practical problems, which lay before us on the way to German unity, have been solved,'' Kohl said. He said elections for a united German parliament on Dec. 2 were ``presumable.'' But whether East Germany merged with the West before or after the elections had to be decided by East Berlin, he added. The deputy chairman of the largest faction in the East German Parliament said East Germany could vote to join West Germany under its constitution on Dec. 1. Udo Kamm of the Christian Democratic coalition said his faction would vote for such a proposal in a committee Thursday. The proposal would then go to the full Parliament. In Washington, President Bush said Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's consent for a united Germany in NATO was ``very, very significant and very important.'' Bush said the United States deserves a lot of credit. ``I take pride in the way Europe is moving into this new era of freedom,'' he said. ``It's a goal that we Americans have long worked to achieve.'' In a 40-minute telephone call to Gorbachev, Bush assured him that NATO poses no threat to the Soviet Union and that the United States is ready to move toward warmer relations, officials said. Kohl also tried Tuesday to reassure Germany's neighbors. ``We are no world power,'' he said, emphasizing that the new Germany would be embedded in the ``European security architecture.'' He said he was sensitive to the concerns of fellow Europeans. He noted that Britain had gambled ``its very existence'' in battling Hitler. He said it was no accident Germany had agreed to reduce the size of a united army to 370,000 and cut compulsory military service from 15 to 12 months. East German Foreign Minister Markus Meckel, however, rejected the idea of one German army and said East Germany needed its own military. Currently, the two Germanys have about 600,000 men under arms, 480,000 of them in West Germany. In Paris, meanwhile, the nations negotiating German unification reached a historic agreement, confirming Poland's border with East Germany and clearing the way for one Germany by year's end. West Germany also agreed to hold economic assistance talks with Poland later in the summer. Terms of the border settlement were not announced. Polish Foreign Minister Krysztof Skubiszewski said they were confidential, but all the foreign ministers stressed the border would be the line between Poland and East Germany that was drawn at the end of the war. ``We are very happy with the results,'' Skubiszewski said. ``The border has been confirmed.'' The border settlement should serve to allay Polish concerns that a merged Germany would revive old claims on territory given to Poland in partial compensation for a larger area taken over by the Soviet Union. In evaluating the role of the new Germany in central Europe, Kohl said he envisioned it as a ``transit point for ideas and perspectives'' between West and East. The treaty with the Soviets, Kohl said, could include economic aid. But he said no specific financial aid was offered during his weekend visit to induce the Soviets to remove one of their biggest obstacles to German unification _ objections to a united Germany in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who accompanied Kohl and Finance Minister Theo Waigel on the trip to Moscow, also said West Gemany and the Soviet Union reached agreement on cooperation without West Germany giving specific aid promises. ``We reached agreement ... on long-term cooperation, but we have not discussed any numbers,'' Genscher said in Paris. Waigel said the Soviets presented ``no bill'' for their acceptance of German reunification. But he said it was in the German interest for the Soviet reform process to succeed. West Germany has already backed a $3 billion bank credit to help the Soviet Union revamp its economy and has agreed to pay $780 million toward the upkeep of Soviet soldiers stationed in East Germany in the second half of this year. At last week's Houston summit of Western industrial powers, Kohl had pushed for a $15 billion international aid package for the Soviet Union. Instead, the leaders asked the International Monetary Fund to study what kind of aid would be most beneficial. Kohl ruled out the possibility that West Germany would be the sole future source of financial aid to the Soviets, saying the burden would be too great. However, he said he could envision West Germany helping the Soviets retrain thousands of soldiers returning from East Germany, who could face unemployment back home. It was also possible, he said, for West Germany to help in supplying housing but ``not for a certain category of Soviet residents.'' West German officials are concerned about the domestic political fallout of building housing specifically for returning Soviet troops.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Soviet Concession `Very Significant'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush called Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev on Tuesday and said his consent for a united Germany in NATO was ``very, very significant and very important.'' Bush also said the United States deserves a lot of credit for helping remove the last major obstacle to German unity. ``I take pride in the way Europe is moving into this new era of freedom,'' the president said. ``It's a goal that we Americans have long worked to achieve.'' In a 40-minute telephone call to Gorbachev, Bush assured the Soviet president that NATO poses no threat to Moscow and that the United States is ready to move toward warmer relations, officials said. Bush also briefed Gorbachev on last week's seven-nation economic summit and the decision not to block any Western nation from providing cash assistance to Moscow, said the officials, who requested anonymity. Bush explained that the United States is willing to provide technical help but not money. It was the fourth telephone call to Gorbachev by Bush in his 18 months in office. Separately, Bush also called West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and congratulated him on his talks with Gorbachev and the dropping of Soviet objections to East Germany joining West Germany under the umbrella of the Western alliance. Amid a glow of triumph in the West, Bush made a deliberate effort to highlight his own role in promoting German unity. There was an apparent feeling in the White House that Monday's announcement of a deal between Gorbachev and Kohl failed to give proper credit to other Western leaders. ``When good things happen as a result of the combined efforts of the allies, it makes sense to take note of that,'' one administration official said, speaking privately. Bush, addressing a gathering of magazine publishers, said the Gorbachev-Kohl statements about a unified Germany were ``very, very significant and very important and ... let me reflect on how we got here.'' He said, ``I remember telling the press last October, before the Berlin Wall came down, that when we said we supported German unity we really meant that and we meant it without qualifications. ``I know the German people have appreciated that stand by the United States.'' The president recalled that he had held separate meetings with Kohl, French President Francois Mitterrand and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to forge a unified position, and then discussed the subject at length with Gorbachev, particularly during a meeting at Camp David on June 2. Bush noted that he had said, at a wrap-up news conference with Gorbachev, that they had agreed that Germany should be free to choose its own alliance. ``President Gorbachev, if you remember, didn't challenge that, and I _ we all thought that that was a good sign then.'' Bush said, ``We also had to show him that the NATO alliance was not his enemy but was a force for stability that could adapt, could indeed change, adapt to the new realities in Europe.'' On that point, Bush noted that it was the United States that drafted the NATO-restructuring plan adopted at a summit of alliance leaders in London July 6. Bush quoted Gorbachev as having said Monday that it would have been difficult to make headway on Germany with the ``very important impulse'' from NATO. Bush said that Gorbachev and Kohl ``have displayed, I think, exceptional qualities of leadership during this challenging period.'' A senior White House official said Bush had no misgivings about Kohl and Gorbachev striking a deal themselves without involving other Western leaders. The official said, ``It's clear that the whole process of diplomatic efforts _ of Mitterrand, Thatcher, Kohl and Bush visits with Gorbachev _ then the NATO summit and then the economic summit were a very strong and powerful impetus towards Gorbachev moving in this direction.'' ``Basically, everybody was in it together,'' he said. As for Kohl and Gorbachev announcing the breakthrough, he added, ``That's where it should have been. That's where the front line is. That's where these two leaders have got to work out their relationship.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Novelist Valentin Pikul Dead at 62
DOC.TEXT: Popular historical novelist Valentin Pikul, whose books focused on Russia's sweeping upheavals, has died, the Tass news agency reported Tuesday. He was 62. The dispatch from Riga, which quoted the Union of Latvian Writers, did not give the date or the cause of death. Pikul's novels often delved into topics that were long taboo, such as the downfall of the Russian royalty and the influence of the monk Grigory Rasputin over the family of Czar Nicholas II. In some of his historical novels, he was accused of being anti-Semitic. In his 1979 novel, ``At the Final Frontier,'' he tried to show that Rasputin was a tool of Zionists. Other literary critics accused him of a nonchalant attitude toward historical facts. ``The novel is the form of self-expression that I love,'' he once wrote. ``I love a novel with a multitude of characters and a furious succession of events. I hate those feeble little novels in which the author pokes around in the intimate psychology of characters that are depressed and bored by life.'' During the World War II German blockade of his native Leningrad, Pikul was evacuated to Archangelsk, where he entered the navy and served on the destroyer Groznyi. His first novel, ``Ocean Patrol,'' published in 1954, was about the Soviet fleet. In 1961, he published ``Bayazet,'' about the Russo-Turkish War of 1877-78. Other books included ``With Pen and Rapier'' (1970),``Moon Sound'' (1973) and ``Word and Deed'' (1975).

DOC.HEAD: GAO Critical of Social Security 800 Number
DOC.TEXT: The Social Security Administration's new telephone system is leaving many people waiting in vain for their calls to be returned, government auditors said Tuesday. The General Accounting Office said that, in some types of cases, 42 percent of callers never received the follow-up calls they were promised when they dialed Social Security's toll-free 800 number. Social Security follows up 97 percent of the time in other categories, the report said. ``It is difficult to avoid the conclusion that the Social Security 800 system is not a working number, or at least that it is not working very well,'' said Rep. Andy Jacobs Jr., D-Ind., chairman of the House Ways and Means Social Security subcommittee. GAO, an arm of Congress, began investigating the phone system after Social Security blocked telephone access to its local field offices. Social Security officials insisted that requiring that all calls be made to the 800 number would improve service. Jacobs said the GAO study offered proof that service had not been improved. While it may save time for Social Security workers, Jacobs said, it wastes the time of people the government is supposed to be serving. He said 800-number operators lack training and expertise to answer non-routine calls. Although it's far easier to get through to the 800 number than it was earlier this year, Jacobs said, a caller still will get a busy signal 35 percent of the time. Social Security spokesman Frank Battistelli said the agency would not comment because it had not been given a copy of the GAO report. However, he said that at least 80 percent of problems or questions posed in calls to the 800 number are settled on the spot, without the need for any call back or referral to a field office. Even after repeated unsuccessful attempts to get back to a caller, Social Security offices don't let a case ``slip through the cracks,'' Battistelli said. ``We then send a letter asking the caller to get back in touch with us,' he said. Social Security expects to receive as many as 70 million calls this year; GAO estimated that only about 5 percent require referrals. GAO acknowledged the difficulty in trying to get back to a caller. In doing its survey, GAO said, its workers were unable to make contact in five attempts with many of those who had called the 800 number.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, British Opposition Leader Meet
With AM-Bush-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: British opposition leader Neil Kinnock discussed with President Bush on Tuesday the growing momentum toward German unification and pressed for Western aid to the Soviet Union. Kinnock, on a two-day visit to the United States, hopes to convince U.S. officials and lawmakers that his Labor Party would be a more reliable partner for Washington in the new Europe than the government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. ``I hope we were able to present a prospective government of the United Kingdom ... as a reliable partner in NATO'' and within the European Economic Community, said Gerald Kaufman, the Labor Party's shadow foreign minister. He spoke to reporters after Kinnock's 30-minute meeting with Bush, which he described as ``extremely useful and amicable.'' Kinnock and Bush talked about Monday's announcement by Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev that the Soviet Union would allow a united Germany in NATO. The two also talked about aiding Eastern Europe and the Soviets, with Kinnock emphasizing the need to provide frustrated Soviet consumers with goods. ``We talked about how to help the Soviets without being patronizing,'' said Kaufman. Kinnock differs from Thatcher and Bush in believing Europe should help the Soviet Union with more than just technical advice. The aid from Britain should be loans and investment resulting in the purchase of British goods, he emphasized in a speech Monday to the Council on Foreign Relations in New York. He said it was premature to assign a monetary figure to aid at this time. Kaufman said Kinnock congratulated Bush on his role in bringing about a relaxation of NATO's defense strategy at the 16-nation alliance summit in London earlier this month. The changed strategy enabled Gorbachev to make his decision about NATO membership for a united Germany, Kaufman quoted Kinnock as saying.

DOC.HEAD: EEC Being Pressured on Export Subsidies
With AM-Textile Imports
DOC.TEXT: The United States is putting more pressure on the European Economic Community to negotiate the elimination of export subsidies from world trade, administration farm officials said Tuesday. One of the weapons in the U.S. trade arsenal is the 5-year-old Export Enhancement Program, which provides ``bonuses'' or subsidies to make U.S. commodities cheaper for selected foreign buyers. But Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said the U.S. subsidy program was modest compared with the $10 billion annually spent by the 12-nation European trade bloc on farm export subsidies. Further, he said, the House Appropriations Committee recently cut the subsidies under EEP to $500 million from the $900 million the administration had requested. Yeutter said export subsidies were ``probably the most important part'' of the ongoing trade negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The 97-member GATT is scheduled to conclude the current Uruguay Round of talks by the end of this year. ``If we can have a successful negotiation on export subsidies, a lot of countries around the world will benefit, including the United States,'' Yeutter told a telephone news conference with a group of farm broadcasters. Undersecretary Richard T. Crowder, who oversees international and commodity programs in the Agriculture Department, said EEP programs were ``in place for all the major targeted customers and markets'' of American farmers. Crowder said the subsidy programs served a dual purpose: achieving and maintaining a market share for U.S. agricultural exports, and ``for the trade policy effect that it will have on the (EEC), particularly as we enter the critical phase'' of the trade talks. ``So, we are prepared to use EEP as aggressively as possible to ensure our competitiveness in the world market against those $10 billion of export subsidies,'' he said. Yeutter, asked if EEC policies had changed as a result of trading pressure over the years, said there has been ``very little'' so far. ``They have been bringing their (domestic) price support levels down in a modest way over the last two or three years but not enough to have very much effect on production thus far,'' he said. ``We've been pointing out to them they need to bring those stratospheric supports down much closer to world market prices.'' The high supports stimulate production, and the surpluses are dumped on the world market through EEC export subsidies, Yeutter said. Yeutter was asked if the United States had backed off at last week's economic summit in Houston from an earlier position calling for the elimination of export subsidies. ``We have by no means altered the U.S. position,'' Yeutter said. ``We did not have to change it one iota in Houston.'' The key language used in the Houston agreement was worked out a year or so ago and remained unchanged, he said. It calls for a ``substantial, progressive reduction'' in subsidies. ``We believe that calls for ultimate elimination,'' Yeutter said. ``The EEC) knows that's our interpretation.'' But how long that might require is another matter, he said. The United States has proposed a five-year phase-out of export subsidies, but the EEC ``objects vigorously'' to that timetable, Yeutter said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Guard Sentenced to Eight Years For Heist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for story slugged AM-Brinks Guard Sentenced on News Advisory.
DOC.TEXT: A former armored car guard who stole $651,000 from a truck and claimed he gambled it away during two years on the lam was sentenced to eight years in prison Tuesday by a skeptical judge. U.S. District Judge Louis C. Bechtle imposed a stiffer sentence on Edward Leigh Hunt Jr. than guidelines suggested because Hunt refused to detail how the money was spent. ``I have some concerns about the gaps in information as to what happened to the money,'' Bechtle said. Guidelines indicated a sentence of 27 to 33 months, but the sentencing commission's intent was ``thwarted by a refusal of the defendant to cooperate,'' the judge said. ``The system, I believe, is being used,'' he said. Hunt, 26, stole the money on Jan. 20, 1988, from a Brooks Armored Car Service truck parked outside a center city bank. He said said he spent the next two years in Hollywood, gambling illegally on sports and buying California lottery tickets, sometimes a hundred at a time. Two years later, ``I was broke so I turned myself in,'' he told Bechtle. Hunt surrendered Jan. 20. He pleaded guilty in April to one count of interstate theft in a plea agreement that required him to tell investigators where the money went. Hunt, a Wilmington, Del., resident and son of a former Delaware deputy attorney general, told the judge he feared facing additional illegal gambling charges if he detailed where the money went. Assistant U.S. Attorney Frederick Herold said the judge made it clear when Hunt pleaded guilty that participating in the investigation into the whereabouts of the money was very important. ``The big question in this case from the government's point of view,'' Herold told the judge, ``is did he really gamble the money away?'' Hunt was also fined $3,000 and ordered to make restititution to Brooks. The maximum sentence allowed was 10 years, and Herold said Hunt would probably serve nearly all eight years, unless he gets time off for good behavior. ``There is no parole,'' he said. Hunt showed no emotion as Bechtle pronounced sentence. His attorney, Albert J. Raman, put his hand on Hunt's shoulder. Raman declined to comment on the sentencing. Hunt spoke briefly, telling the judge that ``jail's a terrifying experience,'' and suggested his sentence include outside work. ``I'd like to help Philadelphia by picking up garbage or removing graffiti _ some kind of public service,'' Hunt told Bechtle. The day after his theft, Hunt said, he got on a train and three days later was at a Holiday Inn in Hollywood. ``They wouldn't take anyone who didn't have credit cards, and I only had cash,'' Hunt told the judge, prompting chuckles from spectators. He said he lived in a hotel and an apartment on the same block as the Holiday Inn. Hunt claimed he planned to use a ``gambling system'' to quadruple his stake and pay back the company half his proceeds. He said he bet heavily on football and basketball through bookmakers because legal gambling in Las Vegas was too risky. ``As a fugitive, I wouldn't have lasted a week there,'' he said, referring to surveillance at legal gambling parlors and requirements to report winnings over $10,000. He said he spent $50,000 on state lottery tickets.

DOC.HEAD: Investigator Says Tougher Regulation of Medical Devices Needed
DOC.TEXT: Flaws in the Food and Drug Administration's regulation of medical devices may allow unsafe products on the market, witnesses told a House panel on Tuesday. Investigations by the inspector general of the Health and Human Services Department suggest the FDA's regulatory system may prevent the agency from detecting device problems early and acting promptly, Inspector General Richard Kusserow said. Kusserow said the problems with the medical device approval process ``parallel what we encountered in our extensive reviews of the generic drug division,'' which turned up evidence that generic drug companies had cheated on tests required to win FDA approval and bribed FDA officials. ``Although our findings here are similar, we have no evidence of these vulnerabilities manifesting themselves in any detected criminal wrongdoing,'' Kusserow told the House Energy and Commerce health subcommittee. The inspector general said that in addition to needing more internal controls over the approval system, the FDA also needs stronger authority to remove defective devices from the marketplace. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the committee, said, ``It is clear that the current statute does not adequately protect the public from unnecessary risks. In addition, the FDA lacks the resources and the authority to enforce the law.'' Dingell and Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., chairman of the health subcommittee, have introduced legislation to overhaul the law governing regulation of medical devices. It would require closer scrutiny of the most dangerous devices and require hospitals and other major medical device users to report deaths and other serious problems with medical devices to the FDA. It also would give the FDA more authority to remove products from the market. More than 1,700 medical devices are available in the United States, representing an industry of more than $17 billion a year, said Carl Wisler of the General Accounting Office. FDA Acting Commissioner James Benson said in his statement to the subcommittee that reporting the provision of the Dingell-Waxman bill ``is neither necessary nor feasible.'' He said he also opposes another provision that would require more devices to undergo more intensive scrutiny even though they were similar to devices already on the market. He said this provision ``would lengthen product review times, raise health care costs and impede the introduction of new technologies to the market.'

DOC.HEAD: Barry Prosecution Nears End; 10 Witnesses Have Said He Used Drugs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with afternoon testimony.
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors neared the end of their month-long drug and perjury case against Mayor Marion Barry on Tuesday after two women _ a former Carter administration aide and a Barry friend testifying under court order _ outlined a history of drug use with him. They were the ninth and tenth witnesses to testify they saw Barry use illegal drugs. Doris Crenshaw, who was a White House small business aide, said she had snorted cocaine powder, smoked crack cocaine and used cocaine-laced cigarettes with Barry _ including an episode at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. She said she began using drugs with him in 1985. Bettye Lynn Smith, who was flown in from Tennessee under court order, testified she had used cocaine with Barry many times and supplied him with it for years, including less than a month before his Jan. 18 arrest in an FBI sting operation. Reluctant to testify against Barry, whom she described as ``a close personal friend of mine,'' Smith appeared in court only after being ordered by a U.S. magistrate to return to the nation's capital to testify. She had been undergoing treatment for stress at a psychiatric hospital in Chattanooga. Crenshaw said she and the mayor used cocaine at the Democratic convention in Atlanta, where Barry was heading the District of Columbia's delegation. ``We used it at the hotel,'' Crenshaw said. ``It was powder cocaine.'' Crenshaw, who met Barry when both were active in the civil rights movement, described him as ``a very kind and understanding and sympathetic person.'' She said she first offered the mayor powder cocaine at her Capitol Hill home where ``we snorted it ... off business cards.'' Crenshaw also testified that she used drugs with Barry on Dec. 22, 1988, the day Barry's ties to Charles Lewis, who later pleaded guilty to drug charges, became public. She said she visited the mayor that day at the Washington hotel room of Willie Davis, a former aide to Birmingham Mayor Richard Arrington. There, Barry smoked crack cocaine out of a pipe fashioned from a drinking glass and tin foil, said Crenshaw testified. She said she also used the drug. Prosecutors expected to conclude their case Wednesday with testimony on Barry telephone records. The defense will then open its case, which could include testimony from 10 to 15 witnesses, said Barry attorney R. Kenneth Mundy. Since testimony in the case began June 19, 10 witnesses have said they saw Barry use drugs at a total of 14 hotels, 20 private residences, two businesses and on four boats in a period ranging from 1984 to the mayor's Jan. 18 arrest at a downtown Washington hotel. On Tuesday, Smith was questioned about her fitness to testify by U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who had demanded her return pending the dawn magistrate's hearing in Chattanooga. ``I'll try,'' Smith said, choking back tears. Once the trial questioning began, Smith described in a soft, calm voice a long history of drug use with Barry. Smith told the jury that she and the mayor snorted cocaine powder at her Capitol Hill home ``maybe five times'' in 1983 and up to half a dozen times a year after that until 1986 when she stopped using the drug with him. She continued to supply him, she said. On the other hand, Smith also testified she never saw Barry use or possess cocaine in the Bahamas _ even though other witnesses have testified that she and the mayor used drugs during a Thanksgiving 1987 trip there. Early this January was the last time she offered cocaine to the mayor, she said. He went in the bathroom and ``was in there long enough to use the cocaine ... but I don't know if he ingested it,'' Smith said. On Jan. 18, former model Rasheeda Moore persuaded Barry to come to her room at the Vista Hotel, where the mayor was arrested after being videotaped smoking crack cocaine. During cross-examination by Mundy, Smith said prescription antidepressants she had taken Tuesday morning prevented her from recalling exact dates on which she supplied the mayor with drugs. Barry is accused of 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession counts, one misdemeanor count of conspiracy and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury. Attending Tuesday's court proceedings was Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan, who was allowed access to the trial last week after the judge reversed himself. Jackson had previously barred the Muslim leader, ruling that his presence might intimidate witnesses and jurors in the case. At a lunch recess, Farrakhan termed the case ``an assault on black people in general.''

DOC.HEAD: OSHA Wants To Lower Limit For Asbestos Exposure
DOC.TEXT: The federal limit on workplace exposure to asbestos would be cut in half under a change proposed Tuesday by the Labor Department. About 700,000 American workers in general industry, mostly in auto repair operations, and up to another 1.4 million construction and building renovation workers would be affected by the revised guideline, said the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Now OSHA rules permit workers to be exposed to no more than 0.2 fibers of asbestos per cubic centimeter of air over an 8-hour period. The proposed change would cut that limit to 0.1 fiber per cubic centimeter of air over an 8-hour shift. ``OSHA believes that the proposals will significantly reduce worker deaths from cancer resulting from exposure to asbestos,'' said Gerard Scannell, the assistant labor secretary who heads OSHA. The revision to the OSHA standard will not take effect until after a public comment period and a hearing in October. The change also calls for: _Expanding the notification provision for owners of buildings where demolition, renovation and asbestos removal activities are taking place. Under the change, they would have to notify occupants of asbestos-disturbing activities and steps being taken to reduce exposure risks. _All employers engaged in demolition, renovation and removal operations other than small-scale, short-term operations would have to notify OSHA before starting work. The Environmental Protection Agency is phasing out, between this August and 1996, the future manufacture, importation, processing and distribution of asbestos in almost all products. OSHA's proposal would allow employers to meet the new 0.1 fiber requirement, without additional engineering control costs, by using respiratory protection for workers until the new EPA guidelines take effect. The change comes from a 1988 federal appeals court ruling that generally upheld the current standard but asked OSHA to re-examine several issues relating to asbestos.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets With Japanese Ruling and Opposition Party Lawmakers
DOC.NOTE: EDs: RETRANSMITS a0648 to DELETE extraneous sports matter and end and RESTORE missing original copy
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told a visiting delegation of Japanese lawmakers Tuesday that the relationship between the United States and Japan is ``absolutely vital.'' Bush discussed trade, Soviet relations, the breakthrough on Germany and other issues with the delegation of legislators from both the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and opposition parties. Kichi Miyazawa, a former deputy prime minister and senior member of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's Liberal Democratic Party, told Bush the U.S.-Japanese relationship was becoming ``more and more complex and important.'' He led a group of 11 lawmakers, including eight opposition party leaders. ``I hope I need not tell you this, but the relationship between Japan and the United States is absolutely vital, and it does not depend on the relationship the United States has with other countries. It stands on its own two feet,'' Bush said. Afterwards, Miyazawa told reporters he congratulated Bush on Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's agreement to NATO membership for the united Germany. Miyazawa also thanked Bush for his strong support at the Houston economic summit for the Japanese claim to the four northern territories controlled by the Soviet Union since the end of World War II. ``That will certainly facilitate our position when we are going to negotiate the matter with President Gorbachev'' when the Soviet leader visits Japan next year, Miyazawa said. Miyazawa said Bush also discussed the Uruguay Round of trade talks, but provided no details. Other Japanese officials said Bush stressed the talks cannot succeed unless agricultural issues are dealt with. The United States has applied heavy pressure on Japan to open up its rice markets. The president and the lawmakers also discussed the Japanese plan to resume a $5.4 billion loan to China interrupted last year after the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. Bush told Kaifu in Houston the United States would not stand in Japan's way, but the summit as a whole decided to keep economic sanctions imposed on China last year. Miyazawa said the Houston summit gave ``some understanding'' to the Japanese position on aid or China. He said Bush told the lawmakers that the summit countries expect China to take more ``concrete steps'' to respect human rights. Miyazawa is visiting China next week and he said Bush suggested he convey that message to the authorities in Beijing. Michael Armacost, the U.S. ambassador to Japan, attended the White House meeting with Bush, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and Robert Gates, Scowcroft's deputy.

DOC.HEAD: Artillery Accident Kills Five Israeli Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: An off-target 155mm artillery shell landed near reserve soldiers during a training exercise Tuesday and killed five of them and wounded 10, the army command said. It said three of the wounded were badly hurt. Less than three months ago, on April 23, seven Israeli airmen were killed in another training accident when their transport helicopters collided during a flight over the occupied West Bank. The army said in a statement that Tuesday's accident occurred when a reserve unit was conducting an exercise involving the capture of a position at a training base in southern Israel. Army officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the base was near Tzeelim in the southern Negev desert, 15 miles from the Egyptian border. Israel radio said the shell was fired by troops training at one section of the base and fell near other soldiers training in a different area. ``According to the information I have, the reason for the accident was human error,'' Maj. Gen. Uri Saguy told Israel army radio. Saguy, chief of army ground forces, was at the exercise and ordered an immediate investigation, the army said. One of those wounded, 29-year-old Yair Cohen, told Israel radio from his bed at Soroka Hospital in Beersheba: ``I stepped out of the armored personnel carrier and there was an explosion. ... I was hit in the leg by shrapnel. I felt pain in my leg and saw blood and started running.'' Israeli men up to the age of 55 serve up to a month each year on reserve duty after three years of compulsory service starting at age 18. One of those seriously wounded Tuesday was a female instructor.

DOC.HEAD: Beijing University Freshmen Return after Military Training
DOC.TEXT: Beijing University's freshman class completed a year of training at an army base and was welcomed back to campus on Tuesday by happy parents and curious upperclassmen. The 728 students were the first freshmen at the university since last year's mass pro-democracy movement. Beijing University students helped lead those protests, which were crushed by the army. Hundreds, perhaps thousands of people died when the army moved in on the Beijing demonstrators June 3-4, 1989. The freshmen were ordered to undergo a year of military training and political education at Shijiazhuang Military Academy before starting their regular, four-year classes. They lived the lives of soldiers, rising at 6 a.m. for marches and drills on marching, saluting, shooting and throwing grenades. They attended political study classes where they read the works of Marx, Lenin and Mao Tse-tung and heard lectures about the error of last year's protests. The class graduated from the academy last Saturday and will spend three days on campus for welcoming activities and orientation before going home. Upperclassmen watched the new students with interest, some with bemused expressions. A law school senior keep shaking his head and repeating, ``They're so young. They look so well-behaved.'' One mother, who waited more than an hour for the freshmen to arrive Tuesday, said she and other parents took turns making weekly visits to the army base, about 170 miles south of Beijing, the capital. ``We went to give them emotional support. They were really lonely out there,'' she said. As she spoke, a caravan of buses carrying the students dressed in army uniforms rolled through the school gate, under a red banner reading, ``Warmly welcome the class of 1989 from the military academy.'' The mother anxiously scanned the faces, waving a brightly colored skirt she had brought for her youngest daughter. ``What's the matter with them? They looked dumbfounded,'' she said. But other students were hanging out the windows waving happily to the crowd. Two even flashed V signs. A man and a woman took turns announcing flowery words of welcome on the school's public address system, between military marches. Friends embraced and parents rushed to take heavy backpacks from their children in an open area near a cafeteria. ``Happy? Of course I'm happy,'' one father said while loading his daughter's belongings on his bicycle to take to her dormitory. ``I haven't seen her since Spring Festival,'' or Chinese New Year in late February. His daughter, wearing her army uniform of olive shirt and dark blue skirt, said of the year of military training, ``Well, at least it's over.'' The State Council, China's Cabinet, last week announced that the new freshmen class this fall at Beijing University and Shanghai's Fudan University would also undergo a year of military training. At other schools, shorter periods of army training have been organized. The renewed emphasis on military training reflects leadership belief that weak ideological education was to blame for last year's pro-democracy movement.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo: Bush Administration `Just Might Change My Mind' About Presidency
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo said Tuesday that if Republicans keep challenging him to run for president, they just might get their wish. Democrat Cuomo, speaking to reporters in this town west of Binghamton, took note of recent partisan attacks from federal drug czar William Bennett and U.S. Rep. Newt Gingrich. ``Last night, Gingrich got up and said, `Let Mario run,''' Cuomo said. ``He said I should run, Bennett said I should run. They're being so nice about it, they might just change my mind.''
