Georgia Republican Gingrich told the audience at the annual New York Republican Party dinner Tuesday that Cuomo was a high-taxing liberal who should run for president to ``put to rest the claim that liberalism can win in America.'' Bennett last month came to Albany to attack Cuomo administration drug policy, daring Cuomo to run for president in 1992. Bennett told the New York Daily News this week he got a personal thank you call from President Bush after his comments on Cuomo. Cuomo spokesman Gary Fryer said Cuomo, who's running for a third term as governor, was just being humorous at his Nichols stop. ``With a little bit of fun, the governor is just trying to make the point that they're a lot more concerned about the future than he is,'' Cuomo said. ``He's still concerned about the present.''

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rains Bring Threat of Floods in Texas
DOC.TEXT: Rainshowers and thunderstorms during the afternoon Tuesday brought a threat of floods in Texas. In south-central Texas and Rio Grande plains of Texas, where rain and thunderstorms continued into the afternoon, the threat of further flooding continued. Beeville, Texas, got 10.64 inches of rain the 24 hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT. Up to 15 inches of rain fell in two days, causing extensive lowland flooding along the Guadalupe, Aransas, Nueces and Mission rivers. Showers and thunderstorms extended from Florida north through Virginia and west through the eastern three-fourths of Texas. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered over northwest California, parts of Nebraska, South Dakota, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New York state. Heavier rainfall in the 6 hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included 1.71 inches at Del Rio, Texas. Pueblo, Colo., tied its record low of 54. The record has stood since 1891. Tuesday's low in the Lower 48 states was 42 at West Yellowstone, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 54 degrees at Arcata, Calif., to 105 degrees at Palm Springs, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam, Rafsanjani Hope Iran-Iraq Talks Will Lead to Peace
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein said Tuesday he hopes Iraq's direct talks with Iran will lead to peace between the two nations, and Iran's Hashemi Rafsanjani also expressed optimism that a settlement was possible. The two Persian Gulf neighbors fought for eight years before the guns fell silent under a United Nations-sponsored cease-fire in August 1988. Foreign ministers Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran and Tariq Aziz of Iraq met in Geneva this month for their first face-to-face talks since the cease-fire. ``The Iranians responded favorably to our proposal for a summit meeting and we hope that recent diplomatic and ministerial meetings will pave the way for progress toward peace,'' Saddam said in a speech broadcast on state Baghdad Radio. His address marked the 22nd anniversary of the coup that put his Baath Arab Socialist Party in power. On Tuesday, Tehran Radio, monitored in Cyprus, quoted Rafsanjani as telling Tehran's Assembly of Experts: ``The talks have been fruitful, and the two countries are expected to move toward peace. ``The Iraqis, too, have adopted a more positive stand toward the establishment of peace.'' Rafsanjani was quoted as saying both Iran and Iraq realize now only ``the arrogant powers,'' a common Iranian reference to the United States and its Western allies, ``benefit from the no-war, no-peace situation in the gulf.'' The English-language Tehran Times, a newspaper close to Rafsanjani, urged that future meetings be held in Baghdad or Tehran. Iraq has been pushing for a Saddam-Rafsanjani summit. The Tehran Times said nothing was achieved at Geneva beyond creating an ``amiable atmosphere.'' U.N.-brokered talks began five days after the cease-fire but quickly collapsed. Iran insisted Iraq withdraw from territories occupied in the last weeks of the war. Iraq said Iran must agree first to dredge the Shatt-Al-Arab waterway, confluence of the Tigris and Euphrates rivers, of war debris. A 1975 treaty drew the border down the middle of the 120-mile channel, giving Iran navigation rights to the strategic waterway for the first time. Iraq unilaterally abrogated that treaty when it invaded Iran in September 1980 following border clashes, and demanded full sovereignty over the waterway. But Velayati told theologians in Qom on Tuesday the talks were being held within the framework of that treaty, Iran's Islamic Republic News Agency said. It quoted him as saying Iran would ``welcome goodwill gestures from Iraqi officials.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says de Klerk Visit Important to South Africa's Future
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday described his administration as a catalyst for dialogue in South Africa, saying it is important that President F. W. de Klerk now visit the White House after Nelson Mandela's recent trip. No date has been set for a de Klerk visit, although Bush extended an invitation earlier this year. Mandela, the African National Congress leader freed by de Klerk after 27 years in prison, met with Bush during a nationwide tour last month. Bush predicted that de Klerk's visit will be ``somewhat controversial'' because of widespread opposition to Pretoria's apartheid policies of racial separation. ``There will be a lot of picketers out here. I think they're wrong,'' Bush told a gathering of magazine publishers at the white House. ``I think in de Klerk you have a new kind of leader in South Africa,'' Bush said, adding that he had detected in Mandela ``quite a respect'' for de Klerk. Bush reiterated that U.S. economic sanctions against South Africa will not be lifted until there is more movement toward ending apartheid. But he also said he does not want the sanctions toughened. He said Mandela called him before he left the United States ``with a feeling that the United States government had been responsive and certainly interested.'' ``I think more than any of the European countries we can be catalytic. We were not a colonial power and we are united in our opposition to apartheid,'' Bush said. ``And then we have an Afro-American population here that feels fervently, this is a gut issue. And I think that's a good thing that might not be quite as prominent in other countries as well.'' ``Those ingredients make our country uniquely able to serve as a catalyst between the various factors in South Africa, and that's what I want to try to do.''

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Rejects Woman's Claim of Skin-Tone Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: An attorney for a black woman who lost her fight to prove she was fired from her IRS job because of her light skin tone says it was a difficult case to prove, and he doesn't know whether his client will appeal. ``She seemed confident, not totally surprised about it, a little upset, and said it's time to move on with her life,'' attorney Hillard J. Flint said after talking to Tracy L. Morrow. U.S. District Judge Charles A. Moye Jr. ruled Monday that Ms. Morrow lost her job because she had a poor attitude that eventually led to her dismissal, not because of her skin color. Ms. Morrow had contended she was targeted for harassment by her boss, Ruby Lewis, and was fired from her job as a clerk-typist for the Internal Revenue Service because of her lighter skin tone. Ms. Lewis had said that Ms. Morrow was error-prone, belligerent, frequently late and dishonest. In his ruling, Moye said, ``There was considerable testimony, not only from Ms. Lewis, but from others, that the plaintiff, unlike her fellow employees, may have been insubordinate, immature, impatient, disrespectful and unmanageable.'' Flint said that without testimony to support Ms. Morrow's claims, it was a ``difficult case to prove.'' Ms. Morrow, a former IRS temporary employee in Seattle, was hired in Atlanta as a clerk typist in 1985. She entered probation for a permanent position on Dec. 9, 1985, but was fired on March 14, 1986. Moye last year ruled that such light vs. dark, black-on-black discrimination is possible and that the issue should be decided in court. A non-jury trial was held earlier this year on Ms. Morrow's claims. Moye, who made his ruling after examining closing briefs filed by both sides, said Ms. Morrow failed to prove anything other than that there was animosity between the two women. ``Other than the testimony by plaintiff, the record is devoid of any testimony or evidence that would lead this court to believe that Ms. Lewis would be likely color-biased,'' the order said. Curtis E. Anderson, head of the U.S. Attorney's civil division, said he was pleased with the decision. Ms. Morrow, reached at her Union City home, indicated she did not know about the judge's ruling. ``Wow. Hmm. Wow,'' she said, before hanging up. Ms. Morrow had sought up to $60,000 in back pay and other payments, plus reinstatement to her job.

DOC.HEAD: Press Freedom Group Calls Meeting to Aid Media in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: The World Press Freedom Committee on Tuesday urged all organizations hoping to foster a free press in Eastern Europe to coordinate their efforts through a meeting next October. ``An entirely new dimension of needs and opportunities faces all of us,'' said Harold W. Andersen, chairman of the committee and former publisher of the Omaha World-Herald Company. ``We all need to know what is being done _ and not being done.'' He urged interested organizations to take part in a one-day conference at the National Press Club in Washington on Oct. 10. The 14-year-old committee, which represents 33 national and international news organizations from five continents, has already surveyed the media of Eastern Europe and has prepared a list of possible projects. It also has published a ``Handbook for Journalists of Central and Eastern Europe'' and is serving as a clearing house for media organizations to match needs and resources. ``A substantial number of people and organizations, both public and private, are trying to help,'' said Anderson. ``We need to share information as to who is doing what. This should help all parties avoid duplication and cooperate more freely.'' He said the committee wanted participation from every organization already helping East European media or even thinking about it and urged them to contact the committee's Washington office.
The commitee's address is: The World Press Freedom Committee, care of The Newspaper Center, P.O. Box 17407, Washington, D.C. 20041. Telephone: (703) 648-1000; Fax: (703) 620-4557; Telex: 292810.

DOC.HEAD: Drivers Buy Out Soviet Gasoline as Oil Shock Hits Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of drivers lined up at dawn Tuesday at pumps nationwide to buy cheap Soviet gasoline ahead of an anticipated price increase of at least 50 percent. ``The oil shock has hit the country a little sooner and in a more dramatic way than we have expected,'' Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus said. He told journalists oil supplies from the Soviet Union have dropped by one-third since Jan. 1 and said prospects for the rest of the year were ``very uncertain.'' Czechoslovakia imports 16.6 million tons of crude per year from the Soviet Union, the sole source of oil and natural gas for the country. ``The lower supplies of oil just happened. That is a fact. And the only way to cut consumption is to increase the prices,'' Klaus said. Pressed for figures, Klaus said the price rise would be ``probably more than 50 percent.'' But he refused to be more specific, saying the new prices would be announced later. Klaus did not say when the new prices would become effective, but Economics Minister Vladimir Dlouhy said Monday it would be ``a matter of days.'' The current price of gasoline in Czechoslovakia is about $1.10 per gallon. The average monthly income is about $200. During four decades of Communist rule, Czechoslovakia, like other East bloc nations, was fully dependent on the Soviet Union for oil. This spared them the oil crises the West suffered through in the 1970s. ``Right now and especially at the beginning of next year when imports from the Soviet Union will be payable in hard currency, we are going to pay for those two crises we have managed to ignore,'' Klaus said. Comecon, the Soviet-led Eastern trading bloc, has agreed to switch to hard currency accounting as of Jan. 1. Klaus said talks were underway with Venezuela, Iran and Iraq to try to secure other sources of oil. Planned radical economic reforms to begin next year are to raise prices in the country to approximate world levels while lowering the exchange rate and making the currency convertible.

DOC.HEAD: Six Arrested in Gay Rights Protest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with six people, sted five, arrested and CORRECTS police report on sex of those arrested
DOC.TEXT: Six people promoting gay rights were arrested Tuesday after staging a vocal sit-in in the office of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., authorities said. The four women and two men were charged with unlawful entry and demonstrating within a building in the Capitol, said U.S. Capitol Police Officer Dan Nichols. Each offense carries a maximum fine of $500 and six months in jail. The six were arrested in the reception room of Helms' Senate office. ``They started chanting, they sat down and refused to leave when ordered to,'' Nichols said. Lee Bush, a spokesman for the group, said the activists were upset because they believe Helms has blocked AIDS funding.

DOC.HEAD: Army Says Absent Soldiers May Have Been in Cult
DOC.TEXT: Six soldiers who disappeared from a classified intelligence unit in West Germany and believed to be members of a mysterious group called ``The End of the World'' have been caught in Florida. The five men and one woman, caught over the weekend in this Florida Panhandle city, were being held at Fort Benning, Ga., pending a counterintelligence investigation. However, Bob Hall, a spokesman for Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, said the counterintelligence investigation is being conducted as a matter of routine because the soldiers had access to classified information. ``The Army says this does not appear to be an espionage case,'' said Hall. Maj. Joe Padilla, an Army spokesman at the Pentagon, said he had no information about ``The End of the World'' group except that the six are apparently members. He could not say if it has any significance in the investigation, or how and when the Army came to know of their affiliation. ``I've heard of a lot of cults but this is a new wrinkle,'' said Gulf Breeze police Chief Jerry Brown. Dallas Blanchard, a sociology professor and cult expert at the University of West Florida in nearby Pensacola, said he hadn't heard of the group. All six soldiers were Army intelligence specialists assigned to the 701st Military Intelligence Brigade at Augsburg, West Germany, Padilla said. He wouldn't say exactly what jobs they performed but that their training was in analyzing foreign communications. The Army hasn't filed charges against the six soldiers, Padilla said. He said an absent-without-authorization allegation could encompass either absent without leave or the more serious charge of desertion. The disappearance came to the attention of military authorities on July 9, Hall said. Brown said that is the date they arrived in Gulf Breeze. Hall and Padilla said they didn't know how the six got to Florida from Germany. The absent soldiers had been staying with two Gulf Breeze women, Brown said. One of the women had met one of the male soldiers last year in Gulf Breeze and struck up a friendship. He called her and asked if the group could stay with them for a few days, Brown said. They were caught after one of the men was stopped by a police officer Friday night because the taillights on the van he was driving weren't working, Brown said. The man had no driver's license and warrants showed he had been listed on Thursday as wanted for desertion from the Army, the chief said. After officers called security police at the Pensacola Naval Air Station to pick up the man, the Navy called back to say he was traveling with five other soldiers also wanted for desertion or being absent without leave, Brown said. Soon after, representatives of the FBI, the CIA and the National Security Agency called his department as well, Brown said. Police learned that the five suspects might be at the home of the Gulf Breeze women. Officers arrested the four men Saturday. At the home, police learned the woman was staying at a nearby campground on the Gulf Island National Seashore near Fort Pickens, where she was arrested, Brown said. The two Gulf Breeze women are not suspected of any wrongdoing, but Brown said he may ask them some more questions after being told of the apparent cult connection. ``They are just scared to death,'' he said. He said the soldiers did little more than sleep and watch television while at the women's home. ``It sounds like they were just resting up and then they were out,'' Brown said.

DOC.HEAD: NTSB Cites Truck Driver In Texas School Bus Crash
DOC.TEXT: The driver of the truck that hit a Texas school bus last fall, sending it into a water-filled pit and killing 21 students, should have been able to stop despite faulty brakes, the National Transportation Safety Board said Tuesday. Forty-nine other students were injured in the accident near Alton last September. It was the nation's worst school bus accident since 1976. The lack of emergency exits _ there were only two _ contributed to the number of deaths, the board said. NTSB Chairman James Kolstad said that there were ``clear deficiencies'' in the truck's brakes but that driver Ruben Perez ``did not respond soon enough and he did not respond aggressively enough.'' Investigators found the truck's brakes were operating at about two-thirds strength, which should been enough to stop the truck. Perez had said he began applying the brakes 300 feet before the collision. Perez said that the brakes failed and that he began to use those on the truck's trailer, then downshifted gears to try to stop. Perez' attorney, Bob Binder of Austin, Texas, said the board was ``compounding a tragedy to put the blame on the driver when he was given a truck with bad brakes.'' ``The brakes were failing. They were not in complete failure but they were failing. So he (Perez) downshifted, which is the proper procedure, and applied the trailer brakes by hand,'' Binder said. Perez watched the NTSB hearing impassively. Binder would not let Perez talk to reporters, citing a lawsuit Perez has filed against Valley Coca-Cola Bottling Co., which owned the truck. The NTSB urged the bottling company to improve its driver-training and fleet-maintenance programs. Most of the victims drowned because they couldn't get out of the submerged bus, the NTSB said, calling for more emergency exits on school buses. It made a similar recommendation last year in its report of the May 1988 bus and truck collision in Kentucky that killed 27. That accident involved a school bus converted for use by a church. The Texas collision was the worst U.S. school bus accident since May 1976, when 29 were killed in a bus that plunged from a freeway ramp near Martinez, Calif. In the Texas accident, the bus fell 25 feet into a water-filled pit, flipped on its front end and settled. The windshield was forced out and water rushed into the bus. The way the bus settled rendered the rear emergency door useless. The NTSB recommended federal regulations requiring emergency bus exits that would not close once they are opened.

DOC.HEAD: Crisis Shows Power Politics, Patronage Still Dominate in India
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh's battle with his chief rival in the Cabinet showed Tuesday that old-style patronage still plays a big role in India's political life. But Singh's victory in the four-day government crisis also demonstrated that India's traditional power politics may be changing as the democracy matures. In last year's election, Singh ousted the Nehru-Gandhi family, which had governed India virtually since independence in 1947. Over the weekend, he forced the deputy prime minister, Devi Lal, to rescind the appointment of his son to a powerful local post. Singh, a self-styled champion of clean politics, emerged from the fight slightly muddied. ``No doubt V.P. Singh's image has suffered. The events have damaged his reputation, but he will come out of it,'' predicted Bhabani Sengupta, a political commentator for the Center for Policy Research. ``What happened was a clash between the old style of politics and the new style. Singh wanted to be democratic, but Devi Lal played the bad old game and he lost,'' Sengupta said in an interview. The crisis erupted last Thursday when Devi Lal engineered the reappointment of his eldest son, Om Prakash Chautala, as chief minister of the northern state of Haryana. Chautala, 55, previously held the post, but was accused of indirect responsibility for election violence in his constituency that killed at least 12 people, including an independent candidate. He was forced to quit May 22, but the violence was never investigated. News reports said his reappointment was part of a deal between Singh and Devi Lal to end a cold war between them. Denials from both failed to dispel all suspicion. Challenged by Devi Lal, Singh resorted to a threat to resign. Many commentators thought it was a ploy, and he retracted the threat within 24 hours. Before the conflict was resolved, 13 ministers in the 38-member Cabinet, or Council of Ministers, resigned and the workings of government came to a halt. Air force planes flew leaders from around the nation to New Delhi, where about 100 meetings took place in four days. The crisis ended Monday when Chautala agreed to step down ``for the good of the party.'' His father remained in the Cabinet, and the 13 ministers who quit were reinstated. But few believe the game has been decided. The skirmish exposed the deep cracks in the governing Janata Dal party, which dominates the five-party minority coalition and underlined the personal hostility between Devi Lal and Singh. ``After all this mudslinging, it looks they all are friends again,'' said Mool Chand Jain, a political analyst in Haryana. ``For them, political survival is more important than clean politics.'' Chautala inherited the post of Haryana's chief minister when it was vacated by Devi Lal, a former wrestler and landowner who built a power base on pro-farmer populism and political handouts. Indian news reports say that as many as 135 family members of Devi Lal received government favors in one form or the other. ``Dynasty is natural,'' Devi Lal said in a magazine interview recently. ``Everyone learns from the head of the family.'' He added: ``I appoint my relatives because I have got control over them. They will go by my directives.'' Former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi called the crisis an internal affair of the Janata Dal party, but Gandhi's supporters enjoyed watching Singh's difficulties. ``The events since Thursday have made it clear that the clean government Mr. Singh had offered us is just a mirage,'' said one official of Gandhi's Congress party.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Find People Can be Encouraged to Live More Healthy Lives
DOC.TEXT: People who eat too much fat and salt and don't exercise enough already may know better, but a five-year research project shows these destructive habits can be discouraged, scientists said. There may be as many as 525 people alive today in Salinas and Monterey, Calif., who would have died during the past 10 years if it hadn't been for specially designed health education programs there, said Dr. John W. Farquhar of Stanford University's school of medicine. ``Methods do exist for self-improvement,'' Farquhar said in a telephone interview Monday. After five years of community education, Farquhar said, the average plasma cholesterol level among residents in Salinas and Monterey was 2 percent below that of people in Modesto and San Luis Obispo, which were used for comparison. He said the pulse rate was 3 percent lower; the smoking rate 13 percent lower. These figures mask the study's true importance, Farquhar said, because people with higher levels would have experienced more dramatic declines. Using a method developed by other researchers, the data from Salinas and Monterey translates to a 15 percent improvement in the mortality rate and a 16 percent decline in heart attack risks. Billions of dollars could be saved annually by this kind of reduction in heart attacks nationally, said researchers, who reported their findings in Wednesday's issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association. Because so many people continue their unhealthy habits despite the risks, Farquhar and his associates reasoned that a program going beyond mere education was needed. So, they prepared a special series of radio, television and newspaper announcements and developed classes, meetings, mailings and other approaches for delivering their message. The idea was not only to instruct residents on what's healthy but also to train them on how to make changes. ``If you want to start a walking program, where to you get the shoes, what kind of shoes do you get and how do you get the friend down the block to go with you?'' Farquhar said, illustrating the kinds of practical questions his program sought to answer. ``Or how do you get a healthy meal at a restaurant'' without being obnoxious? he said. ``We got down to these kinds of specifics.'' Twice a week for a little more than five years, residents of Salinas and Monterey were indoctrinated with this kind of information. If the 15 percent decline in mortality rate proves accurate, it's far better than Farquhar's expectation. ``We would have been satisfied by 5 percent,'' he said. The Stanford researchers plan to count the number of deaths in Monterey, Salinas, Modesto and San Luis Obispo to establish a more precise mortality rate. The 15 percent cited in the study is an estimate based on the improvement in cholesterol, blood pressure and other health data. ``The study is very impressive,'' said Thomas M. Lasater, a community health educator at Brown University involved in similar research at Memorial Hospital of Rhode Island in Pawtucket. He said the direct medical costs for people with heart disease is equivalent to $300 to $400 a year for every person in the United States. Lasater said that if the improvement in mortality rate proves accurate, the nation could save $11 billion or more a year if Farquhar's methods could be applied across the country. The cost of Farquhar's program came to about $4 per person in the cities each year. Farquhar estimated that this is 4 percent of the annual per capita expenditure for cigarettes. ``What we're trying to do is get out a message of hope to policy planners, health specialists, educators and others that methods do exist to help communities help themselves,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Put Lid on Manhole Cover Heists
Ed: LEADS throughout with case solved: covers were used to boost weight of loads of scrap iron.
LaserPhoto LA3
DOC.TEXT: The mystery of the missing manhole covers was apparently solved Tuesday when some of the more than 185 purloined lids turned up at a scrap-metal yard. The case had police and city workers scratching their heads as covers disappeared at a rate of more than 25 a day for the past week. They even considering the possibility of some bizarre new fad among children. But on Tuesday, cast-iron manhole covers ranging in weight from 50 pounds to 200 pounds were found to have been sneaked into truckloads of higher grade iron sold to the Downtown Metal Center. The higher weight brought a higher price, said center manager Robert Kelman. ``The manhole covers are pretty flat so they can hide them well,'' said Kelman. ``Basically, they just used them to weigh down the load.'' No arrests had been made as of late Tuesday afternoon. ``Police are still pursuing additional leads,'' said Anna Sklar, spokeswoman for the city Bureau of Sanitation. The discovery of Los Angeles City manhole covers in piles of old pipes, truck bodies, and reinforcement bars solved the biggest mystery in the disappearances: What use were the things? Since the covers by themselves were worth only $1.50 each at scrap yards, police and city officials couldn't figure out why anyone would bother trying to steal the heavy, unwieldy covers. The thief was dubbed ``Manhole Man'' but police don't know whether it was a man, even a single person or a gang of thieves. One of the more unusual theories was the covers were being stolen by fans of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, stars of TV cartoons, mass merchandising and a hit movie. The turtles use manhole covers for shields. Most of the covers reported stolen were 2-foot diameter cast-iron covers placed over sidewalk storm drains, but the metals center received even larger, middle-of-the road covers. Detectives and workers at the metals center were digging through heaps of metal to find out how many manhole covers were in the yard and looking through files to trace the origin of the scrap metal containing the manhole covers. They didn't immediately report how many they had turned up. ``There is some kind of paper trail that can hopefully lead to people who did this,'' said Kelman. Loads of scrap metal aren't checked closely; the yard simply weighs the truck full, then empty. By weighing down the load of higher grade iron with the lower-grade cast iron manhole covers, the thieves stood to make about $10 more a ton, said Kelman. ``Not a lot, but it was something,'' he said. It had cost the city more than $15,000 to buy new covers and to pay labor costs to replace them or cover the holes with plywood. Officials were also worried a pedestrian could fall into the 2-foot holes, but so far no injuries have been reported.

DOC.HEAD: English-Language Newspaper Founder Fighting for Life after Attack
DOC.TEXT: The American founder of Venezuela's English-language ``Daily Journal'' on Tuesday was fighting for his life after thieves broke into his home, bound and gagged him and stripped the house of the valuables. Jules Waldman, 74, formerly of New York City, remains in intensive care at a Caracas hospital following the June 30 incident, Daily Journal editor Tony Bianchi said Tuesday. Waldman and his wife, Agnes, have lived in Venezuela for more than 40 years. They founded the 15,000-circulation Journal in 1945; Waldman is chairman of the board. Bianchi, who wrote an angry editorial urging the government to crack down on rising crime, said 25 of the Journal's 80 employees had been attacked during the past eight months.

DOC.HEAD: Court Widens Jurisdiction of Prosecutor in HUD Probe
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 7th graf: ``Thornburgh referred,'' to CORRECT Gilliam's title from assistant secretary to deputy assistant secretary; ADDS four grafs on work of consultants and lobbyists
DOC.TEXT: The independent counsel investigating former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. was given a significantly broader jurisdiction Tuesday to probe developers who received federal housing grants during the Reagan administration. The court that supervises the work of independent counsel Arlin M. Adams issued an order authorizing him to scrutinize developers, lobbyists or others who sought and obtained grants from three programs run by the Department of Housing and Urban Development from 1984 through 1988. Adams was appointed in March to investigate allegations that Pierce and other HUD officials had showed illegal political favoritism in awarding lucrative rent subsidies under the Moderate Rehabilitation Program. The order by the independent counsel panel of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here also authorizes Adams to investigate allegations of political favoritism in the operation of the Urban Development Action Grant program and the Secretary's Discretionary Fund for technical assistance and special projects. It also widens the circle of people who may be investigated to include officials of other government agencies ``or other persons and entities.'' Adams's review of the operation of the two additional programs was sought by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh in a May 25 letter to the independent counsel. Thornburgh referred to allegations made by DuBois L. Gilliam, a deputy assistant secretary at HUD, that political considerations were an important factor in the award of UDAG and discretionary funds. Gilliam, who is serving an 18-month sentence for corruption, told the House Government Operations employment and housing subcommittee that Pierce had ordered HUD to award grants to politically connected developers. In one instance, Gilliam said, Pierce had ordered the approval of a $5.6 million UDAG grant because his former executive assistant, Lance H. Wilson, was a private consultant for the developer of the Florida project. The original mandate authorized Adams, himself a former federal appellate judge, to investigate whether Pierce and other HUD officials ``may have committed the crime of conspiracy to defraud the United States or any other federal crimes'' in selecting developers to receive subsidies from the Moderate Rehabilitation Program. The broader mandate issued Tuesday empowers Adams ``to fully investigate and prosecute all government officials, or other persons and entities for any federal crimes, including conspiracy and aiding and abetting'' in connection with the operation of all three programs. Pierce, who ran HUD for all eight years of the Reagan administration, has denied any wrongdoing. He also told Congress that he did not participate in the day-to-day operation of specific programs and did not order his aides to award grants. But Gilliam offered a conflicting account in his congressional testimony, telling lawmakers that Pierce had ordered him to intervene in projects in Nashville, Cleveland and Miami that were backed by influential Republicans. Gilliam, who pleaded guilty to conspiring to manipulate the award of a grant and accepting $8,000 in illegal gratuities, is cooperating with Adams' investigation under a grant of immunity from prosecution, according to sources who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The investigation of the House subcommittee chaired by Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., also focused on the work of Republican consultants and lobbyists who helped clients deal with HUD. These consultants included Paul Manafort, a partner in the political consulting firm of Black, Manafort, Stone & Kelly, and James Watt, an interior secretary in the Reagan administration. Manafort, a leading campaign strategist for President Bush, acknowledged to the panel that he engaged in ``influence peddling'' to help steer millions of dollars worth of HUD funds to a project he partly owned. Manafort said his firm was also paid $326,000 to help developers get HUD backing for a project in New Jersey. Watt said he met with Pierce to help developers win $28 million worth of Moderate Rehabilitation Program subsidies for a suburban Baltimore project.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Present Closing Arguments in Senator Suicide Case
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. John East committed suicide because government doctors failed to diagnose and treat him for a thyroid disorder, attorneys for the North Carolina Republican's widow told a federal judge Tuesday. ``This is a case about a death that never should have occurred,'' attorney James Hourihan said in closing arguments in Priscilla East's $3.5 million wrongful death lawsuit against the federal government. East, convinced that late diagnosis of his condition had permanently impaired his intellect, killed himself in his garage on June 29, 1986, with carbon monoxide from a running car. He left a note blaming his doctors, saying they ``ruined my health.'' But federal attorneys said East, 55, freely chose to end his life and had been pronounced cured of hypothyroidism for 11 months when he died in Greenville, N.C. ``This man was able to control himself, was lucid in the last six months of his life,'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Ira Oring. U.S. District Judge Walter Black Jr., who heard the case without a jury, took it under submission, saying he would rule in a timely manner. He did not set a date. During an eight-week trial, Mrs. East's attorneys tried to prove that Navy doctors, who provide medical care for Congress members, were negligent in John East's care. Hourihan said that if physicians had administered a simple blood test as early as April 1983, they would have detected East's thyroid deficiency. Hypothyroidism occurs when the thyroid gland fails to produce the hormone needed to regulate the body's metabolism. Hourihan noted that for 52 years East had overcome such obstacles as partial paralysis by polio, his brother's suicide and parents' deaths. He pointed out that East was a lawyer and political science professor at East Carolina University before being tapped to run for the Senate in 1980 by the National Congressional Club, the political organization of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. East lapsed into a coma when he was admitted to Bethesda Naval Medical Center in April 1985. Not long after he regained consciousness, East tried to kill himself by ramming a chair leg down his throat, a manifestation of the psychotic state induced by extreme hypothyroidism. East's condition was diagnosed when a hospital resident ordered the appropriate blood test. Hourihan said that whether or not East's thinking abilities actually were damaged after his metabolism was returned to normal, the senator believed they were beyond repair. Hourihan said the fact or the belief created in East an irresistible impulse to kill himself attributable to Navy doctors' failure to treat the senator according to medical standards. Hourihan faulted Rear Adm. Freeman Cary, head of the congressional medical office, who Hourihan said treated East for a myriad of symptoms over two years. ``Dr. Cary treated each of these problems separately, he never put them together and tried to evaluate them,'' Hourihan said. But government defense attorney Oring contended that Mrs. East's attorneys failed to show East's suicide was inevitable and a direct result of the late diagnosis of his thyroid disorder. Oring showed a portion of a one-hour cable television interview with the senator in May 1986, a month before his death, in which a poised and articulate East discussed national politics.

DOC.HEAD: Cosmonauts Walk in Space to Try to Repair Capsule Damage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with later report on cosmonauts. Vladimir A. Solovyev cq. Picks up 7th graf, `It was...'
DOC.TEXT: Two cosmonauts took a walk in space Tuesday to try to repair a thermal blanket that has partially ripped apart and could interfere with their safe return to Earth, Soviet media reported. Cosmonauts Anatoly Solovyev and Alexander Balandin opened the hatch of the Mir space station as the orbiting spacecraft entered the shadow of the Earth, Radio Moscow reported. They moved along the outside of the station to their Soyuz TM-9 capsule, which is docked to the Mir, to inspect and make decisions on whether they could repair the thermal insulation, the radio report said. ``According to the results we have gotten so far ... we can almost definitely state that it (the thermal insulation problem) will not affect the landing,'' Vladimir A. Solovyev, a former cosmonaut and the flight controller, said in a live report from Baikonur Space Center on the evening news program ``Vremya.'' He said the landing would take place on Aug. 9, as scheduled. The cosmonauts experienced some delays during their space walk, but caught up to their schedule and the time spent on the walk would total more than 4{ hours, the controller reported. There were no further reports immediately in the Soviet media on whether they actually repaired the thermal insulation or other results of their space walk. ``Vremya'' showed a fuzzy picture of the spacecraft, with what appeared to be flapping thermal insulation. Part of the insulation has been flapping uselessly for months. Earlier Tuesday, a correspondent for ``Vremya'' displayed some of the tools the cosmonauts would use, including what looked liked a large pair of shears. Soviet officials extended the cosmonauts' flight until Aug. 9 to give them extra time to make the repairs, Soviet newspapers reported last month. They had been scheduled to return July 30 after nearly six months in space. It was the latest in a series of problems in the Soviet Union's manned space program, which for decades has been a source of national pride. For the past two years, the program has been plagued by docking equipment malfunctions, human error and budget cuts. Soviet officials have minimized the danger, saying the capsule could withstand such damage to its thermal blanket, the newsaper Izvestia reported. James Oberg, an American specialist on the Soviet space program, agreed. ``I don't think there's danger. I think there's anxiety over something more going wrong,'' Oberg said last month in an interview. Nearly half the thermal blanket has separated from the capsule and a 6{-foot-long section is hanging off, attached only on one side, the newspaper Trud reported. The damage probably occurred during launch of the capsule Feb. 11 when a ground rescue structure scratched the thermal blanket, according to deputy flight director Viktor Blagov. The American magazine Aviation Week and Space Technology reported May 21 that because of the damage, the Soyuz spacecraft had cooled and moisture built up inside. Izvestia said temperature changes could damage equipment needed for re-entry. The space station is being turned twice daily to keep the damaged section in the sunlight so it stays warm, and hot air is being pumped from Mir into the capsule to prevent a moisture buildup, Izvestia said. But Izvestia also said part of the ripped shield is blocking an infrared sensor used for navigation, meaning a manually controlled landing might be necessary. In addition, Izvestia said, the ripped section might catch on an antenna attached to the Mir as the Soyuz capsule undocks. Oberg said there was little threat the capsule would burn up during its re-entry into the atmosphere because the thermal blankets are separate from the shield used to protect the craft in that phase of the flight. A new crew is scheduled to be launched Aug. 1 to occupy Mir after Solovyev and Balandin leave.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Blames Apartheid for Regional Wars in Southern Africa
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said Tuesday that there could be no lasting peace in the southern African region until apartheid was ended in his homeland. The black South African leader said his country's white-minority government bore a large responsibility for the civil wars in Mozambique and Angola that have continued since the mid-1970s, the Mozambican national news agency AIM reported. ``As long as apartheid exists, there can be no lasting peace in Mozambique, or anywhere else in the region,'' Mandela told a rally in the coastal city of Beira. ``A peace based on democracy and justice for all in South Africa will result in establishing permanent peace in southern Africa, especially in Mozambique and Angola,'' Mandela said. Mandela is scheduled to return to South Africa on Wednesday, his 72nd birthday, after a six-week, 14-nation tour of Africa, Europe and North America to rally support for the African National Congress. Mandela, the ANC's deputy president, is expected to meet soon with South African President F.W. de Klerk to arrange further talks aimed at clearing the way for full-scale constitutional negotiations. Both sides say they want to negotiate a new constitution that will give political rights to the 30-million black majority. Mandela's tour has raised millions of dollars for the ANC as it formally re-establishes itself after being legalized by de Klerk in February. Mandela has also been urging foreign leaders to maintain economic sanctions against South Africa despite de Klerk's reforms. During the 1980s, South Africa openly supported rebel movements in Mozambique and Angola that were opposed to the Marxist governments of those countries. South Africa signed a mutual non-aggression pact with Mozambique in 1984, but until last year was repeatedly accused of violating the pact. South Africa signed a peace treaty with Angola in 1988 shortly after removing all its troops from that country. The wars in Angola and Mozambique continue despite recent peace talks aimed at resolving both conflicts. An estimated 600,000 people, mostly civilians, have died in the 13-year-old insurgency waged by RENAMO, the Portuguese acronym for the Mozambican National Resistance, against the leftist government. The war has left this former Portuguese colony one of the world's poorest nations. The annual per capita income is about $200 and almost half of Mozambique's 15 million people require some level of food assistance. In Angola, the rebel National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or UNITA, has been fighting the government since the country gained its independence from Portugal in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: When Insomnia Strikes, President Likes To Nod With A Novel
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 6th graf: ``He said,'' to CORRECT name of book to ``Evening News'' sted ``Network News
DOC.TEXT: When President Bush needs help sleeping, he reaches not for the medicine cabinet but for the bookshelf. The president said on Tuesday he doesn't have much use for the popular sleeping drug, Halcion. Instead, he said he likes to read about former presidents, Wall Street brokers and sleuths. ``Most of my reading is formal and heavy going,'' Bush said when asked at a newspaper publishers' gathering what he reads for fun. For pleasure, he said he picks things that are not ``particularly weighty,'' he said. Recent selections, he said, included ``Bonfire of the Vanities,'' Tom Wolfe's novel about a Wall Street bond broker involved in a criminal case. He said he was reading ``Evening News,'' by Arthur Hailey, Robert Caro's biography of former President Lyndon Johnson, a couple of books on Theodore Roosevelt and a mystery ``May Day Man'' by William Beecher. Bush said he likes to do ``a relaxed kind of reading'' before going to sleep ``instead of taking one of those ... Halcion sleeping tablets _ a good novel will help.'' Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said, ``No,'' when asked if the president had ever ingested the drug. Bush said a lot of his reading is from the CIA which has ``marvelous studies of things all around the world.''

DOC.HEAD: New Trouble for Protester at Site of King's Death
DOC.TEXT: A protester who was just evicted from her campsite at the motel where the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. was killed faced a new threat Tuesday: a summons for blocking the sidewalk at her new protest camp. Jacqueline Smith had camped in front The Lorraine Motel for more than two years _ ever since deputies evicted her from the motel itself _ to protest the construction of a civil rights museum there. Ms. Smith pitched her tent on the other side of the street after sheriff's deputies acting on a court order carried her from the original campsite Monday. She had hardly settled in, however, before city police handed her a summons for blocking the sidewalk. She was scheduled to appear in court Sept. 5, and a police commander said the city would order her to move if she is convicted. ``I intend to remain right here,'' said Ms. Smith, 39, a former motel employee who wants a homeless shelter or medical clinic built on the site. Much of the small, downtown motel has already been demolished to make way for the National Civil Rights Center, which is to open next year. The wing where the civil rights leader was shot to death on April 4, 1968 is being restored and will serve as the museum's centerpiece. Inspector David Dugger, commander of the neighborhood's police precinct, said Ms. Smith is charged with blocking a sidewalk with her tent and other belongings. ``We'll leave her there until such time as she has her day in court,'' he said. Ms. Smith's first camp was on state property, but she moved onto city land Monday after her eviction, Dugger said. The court order to evict was issued last week after the construction company said Ms. Smith was in the way. The Lorraine was in disrepair when when it was sold at a foreclosure auction in 1982. It took another several years for the citizens group that bought it to persuade the state, county and city governments to build the museum.

DOC.HEAD: Next Round of El Salvador Talks in Costa Rica on July 20-25
DOC.TEXT: The next round of direct talks between the government of El Salvador and rebels will take place in Costa Rica from July 20 to 25, U.N. officials announced Tuesday. A statement said leaders of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, FMLN, will meet government officials, with the participation of Alvaro de Soto, the U.N. secretary-general's representative for Central America. The last round of talks was held six weeks ago in Caracas, Venezuela. The discussions are expected to focus on arranging a cease-fire. Further details were not disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: Serbian Leader Closes Founding Socialist Party Congress
DOC.TEXT: Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic on Tuesday closed the founding congress of the republic's Socialist Party with a pledge that the renamed Communists would not veer from their political objectives. In a bid to discard their conservative image, Serbia's ruling Communists merged with a sister organization and renamed themselves the Socialist Party. Milosevic, who also is Serbia's president, was elected leader of the new party. It seeks to unite all left-wing groups in the largest Yugoslav republic. ``The left should not fear that this party will swing toward the right, while the right should not hope that this party will come closer to them,'' Milosevic said. In the weeks preceding the merger between the Communist party and the republic's Socialist Alliance, a Communist-run mass movement, Serbia's still illegal opposition denounced the move as a sham designed to keep the Communists in power as long as possible. The growing opposition, which has demanded free elections in the republic, says the merger gave the Communists control of the Socialist Alliance's substantial assets and media it currently controls. Two Serbian opposition groups, in another show of dissent, on Tuesday scheduled a memorial Mass throughout the republic for Gen. Draza Mihajlovic, a former leader of royalist Chetnik guerillas who fought Communist partisans in World War II. About 2,000 anti-Communists hailed Serbian Chetnik Movement president Vojislav Seselj, who praised the general as a ``hero and martyr,'' and denounced the Serbian Communist regime. The rally also cheered Mirko Jovic, the leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, another nationalist party, and sang Serbian nationalist songs. Police tried on two occasions to stop the rally on grounds that it was not officially approved, but the gathering ended without incident. Mihajlovic, depicted by the victorious Communists as a war criminal, was executed after a brief trial on July 17, 1946. Notices printed by the newly-formed Chetnik party and calling for Serbs to attend the church commemorations and a rally in downtown Belgrade were torn down by police, newspaper reports said. Croatia and Slovenia, Yugoslavia's two westward-leaning states, earlier this year held the first free elections in the country in 45 years. Both ballots were won by center-right parties. The founding congress was marked by infighting among delegates over who should be included in the Socialist Party's new 111-member ruling council. Several speakers complained that most of the proposed members were in the Communist Party leadership. Milosevic gained popularity in Serbia for virtually abolishing the autonomy of the republic's Kosovo province, where ethnic Albanians make up a majority of the people. Earlier this month, Serbia disbanded Kosovo's Parliament after 114 ethnic Albanian deputies announced plans to declare Kosovo's independence from Serbia.

DOC.HEAD: Mentally Retarded Inmate Sentenced to Death
DOC.TEXT: A mentally retarded man was sentenced to death Tuesday for a second time for raping and fatally stabbing a young woman in 1979. Jurors deliberated for about 2{ hours before deciding Johnny Paul Penry, 34, should be executed for the death of Pamela Carpenter, 22, the sister of former National Football League kicker Mark Moseley of the Washington Redskins. The state District Court jury, which last week convicted Penry of capital murder, could have sentenced Penry to life in prison or death by injection. Penry showed no emotion when the verdict was announced. ``He asked me what the verdict was,'' said defense attorney John Wright. ``I think he did not understand.'' Wright and fellow defense attorney Robert Smith said they would appeal. Mrs. Carpenter's mother, Rossie Moseley, expressed relief at the verdict. ``This can't bring Pam back. But really, I think he deserves the punishment,'' she said. District Attorney Joe Price said he was hopeful all along of a death sentence, but feared questions about Penry's mental retardation would hamper the jury. ``I was delightfully surprised,'' Price said. ``They didn't get confused over the judge's instructions.'' In final arguments, Smith urged jurors to sentence Penry to life in prison. ``He deserves very severe punishment,'' Smith said, standing behind Penry with his hands on his client's shoulders. ``It is right to punish him. It is wrong to kill him.'' ``If there's anybody in this room who believes in the death penalty, it's Johnny Paul Penry, because he inflicted it,'' said Polk County District Attorney Joe Price. ``He's got no internal controls, no remorse, no conscience. He's dangerous.'' Tests have shown Penry has an IQ of about 60 and the reasoning capacity of a 7-year-old. Penry has been on death row since 1980, when he was convicted and sentenced to die for Mrs. Carpenter's slaying. In 1986, he came within hours of lethal injection before getting a stay. The case went to the U.S. Supreme Court, which upheld the constitutionality of executing retarded killers. But the court vacated Penry's sentence, agreeing with defense attorneys that the jury should have been told of Penry's retardation. In his charge to the jury Tuesday, State District Judge Joe Ned Dean pointed out they must weigh mitigating circumstances. Mrs. Carpenter was stabbed repeatedly in the chest with a pair of scissors she was using to make a Halloween costume for her niece. She described her killer to police before dying in a hospital emergency room. Penry, who confessed to the slaying, had been on parole for about three months after serving two years of a five-year term for rape.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Approves $11.5 Billion in 1991 Defense Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Appropriations Committee voted Tuesday to limit defense spending next year to $294.9 billion, $8.4 billion less than President Bush wants. The 24-4 bipartisan vote was only the most recent indication that in light of improving relations with the East, Congress intends to give the Pentagon less than the White House thinks is right. All 15 voting committee Democrats and nine of its 13 Republicans voted for the $294.9 billion figure. Both Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, chairman of the Appropriations defense subcommittee, and the subcommittee's ranking Republican, Sen. Ted Stevens of Alaska, complained that the defense figure was too low. But Appropriations Committee Chairman Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., whose panel also adopted limits on spending for domestic and foreign aid programs, said the deficit was putting pressure on all programs. ``Tough choices will be necessary for all subcommittees,'' Byrd said. The figure the appropriations panel approved is halfway between the defense spending totals that have been approved by two rival Senate committees. The Senate Budget Committee, headed by Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., a negotiator at the budget talks between Congress and the White House, would cut military spending to $293.4 billion. The Senate Armed Services Committee, whose chairman is the influential Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., has voted for a level of $296.4 billion. The figure adopted by the Appropriations Committee is the starting point from which the panel's members will craft military spending legislation for fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1. The number could change, however, if budget negotiators work out a deal. Their talks have been under way for more than two months. Meanwhile in the House, the chairman of the Armed Services Committee and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., reached a tentative agreement on Tuesday for the panel to begin crafting a fiscal 1991 defense bill later this month. Committee action on the bill was not expected until September, but the panel's subcommittees will likely start work on the legislation the week of July 23, said the committee's ranking Republican, Rep. William Dickinson of Alabama. Unlike the Senate Armed Services Committee, which crafted a bill based on its chairman's total of $289 billion, the House panel will draw up legislation based on the lower House-approved budget of $283 billion, $24 billion less than requested by Bush. It faces opposition from Republicans and conservative Democrats. ``It's going to be horrendous, gut-wrenching,'' Dickinson said.

DOC.HEAD: James Meredith Accuses NAACP Delegates of Involvement in `Drug Culture'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to move up background on Meredith and Helms race against black candidate, clarify when statement was made. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: James H. Meredith, a civil rights pioneer who now works for Sen. Jesse Helms, contended Tuesday that a cadre of white men control American blacks and their leaders. Meredith made the allegation when asked about a charge he made Monday that many of the delegates to last week's NAACP convention are ``involved in the drug culture.'' Helms, R-N.C., is running for re-election against Democrat Harvey Gantt, a black who was mayor of Charlotte. Helms said he did not approve in advance the statement Meredith issued Monday on Helms' stationery, but said he generally agreed with it. When informed of Meredith's comments, Gantt said, ``I don't know what the heck he's talking about.'' Meredith, who in 1962 was the first black to enter the University of Mississippi, was active early in the civil-rights movement. But he soon fell out with such mainstream organizations as the NAACP and has been a harsh critic of the civil-rights establishment. He argues that the laws those groups advocate just reinforce the concept that blacks are inferior to other Americans. In the news release, Meredith said had background profiles on more than half of the 3,000 delegates to the NAACP convention in Los Angeles, ``and over 60 percent are involved in the drug culture and at least 80 percent are involved in criminal or immoral activities.'' He said Tuesday he stood by the allegation. Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, responded by calling Meredith ``an intellectual vagrant _ lacking any visible means of support.'' ``We call on Sen. Jesse Helms ... to disavow this statement and to take appropriate disciplinary action against Mr. Meredith,'' Hooks said in a statement issued in Baltimore. ``It would serve no useful purpose to address such ludicrous accusations from one who has obviously lost touch with reality.'' Meredith maintained all high-level black government officials owe their positions to the purported group of 15 whites. That includes, he said, ``the chairman of the Democratic party, the mayor of any city, city councilmen in most cases in the big cities, any high-level position in city government.'' He said he knew the names of the 15 men, but refused to divulge them. Helms, who hired Meredith as a special assistant last year at a salary of about $30,000 a year, defended his aide. ``It is his right to express his opinion and I would think the press would respect that _ even if he does not espouse the liberal ideas the press supports,'' Helms said. ``The press in North Carolina seems bent on injecting race into this campaign, rather than fairly reporting the facts.'' Meredith also said that blacks had more control over their lives during slavery than they do now. ``Until 25 years ago, the black race had control of all their domestic affairs,'' he said. And he accused black leaders, especially leaders of the NAACP and the Democratic Party, of not caring. ``I bet you there were not 10 people in that convention who lived near the black community,'' he said. ``Three thousand people don't have the right to sell the interest of 30 million people. Meredith said his prime sources of information on the NAACP's leaders were ``people who were there,'' and said he has a nationwide network of connections. He added that this activity was not part of his official duties. The news release dated July 14 was mailed to North Carolina reporters at Senate expense. It said, ``According to reports in The Washington Post, the 3,000 delegates at the NAACP's 81st National Convention `were unanimous' in agreeing that black officials are being harassed by government prosecutors. Why are they taking this stand?'' ``I think we need to look into the backgrounds of these so-called leaders,'' Meredith said. He called upon the NAACP's Hooks and two other black leaders _ Democratic National Committee Chairman Ron Brown and National Urban League head John Jacobs _ to reveal whether they'd ever taken drugs and to discuss their ``moral standards.'' Jenny Terzano, a spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee, said Monday that Brown ``will submit to a drug test any day of the week if James Meredith submits to an IQ test.'' Calls to Jacobs seeking comment Tuesday were not immediately returned.

DOC.HEAD: Michigan Governor, Company Unveils Recycling Program
DOC.TEXT: State employees will recycle more than 2 million foam coffee cups a year under a program announced Tuesday by Gov. James Blanchard. ``This is really a milestone in recycling,'' Blanchard said at a news conference. ``It is not only good for state government, it's good for the state and it will set an example for other states.'' He described the program, sponsored by Dart Container Corp., as the largest polystyrene recycling effort in the nation. Blanchard and William A. Dart, the company's chairman, showed reporters the Mason plant where the foam containers will be turned into pellets, eventually to be sold and recycled as containers, coat hangers, toys and desk equipment. ``It proves how much we can accomplish when we work together,'' Dart said. ``There has to be a public interest in it to make it work.'' About 230 state employees will volunteer to help collect more than 2.1 million cups bought each year for use in 80 state office buildings in the Lansing area. The plant is about 10 miles south of Lansing. The program, which won't use taxpayers' money, will be expanded later this year to include state offices elsewhere. The company already has a plant in Ontario, Canada, and will be able to recycle more than 10 million pounds of polystyrene a year after it expands its center in Mason and opens new recycling centers soon in Leola, Pa., and Plant City, Fla. Michigan state offices already recycle paper and by October are projected to have collected more than 6 million pounds this year.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Devastates Holiday Resort, Looting Breaks Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with at least 279 reported dead, looting reported in Baguio, Aquino visit, minor editing to conform. No pickup
With LaserPhotos MLA7,13,15
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of residents of this devastated city endured severe food, water and power shortages on Tuesday, a day after a major earthquake nearly isolated this luxury mountain resort from the outside world. The quake, which measured 7.7 on the Richter scale, killed 82 people here and more than 195 elsewhere in the Philippines. Most of the Baguio casualties died in the rubble of four luxury hotels and 23 other buildings that were severely damaged. Hundreds more are believed still trapped in debris. President Corazon Aquino flew to Baguio early Wednesday to inspect the damage. ``I never thought in my entire life that I could see such destruction,'' said Ed Pangilinan, a spokesman for the Defense Department who accompanied Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos to the city 110 miles north of Manila. He said townspeople lined the streets begging for food as Ramos' party drove past. Philippine television stations reported widespread looting in the city Wednesday. Baguio was the town most heavily damaged by the earthquake, which left at least 279 dead. U.S. Embassy spokesman Stanley Schrager said about 1,500 Americans live in Baguio but there were no reports of deaths or injuries among them. The city's two funeral parlors have more business than they can handle and have refused to accept more dead. During his Tuesday tour, Ramos said he would ask for preservatives to be flown into the city so the dead could be safely stored until they can be properly buried. Tuesday, Rep. Raul Roco, assistant House majority leader, stood helpless outside the Nevada Hotel, which was ripped in half by the quake, shouting to his wife who was trapped inside. A frustrated Roco urged cadets of the Philippine Military Academy, located here, to help him rescue his wife. ``Sir, we want to help you but what can we do? How can we, with our bare hands?'' one cadet replied. The isolation of this mountain town, which helped make it a favorite resort among Filipinos seeking to escape the summer heat, hampered rescue effforts. Monday's quake closed the airport, knocked out telephone, water and electricity services and buried the access roads under tons of mud and stone. The military said it was unable to bring cranes, tractors and other heavy equipment to the city because of the landslides. The landslides also trapped hundreds of people in passenger buses, trucks and private cars. Food and fuel supplies in the city were reportedly running low. Col. Bienvenido Liclican, spokesman for the military rescue team, said the search for survivors has to be suspended at night because there is no electricity to power searchlights. Officials said it may take up to six months to clear the main highway linking Baguio with the rest of the country. Commercial life in this city of 120,000 has all but ceased. Most stores are closed, and residents are running out of food. One grocery store opened Tuesday but quickly shut its doors after setting off a stampede. Only one of the eight service stations is operating, and motorists must line up to buy the $4.50 of gas that rationing permits them. Since the quake struck thousands have been living in their cars or camping out in the city's park, fearful of returning to their homes. A U.S. Air Force engineering team joined the search for up to 1,000 people believed trapped in the rubble of 27 buildings. The damaged buildings included four luxury hotels that cracked under the force of the quake. The entire front section of the Hyatt Terraces Baguio, which featured a floor-to-roof inner atrium, tumbled down on the lobby area, trapping an estimated 150 people.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Leaders Called to Meeting over Mohawk-Quebec Standoff
DOC.TEXT: More than 250 Indian chiefs from across Canada were called into emergency session Tuesday to plan strategy in a land dispute case that has led to an armed standoff between Mohawks and Quebec police. One police officer has been killed, though responsibility in that death has yet to be fixed. Area residents have asked for military intervention, and the Montreal La Presse said possible vigilante action was being plotted. The paper said Tuesday that members of a citizens' movement, supported by some local business people, were ready to take action themselves if the Mercier Bridge into nearby Montreal stays blocked. A reporter was shown weapons stockpiled by the group. Mohawks from the Kahnawake reserve have blockaded the bridge for a week in support of the Oka Indians. As a result, people in the suburb of Chateauguay have had to spend an extra two hours a day traveling to and from work. Anti-native demonstrations have taken place at police cordons near the bridge, including the nightly burning of a Mohawk in effigy. The dispute stems from plans by Oka, a town 18 miles west of Montreal, to build a golf course addition on what the Mohawks say is ancestral land. Quebec police last Wednesday tried to tear down an Indian blockade and an officer was killed during a brief gunfight. Arrangements were made to ferry the convening Indian chiefs across the St. Lawrence River to the Kahnawake reserve Tuesday to avoid police roadblocks. Joe Norton, band council chief at Kahnawake reserve who invited the chiefs, said, ``I hope this will kick the federal government in the pants and get them moving ... to do something positive.'' Oka was quiet Tuesday. Quebec's native affairs minister, John Ciaccia, was expected to return for negotiations but did not arrive. The Mohawks announced late Tuesday they have called in lawyers who specialize in native affairs to help with negotiations. An Indian statement said William Kunstler of New York, a human rights lawyer and constitutional expert, and Stanley Cohen, a New York civil rights lawyer, will also join the Oka Mohawks. Kunstler, who has represented Indian groups in the United States, arrived at the Mohawk barricade in Oka Tuesday night. He said he waited 10 hours on a bus before being cleared for entry by Quebec police. On Tuesday, a Red Cross medical team went behind Indian lines at Oka to evaluate the health of seniors, pregnant women, children and the sick. A convoy of Red Cross supplies of food and medicine was also allowed onto the Mohawk-controlled territory. Canadian Forces soldiers and equipment were moved to Longue Pointe military base in Montreal on standby in the stalemate. An armed forces officer who visited the base told the Montreal Gazette on Monday he saw convoys of military trucks, armed personnel carriers, communications vehicles and anti-tank weapons. Capt. Alain Lefrancois, Quebec public affairs officer for the Department of National Defense, said Tuesday soldiers would not intervene unless asked to do so by the provincial government. Royal Canadian Mounted Police officers from across Canada also moved into the area to act as reserves for Quebec police in case fighting flares up again.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Embassy Official in Tokyo Charged With Smuggling Heroin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `Authorities in...,' to UPDATE with Nicaraguan government comment; INSERTS 1 graf after 10th graf pvs, `Rueda was...,' to UPDATE with description of arrested man's job. Pick up 11th graf pvs, `Palmer said....
DOC.TEXT: A Nicaraguan diplomat who allegedly recruited other embassy workers to smuggle heroin-filled suitcases into the United States and Australia was arrested in Tokyo on Tuesday, authorities said. William Tapia, recently promoted to the No. 2 position in the Nicaraguan Embassy in Tokyo, was charged in a federal indictment unsealed Tuesday with conspiring to smuggle heroin worth up to $21 million from Thailand to New York. He was dismissed from his job by the Nicaraguan government and arrested by Japanese authorities, acting on a warrant issued in Brooklyn, said U.S. Attorney Andrew Maloney. In Managua, the Nicaraguan Foreign Ministry said it had stripped Tapia of his diplomatic immunity at the request of the U.S. and Japanese governments so that he could be arrested. Tapia, 47, will be extradited to New York within 45 days to stand trial, Maloney said. Tapia worked since at least 1986 with two prominent Hong Kong dealers to smuggle heroin to New York and Sydney, Australia, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Cathy Palmer. The indictment, filed Feb. 6 in New York after an 18-month investigation, charges Tapia arranged two trips in 1987 for a Guatemalan diplomat, Jorge Rueda, to smuggle a total of 125 pounds of ``China White'' heroin to New York. Tapia received between $300,000 and $400,000 per trip for recruiting the diplomats. He is suspected of arranging at least four more trips, Maloney said. All of the diplomats recruited were from Central or South American countries and stationed in Tokyo, he said. Rueda was arrested in Australia in April 1988 on heroin importation charges and subsequently convicted. A Foreign Ministry official in Japan, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Tapia first came to Japan as the embassy's cultural attache in 1968. He resigned in 1979 but rejoined the embassy as first secretary in June 1986 and was recently promoted to counselor, the official said. Palmer said Tapia's arrest may not significantly affect the amount of heroin on the streets in New York, but that it would make it harder for Hong Kong drug lords to bring it in. ``It takes out a very secure method for smuggling _ using diplomats,'' she said. ``They are subject to almost no scrutiny upon arrival.'' U.S. Customs agents normally do not inspect the luggage of diplomats because of their status, Maloney said. Tapia faces at least 10 years and up to life in prison if convicted of all charges. The investigation is continuing and more arrests were possible, Palmer said. Also involved are the federal multi-agency Southeast Asian Heroin Task Force and authorities in Hong Kong, Australia and Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Dumping Complaint Filed Against Japanese Electronics Firms
DOC.TEXT: American makers of new type display screens for use in electronic gear of the future accused major Japanese competitors Tuesday of unfair price-cutting on U.S. sales. A petition filed by the Advanced Display Manufacturers of America asked the government to order penalty duties as high as 318 percent on Japanese imports that it said violate this country's anti-dumping laws. Dumping is selling at less than production costs or home market prices to capture an unfair share of a market. The petition filed with the U.S. Commerce Department named 12 Japanese electronic companies, including Sharp Corp., Matsushita Electrical Industrial Co. and Hitachi Ltd. Those three were identified as the major suppliers to the United States, with a total of 38.5 percent of the U.S. market in recent years. Japanese imports have captured 90 percent of the fast-growing, multimillion-dollar American market for flat panel display screens, a technology originated in this country, the petition claimed. The other firms named were Toshiba Corp., Fujitsu Ltd., Hoshiden Electronics Co., Kyocera Corp., Matsuhita Electronics Corp., NEC Corp., Optrex Corp., Seiko Epson Corp. and Seiko Indstruments and Electronics Ltd. The American manufacturers said the petition would also be filed with the U.S. International Trade Commission. The two agencies may decide to hold public hearings in a procedure that lasts about a year before the final decision on whether to charge penalty duties. Flat panel display screens are replacing the larger conventional cathode ray tubes that now form the screens of television receivers, word processors, and computers, aircraft control panels, medical imaging devices and other equipment. The technology would be incorporated in high-definition television. Members of American manufacturers association include Planar Systems, Plasmasco Inc., Ovonic Imaging Systems Inc., The Cherry Corp., Electro-Plasma Inc., Photonics Technology Inc. and Magnascreen Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Labs in Pittsburgh, Memphis Had Problems, FDA Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDS graf with comment from Memphis lab
DOC.TEXT: Inspections by the Food and Drug Administration of the top 13 laboratories that conduct a key test on generic drugs found problems at two, an agency spokesman said Tuesday. The problems were most severe at Biodecision Laboratories in Pittsburgh, where all but two of 13 studies reviewed by the inspectors violated FDA regulations or fell short of accepted laboratory practice, said FDA spokesman Don McLearn. Problems were also found at the University of Tennessee College of Pharmacy in Memphis, McLearn said. He said he did not know the specific problems there, but he said ``they're minimal ... they're clearly not to the degree as the one in Pittsburgh.'' The inspections at the 13 labs, which conduct 95 percent of the bioequivalency studies done on generic drugs, were conducted as part of a follow-up to disclosures of fraud and corruption in the generic drug industry last year. Eleven of the labs ``had no problems,'' McLearn said. Bioequivalency testing is aimed at showing that a candidate generic drug reaches the same concentration in the bloodstream as the patented drug for which it would be sold as a substitute after the patent expires. The inspection at Biodecision was conducted also as a follow-up to ``anonymous allegations of wrongdoing,'' according to the FDA inspection report. The document said ``allegations of poor science were found to be supportable. Evidence of fraud, conspiracy and conflict of interest was not.'' However, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce investigations subcommittee, wants the FDA to conduct more intensive examinations of the studies done by these labs on generic drugs that were approved based on those studies. Dingell, in a letter Monday, also asked Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan to instruct the FDA to come up with a plan by Aug. 8 to determine the validity of the Biodecision studies. Biodecision has conducted 20 percent to 30 percent of the bioequivalency studies that have resulted in approved generic drugs, Dingell said. ``Given the impact on the generic industry from corruption found to date, this latest revelation (concerning Biodecision) of impropriety is truly calamitous,'' Dingell said. McLearn said the FDA has not responded to Dingell's request for more investigation of Biodecision's studies or his request for more intensive investigations at the other testing labs. Dingell said that since the Biodecision inspection was triggered by fraud allegations, he doubted the inspections at the other labs were as intense. McLearn said Biodecision promised to correct the flaws. Company president Robert Lecher did not return a telephone for comment on Tuesday, but he was quoted by The Washington Post as saying, ``We view the entire process as very constructive and have taken it extremely seriously. We don't take issue or disagree with any of the observations.'' In Memphis, Gil Hayes, a spokesman for the College of Pharmacy, said: ``We have no information as to what the nature of the deficiency might be. We'll investigate that ... We feel quite confident that our College of Pharmacy has performed an exemplary service over many years.''

DOC.HEAD: South African Zulu Leader Criticizes ANC, Economic Sanctions
DOC.TEXT: The leader of South Africa's Zulus on Tuesday denounced the African National Congress refusal to reject violence and reiterated his opposition to economic sanctions against South Africa. Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi, whose Inkatha movement is the ANC's chief rival, also said the ANC was seeking political gain through confrontation. He warned that unless other predominantly black groups were included in constitutional negotiations with the white-led government, the ANC would have a stranglehold on black representation. ``South African revolutionaries, like revolutionaries everywhere, do not fight revolutions to enable other political parties to gain power,'' Buthelezi said in an address to the Center for Policy Studies. The center is a right-wing think tank that advises Britain's Conservative government.
