Buthelezi arrived in Britain Monday on a mainly private visit. ``(The ANC) is entirely wrong when it calls for continuation of the armed struggle; calls for the continued employment of economic sanctions against South Africa; calls for the general punitive isolation of South Africa in every way possible,'' he said. Inkatha, which claims 1.5 million members, announced over the weekend it had become a multiracial political party. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is the most outspoken advocate of easing sanctions against South Africa to reward President F.W. de Klerk for his reforms and his pledge to end apartheid. Apartheid establishes a racially segregated society in which South Africa's 30 million blacks have no vote in national afairs. The country's 5 million whites dominate politics and the economy. Nelson Mandela, the ANC deputy president released in February after 27 years in jail, says economic sanctions should remain until South Africa's black majority is enfranchised under a new constitution. The 12-nation European Community last month refused to lift its relatively mild embargoes, saying it needed further evidence that reforms were continuing. British Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave, who was in the audience Tuesdsay, said South Africa's public services for blacks were ``woefully inadequate'' for such a wealthy country.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Accused of Hijacking Returns to Soviet Union Contrite
DOC.TEXT: A 17-year-old who allegedly hijacked a Soviet jetliner to Sweden last month was extradited Tuesday to the Soviet Union, state media reported. ``Several rides in a Volvo and tasty lunches are not worth the punishment I will receive under Soviet law,'' a handcuffed Dmitry Semenov said to television reporters as he was put into a police car after returning to Moscow. Semenov was presumably referring to rides he had gotten in the Swedish-made Volvo automobile while in custody of Swedish authorities. Airline hijackings carry a penalty of 5 to 20 years in jail in the Soviet Union. Because Semenov is under 18, he faces a maximum of 10 years, according to Swedish Foreign Ministry spokesman Bo Heineback. urn was shown on the Soviet TV news program ``Vremya,'' and an account also was carried by the official Soviet news agency Tas Semenov's rets. Earlier Tuesday, accused Soviet hijacker Oleg Kozlov, 20, appeared in a Finnish court for the first time since he took over a Soviet domestic airliner June 19 and forced it to land at Helsinki's airport. Finnish Justice Minister Tarja Halonen was expected to decide this week whether to extradite Kozlov. The Supreme Court said last week there were no legal obstacles to his extradition. Soviet media have reported 11 airline hijackings this summer, with sison became religious in 1983 and threw away his collection of rock albums, but later resumed listening to the music. ``He couldn't do both at the same time,'' Mrs. Vance said. ``He was either true to the God of our church, or he was true to the god Judas Priest.'' Under cross examination, she said both she and her husband were heavy drinkers and had ``whipped'' James as a child. Her husband was also a compulsive gambler, she said. After the suicide attempt, James beat her up twice, once breaking her nose, Mrs. Vance testified. District Judge Jerry Carr Whitehead is hearing the case without a jury.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Textile Imports
NBC Names Programs Chief Tartikoff to New Post
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with quotes and details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Brandon Tartikoff, who as programs chief helped make NBC first in evening ratings for five seasons, was appointed Tuesday to head a new division that will try to find markets for network-produced shows. Tartikoff's duties will include devising programming ideas for NBC's in-house production company and overseeing the network's development think tank of executives for sports, prime time, daytime and late-night programs. The Tartikoff switch was announced Tuesday as part of a high-level reorganization of the network. Replacing Tartikoff as NBC entertainment president will be Warren Littlefield, whose post as executive vice president of prime time programs will be assumed by Perry Simon, the department's senior vice president. John Agoglia, executive vice president of NBC productions, also will now head the recently formed NBC Enterprises, which handles international distribution and other efforts by the network to diversify its business holdings. Tartikoff's admittedly ill-defined new job will consist of being the ``grand architect'' of NBC's ``big picture,'' he said. The 41-year-old executive took over NBC's prime time schedule 10 years ago and was hailed for pushing it out of last place into first for the last five seasons. His new post was created to breathe life into NBC's leading but aging programming and to hold onto executives such as Littlefield, whose contract expires next month. In an interview Tuesday, Littlefield said he asked for Tartikoff's job and got it. ``Brandon said he didn't want to sit in on these (prime time) meetings anymore and I said `Good. I don't want you here,' '' Littlefield said. ``Brandon was great about it,'' Littlefield said. ``This gives him more time to run NBC Productions and the development group.'' The NBC network currently serves more than 200 affiliates. NBC's announcement didn't specify what kinds of new outlets Tartikoff will seek for NBC-made productions. But the company is active in cable as a co-owner of CNBC and SportsChannel America. It also is a partner with three other companies in Sky Cable, a direct broadcast satellite program service scheduled to begin operations in late 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Social Democrat Lafontaine Makes Campaign Appearance in East Berlin
DOC.TEXT: West German politician Oskar Lafontaine, who says German unification is going too fast, used an East Berlin campaign appearance Tuesday to say the once-divided city deserved its place as a ``central European metropolis.'' He did not say what he thought about Berlin's becoming the capital of a united Germany, as most other East and West German politicians have suggested. Lafontaine only recently recovered from an attempt on his life. A disturbed woman stabbed him in the neck during the April party conference that nominated him for chancellor and he was rushed to a hospital in serious condition. His assailant was committed to a mental asylum. Social Democrat Lafontaine is Chancellor Helmut Kohl's main rival in general elections scheduled in West Germany for Dec. 2. The 42-year-old prime minister of West Germany's Saarland region has repeatedly criticized Kohl, a Christian Democrat, for proceeding too quickly with German unification. But Lafontaine could end up playing a major role in joint East-West German elections. Those elections, expected also on Dec. 2, probably will lead to formal unity that month. During his daylong East Berlin visit, Lafontaine said he would play an active role in the campaign for next October's elections in the five soon-to-be-established East German regions that are to make up the eastern part of a united Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Relief Organizations Work to Help Philippines, Relatives Worry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to UPDATE with new death toll, CORRECT that thousands homeless sted dead.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Philippines-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American relief organizations worked Tuesday to rush aid to the quake-battered Philippines as anxious relatives in the United States tried to find out if loved ones were among the dead or injured. ``Everywhere, people are saying they have relatives who are missing. It's all confusion,'' said Lindy Batara, of Fremont, Calif., executive secretary of the Ilocano National Association, an ethnic Filipino organization. Monday's earthquake, which registered 7.7 on the Richter scale and was centered about 70 miles north of Manila, left 283 dead, hundreds injured and thousands homeless, officials said. The Aloha Medical Mission, a Hawaii organization that sends physicians to the Philippines every year, planned to send medical supplies Tuesday night aboard a Philippine Airlines jet, said Pedro Chan, acting chief officer for the Philippine Consulate in Honolulu. Chan said the consulate had received some cash and clothing for earthquake victims. But he encouraged people to donate money to the Red Cross, which has set up a relief fund. Chan said the consulate was receiving calls about every 10 minutes from anxious Filipinos with relatives in the devastated area. ``Unfortunately, we don't have the names,'' Chan said. The AmeriCares relief organization in New Caanan, Conn., had supplies and volunteers in the Philippines before the quake, spokesman Steve Norman said. ``If a disaster had to occur in a place where we had to get to quickly, the Philippines was an ideal place,'' Norman said, explaining that the group had been working for some time there with the Knights of Malta, a Roman Catholic humanitarian group. An AmeriCares plane carrying medical supplies was to leave from Memphis, Tenn., early Wednesday, Norman said. The organization recently sent supplies to Iran after the devastating earthquake that reportedly killed 40,000 people. Norman said donations have been generous, but said people may be ``tapped out'' due to other recent disasters. Phone lines to the Philippines were jammed Monday by an unusually large number of calls, American Telephone & Telegraph Co. spokesman Randy Shields said in San Francisco. The company, following its policy in disasters, allowed more calls going out of the Philippines than coming in, Shields said. ``As each hour passes, it ought to be easier to get in,'' he said. In the San Francisco Bay area, where an estimated 400,000 Filipino-Americans live, the Ilocano National Association collected at least $14,000, Batara said. The Philippine Assistance for Technology & Health in Berkeley, Calif., and the Philippine Consulate also set up relief funds.

Checks to the American Red Cross relief fund can be sent to P.O. Box 37243; Washington, D.C. 20013, and should be earmarked ``Philippine Disaster Relief.'' Contributions by credit card can be made by calling 1-800-842-2200. Checks can also be sent to Philippine International Aid; Philippine Consulate; 447 Sutter St.; San Francisco, CA 94108.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuela Orders Three Former Top Government Officials Arrested
DOC.TEXT: A court ordered the arrests Tuesday of three former top government officials on corruption charges after they were accused of stealing $337,000 seized from alleged drug runners. The Public Service Court issued arrest warrants for former Interior Minister Jose Angel Ciliberto, ex-national intelligence director Porfirio Antonio Valera and former intelligence investigations director Juan Oswaldo Granadillos, the government news agency Venpres said. Ciliberto is believed to have fled the country after an arrest warrant was issued last week for him in a different case. The government did not say whether Valera or Ganadillos were in custody. All three served under former President Jaime Lusinchi, whose term ended in February. The three are accused of embezzlement stemming from a 1985 case in which $337,000 disappeared while in the care of the intelligence police. The money was seized from two Puerto Rican brothers who were arrested at Caracas's Simon Bolivar airport and accused of drug trafficking. They remain in jail. The warrants are the latest in a series of corruption charges made by the government of President Carlos Andres Perez. Warrants were issued for Ciliberto and for 11 other prominent figures by the same court last week, after the officials were accused of using state security funds to buy cars for pleasure and for an electoral campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Arrest 17 in Multi-State Drug Case
DOC.TEXT: Authorities Tuesday arrested at least 17 people accused of being part of a 16-state cocaine and marijuana ring, a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration official said. ``We feel confident we have pretty much immobilized an entire organization,'' said Gerard Murphy, the top DEA agent in Arizona. Another two of the 40 people indicted in the case were in Mexican jails, Murphy said. Twenty-one remained at large. Law enforcement officers also seized $1 million in cash, cars and other assets, he said. Since 1984, the southern Arizona-based ring has distributed 1,000 kilograms of cocaine, 305 tons of marijuana and 1 million methaqualone tablets around the country, Murphy said. He could not estimate the value of the drugs. The ring was headed by Michael Hooks, who has been in a Mexico City prison on Mexican charges since June 1987, the agent alleged. Murphy declined to release any other information about Hooks. Authorities arrested seven people in Tucson and one each in San Francisco, Mobile and Birmingham, Ala.; Nashville, Tenn., and Grand Rapids, Mich., Murphy said. Three other suspects were already in prisons in California and another was in Douglas, Ariz. Mexican officials have been asked to transfer Hooks to American custody, he said. Suspects were also being sought in Florida, Illinois, Oklahoma, Texas, and Arkansas, Murphy said. The ring also operated in Minnesota, Wisconsin, Ohio, New York, Pennsylvania and North Carolina. The DEA began its investigation after a plane crashed in 1985 near San Manuel, about 40 miles northeast of Tucson, Murphy said. The U.S. Customs Service, the Internal Revenue Service and the Arizona Department of Public Safety also took part in the probe. A 1986 raid in Tucson turned up 16 kilograms of cocaine and detailed drug ledgers containing ``staggering'' numbers, he said. The investigation earlier led to the indictment of Mexican marijuana trafficker Rafael Caro-Quintero on charges he operated a continuing criminal enterprise, Murphy said. Caro-Quintero, serving a sentence in Mexico City for his role in the kidnapping and torture murder of DEA agent Enrique Camarena, has been identified as one of the Hooks' organization's main suppliers of marijuana, Murphy added. The cocaine source has been narrowed to Medillin, Colombia, he said. The ring flew and dropped off all but two drug loads at clandestine Arizona airstrips for storage and subsequent distribution, he said. Murphy said the charges in the indictment returned June 28 by a federal grand jury in Tucson involved actions in 1985 and 1986. The indictments were the fourth set the grand jury has issued concerning the Hooks organization since June 1986, he said. In all, the grand jury has named 96 defendants and panels in Minnesota and Alabama have named another 14. Twenty-five of the 70 indicted previously remain fugitives, and all but one of the remaining 45 have been convicted.

DOC.HEAD: Dominican Police Fire Upon Election Protesters
DOC.TEXT: Security forces opened fire on rock-throwing protestors Tuesday in the provincial city of Bonao. It was the second day of protests against President Joaquin Balaguer's narrow election victory. One woman was wounded when a bullet struck her in the head, police said. Large-scale demonstrations also occurred in the three northern cities of Santiago, Nagua and San Francisco de Macoris, but no injuries were reported, police said. No disturbances were reported in Santo Domingo, the capital of 2.2 million people on the southern coast. However, the state university was closed because of clashes on Monday between police and students. Witnesses said the injured woman was wounded when police and soldiers opened fire on protesters who were throwing rocks at vehicles and shops in Bonao. Protesters also burned tires and set up roadblocks, according to police. Two protesters were wounded by police gunfire in separate clashes Monday in San Francisco de Macoris and the western city of Azua. The demonstrations were part of a 48-hour period of ``national mourning'' organized by Juan Bosch's Dominican Liberation Party to protest his defeat by Balaguer in the May 16 election. Bosch, 81, a former leftist president ousted by a military coup in 1963, accused the conservative Balaguer of widespread election fraud. Balaguer won the election with a victory margin of less than 2 percent. The Central Election Board announced the official results last week after a review of tally sheets and said it had found no evidence of fraud. Balaguer, 83 and blind from glaucoma, has served five previous terms as president of this Caribbean nation of 7 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Mega Borg Sold for Scrap
DOC.TEXT: The Norwegian tanker that exploded and burned in the Gulf of Mexico last month, has been sold for scrap. The 886-foot Mega Borg, which some worried would break up and spew its 38 million-gallon cargo of Angolan crude into the Gulf, was sold for about $2.4 million, attorney Robert Klawetter said Monday. He said the buyers' identities hadn't been disclosed. ``The ship is going to be towed to Karachi, Pakistan, where it will be broken up for scrap,'' he said. The new owners take possession Friday, he said. An explosion ripped through the pump room of the vessel June 8 as it was transferring the cargo to another vessel for transport to a Houston refinery about 57 miles southeast Galveston. Two men died in the explosion, two are missing and presumed dead, and 37 others were rescued by a nearby vessel. The U.S. Coast Guard estimated that 3.9 million gallons of crude escaped, but most of most of that burned or evaporated.

DOC.HEAD: Man Seized, Beaten at U.S. Compound in Havana, State Dept. Says
With AM-Cuba-Asylum a0735
DOC.TEXT: A man was beaten and taken away by Cuban police Tuesday as he tried to enter what serves as a U.S. diplomatic office in Havana, a State Department spokesman said on Tuesday night. The unknown man entered the grounds of the U.S. interests section of the Swiss Embassy shortly after 8 a.m., said the spokesman, David Denny. ``While he was on interests section grounds but before he could enter the building, he was seized, beaten and taken away by Cuban police who entered U.S. diplomatic property,'' said Denny. U.S. diplomats protested the action to the Cuban Foreign Ministry, he said. The United States and Cuba have had no formal diplomatic relations since 1960. Each has designated another country to be its formal representative in the other's capital, Switzerland in Havana and Czechoslovakia in Washington. In practice, U.S. diplomats work out of the old U.S. embassy in Havana under the name of the U.S. interests section of the Swiss Embassy. Cubans seeking asylum have invaded the Spanish, Italian and Czech embassies in Havana in recent days. Denny said he did not know whether the appearance of the man at the U.S. interests section was connected with those other asylum-seekers.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Press Claim that Electric Chair is in Tortourous Condition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 9-10, `The court...,' to UPDATE with federal court rejecting request, execution rescheduled. Pick up 11th graf pvs, `White, 42...
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for Florida's death row inmates have seized on a botched execution, arguing their clients would be burned alive in the state's electric chair. They contend the electric chair is broken, and have produced photographs of executed inmates in an attempt to prove that killing a person in the chair amounts to unconstitutionally cruel and unusual punishment. Two state-paid attorneys have even offered $4,000 to fix the 66-year-old chair. The issue has been raised in five appeals by death row inmates since the state's last execution May 4. Courts delayed the executions of all five, but in only one case did the chair issue play a role in a decision. Two other courts rejected the defective chair issue. The efforts began after the electrocution of Jesse Tafero. Flames and smoke shot from under the headpiece he wore. The state Department of Corrections and Gov. Bob Martinez have maintained that Tafero died instantly and that the fire was caused by a new, synthetic sponge under the headpiece instead of natural sponge used in other executions. The defense lawyers contend that Tafero was burned alive and that anyone else put to death in the chair would be subjected to the same torturous fate, thus violating the constitutional ban against cruel and unusual punishment. The faulty-chair issue was raised for the fifth time in an appeal filed with the Florida Supreme Court for Jerry White, who was scheduled for execution Wednesday at 7:01 a.m. The court on Tuesday rejected White's claims, but gave him his second 24-hour stay in as many days. His attorneys then turned to U.S. District Judge Patricia Fawsett in Orlando, who also rejected his claims in an order issued late Tuesday. His case now goes to the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. White's execution was rescheduled for Thursday at 7:01 a.m. White, 42, was condemned for shooting a customer to death during the 1981 robbery of a small grocery store in the central Florida town of Taft. The issue of the chair's condition was raised in the case of Judi Buenoano, who was granted an indefinite delay by a federal appeals court. The electric chair argument has been rejected in her appeals by a federal judge in Orlando and by the state Supreme Court, which said the chair's condition should be decided by the executive rather than the judicial branch. Defense attorneys argue that a broken head electrode lowered the level of electricity sent through Tafero's body from a fatal 2,400 volts to as low as 90 or 100 volts. Witnesses saw Tafero move and breathe after the first two jolts of electricity. He was pronounced dead after the third. Color photographs of the last nine men executed in Florida have been included in the defense motions in an attempt to show that the damage done to Tafero's skull and leg differs from the damage done to the head and legs of the eight men executed before him. Burn marks on Tafero's body show that he received a much lower voltage, according to the state agency that represents poor death row inmates. Last week, two agency attorneys offered to donate up to $4,000 to buy a new electrode. In exchange, they would drop the issue from one inmate's appeal. The attorney for a death row inmate executed last week in Alabama also argued that state's electric chair was defective. The appeal claimed that electric chair is inhumane, based on two instances in which inmates were not killed with the first flip of the switch.

DOC.HEAD: Christian-Dominated Party Returns to Power in Borneo Election
DOC.TEXT: The Christian-dominated Sabah United Party again won a majority of seats in legislative assembly elections in the Malaysian state of Sabah on Borneo, officials said Wednesday. The Sabah United Party campaigned on a platform of more autonomy for Sabah. The Elections Commission said that by early Wednesday the Sabah United Party had taken 33 of the 48 state assembly seats. About 70 percent of the 500,000 eligible voters cast their ballots Monday and Tuesday choosing among 251 candidates. Lawmakers will serve a 5-year term. The Malay-Moslem backed United Sabah National Organization of former Chief Minister Mustapha Harun won 12 seats. No results were available yet in the voting for the three remaining seats. In the last election, the Sabah United Party won 39 seats in the oil and timber rich state on Borneo island. Joseph Pairin Kitingan, a Catholic, retained his seat and will head the state government once again as chief minister, said party officials. During the campaign, Pairin had called for less interference in Sabah by the national government of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with Kinnock comments
DOC.TEXT: British opposition leader Neil Kinnock discussed with President Bush on Tuesday the growing momentum toward German unification and the need for Western aid to the Soviet Union. Kinnock, on a two-day visit to the United States, hopes to convince U.S. officials and lawmakers that his Labor Party would be as reliable a partner for Washington in the new Europe as the Conservative Party government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, or more so. Kinnock conceded that his party had traditionally been closer to the U.S. Democratic Party, but said his talks with the Republican administration were ``very amicable and rewarding.'' He said it was too soon to say whether Bush shared with Mrs. Thatcher the same close relationship she enjoyed with his predecessor, Ronald Reagan. ``I hope she won't be around long enough for us to find out,'' Kinnock said. Mrs. Thatcher has been prime minister since 1979, the longest tenure in office of any government leader in a major Western country. At the start of the 30-minute meeting with Bush in the Oval Office meeting, Kinnock was asked whether he shared the views of Thatcher's confidant, Nicholas Ridley, about ``uppity Germans.'' His reply was emphatic. ``Absolutely not. I know very few people who do.'' Ridley said in a magazine last week that the Germans were trying to take over Europe. The ensuing furor led him to resign as Mrs. Thatcher's trade secretary. ``We talked about how to help the Soviets without being patronizing,'' said Kaufman. Kinnock differs from Thatcher and Bush in believing Europe should help the Soviet Union with more than just technical advice, but loans and investments that could lead to the purchase of British goods. Kaufman said Kinnock congratulated Bush on his role n bringing about a relaxation of NATO's defense strategy at the 16-nation alliance summit in London earlier this month. The changed strategy enabled Gorbachev to make his decision about NATO membership for a united Germany, Kaufman quoted Kinnock as saying. Earlier, in separate meetings with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger, Kinnock emphasized Labor's support for a continued U.S. military presence in Europe. ``The continued U.S. presence is a matter of importance,'' Kinnock said he told the U.S. officials. Kinnock's visit was in sharp contrast to his previous trip in 1987, when President Reagan gave Kinnock less than 20 minutes in the White House, all the while criticizing Labor's demands for unilateral nuclear disarmament. Since then, Kinnock has persuaded Labor to give up that policy and to accept the presence of American troops and nuclear weapons in Europe. On Wednesday he will be guest of honor at a lunch given by Sen. Joe Biden, D-Del., who was forced to withdraw from the campaign for the 1988 Democratic presidential nomination after admitting he plagiarized a Kinnock speech.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Police Free West German, Arrest Kidnappers
DOC.TEXT: Police on Tuesday rescued unharmed a West German businessman abducted at gunpoint five days ago and arrested four people as kidnappers. Wolfgang Rudolf Prinz, 47, president of the Brazilian subsidiary of Aumund, a West German industrial equipment manufacturer, was seized by six men on July 12 when he arrived at his factory in Rio. TV networks said police trailed two suspected kidnappers to a two-story house in the Jacarezinho slum district. Law agents raided the house and freed Prinz, who was found tied up and with a brown plastic bag over his head. Prinz told reporters he was ``well-treated'' by his abductors, given food on an aluminum plate and beer. He was the 30th executive kidnapped in Rio since January and the first foreigner. About $16 million in ransoms have been paid.

DOC.HEAD: Dad Having `Bad Day,' Prosecutor Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The state...,' to CORRECT to Circuit Court sted Superior Court. Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A stepfather fatally injured a 2-year-old by plunging him headfirst into a toilet during potty training ``because he had a bad day,'' a prosecutor told jurors Tuesday in the man's murder trial. Thomas Coe, 23, sat expressionless as attorneys made opening arguments in the first-degree murder and aggravated child-abuse case, which has already brought changes in state law and prosecutions of several social workers. Bradley McGee died of head injuries July 28, 1989, two months after he was ordered returned from state foster care to his biological mother, Sheryl Coe, and her husband, Thomas. The defense insisted the parents were just toilet-training the youngster and believed they were doing right, even if they ``crossed the line.'' The state, which plans to seek the death penalty if Coe is convicted, focused opening arguments on the day leading up to the child's death. Early on, prosecutors told Circuit Court jurors, Coe flew into a rage, searching for a clean shirt for a job interview. He took Bradley and his wife with him and arrived late for the interview. On the way home, Bradley soiled his pants, the last straw for Coe, prosecutors said. ``That defendant right there,'' assistant state attorney William Jennings shouted, ``because he had a bad day, took Bradley back into the bathroom of that trailer, picked him up by the ankles and repeatedly plunged this small helpless child into that hard porcelain toilet. ``He fully confessed to having dunked Bradley into the toilet so many times he couldn't even remember,'' Jennings said. ``And the evidence will show that with Bradley's head still in the toilet _ he flushed it.'' After that, Coe put his stepson in the shower, then both parents beat him with pillows until he stiffened and collapsed, prosecutors said. Defense attorney Robert Norgard urged jurors to look at the facts and not be swayed by emotion. ``The bottom line is Mr. Coe did not torture Bradley and did not maliciously punish him as defined by law,'' Norgard said. The Coes were having trouble toilet training the boy and made a point of using ``negative reinforcement,'' Norgard said. ``In their minds they were doing what was right,'' he told the jurors. The defense also asked jurors to be wary of the testimony of Mrs. Coe, 21, who pleaded no contest to second-degree murder and aggravated child abuse and is serving 30 years in prison. She is expected to be the prosecutions' key witness, testifying that Coe routinely abused Bradley. Norgard said Mrs. Coe has given at least four different versions of events, trying to distance herself from the incident to make life easier for herself in prison. Bradley was placed in foster care after his mother abandoned him at a shopping mall when he was 3 months old. His death came after a state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services caseworker recommended a judge return the child to his mother, who by then had married Coe, despite a psychological report that questioned the couple's abilities as parents and explosive personalities. Public outrage over the child's death led legislators to change the law, placing child welfare above state attempts to reunite families. The case also brought unprecedented charges against four social workers over their handling of the case. Bradley's main caseworker was convicted June 15 of felony child abuse for negligence in recommending that the child be returned to the Coes. The other three were cleared.

DOC.HEAD: Young Man Charged in Firebombing at Wesleyan University
DOC.TEXT: A young man whose father was on Wesleyan University's faculty and whose cousin is accused of killing a school activist was charged Tuesday in the firebombing of the school's administration building. Federal authorities refused to release the suspect's name because he was a juvenile at the time of the April firebombing, and all court proceedings in the case were closed. However, police sources speaking on condition of anonymity identified the suspect as Sudhama Ranganathan, 18, of Middletown. Ranganathan's father, Tanjore Ranganathan, who died in 1987, was an artist in residence at Wesleyan for more than 15 years. Ranganathan was a friend of Nicholas Haddad, a 21-year-old Wesleyan activist who was shot to death July 6 by partners in a drug distribution ring, according to Hartford police. Ranganathan is also the cousin of Kumar Viswanathan, 21, of Hartford, who has been charged with murder and conspiracy to commit murder in Haddad's slaying. According to the arrest warrant, which was viewed by two reporters in Middletown before being sealed, Ranganathan is accused of maliciously damaging and destroying and attempting to damage the office of Wesleyan President William Chace, which was firebombed April 7. The warrant signed July 16 by federal Magistrate Arthur H. Latimer in New Haven also accused Ranganathan of receiving and possessing a firearm that was not registered to him. Ranganathan was arrested in Middletown, then taken to federal court in New Haven. He was 17 at the time of the crime. Prosecutors and agents from the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms refused to discuss the status of the case. But a U.S. marshal said Ranganathan was not being detained. He left the U.S. courthouse with Allan MacDonald, the chief ATF agent in New Haven. They then went to MacDonald's office with Assistant U.S. Attorney Bob Lynn. According to Hartford police, Ranganathan had traveled to Cleveland with his cousin after Haddad's slaying, but returned to Connecticut on his own. Viswanathan, who was arrested at a Cleveland bus station July 14, was arraigned Tuesday in Cleveland. The judge posted a $750,000 bond and Viswanathan waived extradition. Hartford police said Tuesday that arrangements were being made to return Viswanathan to Connecticut. According to Hartford police, Viswanathan said he met Haddad through his cousin in Middletown. Haddad was found shot in the head in Hartford's Keney Park in his car, which contained an undisclosed number of semiautomatic weapons. Haddad's activism on the Wesleyan campus had led authorities to believe he was linked to two firebombings at the school. But state prosecutors said last week there was no evidence to link the slaying and the campus attacks. The first bombing April 7 burned the rug and floor of Chace's office in the building and caused extensive smoke damage. The second firebombing April 29 caused only slight damage to the outside of the Wesleyan boathouse. Dressed in shorts and a tank-top shirt, and wearing earrings in both ears, Ranganathan was led in handcuffs early Tuesday afternoon into Latimer's courtroom. He left 45 minutes later with the handcuffs removed. He was then taken to the U.S. District Judge Ellen Burns, where he spent 25 minutes before being brought to the clerk of court's office for processing. A woman who answered the telephone Tuesday night at the Middletown home of Tanjore Viswanathan, the father of Kumar Viswanathan, said, ``None of the family has anything to say.'' The telephone number for Sudhama Ranganathan in Middletown is unpublished.

DOC.HEAD: New Parliament Elects Former U.N. Official as Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Bulgaria's freely elected Parliament on Tuesday chose as its chairman a former U.N. official who declared his opposition to past discriminatory policies against the country's ethnic Turkish minority. In a secret ballot, Nikolai Todorov, 69, the candidate of the ruling Socialist Party, received 217 votes. Stefan Savov, representing the opposition Union of Democratic Forces, got 172 votes. Seven deputes abstained and four were absent. The Grand National Assembly, or Parliament, still has to elect a new president to replace Petar Mladenov, who resigned July 6 after pro-democracy demonstrators claimed he favored using force to put down pro-democracy demonstrations last year. Todorov's election followed a morning session that was marked by an uproar reflecting lawmakers' inexperience with democracy. It was the Parliament's first regular meeting. A brief ceremonial inaugural session was held July 10 in Veliko Turnovo, the ancient capital. The furor erupted when Chavdar Kyuranov, the presidential candidate of the Socialist Party, tried to make an unscheduled address. Opposition deputies shouted and stamped their feet, not knowing that their own leadership had agreed to the late morning speech. The uproar was finally quieted by Premier Andrei Lukanov, who told the chamber of the agreement. Zhelyu Zhelev, chairman of the opposition coalition, confirmed it. When he finally got the floor, Kyuranov made a patriotic appeal for unity. ``Bulgaria is above all, above anyone. Bulgaria is above the opposition and above the majority (former Communists) as well, because in the whole economic, political and social pluralism there is one Bulgaria,'' said Kyuranov. It was a far cry from parliament meetings in the past when deputies routinely supported the policies of the orthodox Communist leader Todor Zhivkov, who was deposed by reform Communists last November. In the afternoon session, both Todorov and Savov underwent questioning by the lawmakers, a novelty in Bulgaria. Todorov said that in articles and interviews, largely published abroad, he had opposed Zhivkov's policy of persecuting the Turkish minority, which climaxed in 1984-85 when ethnic Turks were forced to change their Moslem names to Bulgarian-sounding ones. Todorov, a professor and member of the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, is the founder of the academy's Institute for Balkan Studies. He worked for several years at the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization and served as ambassador to Greece in 1979-83. The Socialists, the former Communist Party, won a majority of 211 places in the 400-seat Parliament in Bulgaria's first free elections in 58 years last month. The Union of Democratic Forces captured 144 seats. Smaller parties shared the remaining seats. It was not clear whether the Parliament would elect the country's new president when it reconvenes Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Head of Computer-Smuggling Ring Pleads Guilty
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of heading a scheme to smuggle a sophisticated computer with military applications out of the United States pleaded guilty Tuesday in federal court, officials said. The computer was bound for the Soviet Union, said U.S. Attorney Mike McKay, who announced the plea. Shiv Mohan of New Delhi, India, was ordered to pay $1.5 million in fines and forfeitures and could serve as much as 3{ years in prison, said U.S. Attorney Mike McKay. Mohan, 47, pleaded guilty to 24 counts of conspiracy to violate the Export Administration Act, money laundering statutes and other charges before U.S. District Judge William L. Dwyer. Sentencing was set for Sept. 10. Mohan admitted involvement in smuggling a DEC VAX 8700 computer out of the United States. He said he transferred $490,000 from Great Britain to the United States to purchase the computer. The computer was stopped in transit by commerce agents, who were tipped off and found it being shipped in several boxes marked ``spare parts,'' said Paula Boggs, assistant U.S. attorney. Four other defendants have also pleaded guilty in the case. Sentencing is scheduled for Aug. 3 for Robert Casperson, 44, of Kirkland, Wash.; John Townsend, 41, of Sydney, Australia; David Whyte, 42, of Toronto and Sham Malhotra, 47, of New York. Authorities still sought for two defendants who fled; Dr. Sidhartha Bose of London and T. Raganathan of Singapore.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Cubans Remain in Diplomatic Compounds; 12 Leave Czech Embassy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with State Department spokesman reporting Cuban detained trying to enter U.S. interests section in Havana; edits to trim. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: At least 12 Cuban asylum-seekers remained holed up Tuesday in diplomatic compounds in Havana, but another 12 Cubans voluntarily abandoned the Czechoslovak embassy where they had sought refuge, according to officials and news reports. Cuba's official Prensa Latina news agency quoted a foreign ministry statement as saying the Communist government would never yield to any ``pressure or blackmail'' by people seeking to leave the Communist island 90 miles south of Florida. In Washington, a State Department spokesman said a Cuban man was beaten and taken away by police Tuesday morning as he tried to enter the U.S. interests section in Havana. It works out of the former U.S. Embassy but officially operates under the auspices of the Swiss Embassy. ``While he was on interests section grounds but before he could enter the building, he was seized, beaten and taken away by Cuban police who entered U.S. diplomatic property,'' said State Department spokesman David Denny. U.S. diplomats protested the action to Cuba's foreign ministry, he said. The Spanish news agency EFE reported four Cubans seeking political asylum took refuge Tuesday afternon at the Italian ambassador's residence in Cuba's capital. The two men and two women first climbed to the roof of the ambassador's house after failing to gain entry, EFE said in a report monitored in Madrid, Spain. They later managed to get inside the building. Three Cuban asylum-seekers who took refuge last week remained at the Spanish embassy in Havana. A Spanish foreign ministry spokeswoman said a Cuban family entered the Spanish embassy Tuesday seeking refuge and assistance in getting to Spain. EFE reported the couple and their two children left the building several hours later after speaking to embassy officials. The four were carrying Cuban passports with exit visas, and had come to the embassy to request visas permitting them to enter Spain, EFE said. On Friday, Cuban police entered the embassy grounds in pursuit of a young Cuban who was attempting to seek refuge and arrested him. The Cuban foreign minister apologized for that incident after the Spanish ambassador sent a note or protest. Five Cubans remained holed up Tuesday in the apartment of the Czechoslovak Charge d'Affaires Jan Doemoek, according to a statement released by the Cuban foreign ministry. Another 12 Cubans voluntarily and unconditionally abandoned the Czechoslovak embassy on Monday evening, according to officials and news reports. The first Cubans had arrived there July 9. There were conflicting reports about the terms of their agreement to leave the embassy. The Cuban foreign ministry, in its statement released by Prensa Latina, said the 12 Cubans were detained for questioning in an investigation into what the Cuban government described as ``a planned provocation'' around the Czechoslovak embassy, according to Prensa Latina. It said the Cubans would not face prosecution because they had left the embassy voluntarily and would be allowed to return to their homes upon completion of the investigation. However, the statement indicated that they would not be allowed to leave Cuba. ``The elements who enter ... any Western embassy, if they do not merit asylum, will never leave this country in that manner,'' the statement said. A Czechoslovak foreign ministry official, Jindrich Opava, said by telephone Tuesday that he had no details on the circumstances of the asylum-seekers' leaving. Seven of the 12 Cubans took several diplomats hostage Monday at the Czechoslovak embassy. Czechoslovak television reported later that all the diplomats were released unharmed. Notimex, the Mexican government news agency, reported from Havana that the seven then shouted out a window they would blow up the embassy if their demand for a plane to the United States was not met. Cuba and Czechoslovakia had been close allies until last fall's democratic upheaval toppled Prague's hard-line Communist leaders. Cuban President Fidel Castro is one of a handful of surviving hard-line Marxist leaders after a reformist trend swept Eastern Europe last year. Castro, in his first official statement on the matter, called the asylum-seekers ``antisocial elements encouraged by Czechoslovak diplomats,'' the Czechoslovak newspaper Lidova Demokracie said Monday. Ramon Cernuda, an anti-Castro Cuban human rights activist in Miami, said that among the asylum seekers identified by the Cuban government were three noted dissidents. Novoa Ponce, Mari Becerra and Cabrera Puentes had been imprisoned last year after they formed a group to promote artistic freedom, Cernuda said. It was not immediately known whether they were among those who left the Czechoslovak embassy.

Western countries are praising Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decision to allow a united Germany the freedom to join NATO, calling it a turning point in European history. The decision, announced Monday by Gorbachev and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, was ``an extremely positive development in Soviet thinking,'' Britain's Foreign Office said. ``We have throughout argued that a united Germany in NATO would be in the best interests of all those concerned,'' it said in a statement. By dropping its objection to NATO membership for a united Germany, the Soviet Union removed the last big obstacle to German unification, which could be completed by December.

Authorities said today that about 200 people were killed in a major earthquake, and television reports said the worst affected areas were woefully short of blood, medicine and rescue equipment. Scores of buildings were destroyed by Monday's temblor and the death toll was expected to rise as rescuers pulled more bodies from the rubble. The Office of Civil Defense counted 193 dead and 595 injured in the quake, which measured 7.7 on the Richter scale and struck the country's main island of Luzon, including Manila. Its epicenter was 60 miles north of the capital. Officials complained that rescue efforts were hampered by a lack of heavy equipment to remove rubble.

News that the White House boosted its projection of next year's budget deficit caused barely a blip in the bond market, while the stock markets roared ahead to a record-high close. The reaction Monday _ or lack of one _ wasn't unusual, corporate economists say, considering the executive branch's horrendous track record on deficit figures. ``Private estimates both on Wall Street and elsewhere have been very large, and the market knew that,'' said James L. Kochan, chief bond market strategist at Merrill Lynch & Co. Kochan said White House budget reports ``have always been viewed with a high degree of skepticism as being somewhat tainted or being overly optimistic.''

Barring any intervention by a federal judge in today's Democratic primary, Andrew Young's gentlemanly bid to become Georgia's first black governor appeared headed for a runoff next month. The former Atlanta mayor, U.N. ambassador and congressman barnstormed the state Monday, promising to run more strongly in predominantly white areas today than pollsters and other observers expect. ``A lot of people who say I couldn't get votes in south Georgia have implied there's something backward about south Georgia, and I think they've underestimated south Georgia again,'' he said in Columbus. ``We're going to surprise people in where we get votes.'' Recent polls showed Young in second place in a tight, five-way race for the nomination, and the law provides for the top two finishers to meet in an Aug. 7 runoff unless someone wins more than half of today's votes.

The nation's first program allocating state money to poor parents so their children can attend private schools is nearing its autumn startup, but critics are planning a last-ditch effort to block it. The school choice plan, which has drawn praise from the Bush administration and Republican Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, faces a court hearing this month that could determine its immediate fate. The hearing is the result of a lawsuit, urged by state School Superintendent Herbert Grover and filed by opponents of the plan, that challenges the constitutionality of using state money for private schools. The Wisconsin Supreme Court declined to immediately review the lawsuit and referred it to Dane County Circuit Court, which has scheduled a July 28 hearing.

DOC.HEAD: European Mollusks Invading Great Lakes Are Here To Stay
DOC.TEXT: By JEFFREY ULBRICH= Associated Press Writer= TORONTO (AP) _ A small European freshwater mollusk called the zebra mussel has spread at an alarming rate since it was found in the Great Lakes in 1988, threatening the ecosystem and clogging up industry. Experts say there is no way to wipe the mussels out. ``In the Great Lakes, all we can do is accept the fact that they are here and learn to live with it,'' said Gerry Mackie, a biology professor at the University of Guelph who specializes in freshwater bivalves. Criticism in Canada focuses on the government's slowness in attacking the problem. ``The invasion of the zebra mussels was preventable,'' the Toronto Globe and Mail said in an editorial. ``Canada's complacency let it happen, and may enable similar invasions unless the country takes strong preventive measures.'' Joe Comuzzi, a Liberal member of Parliament, complained recently that Ottawa had committed only $230,000 ($195,500 U.S.) to the problem. He said that ``doesn't even pay for the paper to write a report.'' The mussel invasion has been expensive for Ontario Hydro, which has power plants along the lake shore. Zebra mussels produce a sticky thread that attaches them to solid objects _ water pipes in Ontario Hydro's case. The mussels are capable of sticking in such numbers that they stop or greatly reduce the flow of water. Large intake pipes are not affected, but the mussels swim up into the small-diameter service piping inside the plants. Their presence also leads to corrosion. ``It has cost us well over $6 million to retrofit all of the stations for this year, and it's costing us lots in research,'' said Renata Claudi, a senior scientist with the utility company. Representatives of 13 companies in the Chemical Valley of Sarnia, Ontario, got together this month to work out a common strategy against the mollusks. The zebra mussel, about 1{ inches in diameter, is a dark-colored, clam-like creature with white stripes. It has a larval stage of about a month when it swims with the currents. That accounts for much of its rapid spread throug the Great Lakes. Some of the mollusks hitch rides on ships up the lakes through Huron, Michigan and Superior and others swim down the current into the St. Lawrence Seaway. A female produces 30,000 to 40,000 eggs in each of its two or three years of life. Experts agree zebra mussels entered the Great Lakes system in Lake St. Clair in the summer of 1985 or 1986. They probably were flushed from the ballast of a ship that came from Europe. All the Great Lakes now are infested and scientists say their passage into the Mississippi River system is inevitable. ``They have gone through the Niagara River and into Lake Ontario,'' Ms. Claudi said. ``Now they are swimming their way toward Toronto.'' Scientists are not sure what the ecological impact will be, but are fearful of it. ``You have to keep it in perspective,'' said Joe Leach, a research scientist with the Ontario Natural Resources Ministry. ``The major impacts right now are with the technical devices, pipes and so on. We ... are looking at potention impacts on ... fishes, but at the present time there is no indication of major ecological impact.'' Leach said the main fears were disruption of spawning for fish like walleye, which lay their eggs on hard, rocky areas, and that the food chain would be altered. ``These things are filter feeders,'' he said. ``They filter an enormous amount of water and take everything out of it. What they don't use, they put mucus around and drop it down to the bottom.'' That shifts a lot of organic matter from the water to the bottom of the lake. Leach said it eventually could change fish populations by reducing the number of water column feeders, such as walleye and trout, and increasing catfish, sturgeon and other bottom feeders. There also is increasing evidence of zebra mussels attaching to other bivalves and smothering them. ``As it stands now, there isn't anything you can do,'' Leach said. ``There is no way you can control them. If you use poison, you are going to poison the system.'' Ontario Hydro uses chlorine, the most effective molluscicide found so far. In one affected plant, Ms. Claudi said, the company ``applied sodium hypochlorite in relatively small doses for about two weeks. That basically did them in and all we had to worry about was cleaning out the shells.'' She added that the amount used, in an agreement with the Environment Ministry, ``is never more than 10 parts per billion. Compare that with the five parts per million of the same stuff in the drinking water we happily drink every day.'' Ms. Claudi says Ontario Hydro was talking to other utilities across the lakes, the American Waterworks Association and Electric Power Research Association, ``but we're finding that we are way ahead or at the same level as these guys'' in research. Most experts believe the zebra mussel population eventually will level off and perhaps even decline, but Mackie said the problem was ``trying to determine at what point they will level off or if they will crash.'' Geoff Holland of the federal fisheries and oceans department said Canadian officials probably would meet with provincial and U.S. representatives this fall to work out a budget for fighting the zebra mussel. As for Ontario Hydro, Ms. Claudi said: ``Prevention is really what we're looking at. We just don't want those guys in our pipe.''

DOC.HEAD: Little Italy: Smaller and Smaller
DOC.TEXT: Little Italy is getting smaller. Squeezed by gentrification from Soho to the north and by immigration from Chinatown to the south, the nation's most famous Italian-American enclave is turning into a Mediterranean version of Colonial Williamsburg. Little Italy, says urban folklorist Joseph Sciorra, is ``a Disneyland for suburbanites who want to recharge their ethnic batteries.'' Buildings on Mulberry Street still are filled with Italian restaurants, cafes and food stores, but the names on the mailboxes for the apartments upstairs _ and the deeds _ are Chinese. ``It just isn't an Italian-American community,'' says sociologist Donald Tricarico. ``There's an ethnic economy with nothing underneath. Young Italians have been leaving for years.'' ``This is really Little China,'' says restaurateur Anthony Luna. ``I don't know why they call it Little Italy.'' Little Italy, once a 50-block area stretching from Broadway to the Bowery and from Houston to Canal streets, is now less than half its original size. There are only a few thousand Italians left, many of them elderly. Of the 4,200 legal immigrants who moved into the 10013 ZIP code between 1983 and 1987, 3,727 came from China, Taiwan or Hong Kong. Just 11 came from Italy. Even the Mafia is not the same, certainly not since Little Italy's most famous mob restaurant, Umberto's Clam Bar, was seized by the government. ``The tough guys are still around, but they don't live in the neighborhood,'' says Tricarico. ``They commute.'' That includes John Gotti, reputed boss of the Gambino crime family, who crosses the bridge from Queens every day in his Mercedes. Italians began moving into lower Manhattan in the 1880s, and between 1890 and 1924, they displaced their Irish predecessors on the blocks along Mulberry Street. By 1932, 98 percent of the residents were of Italian birth or parentage, and as late as the 1950s, many young people stayed to raise families. But the tenements got older and even more crowded, and confidence in the neighborhood was undercut by plans _ since abandoned _ to build an expressway through it. Italians fled to the suburbs in vast numbers; today, neighboring Westchester has more Italian-Americans than any county in the nation. Meanwhile, neighboring Chinatown's population was rising from 11,000 in 1941 to more than 70,000 now. For years, Canal Street had divided the two communities, but in the 1970s the Chinese began to spill across that cultural moat. There was some resistance _ graffiti was scrawled on some of the new Chinese signs _ but the newcomers paid top dollar. In 1980, a real estate man named John Zaccaro _ the husband of former vice presidential candidate Geraldine Ferraro _ was quoted as saying that 70 percent of the district's buildings were owned by Chinese. Today, buildings with Italian names carved into the masonry bear signs with Chinese characters, and the floors above the Italian restaurants are occupied by Chinese workshops. Lendy's on Grand Street, for years a popular Italian hardware store, is now a popular Chinese hardware store. But Little Italy is sustained by its two enduring assets: its food and its mobsters, a combination that seems to appeal to tourists. The Chamber of Commerce says Little Italy gets about 100,000 visitors a month, and a seven-story tourist hotel _ the neighborhood's first _ is scheduled to break ground later this year. Although the Mafia's influence has shrunk along with the neighborhood, ``the publicity about the Mafia is good for the restaurants,'' Tricarico says. ``People come in to drink cappuccino and see the mobsters.'' The chief attraction is Gotti, who eats lunch at restaurants like Forlini's and Giambone's, where he frequently shares the dining room with prosecutors and judges from the court buildings nearby. Sated, he repairs to the Ravenite Social Club for meetings with associates. A walk past the Ravenite, a modest brick storefront at 247 Mulberry, has become part of the Little Italy experience, along with pasta at Angelo's and cannoli at Ferrara's. Other stops include Umberto's, where ``Crazy Joe'' Gallo was shot in the back while dining on the seafood combination; Benito II, outside which Salvatore ``Sally Bugs'' Brigulio was gunned down; and Ruggero, where former Gambino consiglieri Joseph N. Gallo _ no known relation to Crazy Joe _ often sat at a table in front of the bar. Sometimes the neighborhood seems like a movie set, and sometimes it really is. Earlier this spring, a make-believe street fair with sausage vendors and ``Kiss Me I'm Italian'' buttons was staged by the makers of ``The Godfather, Part III.'' After a big shootout scene, one elderly onlooker said she was thrilled _ she'd never seen anything like that in the real Little Italy. In fact, as the Mafia's schemes have grown larger and more sophisticated, the old neighborhood rackets _ numbers, extortion, small-time loan sharking _ have become less important. ``They have bigger fish to fry now,'' says Tricarico. ``There's no need to control their old neighborhoods.'' At least, there's still plenty to eat. Little Italy boasts 56 restaurants, 16 cafes and several dozen food stores. The latter include Alleva, founded in 1892 and reputedly the nation's oldest mozzarella maker, and Piemonte, which makes 20 different kinds of pasta daily. ``We serve real Italian food,'' says Anne Compoccia, a leading neighborhood booster. ``Not fettuccine with strawberries on it.'' Ms. Compoccia insists that Little Italy's Old World charm, and its residents' determination to stay put, will ensure the survival of this neighborhood-turned-tourist attraction. ``We're stemming the tide,'' she says. ``Even if it's down to just 10 blocks, we're going to preserve it.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon PMs, July 23

DOC.HEAD: The Folsom Family Struggles With AIDS, Suicide
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Doug Folsom bought a gun, left a recorded message telling his wife to ``hang tough,'' climbed into the hammock outside his family's Duxbury home and pulled the trigger. That was more than a month ago, on June 6. The suicide followed two years of watching his young wife and 3-year-old daughter Angela wither from acquired immune deficiency syndrome. He lived with the fear that 4-year-old Nicolette, who so far has managed to escape the disease, would test positive. ``That poor man, watching his little girl and his wife just go through this deterioration. This forced him to kill himself, something he said he'd never do. So he was forced to leave me,'' said Jennifer Folsom, her body frail from fighting the disease and struggling to keep her family together. She studied a framed photograph of the couple taken years earlier. Both are smiling, Doug's arm is tossed over her shoulders. The picture rests on a table within easy reach of Jennifer's chair, surrounded by tissues and bottles of medication. ``I have a very strong attitude of `Try me.' His whole attitude was `Why me?' He danced as long as he could. The wind was just taken out of his sails. I feel bad for him. He didn't deserve that.'' AIDS has been a relentless enemy since Jennifer was diagnosed in February 1988. The doctor gave her the test results in his empty office after closing; he was concerned, she said, about how his staff would react to an AIDS patient. ``I drove home. It was a long ride,'' Jennifer recalled. ``All I could see was gloom and doom and death. I thought of suicide. I went into my room and I didn't ever want to come out.'' It seemed incredible that a blood transfusion during an emergency appendectomy in a Massachusetts hospital in 1979 _ before blood supplies were tested and purged of the virus _ probably carried the AIDS virus into her body. Angie, she said, contracted the virus during the pregnancy or later from breast-feeding. Nicolette is tested every six months, and Jennifer prays her healthy, older daughter will remain free from AIDS. ``Here I am, this white, middle-class housewife living in Vermont, trying to make a living. How dare this disease come into my home? It's AIDS. I eat and drink and sleep AIDS. But I'm not afraid of it anymore,'' Jennifer said. Jennifer told her parents she was suffering from AIDS, but told others that she had cancer: ``We weren't sure how people were going to react,'' she said. She and Doug worried that business would fall off, that people would be afraid to come to their auto-body shop. The health insurance bill, which runs about $560 monthly, continues to be the first bill paid each month, and she is left with about $10,000 in other unpaid bills. Her nightmare had been that Nicolette would be harassed when she starts school next year _ a fear the school nurse put to rest by telling Jennifer, ``There will be no discrimination here.'' Jennifer lives day to day, and the past week had been a bad one. She was wrapped in a blue-and-white afghan and tired. She had lost 10 pounds last month, and was worried about Angie's lesions and weight loss. Angie, damp from a bath and refusing to be moved off her mother's lap, was struggling to breathe with a feeding tube up one nostril and a pacifier wedged stubbornly in her mouth. Jennifer glanced distractedly out the living-room windows, overlooking a faded yellow motorboat parked in the side yard and a small, neat vegetable garden. Wind chimes blew in a breeze along a second-floor balcony. ``I lie in bed and there are days I don't even want to get up. It's hard dealing with family life and self-worth, knowing that I can't care for my own kids and my husband,'' she said, breaking down. Then quickly regaining control, she said, ``I have such a strong gene in me that wants to go on. I hope I can hang on. ``I went to a party this weekend at my sister's. And I was sitting there exhausted and I thought ... `I'm 29 years old. I just can't be doing what a normal kid would be doing.' '' She wants to tell her story, she said, so people will realize the AIDS epidemic exists in rural areas of Vermont. ``Vermont does have AIDS,'' she said. ``The children of this generation need to be taught now because we don't know if there is going to be a cure.'' She wants to ``live with dignity and not have people whispering behind my back. I'm not ashamed of who I am. (AIDS) invaded my home without permission. I'm just hoping that by me going public, somebody else can be helped.'' For her own help, Jennifer relies on her family. Her parents visit daily to help care for the children, her brother has taken a leave of absence from his Washington job to help Jennifer wade through the red tape of locating financial assistance, and other sisters and brothers help out. ``We've also gone through the anger and the hurt,'' said Jennifer's mother, June Kenney. ``It's not right to see your daughter so sick when she's so young. They should be going on picnics and dancing.'' A visiting nurse stops by the home to provide the health care that supplements Jennifer and Angie's weekly trips to the University Health Center in Burlington, and two community fund-raisers are planned to help raise money to cover the mortgage and medical bills. Jennifer also attends a support group _ one woman, 10 homosexual men. Although a recent entry in her diary reads, ``Survival will come from humor, optimism, laughter and self-worth,'' Jennifer knows death is inevitable. ``I think about it more lately, that death is reality, this is reality. You can't wash it off in the shower. It's here and it's real and there's no light at the end of that tunnel. It keeps closing in. I tell myself constantly, `You've come too far to give in now.' I just wish it would go away, and I know it's not going to go away,'' she said. Doug Folsom knew all of this, and he could not bear it. Nicolette, who says her mother and sister have ``buggies,'' understands as well; she once drew a picture of the blue sky with a rope hanging down to the house, telling Jennifer it was God sending a rope for Angie. But Nicolette recently amended the caption. ``It was for Daddy,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Changing The Attitude Toward Overspending
DOC.TEXT: When some of the best minds and the most powerful legislative bodies cannot resolve budget deficits, taxpayers might have to seek new ways to pressure elected officials. Here are a few suggestions gleaned from various sources. _Question the elected person's patriotism. Since deficits incurred by one generation are a tax and economic liability on future generations, the effect is that of taxation without representation, a a violation of the American principle of fair play. According to the patriots of the American Revolution, taxation without representatation is tyranny, oppression, a violation of the rights of free men and women. Millions of future generations, therefore, are unfairly taxed. Economist E. Erich Heinemann poses the problem and challenges succinctly: ``Unless the generation that consumes federal services also pays for them, there will never be a durable majority to limit the size of government.'' _Apply psychological pressure on elected officials. Individuals who consistently, habitually spend beyond their means are viewed in a variety of negative ways. Many people see them as irresponsible and shiftless. Some view them as ignorant. Some consider them immoral. In serious cases, psychological counseling and therapy are often recommended. It has been recommended that the same attitudes be applied to political spending and spenders. Since public image is essential to political survival, the fear of being branded might stir a politician's survival instincts. _Publicize the historical record. Publicize the broken promises. Attempts to cut budget deficits through higher taxes have a long record of failure. So have so-called budget summits and promises. It is an old political tradition to be against taxes, but somehow taxes continue to rise. Generally speaking, additional revenues from tax increases have been used to justify more spending. ``When the government raises a dollar in revenues, Congress spends a dollar fifty,'' President Bush once explained. Regarding promises, Citizens for a Sound Economy, an independent, non-profit research group, reminded members that a 1987 agreement between the White House and Congress to limit spending growth led instead to quickened spending. That agreement called for restraining spending increases to $50 billion in 1988 and 1989. But in those two years spending increased by $139 billion. It provoked the Tax Foundation _ independent, non-profit, research oriented _ to warn of tax summitry. ``By the light of recent budget summit history,'' it said, ``any deficit reduction deal could be a bad deal for taxpayers.'' A foundation study found that in the 1980s, ``the fiscal years that were not preceded by budget summits actually resulted in the most real deficit reduction.'' _Remind voters that Washington is a somewhat ineffective spender of money. Robert Woodson Jr., congressional liaison for the National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise, which promotes the idea of self-help, contends that social spending has empowered bureaucrats but not necessarily the poor. ``It's been estimated that 70 cents of every federal dollar spent on social service programs goes to the people, agencies, and organizations who serve the poor,'' he states, adding: ``The big spenders in Congress should be asking themselves now, `Why hasn't the face of poverty changed?''' Many other suggestions are heard every day: Demand explanations. Expose selfish, special-interest spending proposals. Publicize waste. Encourage the development of a return-on-investment guide to government spending. All the ideas circulating seem to have one common theme, to again make it politically unpalatable for elected officials to overspend.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Wednesday, July 18.

For release Thurs AMs, July 19, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: O'Flaherty's Irish Channel: Real Irish Music in the French Quarter
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Danny O'Flaherty has just finished a rousing rendition of ``Kelly, the Boy From Killeen.'' A barmaid gives him several slips of paper, some folded around money. He reads them and goes back to the mike at his Irish pub in the French Quarter. ``We've been getting a lot of requests for `Danny Boy.' We don't do that. We only do the right stuff,'' he tells the audience. ``If you'll read the literature at your table, you'll understand.'' ``Danny Boy'' isn't the only tune nixed by O'Flaherty. He also rejects ``When Irish Eyes Are Smiling'' and other overplayed ersatz Irish tunes. ``That's not Ireland,'' he said. ``There's nothing wrong with those songs; we just have something better.'' Opened in December, the Irish Channel is only one block from the Mississippi River in a sprawling old building with a courtyard separating two very different bars. One is the ballad room, featuring regular performances by O'Flaherty, who spent three years touring with The Irish Minstrels and 16 years with his own trio, the Celtic Folk _ a group that has 10 albums and has played for presidents and the pope and in festivals as far away as Israel. The other is called The Informer, the bigger room across the courtyard. It has a jukebox, a television and four dart boards. You can sit and talk as loudly as you want in The Informer or in the courtyard. But if you insist on talking out in the Ballad Room, especially during some of the more poignant songs, you'll be asked to leave. ``It's probably the most unmannerly thing anyone could do _ talk while other people are performing,'' said O'Flaherty. But he acknowledges few other bars or pubs have such a requirement _ especially not in the boisterous French Quarter. ``Maybe we have to open up a university in America so people can go to university and learn how to listen.'' The amplification, from speakers hung at what would be ceiling level if the second floor of the Ballad Room hadn't been torn out, is loud enough to cover most quiet conversations. In fact, although you see mouths moving during sing-along choruses, you don't hear anyone but O'Flaherty until he stops to listen. People drinking Guinness, Harp, Double Diamond, Carlsberg and Miller Lite (``Not everybody likes to drink Irish,'' said the bartender) at the 25 or so little tables include tourists and locals, white-haired couples and young adults with children. O'Flaherty learned how to listen, to sing and to play guitar, mandolin, accordion, banjo, harmonica and tin whistle in Galway and his home island of Innishmor, off the Galway coast. He left in September 1970 to work for his uncle's construction company in Chicago. He played and sang on weekends, and about six months after he arrived, the Irish Minstrels asked him to audition. He toured with them for three years. In early 1974, tired of airports, he decided to settle in Washington, with his first wife. ``I quit the music business for six weeks. That's all I could last,'' he said. A woman hired him to play at her wedding. O'Flaherty and his brother, Patrick, borrowed a mandolin and a guitar. Three weeks later, they were hired as the weekend entertainment at The Dubliner, which had just opened on Capitol Hill. They decided to get away from pseudo-Irish schmaltz and rabid paeans to the Irish Republican Army during the early '80s, when they were performing at clubs and folk festivals around the East Coast. ``We were doing anti-war when it wasn't kosher,'' said O'Flaherty. Patrick O'Flaherty is currently touring with a group called the Gaelic Shores, and Welsh harpist Robin James-Jones shares the Irish Channel stage. O'Flaherty's emphasis on folk music doesn't mean he refuses to sing anything that's not Irish _ or even songs that aren't ancient and anonymous. An evening in the ballad room is likely to include ``And the Band Played Waltzing Matilda,'' an anti-war song about the Battle of Gallipoli, and a spectacularly non-Irish children's tune called ``Waltzing With Bears,'' as well as ``Wild Mountain Thyme'' or ``The Maid of Five-e-o.'' So what's an Irish pub doing in the French Quarter? ``I don't find a bar like this surprising for a city that has five or seven St. Patrick's Day parades,'' said Don Jennings, a member of the Ancient Order of Hibernians and the Irish Channel St. Patrick's Day Committee. Perhaps more to the point, the brothers and Danny O'Flaherty's wife, Susan, like the city, where an invitation for a bar gig during the 1984 World's Fair wound up stretching into a two-year stint that soon was followed by another. When they left, they missed New Orleans, O'Flaherty said. ``We didn't realize how lucky we were to live in New Orleans or how nice it was until we left,'' he said. ``The other reason, my wife and I, before we left New Orleans, we lost twins. They're buried here in New Orleans.'' They returned in 1989 to open a pub as a home base for the Celtic Folk, and as a living that didn't call for quite so much touring. New Orleans' French, Spanish and African-American heritage is well known. ``The Irishness of the city is quiet. Once you research and dig down deep, there's a lot of things the Irish have done in a very positive manner in this city,'' O'Flaherty said. Irish immigrants dug the canal after which Canal Street is named. Many believe they gave New Orleans the accent known locally as ``da Yat axsent'' _ a very close cousin to da way dey talk in Noo Yawk, where Irish immigrants also settled. And they settled the Irish Channel along the riverfront. O'Flaherty said he wanted to make his pub a center for that history, as well as for the older Irish heritage of his native land. However, he said he was advised against actually opening a bar in the Irish Channel, because too few people would find it. The bar has broken even most months, he said, though unluckily it opened in December, when New Orleans went through one of its worst freezes ever. June was also rough _ the number of tourists and conventions had begun to slack off, and the groups that did come to town included the National Baptist Convention. Coming attractions include concerts by Tommy Makem, the Clancy Brothers and bluegrass fiddler Kenny Kosek, who has recorded with Jerry Garcia and Laurie Anderson as well as the Celtic Folk. O'Flaherty also would like to have a pub theater, but that's still a dream. ``We haven't even reached what we want to do yet,'' he said. ``We've got to crawl before we walk.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thurs AMs, July 19
