DOC.HEAD: A Lifer Plays the Percentages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Presumed Innocent'' opens July 27.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY310 of July 14
DOC.TEXT: Bonnie Bedelia has been around long enough to know the percentages: There are more good actors than good parts, and a lot more good parts for men than for women. There's usually one decent female part per film, she says, and the numbers have often worked against her. ``Lovers and Other Strangers'' was a bad role in a good film. ``Prince of Pennsylvania'' was a good part in a bad film. ``Fat Man and Little Boy'' struck out on both counts. ``Die Hard'' and ``Die Hard 2'' were fun, but those movies belong to Bruce Willis. Even a big part in a good film can come up short, such as her acclaimed role as auto racer Shirley Muldowney in the 1983 film ``Heart Like a Wheel.'' Compliment her on it and the response is terse: ``Yeah, it would have been nice if someone saw it.'' But for ``Presumed Innocent,'' there are no frowns or wisecracks. Finally, it's all there: the cast (Harrison Ford, Raul Julia), the director (Alan Pakula _ ``Klute,'' ``All the President's Men''), the script (based on Scott Turow's best-selling thriller) and yes, the part she wanted. ``How often does anyone get a chance to be in film like that?'' says Bedelia, who plays Ford's wife. ``I would have to be put in Bellevue if I didn't want that part. What's not to want to do it? I want to work. I want a career. Everyone wanted to do it. ``It was the top of the line, all along the way. You don't get better than that.'' That's the talk of a self-described ``lifer'' convinced she can play anything, an actress who's been at it for 30 years, first appearing on Broadway in ``Isle of Children'' at age 10. She wishes more people knew who she was _ ``I hear someone say, `She looks familiar, did I go to school with her?''' _ but accepts it all because acting's all she ever wanted to do. ``I did have a natural gift for suspending reality,'' she said, pausing and then smiling at that piece of actor's talk. ``My big brother used to make up these elaborate fantasy games where we'd be on adventures.He'd make up these stories about us being orphans or we'd move our bunk beds and make them into tents and pretend we were in the woods. It's one of those fantastic free association games that kids can do.'' She remembers being homesick during ``Lovers and Other Strangers,'' carrying her first of two sons and wishing she were shopping for baby clothes. And ``They Shoot Horses, Don't They?'' She remembers how much fun it was making the whole film on that single dance floor. On one end of her career is ``Heart Like a Wheel,'' her most challenging, rewarding part, wasted on a box-office flop. It was low budget _ ``Most of the money spent on cars,'' she cracks _ and covered four decades, often in one day of filming. ``I'd get up in the morning and be 40, with the little wrinkles in my eyes and the gray in my hair,'' she said. ``The very next scene, I'd run to makeup and I had to erase all that mileage in my life and suddenly I was 16 years old and had to go greet my dad. Then I was 30 and had this short hairdo and false eyelashes.'' On the other end, are the ``Die Hard'' movies _ the latest one reportedly costing more than $60 million. Everyone's seen at least one of those films, but who remembers that it was Bonnie Bedelia playing Willis' wife? ``I just said my words and went home,'' Bedelia said. ``They were fun, though. I really liked the directors, John McTiernan from the first one and Renny Harlin for this one. And I really liked Bruce Willis. I only worked for a couple of weeks on the first one and a few days on the second.'' So will ``Presumed Innocent'' end the days of Bonnie Watchamacallit? She's not saying _ a lifer's superstition. Again, it's playing the percentages, the invariable rule of mathematics. How often does a film turn out the way it's supposed to? ``I made a movie in Mexico called `Fat Man and Little Boy,''' she said of last year's critical and commercial failure. ``Roland Joffe was directing and he made one of my favorite movies of all time, `The Killing Fields.' Paul Newman was starring, and me and Natasha Richardson and Laura Dern and John Cusack were in the cast, all of us good actors. I felt pretty good about that, too, and look how that turned out. It wasn't that good.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Fri AMs, July 20

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan Tries To Stop Smuggling by Fishermen
DOC.TEXT: At the start of another stifling summer day, the fishermen of Nanliao and their wives gather near a Buddhist temple to pray for the return of their profitable, but illegal, livelihood. The 2,000 villagers have had little else to do since early June, when Nanliao became the first target of a government attempt to stamp out smuggling. ``There is virtually nothing fishermen can now do,'' said one, who identified himself only by the surname Pan. ``Local fishing grounds have been destroyed by pollution and our fishermen had to risk smuggling to make a living.'' Nanliao gets no sympathy from Premier Hau Pei-tsun, a career military man who says the smuggling of guns, narcotics, prostitutes and triggermen for Taiwan mobsters is responsible for a soaring crime rate. Robberies increased by 39 percent and kidnappings by 53 percent in 1989, a record year for violent crime. Police seized nearly 1,000 handguns last year and estimate thousands more remained in the hands of gangsters. They said most of the weapons were smuggled from China and the Philippines. Newspapers print reports of young women from the mainland caught working in the numerous illegal brothels of Taiwan. ``Smuggling has not only posed a threat to public security, but has seriously affected our economic development,'' Hau declared. The premier says crime is driving industries off the island. Military patrols were removed from the ports when Taiwan ended 38 years of martial law in 1987, and smuggling has risen sharply. Nanliao is just 80 miles across the Formosa Strait from Fujian province in southern China. Officials believe nearly everyone in town was involved in smuggling and claim villagers beat up police whenever they tried to stop it. About 1,000 soldiers were sent to reinforce air and coastal patrols in the area and impose a curfew to stop smuggled goods from being brought ashore at night. The trade slowed to a trickle. Fishermen acknowledge their illegal activity has made the village one of Taiwan's richest. With the proceeds from smuggling, residents of Nanliao replaced their traditional brick-and-tile houses with two-story apartment buildings and bought imported luxury cars. Until five years ago, the villagers made more modest livings from coastal waters rich in catfish and octopus. Offshore oil exploration and pollution from industrial waste brought an end to that. Pan said Nanliao fishermen got into smuggling after martial law ended, initially trading Taiwanese consumer goods for fish and agricultural products from China. At first, the villagers exchanged goods with Chinese smugglers at sea, but the easing of hostility between Taiwan and China emboldened them to enter mainland ports. Residents of Nanliao said a boat crew could make nearly $30,000 from a three-day trip. ``Villagers first agreed to stay away from guns, drugs and illegal Chinese immigrants to avoid a harsh crackdown, but the agreement was broken after more fishing boats joined the trade and caused prices to fall for smuggled fish and other produce,'' Pan said. Earlier in June, officials seized a ton of Chinese-made amphetamines with a market value of about $11 million from a Nanliao fishing boat. Five crewmen were arrested. Since the curfew began, only a few Nanliao boats have gone on smuggling missions. Most have returned with empty holds. The government says it will assign about 20,000 soldiers later this year to help anti-smuggling air, sea and coastal patrols, but the illegal trade may be difficult to conquer. Some Nanliao smugglers are said to have moved to other fishing ports. Newspapers report smugglers have begun using motorized rafts to bring goods to shore, leaving pursuing police patrol boats stranded on sandbars in shallow water. The people of Nanliao do not sound defeated. At the temple, villager Chen Chun-hui said: ``Right now we are living on our savings, and are watching.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon AMs, July 23

DOC.HEAD: A Priest's Calling to Danger
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note Monday reference in 4th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Ask Dean Brackley why he is going to El Salvador to take the place of a murdered priest, why he will give up a secure life in academia, and he just gazes at the lush campus of Fordham University. ``I need to be close to the struggle for life and death,'' he says. ``It just isn't happening here.'' It is happening, he says, in El Salvador, torn by a 10-year civil war. Among the casualties: six Jesuit priests, taken from their beds and shot in the back of the head Nov. 16 at the Central America University. ``The murder of the priests affected me deeply,'' said Brackley, 43, one of six priests chosen from around the world to replace their fallen brothers. He leaves Monday. In San Salvador, where he has traveled twice before, Brackley will teach philosophy and religion to graduate students at the university and oversee a large rural parish in Jayaque, 45 minutes west of the city. Among the priests chosen by the university and the head of the Jesuits in Rome is another American _ Charles Beirne, an administrator at Santa Clara University. The others are a Canadian, a Mexican, a Spaniard and a Salvadoran. ``We know it will be dangerous and we're not going down there to commit suicide,'' Brackley said. ``But the truth has to be told.'' The slayings of the Jesuits, their cook and her 16-year-old daughter underscore the dangers facing hundreds of clerics working in Salvador's shantytowns. Since 1980, when El Salvador's leftist rebels began fighting a succession of U.S.-backed governments, 72,000 Salvadorans have died in the war. At least 30,000 died at the hands of right-wing death squads, human rights groups say. Some clerics who work among the dispossessed are viewed as subversives by the military and conservative government, and as enemies by the far right, which considers them Marxist ideologues. Since 1980, 16 _ including Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero _ have been slain. The left-leaning clerics maintain that the civil war arose from vast social injustice and that only by addressing its causes can it be resolved. But the armed forces contend the revolution is fueled by Communist forces outside the country. News of the pre-dawn massacre of the Jesuits initially stunned the world and prompted calls from some U.S. congressmen to reconsider aid to El Salvador. Eight months later, although an investigation continues, no soldier has been tried. An officer never has been convicted of human rights abuse in El Salvador, which receives $1 million in U.S. aid each day. Brackley said he first was struck by the social inequities of life not in Central America, but in his hometown of Troy, N.Y., a declining milltown. ``As a self-conscious little boy I was stunned by poverty,'' he recalled. He also recognized early on that he was ``blessed with a quixotic temperament, given to adventure rather than boredom, even if it hurts.'' Brackley joined the Jesuits when he was 18. But after graduating from Boston College, he had what he termed a ``crisis of faith,'' and went to work on New York City's impoverished Lower East Side. There, he learned Spanish and helped found a junior high school for promising boys from the community. In the early 1970s, as he wrestled with the church's role in society, Brackley met Dorothy Day, the charismatic co-founder of the Catholic Worker's Movement. He remembers her simple advice to him: ``Stay close to the people.'' The encounter with Day taught him ``confusion doesn't clear up until you make a commitment,'' Brackley said. He said he also learned he had ``something to contribute to the poor and their cause.'' Subsequently, Brackley reaffirmed his commitment to seminary in Berkeley, Calif. While doing research, he engaged in what he calls ``theological tourism'' _ he worked as a carpenter in Puerto Rico and studied in Peru. It was in Latin America he was introduced to ``liberation theology,'' the doctrine that champions the poor and oppressed in countries where mass poverty coexists with the opulence of a tiny minority. Since it evolved in the 1960s, the doctrine has splintered the Roman Catholic establishment. Brackley returned to the United States and while completing a doctorate in theology at the University of Chicago, took courses in political science. ``I had found out in Latin America that God was concerned with suffering,'' he said. ``But what was God's view of the International Monetary Fund?'' With a doctorate in hand, Brackley returned to New York and worked as a priest and organizer for the South Bronx People for Change, a church-sponsored group that sprang up in 1979 to force city support for the abandoned community. In September, he took a teaching post at Fordham. But Blanca Ramirez, who heads People for Change, said there are two places Brackley is truly happy: the South Bronx or El Salvador. ``In the South Bronx, I learned how to survive, which meant having a sense of humor, resilience and humility,'' Brackley said. ``I learned who I was and what my mission was.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon AMs, July 23

DOC.HEAD: Spacecraft Will Use Radar To Peer Through the Clouds of Venus
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A bedeviled, beleaguered NASA is hoping the Magellan spacecraft's rendezvous with Venus next month will provide our best look yet at Earth's hellishly hot neighbor. If all goes according to plan, the $413 million unmanned device, centerpiece of a $744 million mission, will orbit the cloud-shrouded planet on Aug. 10 after a 15-month journey from Earth. And NASA desperately wants everything to go according to plan. ``This thing must succeed because of the Hubble Space Telescope effect and the generally bad impression we've all been getting of how NASA has been conducting its affairs lately,'' said Steve Saunders, the Magellan project's chief scientist. But those setbacks _ the crippling of the $1.5 billion Hubble observatory due to mirror imperfections; the temporary grounding of the space shuttles due to hydrogen fuel leaks _ have not dimmed the agency's enthusiasm for Magellan. ``We've dreamed about the sights we would see. Now it's about to happen,'' said Phil Allin, a Magellan project official at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Named for 16th century explorer Ferdinand Magellan, the craft's radar will penetrate acid-laden Venusian clouds to make pictures and maps 10 times more detailed than the best previous images. That will help geologists understand forces that sculpted Venus to create flat lowlands, hilly plains and continent-like highlands capped by peaks such as 35,400-foot Mount Maxwell, which is a mile taller than Earth's Mount Everest. NASA says Magellan's radar will reveal unprecedented details of the planet's terrain, a landscape shaped by meteorite craters, tens of thousands of volcanoes, and perhaps movements of gargantuan blocks of the planet's crust _ a process that may be similar to continental drift on Earth. The 3.7-ton spacecraft also will look for ancient shorelines and channels to learn if Venus once had oceans and rivers, before its carbon dioxide atmosphere trapped the sun's heat in a runaway ``greenhouse effect.'' Such global warming makes modern Venus a bone-dry, 900-degree Fahrenheit oven with an atmospheric pressure 90 times greater than Earth's. Magellan's mission ``is the capstone of the exploration of the inner planets,'' said Jim Head, a member of the Magellan science team and a geologist at Brown University in Providence, R.I. ``We've seen the surfaces of the moon, Mars, the Earth and Mercury, but Venus always has been obscured by the clouds and we've never gotten a good global view of it.'' The 21-foot-long Magellan was released from the cargo bay of space shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989, then launched on its roundabout, 806 million-mile voyage by an inertial upper-stage rocket. At 9:31 a.m. PDT on Aug. 10, Magellan will fire its solid-fueled Star rocket to slow down and go into a elliptical, nearly polar orbit that ranges from 171 miles to almost 5,000 miles above Venus. After a few weeks of tests, the spacecraft will bounce radar waves off Venus to make pictures and topographic maps of 70 percent to 90 percent of the surface. Meanwhile, the planet will rotate once on its axis during a single Venusian day, which equals 243 Earth days. ``It's going to give us a map of Venus that in many ways is better than anything we have for the whole Earth,'' where most of the ocean floor hasn't been mapped in detail, Saunders said. If scientists are lucky, Magellan may tell them if Venusian volcanoes are active, if movements of the planet's crust produce ``Venus quakes,'' and if those movements are more like Earth's drifting continents or like the upward boiling of molten rock that created Hawaii. Venus is the planet most like Earth in terms of size, density and mass, and also is Earth's nearest neighbor, other than the moon. Yet its clouds prevent the surface from being seen by telescopes or optical cameras aboard orbiting spaceships. About 20 spacecraft have visited Venus since the early 1960s, some deploying landers that photographed small parts of the surface. Pictures also were made by transmitting radar waves from Earth, and from NASA's Pioneer Venus orbiter in 1978 and the Soviet Union's Venera 15 and 16 orbiters in 1983. But the best radar pictures until now could distinguish only those landscape features wider than about 1\ miles. Saunders said Magellan's pictures will be roughly 10 times better, capturing features as small as 260 yards, about the length of 2{ football fields. Magellan will take 3 hours and 11 minutes to orbit Venus once. During each orbit, Magellan will spend 37 minutes as it moves from north to south bouncing radar off a swath of Venus' surface about 10,000 miles long but only 16 miles wide. The information will be stored on two tape recorders. During the rest of each orbit, Magellan will radio the information back to Earth, where it will be received by 230-foot-wide, dish-shaped antennas at NASA's Deep Space Network stations in California, Spain and Australia. Computers at Jet Propulsion Laboratory will assemble the data into pictures and topographic maps of each swath. The swaths _ nicknamed ``noodles'' because they are so long and narrow _ then will be assembled into pictures covering larger areas of the planet. ``Mapping a whole new planet will return an enormous amount of data that will keep geologists busy for a long time,'' Saunders said. ``If you printed it in books, it would fill a shelf about 10 miles long. It's very humbling.'' Magellan's main 243-day mapping mission will miss the south polar regions. NASA is expected to approve more 243-day mapping cycles. A total of three are needed to map the entire planet. Cost of the Magellan mission through the first 243-day mapping cycle is $744 million, including the cost of launching the spacecraft from the shuttle, said Bill Dimmer of NASA's comptroller's office in Washington. The spacecraft and its instruments account for $413 million of that total, he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tues AMs, July 24

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Magellan-Venus, b0442
The Magellan Mission at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here are key facts about the Magellan spacecraft, which is scheduled to go into orbit around Venus in August: PRIMARY MISSION: To use radar to penetrate the clouds of Venus and make pictures and maps of 70 percent to 90 percent of the planet's surface with 10 times better detail than any previous images. Magellan will reveal signs of forces that shaped the planet, including volcanism, meteorite impacts and possibly wind, water and large-scale movements of the planet's crust. EXTENDED MISSION: A single Venusian day _ the time it takes the planet to rotate once on its axis _ lasts 243 Earth days. Magellan's primary mission is to map the planet as it rotates once below the polar-orbiting spacecraft. But NASA scientists expect to obtain approval for additional 243-day mapping cycles so they can make pictures and maps of most of the surface. The primary mission will miss the planet's southernmost latitudes. COST: $744 million through the end of Magellan's primary 243-day mapping effort, including $413 million for the spacecraft and its instruments. NASA cut costs by building Magellan using some spare parts from Voyager and Galileo spacecraft. LAUNCH: Deployed from cargo bay of space shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989, then launched by an inertial upper stage booster. THE VOYAGE: A 806 million-mile trip to Venus in 15 months, requiring 1{ loops around the sun. PROPULSION: A solid-fueled Star 48B rocket is to put Magellan into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10. Twenty-four liquid-fueled thrusters help point the spacecraft and adjust its trajectory. ORBIT: Magellan will orbit near Venus' poles once every 3 hours and 11 minutes, at an altitude ranging from 171 miles to almost 5,000 miles. VITAL STATISTICS: Magellan is 21 feet long and 15 feet in diameter, and weighs 7,410 pounds. INSTRUMENTS: Synthetic aperture radar is to send radar waves and catch the reflected waves to make two-dimensional pictures of Venus, measure elevations for topographic maps, and determine heat emissions from Venus' surface to provide clues about surface roughness and rock composition. Engineers on Earth will precisely track Magellan's speed to measure changes in the strength of the gravity field on various parts of Venus. That will yield clues about the planet's interior. POWER SUPPLY: A pair of solar panels charge the spacecraft's two nickel-cadmium batteries. COMMUNICATIONS: Magellan's 12-foot antenna dish radios information back to 230-foot, dish-shaped antennas in Spain, Australia and Goldstone, Calif. The radar information will be relayed to NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., where it will be assembled into maps and pictures. CONSTRUCTION: NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory managed the project. Martin Marietta Corp. built the spacecraft in Denver. Hughes Aircraft Co. built the radar in El Segundo, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Magellan-Venus, b0442
The Planet Venus at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: After the Magellan spacecraft goes into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10, it will use radar to map the surface of the cloud-covered planet. Here is some of what scientists already know about the second planet from the sun: DIAMETER: About 7,520 miles, or 95 percent as wide as Earth; sixth largest of the solar system's nine known planets. MASS: Venus weighs about 82 percent as much as Earth. ATMOSPHERE: About 97 percent carbon dioxide, with trace amounts of nitrogen, sulfur dioxide, water vapor, argon, oxygen, carbon monoxide, neon, and hydrochloric and hydrofluoric acids. The planet's clouds contain sulfuric acid droplets. The atmosphere traps heat in a runaway ``greenhouse effect'' that scientists believe evaporated liquid water long ago, if there ever was any on the planet. Large fluctuations in sulfur dioxide levels may indicate that active volcanoes pump the gas into Venus' atmosphere. SURFACE CONDITIONS: Temperature about 900 degrees Fahrenheit, hot enough to melt lead, zinc or tin. Crushing atmospheric pressure 90 times that on Earth's surface, or equivalent to the pressure 2,700 feet beneath the surface of an ocean on Earth. THE CALENDAR: A day on Venus lasts longer than a year. A Venusian year _ the time it takes for the planet to orbit the sun _ lasts 225 Earth days. A Venusian day _ the time the planet takes to spin once on its axis _ lasts 243 Earth days. Venus also has retrograde rotation, so the sun rises in the west and sets in the east. DISTANCE FROM THE SUN: Venus is the second planet from the sun, orbiting at a distance of 67.2 million miles. It is closer to Earth than any other planet. Other than the sun and moon, Venus is the brightest object in Earth's skies. MOONS: None. GEOLOGY: Earth-based and spacecraft radar revealed hundreds of thousands of volcanoes on the Venusian lowlands, although scientists don't yet know if any are active. Venus also has meteorite impact craters and continent-like highlands with towering peaks that dwarf Earth's tallest mountains. Scientists suspect giant plates of rock may move in Venus' crust in a process vaguely like continental drift on Earth. Venus' surface is about 65 percent rolling plains, 27 percent flat lowlands and 8 percent highlands that may be similar to Earth's continents. GRAVITY: About 89 percent as strong as on Earth. MAGNETIC FIELD: None detected so far, suggesting Venus now lacks a liquid core, which is needed to generate a magnetic field.

DOC.HEAD: After a Century, Is Boll Weevil Being Evicted From Home in Dixie?
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Southerners mostly scorn the boll weevil. Here, they built a monument in the varmint's honor. Like others across the Cotton Belt, many in Coffee County were ruined when the insatiable beetle's migration reached here 75 years ago. But people in Enterprise came to see the weevil as ``the herald of prosperity,'' in the words of the monument's inscription, because its ravages forced farmers to abandon a one-crop economy and begin growing peanuts, corn and other crops. ``It meant that cotton was no longer king,'' said Roy Shoffner, a retired newspaper publisher and local historian. His book about the monument, built in 1919, quotes an official on the lesson learned: ``There is one and only one weapon of defense ..., and that's diversified farming.'' But nowadays there's talk of another weapon, of a frontal insecticide assault to eradicate the bug, to evict it over the Mexican border it crossed nearly a century ago. ``We're trying to squeeze the weevil out,'' says T. Cotton Nelson of the National Cotton Council in Memphis, Tenn. ``Hopefully ... drive him right back out of the country.'' American agriculture's most destructive pest could be eliminated as a threat within the decade, says the cotton council's director of technical operations, Andrew Jordan. That, he cautions, is ``in an ideal world,'' but he adds after some reflection, ``I think the year 2000 is probably realistic.'' Environmentalists and some cotton farmers themselves are not convinced. After all, the boll weevil has proved its durability while changing a way of life in the South. Many areas simply surrendered to the creature. They gave up growing the white fiber whose profits had helped finance the pageant of the antebellum days and whose production was the region's signature, the Land of Cotton. ``Boll Weevil Coming Fast,'' the People's Ledger warned Coffee County's farmers in 1910. The census that year recorded a bumper cotton crop, 25,207 bales. In 1916, a year after the weevil arrived, only 1,500 bales were ginned in Enterprise. Elsewhere it was no different. In 1921, the boll weevil, which devours cotton bolls and buds, went through 30 percent of the South's crop. A folk song tried to make light of the pest. ``First time I saw the boll weevil, he was standin' on the square. ``Next time I saw the boll weevil, he had his whole family there. ``They was lookin' for a home, ``Just lookin' for a home.'' Over time, a variety of control measures, from insecticides to penny-a-bug bounties, helped limit damage. In Enterprise, Clayton Metcalf sold a vacuum-type machine called a Nesbitt Bug-Catcher. ``It helped,'' he recalls, ``but you couldn't get 'em all.'' Even today, crop losses and control costs amount to $300 million a year _ and the bill comes to $12 billion altogether since the weevil entered Texas in 1892, the cotton council estimates. So there was a mixture of hope and skepticism when the U.S. Department of Agriculture launched an experimental ``eradication'' effort in a small area of Virginia and North Carolina in 1978. ``Fear No Weevil'' became the project's unofficial motto. Instead of farm-by-farm measures, it used an area approach. Working from weevil-free zones, the pilot program applied weekly doses of insecticide from September to the first frost to reduce the number of ``over-wintering'' weevils. In spring, bug traps revealed surviving populations, which were sprayed. After the third year, program officials merely mopped up spot re-infestations. The pilot program was expanded to all of North and South Carolina in 1983, with farmers and the government sharing costs. ``It's quite clear that biologically it was successful,'' says Gerald Carlson, an agricultural economics professor at North Carolina State University who studied the program. ``And economically what resulted was some fairly substantial savings to the farmers _ and to new farmers getting into it. There's been a big expansion in acreage.'' While U.S. cotton production rose only 10 percent between 1980 and '89, from 11.1 million to 12.2 million bales, North Carolina's nearly tripled, from 52,000 to 141,000 bales. ``In North and South Carolina, the boll weevil has been eradicated as an economic pest of cotton,'' the National Cotton Council said in a 1989 report. Further, ``results in the Southwest (Arizona and Southern California) eradication program are equally impressive. Weevil populations fell approximately 95 percent in the first year ... The containment program also is working in Texas,'' the council said, referring to the High Plains growing area near Lubbock. USDA also lists Virginia within the eradicated zone. Is the weevil finally on the run then, as the eradication effort continues in Georgia, northern Florida and southern Alabama? It's not that simple. First, even now less than 1 million acres of the 12 million-acre U.S. cotton crop are under the eradication and containment programs, says Jordan of the cotton council. Second, there's been active resistance to expansion. Farmers in Alabama this spring voted down a proposed eradication assessment increase when program officials concluded that more had to be spent in areas where winter cold was less an ally in the weevil war than it was in the Carolinas. In a second vote in June they approved the increase. Environmentalists also fought the plan. ``We just didn't feel that that made environmental sense, a massive malathion spraying program, especially by air,'' says Jim Taylor of the Alabama chapter of the Sierra Club. Cars and homes were accidentally sprayed with the pesticide, he said. The group sued, along with the Alabama Conservancy and the Southern Environmental Law Center. Under a resulting 1988 agreement, the government is drafting an environmental impact statement and is now spraying with what Taylor calls ``more benign'' pesticides. Supporters of the eradication effort insist one of its benefits is a long-term reduction in pesticide use as weevil populations dwindle. Without the program, ``20 years from now you're going to be spraying just as much as you are now,'' says Robroy Fisher, a Mississippi Delta cotton planter who is active in weevil control efforts. Taylor dismisses the effort as ``voodoo science.'' And the goal of eradicating the perennial pest? Says Taylor, ``I'll bet on the boll weevil.'' In Coffee County, they're not taking any bets. People know of the eradication program, and they know cotton acreage is up some. But, says county agent Dan Presley, ``I don't think cotton'll ever come back as king.'' Peanuts and corn are the main crops here now. The weevil's lesson about diversification remains, whether the bug does or not.

DOC.HEAD: Handful of Candidates Push for Pot Legalization
DOC.TEXT: Gubernatorial candidate Gatewood Galbraith wants to put the law back on the side of a Kentucky agricultural tradition: growing marijuana. ``Our granddaddies used to grow it by the thousands of acres'' when marijuana was legal and grown mainly for fiber for rope and textiles, said Galbraith, a 43-year-old Lexington attorney. Galbraith, a long shot in next year's Kentucky race for governor, is among a handful of pro-legalization candidates who consider themselves political trailblazers for millions of Americans who smoke pot regularly. They also style themselves as champions for the taxpayers who are footing the bill for the nation's war on drugs. In New Hampshire, congressional candidate Michael Weddle is challenging voters to heed their state motto _ ``Live Free or Die'' _ by supporting marijuana legalization. Weddle, a state representative, is among eight candidates in a GOP primary for an open U.S. House seat. In Kansas, Democratic congressional candidate Mark Creamer now operates his pro-legalization campaign from a jail cell, where he is serving a six-month sentence for lighting a marijuana cigarette in a police station. Creamer is given little chance against Democratic Rep. Jim Slattery in the state's Aug. 7 primary. Kevin Zeese, vice president of the private, pro-legalization Drug Policy Foundation in Washington, said several other major-party candidates also are carrying the marijuana legalization banner this year. Zeese said incumbent officeholders who support marijuana legalization and are running for re-election include U.S. Rep. George Crockett, D-Mich.; Democratic state Rep. Elbert Walton in Missouri; Democratic state Sen. Joe Galiber in New York; and Bill Mathesius, the Republican county executive in Mercer County, N.J. Zeese believes the political winds have changed since the conservative tide swept the nation during the 1980s, dousing the marijuana legalization debates of the 1960s and 1970s. ``Some politicians are starting to get ahead of the curve on this,'' Zeese said. ``Something like this was unspeakable three years ago and now people are running for office on it.'' Supporters of legalization include conservatives such as economist Milton Friedman and columnist William F. Buckley Jr. Other proponents are former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, Baltimore Mayor Kurt Schmoke and U.S. District Judge Robert W. Sweet in New York. Former Secretary of State George Shultz has said legalization should at least be considered. Many supporters of legalization say marijuana is less potent and addictive than cigarettes or alcohol, and shouldn't be grouped with cocaine, heroin, crack or other hard drugs. They also contend legalizing marijuana would be a big weapon against crime syndicates that control the drug world. But federal drug czar William Bennett has branded legalization as ``stupid and morally atrocious.'' ``It doesn't make any sense,'' Bennett has said. ``It is becoming something of a fashion to believe this (legalization) in certain circles of opinion. But even though it's fashionable, it's still every bit as dumb and compassionless as it was before.'' Dewey Stokes, the national president of the Fraternal Order of Police, said legalizing marijuana would prompt more people to develop drug habits and increase demand for harder drugs. ``I think the anti-drug effort has to be successful if we're going to have a country,'' he said. Kentucky Democratic leaders have taken steps recently to distance themselves from Galbraith and a newly formed grass-roots organization called the ``Green Democrats.'' Galbraith, Weddle and Creamer all face long odds at the polls this year. But legalization supporters express confidence their numbers will grow as opposition mounts to the costs of a federal anti-drug policy they deem ineffective. ``As the repression continues and the erosion of civil liberties continue ... so will the awareness that solving the problem with a drug war is not the solution,'' said Weddle, a two-term state House member from Portsmouth, N.H. Weddle, a Democrat who turned Republican for the September primary, said voter response has been better than he anticipated. In Kentucky, where marijuana outstrips tobacco as the leading _ albeit illegal _ cash crop, Galbraith said the response has been ``absolutely stunning'' to his proposal to strictly regulate and tax marijuana. Galbraith, who is among five announced or likely candidates for the Democratic nomination for governor next year, estimates the state could reap up to $1 billion in taxes each year from legal marijuana. He said Kentucky was the nation's leading producer of marijuana _ which was commonly called hemp _ for a century before it was banned in 1936. John Dunlap, a spokesman for the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws in Washington, said legalizing marijuana would generate $40 billion a year nationally. Billions more could be saved by scrapping local, state and federal eradication efforts, he said.

DOC.HEAD: A Warning on Tanker Pileups: `We Are Asking for Trouble'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Graphic
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: After $30 million of repairs, the Exxon Valdez is due back at sea in August with a new crew, new steel in its shredded hull, new ports of call in the Middle East and a new name _ Exxon Mediterranean. But no such industrywide makeover has occurred to limit oil spills and their damage.

It seemed like a maritime version of Murphy's law. The wayward Exxon Valdez plowed into Bligh Reef. Then three shipwrecks oiled three waterways within 12 hours last June. The American Trader ran over its anchor and gashed itself. The BT Nautilus was one of three spills in three months in the New York City area. The Mega Borg caught fire in the Gulf of Mexico. And on and on and on. But these accidents, all within 15 months of each other, are more than just a run of bad luck. Systemwide flaws in the way tankers are built, operated and monitored contribute to accidents, according to records and interviews with industry experts. On an average of five days out of seven last year, a tanker ran aground, hit another ship or a dock, broke apart, sprung a leak, exploded or had some other kind of mishap, according to Coast Guard records. A Coast Guard report on tanker safety cited ``formidable problems'' in regulating tankers. Among them are fatigued tanker crews, shipowners who give more priority to schedules than safety and inspectors who are overworked and burned out. The Center for Marine Conservation has called for a presidential task force to assess tanker safety because no agency is doing a top-to-bottom review. It also criticized cutbacks in the Coast Guard as ``false economizing.'' And despite the Exxon Valdez wreck that caused the nation's worst oil spill on March 24, 1989, the industry remains ill-prepared to handle a major spill and a glacial-paced Congress still hasn't passed a tanker safety package. The result is bleak news for a nation whose gluttonous appetite for oil means more tankers, many of them aging, will be pulling into its ports. On any given day, about 50 tankers carrying 450 million gallons of oil sail into U.S. harbors, each one a potential environmental disaster. ``We are asking for trouble,'' said Clifton Curtis, president of the Oceanic Society. And not just environmentalists are uneasy. ``This industry is in a bad way,'' said Arthur MacKenzie, head of the Tanker Advisory Group and a former Exxon Corp. shipping executive. ``We have to make drastic changes in the way we build, operate and license in this business. ``Who's studying the whole picture? Nobody.'' In sheer numbers, the Coast Guard investigated 265 oil spills from tankers last year, an average of five a week. Most were minor, but six were more than 10,000 gallons, including the 11 million gallons disgorged by the Exxon Valdez. Add last year's 639 tank barge incidents, and the average is 17 a week. A private study by Golob's Oil Pollution Bulletin in Cambridge, Mass., counted 78 spills of 10,000 gallons or more in the past 12 years, an average of nearly seven a year. Total spillage was 41 million gallons. At the same time, 243 billion gallons, or 99.98 percent of the oil shipped, got to shore safely. The oil industry says that record hardly supports the image of an oceanic demolition derby. But six major spills have occurred already this year. And the public, as much as it demands the oil, won't tolerate the sliming of beaches and shorelines. ``What was an acceptable level of performance 10 years ago is not acceptable today,'' said Sean Connaughton of the American Petroleum Institute. ``There's an almost zero tolerance for oil spills. The sensitivity is so much greater now.'' Environmentalists say the breakdowns are not isolated incidents but examples of common problems, the way Three Mile Island was in the nuclear power industry and the Challenger explosion was in the space industry. ``Clearly, this is an issue that has reached and will exceed crisis proportions. The potential for an increasing number and more severe accidents is very high,'' said Roger McManus, president of the Center for Marine Conservation. ``What we have on the seas is something we wouldn't put up with in air traffic,'' he said. ``It desperately needs attention.'' Turning things around is trickier than steering a supertanker in a tight channel. There is no one solution because there is no one problem, and no one agency who can fix it. Each branch of Congress passed its own version of an oil tanker safety bill last fall. But a 100-member conference named to reconcile the differences had met just once before the Mega Borg exploded June 9 and leaked 3.9 million gallons of oil. On July 12, the committee reached a compromise that would require new tankers be built with puncture-resistant double hulls whileexisting tankers be fitted with a second hull or phased out of service over the next 20 years. In addition, the bill would create a $1 billion oil spill response fund, make it easier for the Coast Guard to take over cleanup efforts, set liability levels for spills and toughen licensing requirements for tanker crew members. A final vote is pending.
DOC.NOTE: MORE
$Adv22
For release Sunday, July 22, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: is pending.
DOC.TEXT: Meanwhile, the Coast Guard motto is ``Semper Paratus'' or ``Always Prepared.'' But in an interview, its commandant said the service would be better suited to live up to its motto if Congress acts. ``There is more that can be done. We're less prepared without this bill,'' conceded Adm. J. William Kime. ``We need to do everything we can to minimize the probability we're going to have a spill and then maximize our ability to limit the impact of the pollution.'' The Coast Guard, in a 44-page report by its Tanker Safety Study Group, said a review of tanker operations has not been done in 10 years. Among the highlights of the report, distributed last fall to all admirals, were: Tankers are being driven harder and faster by shipowners more concerned with schedules than safety; the Coast Guard pays too much attention to owners' desires to make money and too little attention to safety; Coast Guard inspectors are overworked and burned out by a ``dirty and tiring job,'' and their training is inadequate; tankers are built with 18 percent less steel than in the 1970s; newer ships are so big only 20 percent of the inside of their cargo tanks are inspected. The report said the best way to avoid shipwrecks is having competent crews, because human error plays a part in 90 percent of the groundings and collisions and 75 percent of the fires and explosions. Cuts in the number of crew have ``severely impaired'' routine maintenance, the report said. And relying on automation and machines as a cure-all ``misses the point and provides a false sense of security.'' Fatigue is also factor. When Coast Guard inspectors met with chief mates to set up inspections, ``some mates were so exhausted they fell asleep during these meetings.'' The Center for Marine Conservation did its own study called ``Shipping Safety and America's Coasts.'' It urged presidential action and assailed Congress for not giving the Coast Guard the money and manpower to do its job right. ``Our coasts deserve a better defense than they are getting from false economizing,'' said the center's Michael Weber. The center said better radar used in other parts of the world could be used in domestic ports for less than the cost of a cleaning up a good-sized spill. Exxon has spent $2 billion on the Valdez cleanup. In Valdez, the Coast Guard cut the power on its radar and reduced crew sizes for budget reasons. The Exxon Valdez was off the screen when it crashed. Foreign ports have radar that beeps an alarm if a ship strays from its channel. In another cost-cutting move, the Coast Guard cut out vessel traffic systems in New York and New Orleans. The system, used in five ocean ports, allows mariners to see beyond blind corners and keep up to date on what other ships are doing. But other countries have better systems. At Sullom Voe, Europe's largest oil and gas terminal operated by British Petroleum Co. in Scotland's Shetland Islands, licensed pilots instead of technicians work at radar screens to steer tankers past reefs and hazards. ``The existing vessel traffic services in the U.S. are far from state of the art,'' said Richard Townsend, who did the study for the Center for Marine Conservation. ``Much better systems currently are available, using off-the-shelf technology that is vastly superior to that currently used by the Coast Guard.'' In the private sector, 20 oil companies formed the Petroleum Industry Response Organization last year. The group would set up five regional centers covering 24 coastal states that would act as gigantic fire houses with booms, skimmers and oil dispersants. But the organization is waiting for Congress before it buys any equipment. ``The void that existed when the Exxon Valdez had its accident still exists as far as cleanup is concerned,'' said retired Adm. John Costello, who heads the group. ``We don't own any ships or any booms yet.''

DOC.HEAD: Double Hulls Create Controversy
With BC-Troubled Waters, b0797-b0798
DOC.TEXT: A double hull creates a ship within a ship. It is two layers of steel, separated by a gap of air, around the sides and bottom of an oil tanker as an extra layer of protection. Environmental groups, in a letter to a congressional committee this month, said requiring double-hull tankers was ``the single most important step Congress can take to prevent oil spills.'' A compromise is pending in Congress to have two hulls on new tankers and to retrofit or phase out single-hulled tankers within 20 years. The House originally wanted a 15-year timetable while the Senate asked for more study. ``A double hull is not a be-all or end-all. But we've got to build redundancy into the system,'' said Clifton Curtis, president of the Oceanic Society. Curtis called the compromise ``a signficant victory.'' But he added: ``We are sorely displeased with the fact that the retrofit schedule is not more rapid.'' Advocates of double hulls say they would limit the impact of oil spills if a tanker runs aground, because a reef or man-made object would have to gash both layers to spill oil. A Coast Guard study of 30 tanker groundings between 1969 and 1973 said 96 percent of the spills would have been averted if the vessels had double hulls. A double hull would not have prevented the Exxon Valdez spill, but some studies say less crude oil would have fouled Prince William Sound in the nation's worst oil spill. ``Double hulls are an extra margin of safety to prevent or minimize marine accidents,'' said U.S. Coast Guard Commandant J. William Kime. But critics say double hulls also may have drawbacks. Water can rush in between layers of the steel and make a ship settle lower, thereby leaking more oil. There are also fears explosive vapors could gather between the gaps. Double hulls are also more expensive. It would have cost 10 percent to 15 percent more to build a double hull on the $125 million Exxon Valdez. Its damaged hull was repaired with 3,000 tons of new steel, but it still doesn't have a double hull. Retrofitting the 153 U.S. tankers at $30 million each would cost $4.6 billion; the same work on 900 foreign-flagged tankers could be as high as $10 billion, industry officials said. But the oil industry believes the debate is misdirected. ``If an airplane crashes into a mountain, we don't build planes that can withstand the impact. We try to find out why and prevent it from happening again,'' said Sean Connaughton of the American Petroleum Institute. ``If we have ships running into underwater mountains, we end up with people calling for ships that can withstand that type of collision,'' Connaughton said. Meanwhile, some companies aren't waiting for Congress. Houston-based Conoco Inc. ordered two double-hull tankers in April and said it would order double-hull ships in the future. Norway's Statoil, the largest producer of North Sea crude oil, said in June that it was ordering five new tankers, two with double hulls and three with double or partial double bottoms.
