DOC.TEXT: Stocks hit record levels again as the Dow Jones industrial average reached its third straight record high, tantalizing Wall Streeters by closing within a hair of 3,000 for the first time. Bond prices were narrowly mixed in light trading Monday. The dollar was higher against most major currencies and gold fell. Wholesale gasoline prices led a sharp rise in energy futures. The Dow briefly forayed above 3,000 for the first time Friday and remained in that territory for much of the session Monday. But it weakened in a bout of selling in the late afternoon and finished at 2,999.75, up 19.55.

McDonnell Douglas Corp. announced plans to reduce its workforce by up to 11 percent, about 17,000 jobs, and cut other costs in an effort to shore up the aerospace giant's sagging bottom line. John F. McDonnell, chairman and chief executive officer, said Monday the measures should save the company more than $700 million this year, or about 5 percent of annual expenses, and put the nation's largest defense contractor on ``very solid footing.''

A rebound in business sales in May helped keep inventories growing at a moderate rate, the government said in another sign of continued economic expansion. The Commerce Department said Monday inventories held on shelves and backlots totaled a seasonally adjusted $799.4 billion, up 0.4 percent after April's 0.3 percent gain. The report, which was in line with economists' expectations, provided fresh evidence that the economy was not in danger of toppling immediately into a recession.

The White House hiked its forecast of next year's budget deficit to $168.8 billion _ $231.4 billion if savings and loan costs are counted _ and warned of devastating cuts in programs without a quick budget compromise with Congress. The estimate Monday was more than two-thirds higher than the administration's projection just six months ago.

Health care cost issues will take up a lot of time in this summer's auto industry labor negotiations, a Ford Motor Co. executive said. ``Health care is just a mega-issue,'' said the executive, who spoke only on condition of anonymity Monday. Negotiations between the UAW and Ford open Thursday. Talks between the union and General Motors Corp. open Wednesday. Chrysler Corp. and the UAW open talks Friday. UAW contracts with each of the Big Three expire Sept. 14.

International Business Machines Corp. said its profit rose 5.2 percent in the second quarter as revenue grew 8.4 percent, results that generally pleased industry analysts. The world's largest computer company said Monday it earned $1.41 billion, or $2.45 a share, in the three months ended June 30, up from $1.34 billion, or $2.31 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $16.49 billion from $15.21 billion.

A federal judge ordered more than 100,000 cases nationwide involving victims of asbestos-related diseases consolidated into a single class action in a dramatic attempt to clear a huge court backlog. The surprise ruling Monday by Thomas D. Lambros, chief judge of U.S. District Court in Cleveland, comes amid mounting problems with a trust set up by Manville Corp. to compensate workers killed or injured from handling asbestos. Plaintiffs lawyers said they expected the order to be challenged in a federal appeals court.

RJR Nabisco Inc. announced the details of a $6.9 billion recapitalization plan the company says will include the retirement of more than $3 billion in junk bonds and a $1.15 billion bridge loan. The recapitalization, unveiled Monday, is aimed at reducing RJR Nabisco's most expensive debt, leaving the firm less vulnerable to the problems that have undermined other debt-burdened companies over the past year. Under the plan, RJR Nabisco's debt will be reduced to less than $20 billion from the current level of approximately $23 billion, said Karl von der Heyden, the company's executive vice president and chief financial officer.

Southland Corp. said it had agreed in principal to sweeten a debt restructuring plan aimed at helping keep the owner of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain out of bankruptcy court. The revision includes cash for some holders of Southland junk bonds plus an agreement by Japanese investors that are taking over the company to provide more money in exchange for fewer shares in the restructured business, it was announced Monday. The founding Thompson family also would end up with a smaller stake in the company.

A judge tossed out all charges against Rite Aid Corp. and its president after ruling the evidence against them in a bribery case was circumstantial. Martin L. Grass, 36, and Rite Aid were accused of bribing a member of Ohio's Board of Pharmacy to resign so the panel would have a makeup more favorable to the drugstore company. Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Judge Lillian Greene Monday granted a defense motion asking for a judgment of acquittal after the prosecution rested its case.

DOC.HEAD: Small-Business Optimism Fades
Moved in advance.
DOC.TEXT: Small-business optimism about the immediate future faded in June to the lowest level for that month in at least four years. In reporting survey results of more than 700 detailed responses from small businesses, economist William Dunkelberg said declines were noted in all but two of 10 components of a so-called optimism index. The index, produced for the National Federation of Independent Business, declined to a reading of 100.1, six-tenths of a point below its year-ago reading and more than two points below June readings in 1986, 1987 and 1988. The report confirms the weakness observed in other business surveys, but it found little evidence among federation members that a credit squeeze was responsible. However, Dunkelberg, dean of Temple University's school of business in Philadelphia, said only 35 percent of reporting companies said they were regular borrowers, a near record low for the survey, which was begun in 1974. The index is based on a formula that includes plans, opinions and hard data on factors such as expected business conditions, expected sales volume, the climate for expansion, job openings, and hiring and spending plans. The study found declines in plans for capital spending, hiring and investment in larger inventories. The labor market weakened slightly, but both the pace of price increases and plans to raise prices declined. The June optimism reading was also the lowest of 1990, although slightly lower readings were measured last October, November and December. While the optimism index measures results and attitudes of mostly small businesses _ although ``small'' can mean companies with more than $100 million in sales _ some economy watchers feel it is a responsive grass-roots tool. Dunkelberg notes, for example, that the business community represented by the survey employs about one-half the private non-farm work force and produces about 50 percent of the nation's gross private sector product. Using 1978 as its base of 100, the index plunged to a quarterly low of just 81.1 in the second quarter of 1980, but rebounded even more sharply to 95.1 in the third quarter of that year, foretelling the rise from recession. By 1983, the index was regularly over 100, reaching an all-time high of 108.7 in the first quarter of 1984. Since the second quarter of 1984 it has wavered between 99.5 and 102.7. While the survey found no evidence of a credit crunch, it found suggestions of tighter lending practices, causing Dunkelberg to comment that while ``there is more selectivity, this should be expected at the peak of a business cycle.'' He observed that projects that may have looked good to lenders at the beginning of the expansion might not appear to have the same promise late in the expansion, especially in real estate development. ``Thus, with the same standards, projects that were accepted earlier will now be turned down,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Young Economics Students Watch as Supply Meets Demand
LaserPhoto CX?
DOC.TEXT: Three dozen teen-agers from across the nation witnessed firsthand Monday the noisy collision of supply and demand. ``It looks like chaos,'' 14-year-old Tara Powell, from Northeastern High School in Elizabeth City, N.C., said as she watched traders at the Chicago Board of Trade try to fit the two sides of the economic equation together. She was one of 36 high school students who showed a special acumen in the futures markets along with their economics classes. The students got a free trip to Chicago and a look at how futures trading is really done. In simulated trading during the school year, Miss Powell made a profit of $16,860 in the gold futures market. ``It was an eye-opener,'' she said, standing beside the crowded corn pit as prices plunged 3 cents to 4 cents lower from Friday's close. Around her, order forms fluttered to the floor from traders' hands, ready to be scooped up by runners who hustle the buy and sell orders back to computer terminals. Like her fellow students, Miss Powell was entranced by the noise and fast pace. ``You get to let loose and yell a lot,'' she said. ``But you've got to know what you're doing.'' Each of the students was assigned to a trader, who was supposed to explain what was going on. Trader Joel Jacobson, amid the din of the corn pit, took a minute out to give some pointers to Bruce Bishop, 15, of Beaumont Junior High School in Lexington, Ky. Jacobson had a hand full of forms and wads of paperwork were jammed into the half dozen pockets in his jacket. He looked like a walking file cabinet. ``This is an order for 5,000 bushels of corn,'' Jacobson said, pointing to a few squiggles on a piece of paper. ``But the price looked too good, so I sent it back for confirmation and the customer said `buy', so we bought.'' ``Five thousands bushels of corn sold just like that, no fuss, no muss,'' he told his student. ``I love it,'' Bishop said. ``It's a tense situation, but it never gets boring.'' A few minutes later Jacobson was asked about a detail of the 5,000-bushel corn trade. ``I don't remember anything about it,'' he said. ``It's 10:21 a.m., that was 10:18 a.m. so it's ancient history.'' Another student, Carmen Barrus, 18, of Los Alamos High School in New Mexico, made $30,000 in her hypothetical trading of sugar futures, but the real trading pits had a special appeal. ``Wow!'' she said. ``It's very exciting. It's something new every day!'' All the students had heard about the indictments last year of 48 people involved in futures trading at the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. None of the teens questioned about this seemed troubled by the allegations of fraud. ``The corruption doesn't seem very widespread,'' said Miss Powell, indicating she wouldn't be concerned about being sullied if she sought a career in futures. ``It's a personal thing,'' she said. ``You don't just get corrupted. If something is against the law, you just don't do it.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Class Action in Nation's Asbestos Cases
DOC.TEXT: In a dramatic step aimed at easing backlogs in the nation's court dockets, a federal judge has ordered consolidation of more than 100,000 liability cases involving workers killed or injured handling asbestos. The ruling Monday by Thomas D. Lambros, chief judge of U.S. District Court in Cleveland, comes amid mounting problems with a trust set up by Manville Corp. to compensate victims of asbestos-related diseases such as lung cancer. Lambros said he issued the order because thousands of victims nationwide could go uncompensated as companies that made asbestos products were or could become unable to pay millions of dollars in asbestos liability. Plaintiffs lawyers said they expected the order to be opposed and challenged in a federal appeals court. ``Each victim doesn't get their day in court,'' said Perry Weitz, a New York lawyer handling hundreds of cases. All cases filed under the umbrella of a class action are bound by a single court judgment, eliminating individual trials and out-of-court settlements. But class action also raises the possibility of an adverse ruling for all victims. The move pre-empted similar action threatened by U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein in Brooklyn, who has sought to take charge of fixing the financially ailing Manville trust fund and clearing the asbestos backlog. Weinstein last week ordered the trust to halt all payments to victims until he receives a proposal on Aug. 6 to restructure and refinance the trust, which was created in 1988 as part of Manville's bankruptcy court reorganization. The trust is out of cash to pay new claims and has said people who file claims now may not be compensated until well into the next century. Asbestos-related cases form the largest number of personal injury lawsuits in the country. Lambros said more than 100,000 claims have been filed in federal and state courts nationwide. Some cases aren't scheduled for trial until the late 1990s, while thousands of others await resolution with the Manville trust. Several dozen companies that made asbestos products and the Manville trust, which is legally separate from the company, are defendants in the cases. In a four-page order, Lambros said the asbestos litigation meets the requirement for creating a class action because ``there are insufficient funds among all of the defendants to pay all meritorious claims'' and the cost of litigation. The judge said that since 1982, Manville and several other companies have sought bankruptcy court protection because of thousands of lawsuits seeking asbestos compensation, while other companies are ``approaching the brink of bankruptcy.'' Lambros said the Cleveland court has 7,000 asbestos personal injury cases with more than 13,000 claims pending, the nation's largest concentration of cases. Manville once was the nation's largest maker of asbestos, which was used widely for decades because of its natural heat-resistance and insulation properties. It later was identified as carcinogenic. Manville, based in Denver, emerged from Chapter 11 proceedings in 1988 and no longer makes asbestos. The trust so far has spent $974 million in settling the first 22,000 cases at an average of $43,509 a claim, well above initial estimates of $25,000 per settlement. Some 130,000 claims are pending but the trust expects no new funds until late 1991. The main criticism of the trust is that it processes claims on the basis of when they are filed, rather than the nature of the disease or the victim's need. The system is expected to be altered under the reorganization ordered by Weinstein. Lambros said his order establishing a class action could be changed only by a decision from a recently formed committee of judges with the nation's largest asbestos dockets. The order also establishes sub-classes of exisiting cases to be managed and processed in state and federal courts. A Manville trust spokeswoman declined to comment on the court order. Last week, Weinstein supported but did not order consolidation of asbestos litigation into a class action, instead ordering an overhaul of the trust. But Weinstein said creating a class action could ``maximize a prompt, fair recovery to all claimants under a final settlement involving all parties _ the trust, claimants, the corporation and other defendant companies.'' He said cases now being settled or tried could be excluded from the mandatory class. The judge also proposed a parallel registration system for less urgent claims by victims presently without symptoms.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Study: Better Safeguards Needed on Financial Planners
DOC.TEXT: A congressional study says investors should not be misled into believing personal financial advisers are closely watched by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Investment advisers and financial planners must register with the SEC and submit to periodic review if they advise on securities or issue analyses of securities. But the SEC doesn't guarantee that investment advisers know what they're doing. A study by the General Accounting Office released Monday found that the SEC was behind in reviewing registered advisers. When advisers are reviewed, usually only inadequate disclosure or record-keeping problems are uncovered and the SEC does little to ensure deficiencies are corrected, the report said. Under the 1940 Investment Advisers Act, the SEC requires investmentadvisers to register with the agency and submit to periodic review. Information submitted at registration is not verified until the first review, which could take up to a year or more, the GAO report said. ``SEC's oversight of investment advisers provides investors little assurance that the information they receive from advisers is accurate or that advisers operate in accordance with'' the law, according to the GAO study. The SEC, however, noted that to implement the report's recommendations would require tripling the staff now devoted to investment adviser review. The GAO, the accounting arm of Congress, warned that current law _ unless improved _ ``may be doing more harm than good'' by lulling investors into a false sense of security ``that SEC-registered advisers have a `seal of approval.''' The study noted that one investor who lost her life savings of $60,000 said she had been ``impressed'' that the investment adviser was registered with the SEC. The investor was not identified in the report. In a letter attached to the report, SEC officials said they do not have enough money and people to adequately regulate the financial advice industry. ``Recently, between 2,000 and 3,000 new advisers have registered annually. To inspect all new registrants within one year of registration would require a very large increase in staff resources,'' Kathryn B. McGrath, who was then head of the SEC's Division of Investment Management, wrote the GAO in an April 23 letter. She noted that the average SEC examiner is able to complete about 25 inspections a year and in 1990, the current division staff of 53 expects to complete about 1,330 examinations. A hearing on the issue is scheduled for Wednesday before the House Energy and Commerce Committee's finance subcommittee, which requested the GAO study. Rep. Rick Boucher, D-Va., a member of the subcommittee, has submitted a bill that would require anyone offering investment advice for pay to register with the SEC and provide clients with accurate information. The bill also would give customers the right to sue for damages when they lose money because of violations of the law. ``This report sounds a warning bell for the millions of Americans who consult financial planners each year,'' Boucher said in a statement issued jointly with Reps. Edward Markey, D-Mass., and Dennis Eckart, D-Ohio. Last year, the SEC submitted legislation that would farm out investment adviser oversight to a self-regulatory organization like the National Association of Securities Dealers. That has yet to be acted on. The GAO study noted that since 1980, the number of investment advisers has tripled to about 14,000 while the assets they manage have increased from $440 billion 10 years ago to about $4.6 trillion today. While the amount of fraud and abuse reported to date has been relatively small compared to the amount of assets managed, the GAO worried that the three-fold increase in the number of people providing financial advice and the 10-fold increase in assets managed ``raises the risk that fraud and abuse will occur and the potential that any amounts lost could be large.''

DOC.HEAD: Feds Move to Speed Sale of Failed S&L Assets
DOC.TEXT: Savings and loan bailout officials hope to speed the sale of distressed real estate and sour loans by mixing them with more attractive assets in multimillion-dollar packages. A Bush administration board overseeing the bailout approved the new sales technique on a trial basis Monday. The Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board, headed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, authorized bulk sales totaling $2 billion. The agency overseen by the board will put together portfolios of similar assets such as commercial loans, commmrcial real estate, apartment properties or apartment loans. The packages will include both good and problem assets. Ed Kane, Ohio State University business professor and thrift expert, said $2 billion is a small amount compared with the huge volume of assets that need to be sold, but he praised the bulk sales concept. ``I think the important thing is to get these things out of the hands of the government, which is run for bureaucratic purposes, and put them into the hands of private people who can make decisions for entrepreneurial reasons. That will be best for the taxpayers in the long run,'' Kane said. Bulk sales have been criticized by others, who label it a fire sale that could depress asset values by flooding the market. However, Kane said, ``When you have the financial equivalent of a fire, a fire sale is the first thing you do.'' Selling properties one by one is ``terribly inefficient,'' he said. In its first 11 months, the RTC has taken over about 460 failed S&Ls, selling or closing about 210 of them. But in S&L sales so far, the agency has been stuck with about half of the institutions' assets, usually the delinquent loans and repossessed real estate. The oversight board is permitting the bailout agency to lend portfolio buyers up to 85 percent of the purchase price for up to five years. ``Ideally we'd like it to be shorter term ... but we wanted to give (the agency) the flexibility,'' said Felisa Neuringer, an oversight board spokeswoman. After the trust corporation completes $2 billion in sales, the oversight board will evaluate the program's success and consider extending it. On a related matter, the oversight board authorized the trust corporation to give some properties away to local governments and non-pofit agencies for use as day care centers, housing for the homeless or other public purposes. Properties will be eligible for the program if the agency determines that the cost of holding and selling them exceeds their value. Another part of the S&L bureaucracy, the Federal Housing Finance Board, announced approval of a $669 million housing program for low-income people. The program, required by last year's S&L bailout bill, is financed by the 12 regional Federal Home Loan Banks, which in turn are owned by the S&L industry. The finance board, headed by Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, is spending $47.2 million from the home loan banks in combination with private and foundation funds and other government grants and loans. The money will pay for 193 projects providing 13,706 housing units in 37 states. Much of it will be used to offer low-interest mortgage loans to low-income homebuyers through thrifts and banks. Fred Webber, president of the U.S. League of Savings Institutions, the industry's largest trade group, noted that the program would not exist without the industry-owned home loan banks. It ``demonstrates that this nation needs a separate, healthy savings institution business to meet the need for decent, affordable housing,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pennzoil to Invest $480 Million in Chevron Shares
DOC.TEXT: Pennzoil Co. has announced that it will invest the remaining $480 million from its $2.6 billion Texaco lawsuit in additional Chevron shares. The investment would give Pennzoil just under 10 percent of Chevron's stock, Pennzoil officials said Monday. In a letter written to Pennzoil shareholders and filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission Monday, Pennzoil also griped openly for the first time about how Chevron management is running the company. Chevron declined to comment on Pennzoil's latest statement of intentions. The San Francisco oil giant has been fighting Houston-based Pennzoil since last year, when Pennzoil used its Texaco spoils to accumulate 8.8 percent of Chevron's stock. Chevron filed suit, claiming Pennzoil lied when it said it was buying the stock for investment purposes only. Pennzoil said Monday it does not currently plan to acquire 10 percent or more of Chevron, a larger stake would trigger Chevron's ``poison pill.'' But Pennzoil also applied Monday to the Federal Trade Commission for clearance under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Act to purchase 15 percent or more of the stock. ``We believe Chevron has the potential to be an attractive long-term investment for Pennzoil and its shareholders,'' Harper said of the additional shares Pennzoil plans to purchase. The balance of the $2.6 billion Texaco settlement is in short-term securities, and the company wants a more lucrative home for them that will provide the tax shelter Pennzoil is seeking, Harper said.

DOC.HEAD: Pathe Delivers Another $53 Million on Its Merger Deal
DOC.TEXT: Pathe Communications Corp. has paid another $53 million toward purchase of MGM-UA Communications Co, bringing its total nonrefundable down-payments to $253 million. ``It is a step in our plans to consummate the merger of the two companies,'' Scott Tagliarino, a spokesman for MGM-UA, said Monday. ``It is a further demonstration of Pathe's seriousness about the transaction and we're confident that the financing for the balance will be arranged,'' said Pathe spokesman Craig Parsons. Under terms of the latest agreement between Pathe chief Giancarlo Parretti and Kirk Kerkorian, who controls MGM-UA, the $253 million will be paid out Friday to MGM-UA shareholders at $4 per share. Kerkorian is the chief shareholder, controlling more than 70 percent of the entertainment company's common shares. Parretti has made payments of $50 million per month since March, while he tried to arrange financing for the $1.3 billion purchase. He has agreed to make another $50 million payment next month and one in September, then come up with the balance in October. Parretti had agreed to a $20-a-share offer, but raised it to $21.50 a share in return for a four-month extension on the deal after failing to come to terms with his major backer, Time Warner Inc. Time Warner had been the most solid-appearing component of Pathe's offer with the rest of the money to be provided by loans and assets from Pathe's affiliates. Time Warner had agreed to provide a $650 million loan to Pathe for the deal in return for a lien on the valuable United Artists film library and extensive distribution rights to Pathe and UA movies. However, Time Warner has sued Pathe for $100 million, accusing Pathe of breaching its contract by, among other things, double-selling some distribution rights. The media conglomerate said Pathe apparently never was able to meet one of the terms of the deal: that it come up with the other half of the $1.3 billion in money that was not borrowed. Pathe counter-sued for $500 million last week, saying Time Warner had breached its contractual duty to provide the $650 million loan.

DOC.HEAD: Ford to Invest $80 Million in Hungary
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. plans to follow General Motors Corp. into Hungary by spending $80 million to build an auto parts factory in the Eastern European nation. Ford, the second-largest U.S. automaker behind GM, said Monday that it would begin making ignition coils and fuel pumps for vehicles built in Western European countries in 1992. The factory will make about 3.2 million parts a year and employ about 200 people when full production is reached. The plant is Ford's first venture into Hungary and Eastern Europe. In January, GM announced a $150 million investment in the state-owned Hungarian company RABA to manufacture automobiles and engines. Ford said that in return for a five-year investment package approved by the Hungarian government, the company will increase the number of vehicles it brings into Hungary from Western Europe. Hungarian Industry and Commerce Minister Peter Akos Bod said about 12,000 Fords were purchased in Hungary last year. Bruce Blythe, vice president for business strategy for Ford of Europe Ltd., said the new plant's products will reduce pollution by his company's cars. ``The components are critical to achieving the low-exhaust emission levels that will become standard across Europe in the mid-1990s,'' Blythe said.

DOC.HEAD: Southland Announces Revised Restructuring Plan
DOC.TEXT: Round-the-clock meetings during the weekend produced an agreement between Southland Corp. and some of its creditors that will pay cash to junk bond holders and give them a larger share of a restructured company. But some analysts questioned if the sweetened deal, which also calls for a larger cash infusion from Japanese investors, can save the 7-Eleven convenience store chain owner burdened by huge debts after a $4.9 billion leveraged buyout in 1987. ``No one's been able to prove to me yet why it wouldn't be better to throw them into bankruptcy,'' said Jay Lustig, who follows distressed companies for Drake Capital Securities Inc. in Santa Monica, Calif. The agreement is the latest revision in a plan first announced in March that involved a bailout by Ito-Yokado Co. Ltd. and Seven-Eleven Japan Co. Ltd., a majority-owned subsidiary. Southland missed $69 million in interest payments due June 15, and a 30-day grace period expired Sunday during which the Dallas-based company could have made the payments without penalty. But weekend meetings between a committee of creditors, the Japanese investors and Southland produced an agreement in principle on the restructuring, spokeswoman Cecilia Stubbs Norwood said Monday. The agreement replaces a proposal that would have paid holders of $1.8 billion in debt about $550 million, plus stock and securities in the new company. Ms. Norwood said no value was immediately available on the revision. Also Monday, some bondholders filed a lawsuit in U.S. District Court in Dallas asking that Southland be forced to pay $69 million in interest payments it missed on June 15. The company reaffirmed Monday that it would not make the payments, leaving open the door for creditors to force Southland into bankruptcy court. Under the new proposal, Ito-Yokado and Seven-Eleven Japan would contribute $430 million in new capital in exchange for 70 percent of the common stock in the restructured company. Previously, the two had agreed to inject $400 million and get 75 percent of the new company. The founding Thompson family's share of the company would be reduced form 6.5 percent to about 5 percent. Bondholders would get the additional shares, upping their holdings to about 25 percent of the new company. Besides the increased stock, the most senior bondholders would receive $57 in cash for each $1,000 of the bonds they currently hold. No cash was included in the previous agreement. Other changes include increasing principal amounts of new securities and common stock swapped for the old debt. In exchange, the maturity dates are lengthened and interest rates lowered. Clark Matthews, Southland's chief financial officer, said holders of more than 70 percent of the most senior notes indicate they support the plan. The notes are considered a key group for this deal, which must be approved by 95 percent of each class of bond, plus two-thirds of preferred shareholders. ``We believe that we can successfully negotiate final documents and complete a restructuring and are now aiming for mid-August,'' Matthews said. ``I would feel a lot better if they would go ahead and pay the accrued interest,'' said David Glatstein of Barre & Co. Inc., a Dallas investment company that holds some of the bonds. Although he said the revised plan ``is more palatable than anything they've presented so far.'' The revisions are ``better for the steering committee. It's not much of a change for the four subordinated,'' classes of bonds, Lustig said. Lustig said he doubted Southland could get 95 percent acceptance _ a self-imposed level. ``My gut feeling is that if they get an 80 percent tender, they should just take it, kiss the ground and be done with it,'' he said. Southland has been struggling under heavy interest payments brought on by the buyout in 1987, which was announced before the Oct. 19 market crash, but financed after it. In addition to the higher interest costs, cash has been drained by increasing competition from proliferating convenience stores run by major oil companies. Southland said last year it would be unable to meet obligations in 1991. In March, the company first announced a proposed restructuring with its Japanese partners. Southland operates about 6,900 7-Eleven stores and other convenience outlets in the United States and Canada, with another 6,000 stores in the United States and 21 other countries run by licensees, of which Seven-Eleven Japan is the largest.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Judge Approves Southmark Reorganization
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge says Southmark Corp.'s restructuring plan is fair and equitable, but offers no assurances that federal regulators will not take further action against it. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Stephen Felsenthal approved the plan Monday, bringing one of the nation's largest bankruptcy cases near an end. Under the plan, the company will liquidate almost all of its holdings except for San Jacinto Savings Association, a $3 billion thrift based in the Houston suburb of Bellaire. But Felsenthal said Southmark has no guarantees that federal regulators will not seize the insolvent thrift. However, he said the reorganization plan improves the prospects for creditors recovering a fraction of what they are owed. ``It is in the public interest,'' said Felsenthal, who also noted that he believes the plan does not rely on San Jacinto's future. ``Reorganized Southmark should be able to perform under the plan even if (San Jacinto) is seized after confirmation.'' But a key element of the plan is an agreement by Southmark to inject $100 million in new capital into San Jacinto, which currently falls far short of regulatory capital requirements. Southmark filed for bankruptcy court protection from creditors last July, listing assets of $1.05 billion and debts of more than $1.4 billion. The plan calls for paying off holders of more than $1 billion in junk bonds with $75 million in cash shortly after confirmation. In addition, debt holders would receive preferred and common stock in the new company, plus representation on a new board of directors. Southmark once held assets of more than $9 billion as it used high yield, or junk bonds, to expand rapidly from a real estate investment trust to a holding company owning campgrounds, nursing homes, an insurance company and numerous other properties. Southmark filed for bankruptcy after a $1 billion first-quarter loss last year put it in technical default on its junk bonds. The company said it also would not be able to make principle and interest payments because of the losses.

DOC.HEAD: Suit Against S&L Settled
DOC.TEXT: The federal government, which sought $400 million, has agreed to settle a lawsuit against former officers of Eureka Federal Savings and Loan for $68 million, according to a published report. The San Francisco Chronicle reported in today's editions that the agreement was reached Sunday night, ending a trial in U.S. District Court in San Francisco that started in May. Former Eureka President Kenneth Kidwell and four other officers of the San Carlos-based thrift were sued by Eureka and the government. They were accused of allegedly mismanaging the institution's loan portfolios in 1983 and 1984 and incurring more than $200 million in losses. Regulators brought in new management in 1985 and three years later sold the institution to American First Corp., in 1988. Federal regulators contended Kidwell, Robert N. Harris, Allan R. Jamieson, Donald B. Keuper, and Walter Gilliam Jr., made more than 150 real estate and commercial loans totaling $260 million that almost immediately went into default. Recipients of the loans included casinos in Reno and Las Vegas and real estate projects in Texas, Wisconsin, Florida and other states. The government charged that the loans were made without required regulatory approval, without adequate assessment of the borrower's financial state and with numerous other negligent actions. Arthur Shartsis, Kidwell's lawyer, said on Monday the settlement was ``a very bad result for the government.'' He said it had refused to accept a $78 million settlement offer from the defendants' insurance company shortly before the trial started. John Thomas, associate general counsel for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said the defendants had refused to negotiate on any kind of settlement until last fall when they came up with a $45 million offer that the government rejected. Thomas conceded that in light of the later $78 million offer, ``with the benefit of hindsight, we probably would do it a little differently today.''

DOC.HEAD: Federal Bankruptcy Court OKs Maxicare's Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: A reorganization plan by Maxicare Health Plans has been approved by a federal bankruptcy court, allowing the health maintenance organization to emerge from court supervision. The plan approved Monday will not be implemented until early October, said Maxicare spokesman Ed Coughlan. The company still must meet technical and cash requirements before emerging from bankruptcy protection, he said. ``We have a significant amount of cash on hand, but we still have to generate more. But we don't anticipate that will be a problem,'' Coughlan said. The plan calls for creditors and shareholders to receive about $130 million in cash, 10-year notes at 13.5 percent interest with a face value of about $67 million, and common stock and options. More than 90 percent of the HMO's creditors and shareholders approved the proposal, according to Maxicare, which had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection March 16. Forty-nine percent of the restructured company will be owned by medical facilities and doctors who continue providing services to Maxicare members. The court also continued a preliminary injunction that prevents creditor doctors and hospitals from billing Maxicare members for debts owed by the firm. The Los Angeles-based health maintenance organization operates in California, Illinois, Indiana, Louisiana, North Carolina, South Carolina and Wisconsin.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Higher at Midday
DOC.TEXT: London stocks were higher at midday Tuesday. One market participant said that institutions were active buyers, inspired by the strong performance on Wall Street Monday. At about noon in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 22.3 points, or 1 percent, at 2,428.8. Volume came to 306.6 million shares at midday, compared with 195.7 million shares at the same time Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Leader Delivers Stern Warning on Oil Over-Production
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein on Tuesday warned Gulf oil producers that Iraq will retaliate against them _ possibly with force _ if they continue producing above OPEC quotas. He said the excessive production is an American plot carried out by some rulers in the Gulf designed to deplete revenues from oil exports, which has cost Iraq billions of dollars. The Iraqi leader, speaking on television on the 22nd anniversary of his ruling Baath Party coming to power, said: ``Raising our voice against the evil is not the final resort if the evil continues.'' ``There should be some effective act to bring back things to their right place ... Iraqis will not forget the proper saying that cutting necks is better than cutting the means of living,'' he said. ``Oh God Almighty be witness that we have warned them.'', Saddam did not mention any country by name. But Iraqi Oil Minister Abdulrahim al-Chalabi has named the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait as the culprits for violating production ceilings set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. ``The policies of some Arab rulers are American. They are inspired by America to undermine Arab interests and security,'' Saddam said. He said that since the collapse of communist governments in Eastern Europe, the United States is seeking to become the only world superpower and ``implement this dream through controlling Gulf oil. He said the overproduction brought prices down and allowed the United States to to add to its strategic stockpiles of oil with cheap oil. The Iraqi leader said certain Gulf leaders are trying to undermine Iraq after it emerged ``triumphant'' in its eight-year war with Iran. He vowed that he will not let them continue this policy which he described as ``dangerous and harming the interests and the security of the Arab nation.'' The United Arab Emirates has been overproducing its OPEC-set production quota by about one million barrels a day and Kuwait by some 200,000 barrels per day. This has been one reason for a recent fall in oil prices from OPEC's benchmark goal of $18 per barrel to as low as $14 dollars a barrel. Saddam's statement comes after an agreement was reportedly reached last week in Saudi Arabia which would increase the U.A.E. quota from 1.1. million barrels a day to 1.5 million. Under the agreement Kuwait would stick to its 1.5 million barrel-a-day ceiling. Iraq was one of the major Arab OPEC producers which accepted the new arrangement. Oil ministers of the cartel, scheduled to meet in Geneva, Switzerland, on July 25, are expected to accept the settlement.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Climbed to $7.73 Billion in May
DOC.NOTE: Eds: removes extraneous matter in middle. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit climbed to $7.73 billion in May, reflecting a big jump in imports of oil and foreign cars, the government said today. The Commerce Department said the May trade deficit was 5.8 percent higher than a revised April imbalance of $7.31 billion. In May, imports climbed 2.9 percent to $40.52 billion, offsetting a 2.3 percent rise in U.S. exports, which totaled $32.79 billion in May. The trade deficit is the difference between imports and exports. The big surge in oil accounted for almost half of the increase in imports in May, with imports of cars and other manufactured goods accounting for the rest of the gain. This increase overshadowed a healthy advance in U.S. exports, which posted their second best showing on record. The Bush administration is counting on strength in exports to offset a sluggish domestic economy and keep the country out of a recession this year. During the first three months of 1990, fully half of all economic growth was contributed by gains in exports. Through the first five months of this year, the U.S. trade deficit has been running at an annual rate of $97.68 billion, surprising many analysts who had been forecasting that this year's deficit would be little changed from the $109.4 billion imbalance recorded in 1989. The Bush administration is confidently predicting that America's trade performance will continue to improve throughout the year. However, many private analysts worry that America's growing dependence on foreign oil will cut into the export gains being made by U.S. businesses. In May, oil imports shot up 15.2 percent to $4.32 billion. The advance reflected an increase in the volume of shipments, which rose to 8.95 million barrelsa day, up from daily shipments of 7.55 million barrels in April. The price per barrel actually fell to $15.57 per barrel, down a full $1 from the April price. Shipments of new cars were up 5.2 percent in May to $3.88 billion, reflecting higher imports from Canada and other countries, which offset a drop in car shipments from Japan. The rise in U.S. exports reflected higher shipments in a variety of areas, including automotive parts, capital goods and consumer products. The United States continued to enjoy a trade surplus with the countries of Western Europe of $812 million in May while Japan continued to be the country with which the United States had the largest trade deficit. In May, the deficit with Japan totaled $2.97 billion, down sharply from a $3.95 billion April imbalance.

DOC.HEAD: CBOT Chief's Firm Ordered to Adjust Finances
DOC.TEXT: A major commodities trading company headed by the chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade says it is parceling out some accounts to get its books back in order. Stotler and Co., headed by Karsten Mahlmann, also said Monday that it is seeking an outside investor. Stotler has been directed by the Board of Trade to bring its amount of cash-on-hand up to 4 percent of customer funds, as required by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, by the close of business Wednesday, said a statement issued by the firm's parent company, Stotler Group Inc. If a brokerage does not maintain the required amount of regulatory capital, the exchange can restrict the brokerage to trading only for the purpose of liquidation and can transfer that brokerage's customer accounts to other brokerages, said Michael O'Connell, a Board of Trade spokesman. He referred questions about the specifics of the case to Chicago-based Stotler Group, where spokesman Vito Piazza declined to comment beyond the prepared statement. The statement said Stotler planned to meet the requirement by transferring a portion of its customer accounts and trading positions to other brokerages and by seeking ``a capital infusion from various parties.'' The moves are likely to reduce the firm's revenue and net income, Stotler said. ``Without a capital infusion, Stotler Group may be unable to meet its debt obligations unless those obligations are refinanced or restructured,'' the company said. The Chicago Tribune reported Saturday that Stotler, one of the nation's 10 biggest futures brokerages, may have run afoul of capital requirements because of its recent rapid growth. Stotler Group said another subsidiary brokerage, R.G. Dickinson & Co. of Des Moines, Iowa, was not affected by the compliance problems at Stotler and Co.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed On Conflicting Signals
DOC.TEXT: Wheat and soybean futures prices were slightly higher while the corn and oat markets slipped a bit this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting a combination of bullish and bearish signals. A National Weather Service forecast for cool, rainy weather early next week in the Midwest was a depressing factor in the corn and soybean pits, analysts said. But selling linked to the six-to-10-day outlook was offset by contradictory forecasts from some private forecasters and by perceptions that the corn and bean markets were due for a correction after sharp recent losses, said Ann Fricke, senior oilseed analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. Wheat futures also were viewed as oversold after three straight weeks of losses linked to the nearly completed winter wheat harvest. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.04{ a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to } cent lower with July at $2.73\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1{ cents lower with July at $1.20 a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 2 cents higher with July at $5.97{ a bushel. Cattle futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange; most pork futures were sharply higher, reflecting continued strength in the cash hog market. Live cattle futures were .03 cent to .13 cent higher with August at 75.50 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .20 cent higher with August at 87.45 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent lower to 1.45 cent higher with July at 64.22 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .90 cent to 1.88 cent higher with July at 50.75 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled mixed on Monday; pork futures rose sharply.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Deficit Estimate Seen Meaning Little to Budget Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with Bush promising to increase pressure for a compromise on new taxes and budget cuts. Picks up 9th graf pvs `No one ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WX6-7
With PM-Deficit-Wall Street, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that disturbing new figures on the federal deficit show that the ``time for game playing is over'' and he pledged to increase pressure for a compromise on new taxes and budget cuts. ``We're getting to a crunch,'' Bush told a group of magazine publishers at the White House. ``It is absolutely essential that something be done. I will do my part.'' He commented a day after the White House Office of Budget and Management boosted its estimate of the fiscal 1991 deficit to $168.8 billion _ up $10 billion from the administration's estimates a month ago and up sharply from the $100.5 billion it estimated in January. The projected deficit is more than $100 billion above the Gramm-Rudman law target of $64 billion. Congressional budget negotiators had given mixed reviews to the administration's gloomy assessment _ some saying it would help prod slow-moving talks and others suggesting the opposite. ``Given yesterday's news,'' Bush said today, ``...the time for game-playing is over. And we have to get something done that is not only a sound budget agreement but is seen by the American people to be a sound budget agreement.'' Bush said that while he was still ``fairly optimistic'' such a pact could be reached, it will require both spending cuts and tax increases. Bush earlier this month abandoned his 1988 ``no new taxes'' campaign pledge. The president said he was fearful ``about the confidence in the marketplace'' should a budget deal not be struck. ``We will be pushing in the next couple of weeks and the meter is running,'' Bush said. Budget summit talks between administration officials and congressional leaders enter their third month this week. Meanwhile, the House planned to vote today on a conservative-backed constitutional amendment that would require a balanced budget. Backers of the amendment conceded Monday they seemed to be several votes short of the two-thirds margin needed to approve a constitutional amendment. Bush sent a letter to Capitol Hill urging support of the amendment and calling for a line-item veto and greater authority for the president to impound funds appropriated by Congress. ``Together with political courage and discipline, these tools are vital to solving the problem of budget deficits,'' Bush said, calling the balanced budget amendment ``crucial to our nation's long-term economic health and prosperity.'' The administration coupled the release of the revised figures Monday with a bleak assessment of how a $100 billion cut in services _ which would be triggered this fall by the Gramm-Rudman law in the absence of a budget accord _ would affect government services. The scenarios included eliminating half the nation's 2 million active military personnel, reducing hours of operation at the nation's airports and halting increased drug interdiction efforts at the country's borders. No one was willing to say they believed such dramatic cuts would be allowed to stand for very long. As recently as last fall, the Gramm-Rudman law required spending cuts that were rolled back as soon as negotiators worked out a budget deal. But some lawmakers argued Monday that the new numbers illustrated a problem that had to be dealt with. ``The day of reckoning has arrived,'' said Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee. He said congressional leaders had asked the White House to illustrate possible budget cuts ``to find a way to convey a sense of crisis ... to show both our colleagues and the country that there is no choice here.'' Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, said the details should send a message to lawmakers who have opposed the budget talks. ``They now have a clear alternative,'' Domenici said. ``If it is not an economic summit, it is this, it is a $100 billion'' automatic spending cut. Not everyone agreed. One of the more partisan Democratic budget negotiators, Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, noted that the new deficit projection was just $9 billion higher than the shortfall the administration informally projected a month ago. Sasser, D-Tenn., described the talks as ``stalled.'' In contrast, Panetta said White House and congressional staff discussed possible tax-raising proposals over the weekend. The $168.8 billion shortfall projection did not include the costs of bailing out the savings and loan industry. When that spending is included, the White House estimated a $231.4 billion budget gap. The balanced budget amendment, if approved by two-thirds votes of each house of Congress and three-fourths of the states, would ban the government from spending more than it takes in unless three-fifths of the Congress voted to waive the requirement. The balanced budget rules would not take effect before fiscal 1993, and would be set aside in time of war. The House last voted on a balanced budget amendment in 1982, falling more than 40 votes short of approval. The House Democratic leadership opposes the amendment.

DOC.HEAD: Prozac Sales Lead to Record Quarterly Earnings for Eli Lilly
DOC.TEXT: Eli Lilly & Co. said Tuesday its earnings rose 26 percent to a record $274 million for the second quarter, led by sales of the antidepressant drug Prozac and other pharmaceuticals. For the three months ending June 30, earnings per share were 93 cents, compared with 75 cents on net income of $217 million during the same period in 1989. Sales rose 24 percent to a record $1.23 billion from $986.6 million during the second quarter last year. Chairman Richard D. Wood said Lilly experienced sales growth in each of its operations. ``Sales increased in both international and domestic markets. Higher unit volume continued to be the main contributor to the quarter's results,'' Wood said. Operating costs grew slower than sales, he added. Worldwide sales of pharmaceutical products ``were significantly higher than those of the second quarter of last year,'' Lilly said in a prepared statement. Besides Prozac, other pharmaceutical sales leaders included the drugs Axid, Ceclor, Dobutrex, Humatrope and Humulin, Lilly said. Lilly also reported record results for the first six months of 1990. Net income increased 23 percent to $615 million, or $2.07 per share, on sales of $2.47 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Recalling Workers at Assembly Plant
DOC.TEXT: About 180 laid-off hourly Chrysler Corp. workers will be recalled to the company's Sterling Heights assembly plant as production increases by 17 percent, Chrysler said Tuesday. Chrysler said it was boosting production at the plant north of Detroit effective Monday following a two-week model-changeover shutdown. The factory, which assembles Dodge Shadow and Plymouth Sundance two- and four-door cars, will employ about 3,100 hourly workers when work resumes next week. Chrysler spokesman Doug Nicoll declined to say how many cars the plant produced an hour before the changeover or how many it will make afterward.

DOC.HEAD: Industrial Production Climbs 0.4 Percent in June
DOC.TEXT: A spurt in automobile production and a heat wave that boosted utility output pushed industrial production up 0.4 percent in June, the Federal Reserve reported Tuesday. Last month's 0.4 percent gain, which followed a rise of 0.6 percent in May, surprised analysts who had been expecting a more modest increase. The June increase helped push industrial production for the second quarter up by an annual rate of 3.5 percent, a significant improvement over the mediocre 0.6 percent annual rate of gain in the first three months of the year. However, private analysts cautioned that the upturn was likely due to temporary factors rather than any long-term comeback in the nation's manufacturing sector, which has been in a slump for months. Analysts attributed much of the recent strength in auto production to the likelihood that automakers have been building up inventories in preparation for a possible September walkout by the United Auto Workers. ``Although the number is good, it's not necessarily a harbinger of strength in the months ahead. The manufacturing sector is still in the doldrums,'' said Michael K. Evans, who heads a Washington economic forecasting company. Still, Cynthia Latta of DRI-McGraw Hill said the increase in industrial production showed ``we're still slogging along with very slow growth, but some growth.'' ``Manufacturing is not booming, it's struggling,'' she said. ``But since output does seem to be expanding slightly, it has to be viewed as a relatively good report.'' The Fed said that the increases in automobile production and utility output accounted for three-fourths of the total June increase. The Fed also reported the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities, which usually move in tandem with industrial production, rose 0.2 percentage point to 83.5 percent of capacity in June. The operating rate measures not only output but changes in productivity levels. While the June operating rate was the highest since December's 83.7 percent, it was still well below the level a year ago when the industrial sector was operating at 84.6 percent of capacity. Industrial production at manufacturing plants making both durable and non-durable goods rose 0.5 percent in June after increasing 0.8 percent in May. Output of durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last at least three years _ also increased 0.5 percent after a jump of 1.3 percent a month earlier. Manufacturing of non-durable goods such as food and clothing was up 0.4 percent after a 0.1 percent increase in May. The Fed said its industrial production index in June stood at 109.8 percent of its 1987 base, up from 109.3 in May.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Finish Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices finished higher on London's Stock Exchange Tuesday but below the day's best levels. Prices shot up in the early going, boosted by Wall Street's performance Monday. But the gains were short-lived, as a mediocre opening on Wall Street Tuesday and concerns about the British economy gave way to selected profit-taking in some of the blue chip stocks. But dealers said there was no heavy selling pressure. ``There's no real disinvestment going on,'' one dealing director said. ``People are hesitant to part with any large lines of stock because they feel they'll have to buy it back later at a higher price.'' At the close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 8.5 points, or 0.4 percent, at 2,415.0. Its peak was 2,430.6 and its low was 2,407.6. The Financial Times 30-share index was up 12 points at 1,912.9 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 2.87 points to close at 1,298.45. Volume came to 493.6 million shares, compared with 346.9 million shares Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Great American Bank to Sell Portion of Operations to Wells Fargo
DOC.TEXT: Struggling Great American Bank announced Tuesday it has agreed to sell its California branch network to Wells Fargo & Co. for $492 million, pending approval by shareholders and federal regulators. The proposed transaction includes Great American's 130 California branches with assets of $5.9 billion, Great American said in a statement. The San Diego-based thrift, the country's eighth largest savings and loan, has been struggling against a rising tide of losses since the fourth quarter of 1988, largely because of a widening loan problem acquired with an Arizona thrift that Great American bought in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Rite Aid Chief Vows Legal Retaliation Against Ohio Officials
LaserPhoto HX1
DOC.TEXT: Martin L. Grass, president of Rite Aid Corp., said Tuesday he will take legal action against Ohio officials who waged what he called an ``outrageous'' prosecution against him. Grass called reporters to company headquarters here and said he will expand his federal defamation lawsuit to include more people at the Ohio Board of Pharmacy. Grass and Rite Aid were cleared Monday of a bribery charge when a Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court judge dismissed the case after the prosecution rested its case. Grass said it was clear from the testimony that the prosecution had no case against him. He charged that no police agency ever investigated the case, investigators were never called to testify, and prosecutor William Caine was more interested in furthering his career. ``When somebody comes at you like that, you don't sit back and take it,'' Grass said. ``You have to retaliate.'' Caine declined to comment Tuesday. Grass and the company were accused of trying to bribe Ohio pharmacy board member Melvin Wilczynski to step down so a new board member favorable to Rite Aid could be appointed. Grass said Wilczynski was a consultant to a drug store chain that Rite Aid had just acquired and the board member was given a Rite Aid check for $33,000 to buy out his contract. Grass' defamation suit was filed last year in federal court in Cleveland against Wilczynski and had been on hold pending outcome of the criminal trial. Accusing Ohio of a double enforcement standard, Grass said other chains, including one Rite Aid acquired, were never cited by the pharmacy board. But he said it appeared to be targeted for alleged violations soon after Rite Aid bought nearly 300 additional stores and became one of the state's largest chains. ``We just didn't like having a dual standard,'' Grass said. ``As far as we're concerned, Ohio is the only state we've been in where there's been selective enforcement. It seemed like there were rules for one group and rules for another group and we were in the wrong group.'' Jack Smittle, assistant executive director for the Ohio Board of Pharmacy, also declined comment Tuesday. Grass said the 15-month ordeal had put a damper on the company stock, with some pensions and other buyers avoiding it because of a cloud of suspicion hanging over Rite Aid. He said the trial had no effect on retail sales and the company will not change operations in Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Draft Treaty on Services Issued, Disagreement on Coverage
DOC.TEXT: A senior world trade negotiator on Tuesday circulated a draft treaty setting out new rules to liberalize global trade in services, worth more than $600 billion a year. The draft provides for the establishment of a General Agreement on Trade in Services, similar to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, GATT, which has governed trade in goods for more than 40 years. But the text by services negotiating group chairman Felipe Jaramillo fails to define what services will be covered, reflecting the deadlock between the United States and other countries involved in the talks. Negotiators are meant to agree on an outline text by the end of this month to enable a services accord to be made final when the four-year round of Uruguay trade talks concludes in December. The ambitious negotiations are also due to draw up new rules in 14 other areas of world trade, such as agriculture and textiles. Industrialized countries have led the way in pressing for a new agreement to open markets to services such as tourism, transportation and telecommunications. The rapidly growing sector now accounts for an average 60 percent of employment and Gross Domestic Product in the developed world, according to estimates from the Geneva-based GATT secretariat. Third World countries were initially worried that, denied protection, their infant service industries would be overwhelmed by competition from indutrialized countries. However, the text presented by Jaramillo, a Colombian national, seeks to ease these concerns by stating that the ``process of liberalization shall take place with due respect to ... the level of development in individual parties.'' The 25 articles of the draft treaty set out the general obligations of signatories, as well as provisions for progressive liberalization, specific commitments on market access, and institutional questions like dispute settlement. The text seeks to reconcile conflicting interests. However, the section titled coverage was left blank. Trade sources say that most countries, including the 12 members of the European Community, have argued that the treaty should cover all services. Under this universal approach special needs of individual sectors could be tackled through more detailed amendments once agreement on a broad framework has been reached. The United States, by contrast, wants coverage of the general treaty to be narrower. In particular, U.S. negotiators have pressed for a format that would allow financial services, aviation and shipping to be excluded. Washington, while pressing for greater overall liberalization, is reportedly anxious to protect existing bilateral deals that benefit the U.S. aviation and maritime industry. On financial services, the U.S. Treasury wants to retain control over prudential regulation _ rules meant to ensure the soundness of the banking system. Trade sources say Japan backs the United States on this.

DOC.HEAD: Royal Jeweler Asprey To Aquire Rivals Mappin and Webb, and Garrard
DOC.TEXT: British jeweler Asprey PLC said Tuesday it will buy rivals Mappin and Webb Ltd. and Garrard and Co. from Sears PLC for 75 million pounds, or $136 million, in stock. Asprey said the purchase would reinforce its position ``at the forefront of the luxury goods trade'' by expanding its customer base in both the domestic and export markets. Garrard is Britain's ``Crown Jeweler,'' appointed to care for the crown jewels worn by Queen Elizabeth II on ceremonial occasions and displayed in the Tower of London. The three prestigious retailers also hold various royal warrants as silversmiths, goldsmiths and jewelers to the queen, the Queen Mother and Prince Charles. The jewelers also sell objets d'art, clocks, porcelain, crystal, antiques and leather goods. They have showrooms in London's posh Bond and Regent streets and in the Harrods department store, among others. Asprey, which is closely held and will continue to be 50.7 percent owned by the Asprey family, said it would issue 18.5 million new, special shares to Sears. These new shares, plus Sears' existing 25.5 percent common stock stake in Asprey, will give Sears the right to 38.5 percent of Asprey's profits. Sears PLC is unrelated to the similarly named American retailer. Asprey's shares fell 15 pence, or 27 cents, to finish at 390 pence, or $7.06, Tuesday on London's Stock Exchange. Asprey will continue to operate Mappin and Webb and Garrard under their own names and plans to maintain the current stores. Asprey Chairman John Asprey called the acquisition ``a landmark in the history of Asprey.'' He said the new group would employ 900 people. Asprey, with stores in London, New York and Geneva, had after-tax profits of 14.9 million pounds, or $27 million, on sales of 75.3 million pounds, or $136 million, in the year ended March 31.

DOC.HEAD: Automakers Expect Lower Second-Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: The Big Three automakers are expected to make about half as much money in the second quarter this year as they did last year, analysts said Tuesday. Economic problems in Brazil caused problems for General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. while incentives and increased Jeep competition reduced profits at Chrysler Corp., they said. GM and Ford report their earnings July 25; Chrysler releases its figures July 31. Average earnings estimates from seven analysts contacted Tuesday by The Associated Press suggested that GM's earnings were expected to drop about 40 percent from a year ago, Ford's would be off about 49 percent and Chrysler's were forecast to be down about 46 percent. In last year's second quarter, GM earned $1.5 billion, Ford made $1.4 billion and Chrysler earned $341 million. GM reported three months ago that its 1990 first-quarter earnings fell to $710 million, down 54 percent from last year's first quarter, Ford's were down 69 percent to $506 million and Chrysler's were off 80 percent to $71 million. ``Except for Brazil, it's pretty much shipping fewer cars for lower prices,'' said analyst David Healy of the Barclays de Zoete Wedd investment banking firm in New York. GM and Ford have large operations in Brazil that supply many of the vehicles they sell in South America. The Brazilian government put the brakes on the nation's economy earlier this year when the inflation rate topped 1,000 percent annually. The two largest U.S. automakers' operations in Brazil were shut down and only recently have they seen the beginning of a recovery. ``For the first four to five weeks in the quarter, there was virtually no production in Brazil,'' said analyst John Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody & Co. of New York. ``Brazil is definitely a drag on the earnings.'' The top two automakers recently have relied on their overseas operations for much of their profits. GM and Ford have reported record overseas earnings recently while North American operations ran on marginal profits. Chrysler, in the worst overall financial shape of the Big Three, has essentially no overseas profit base. In North America, each of the Big Three watched incentive costs and a listless sales pace squeeze their profits. Late in the quarter, the sales pace began to pick up as the companies boosted production and pared incentive offers, estimated to cost about $1,000 per vehicle. ``From a domestic standpoint, it looks like the worst is over,'' said analyst Douglas Laughlin of Bear, Stearns & Co. of New York. ``Chrysler is purely a victim of circumstances in the North American market.'' For Chrysler, the third quarter promises to be a tough one. The nation's third largest automaker plans to stop production at its minivan plants in St. Louis and Windsor, Ontario, during the period to retool for the redesigned 1991 models. That's likely to cause an availability problem for one of Chrysler's most profitable vehicles. ``They fully expect to get hammered by the minivan changeover,'' said analyst Scott Merlis of Morgan, Stanley & Co. of New York. Chrysler's other moneymaker, the Jeep Cherokee, is seeing its dominance of the sport-utility market slip with the recent introduction of the four-door Chevrolet Blazer and Ford Explorer. Analysts expected that the erosion of Cherokee's 25 percent share of the market segment will accelerate as production of the Blazer and Explorer increase.

DOC.HEAD: French Steel Company Plans to Buy U.S. Steel Trading Firm
DOC.TEXT: France's biggest steel company, state-owned Usinor Sacilor SA, said Tuesday it plans to acquire Edgcomb Corp., a privately held U.S. steel trading firm. The French company said the purchase depends on Edgcomb's current owners buying up all of the outstanding debt. No price was given for the acquisition, which must be approved by U.S. authorities. The purchase of Edgcomb will strengthen Usinor Sacilor's market position in the United States, especially in the East and Southeast. Last year, Usinor Sacilor became the world's second-biggest steel producer through the acquisition of the ailing West German steel company Saarstahl. Since then, the French company has sought to build up its U.S. presence through acquisitions and partnerships. The French group already has two steel service centers in Chicago, and is one of the biggest U.S. producers of stainless steel following its acquisitions of Techalloy Inc., Alloy & Stainless Inc. and J & L, a unit of LTV Corp., earlier this year. An official of Usinor Sacilor indicated that Edgcomb has about $100 million of bonds outstanding. Edgcomb has 1,600 employees and recorded 1989 sales of about $600 million, of which 45 percent involved flat products. It also deals in stainless steel, long products and aluminum, and has 18 operational units on the Eastern seaboard. Usinor Sacilor's announcement came the same day as the release of a report in Brussels, Belgium, detailing an aggressive expansion campaign by French state-owned industries. European Deal Review, published by the U.S. consultancy group Translink, said that in 1989 there were 40 French state acquisitions of European targets, valued at $2.67 billion European currency units, the equivalent of about $3.34 billion, which amounted to 28 percent of the total value of all French acquisitions in Europe. ``France is in effect nationalizing Europe,'' commented Mark Dixon, the editor of the review. The review said that many governments consider the takeovers unfair, because of the protection given to the French companies by their own government.

DOC.HEAD: Pfizer Posts 11 Percent Profit Gain
DOC.TEXT: Pfizer Inc. Tuesday said it earned 11 percent more in the second quarter than it did a year earlier as stronger sales in its health care and specialty chemicals divisions helped produce a 15 percent revenue gain. The profit growth came despite disappointing sales from Pfizer's animal health and consumer products segments. A 20 percent drop in specialty minerals sales, reflecting the sale of a pigments business, also restrained the companywide sales gain. Pfizer earned $151.2 million, or 90 cents a share, in the three months ended July 1, up from $135.7 million, or 80 cents a share, in 1989's second quarter. Sales rose to $1.49 billion from $1.30 billion. Edmund T. Pratt Jr., the New York-based pharmaceutical company's chairman and chief executive officer, said the 26 percent growth in health care was fueled by the increasing number of new Pfizer products entering markets worldwide. Among some of the recently launched products are new cardiovascular drugs, such as Procardia XL, Cardura and Norvasc, and the antifungal agent Diflucan. ``Our net income is beginning to benefit from the earnings momentum these products promise for the 1990s,'' Pratt said. By midyear, Pfizer earned $403.1 million, or $2.40 a share, up 7 percent from $376.5 million, or $2.23 a share, through the first half of 1989. Half-year revenue rose 9 percent to $2.98 billion from $2.74 billion.

Stock prices fell marginally today following a spate of disappointing earnings reports that helped spoil an earlier rise in the Dow Jones industrial average. The Dow average of 30 industrial stocks stood at 2,993.56 as of 3 p.m. on Wall Street, down 6.19 from Monday's close. Earlier, the Dow hovered above the 3,000 mark. Among all New York Stock Exchange issues in nationwide trading, declining issues outnumbered advancing ones, with 536 up, 963 down and 513 unchanged. The Dow crossed the 3,000 mark for the second straight session Monday, but was unable to maintain that level by the close, though it ended the session at its third consecutive record high. Trading volume also slowed from last week's strong pace. The Dow never has closed at 3,000 or above. ``After reaching that new high yesterday, it's normal to have a little profit taking,'' said Hank Striefler, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. In addition, he said, the market was concerned about earnings reports as well as the stalled budget talks in Congress. The market had little reaction to two government economic reports this morning. The nation's trade deficit climbed to $7.73 billion in May from a revised April imbalance of $7.31 billion. Meanwhile, industrial production rose 0.4 percent in June and plant capacity utilitzation increased 0.2 percentage point to 83.5 percent. United Telecommunications, parent of US Sprint, was the most-active NYSE issue, with more than 10 million shares changing hands. It fell 8} to 29{ after reporting its second-quarter profit dropped 55.1 percent. GTE Corp., the third most-active NYSE issue, fell 1 to 28. The company's report that its second-quarter profit rose 11 percent was short of analysts' expectations. At the same time, United Telecom said it was postponing its purchase of the 19.9 percent of Sprint owned by GTE. Lower earnings were reported by a number of other companies, including Citicorp, Chemical Banking, Reynolds Metals, FMC and TRW. Coca-Cola, one of the most-active blue chip stocks, rose 1 to 46] after reporting its second-quarter earnings jumped 18.6 percent from a year earlier. Among other active blue chips, AT&T fell ] to 36}, IBM fell 2] to 120 and Philip Morris dropped \ to 50. Volume on the Big Board came to 142.77 million shares as of 3 p.m. EDT. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped 1.54 to 199.59. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index fell 1.72 to 363.86.

Stock prices closed largely lower today following a spate of disappointing earnings reports. The Dow average of 30 industrial stocks stood at 2,998.02 five minutes before the market closed. Earlier, the Dow hovered above the 3,000 mark.
