DOC.HEAD: NYNEX CEO Says Florida Bashes Were Not Company Funded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `Materiel' in 2nd graf is correct.
DOC.TEXT: NYNEX Corp. neither funded nor supported a subsidiary's annual Florida parties that featured call girls and clients, the chairman of the telephone company said Tuesday. The annual Miami parties, which occurred between 1984 and 1988, were attended by employees of Materiel Enterprises Co. _ which at the time was NYNEX's unregulated purchasing arm _ and about 30 suppliers. The parties reportedly featured awards for the most perverted partygoer and to the man who procured the most women. At a news conference, NYNEX Chairman William Ferguson called the activities ``sophomoric'' and ``repugnant.'' He said, ``None of the activities that were investigated were sponsored by the company. None were paid for by the company. None took place on company time.'' An internal 1988 NYNEX investigation of the events resulted in two employees being fired and six others being disciplined for violating NYNEX's code of business conduct. A fired NYNEX consultant, who had no dealings with the parties, told the Wall Street Journal that suppliers who attended and paid for the parties saw their business increase by 67 percent while those who didn't saw an increase of only about 3.5 percent. Ferguson said those figures were misleading and said there was no evidence that any supplier ever benefited due to the parties. He also said the NYNEX investigation showed that employees who attended the parties paid their own way. He said some offered canceled checks as proof, while others said they paid cash. Materiel Enterprises' activities have become a key issue in the company's pending request to New York regulators for a record $919.7 million rate increase. The Federal Communications Commission in February ordered fines totaling $1.4 million against the company's New York Telephone Co. and New England Telephone and Telegraph Co. subsidiaries because of $118.5 million in alleged overcharges made to the two units by Materiel Enterprises. Materiel Enterprises, which was formed in 1983 to provide equipment and services to the telephone companies, allegedly engaged in a series of transactions with the two aimed at increasing NYNEX's overall profit at customer expense. The FCC also ordered the two telephone subsidiaries to refund about $35 million to customers. NYNEX has appealed the fine and refund order. Ferguson said all documents concerning the Florida parties were turned over to the state Public Service Commission and FCC in 1988. Asked why NYNEX didn't make the investigation public at that time, Ferguson said: ``What would you have us do take out a full newspaper ad? There's not a company in the world who would do that. ...We did what we had to do, we investigated and we took action.'' Ferguson, who took over as NYNEX's chairman and chief executive officer last October, said he was talking about the incidents now ``because it's become part of the rate case and because it's in the public and I want some facts out there.'' He said the parties first came to the attention of MECO executives in 1985. An internal investigation was conducted by an outside agency. ``They found no evidence of misconduct with respect to the purchasing arrangement or contract with vendors,'' Ferguson said. ``As a result no action was taken.'' He said the 1985 investigation made no mention of suppliers and NYNEX employees sharing rooms, or of prostitutes attending gatherings. But he said apparently ``these things (the parties) were becoming bigger and bigger year after year.'' Another investigation was launched in 1988. NYNEX transferred ownership of MECO to New York Telephone and New England Telephone in March. The subsidiary now is regulated by the state.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Reports Lower Fiscal Income
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank said Tuesday that efforts to lower costs for Third World borrowers and increased provisions for problem loans resulted in a 5 percent drop in its fiscal 1990 net income over a year ago. The bank, which is owned by roughly 150 countries and is the largest lender to the developing world, said its profit totaled $1.04 billion for the year ended June 30, compared with earnings of $1.09 billion in 1989. The 1990 figures include a $357 million provision set aside to cover future loan losses and a $106 million charge for health and insurance benefits to retired staff. Income was further reduced by about $150 million as a result of the World Bank's decision to lower the loan commitment fees to borrowers for a second consecutive year, the bank said. In discussing the profit decline, Ernest Stern, senior vice president for finance, told a news conference, ``The World Bank does not seek to maximize income. Our first priority ... is to begin to reduce costs to our borrowers. ``Lower net income figures ... would not reflect a lower income-generating capacity, but a discretionary decision not to retain income which is not needed to maintain our very strong financial position, particularly at a time when many of our borrowers face serious cash flow problems.'' The bank said it met its target 11 percent reserves-to-loan ratio during the 1990 fiscal year. The reserves act as a buffer against unforseeable events, such as volatility in foreign exchange or higher interest rates, which could cause borrowing costs to rise or borrowers to cease making payments. At the end of the last fiscal year, nine countries _ including Panama, Nicaragua and Zambia _ were classified as being on a ``non-accrural basis,'' which means they have either stopped or decreased their loan payments. The World Bank granted a total of $20.7 billion of new loans in the year, down from $21.3 billion the year before. Of the latest total, $15.2 billion was lent by its International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Through its International Development Association, which is funded by more than 30 of the richer member countries, including the United States, the bank lent $5.5 billion to the poorest countries. Disbursements on loans reached a record $13.9 billion in the 1990 fiscal year, up from the previous year's $11.3 billion, the bank said. One reason for the increase was a $2 billion disbursement to Mexico under Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady's debt reduction plan. Stern said the World Bank intends to support struggling Eastern European countries by lending about $7 billion to that region over the next three years.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Declines at Citibank, Chemical, Manufacturers Hanover
DOC.TEXT: Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, said Tuesday that its second quarter profit dropped 37 percent due to weakness in the real estate market and the failure of Argentina and Brazil to pay interest on their loans. Three other major banking companies reported profit declines for the quarter: Chemical Banking Corp. fell 12.6 percent, Manufacturers Hanover Corp. tumbled 68.9 percent and Bank of New York Co. Inc. fell 39 percent. Wells Fargo & Co. reported that a one-time gain on a joint venture helped lift its second-quarter profit by 58 percent from a year ago. The reports came on the heels of second quarter profit declines at two other leading banking companies. Chase Manhattan Corp. said Monday its profit plunged 62 percent, while earnings fell 35 percent at First Chicago Corp. ``The operating environment for the banking industry has been poor,'' said James J. McDermott Jr., research director at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc. ``Most banks are bedeviled by deteriorating real estate asset quality and a slow operating economy.'' He said many major banks had ``served notice not to expect much, and we are not getting much.''
DOC.HEAD: Citicorp
DOC.TEXT: The parent of the nation's biggest bank, Citibank, said it earned $248 million, or 64 cents a share, for the three months ended June 30 compared with $395 million, or $1.11 a share, a year earlier. The company said its earnings rose 28 percent in consumer banking activities and 44 percent in international banking and finance activities. But it said results from its global finance operations in Japan, Europe and North America dropped 69 percent, mainly due to weakness in the real estate market, especially in the United States. Citicorp said its net commercial loan writeoffs amounted to $92 million, including $42 million stemming from U.S. real estate, compared with net writeoffs of $29 million a year earlier. ``The continuing uncertain real estate environment may cause write-offs to continue at a relatively high levels until we see some stabilization in values,'' the company stated. Citicorp also reported an $82 million loss for the quarter on cross-border loans, mainly due to non-payment of loan interest by Argentina and Brazil. Citicorp reported a profit of $25 million from such activity in the quarter last year, including $88 million in loan payments from Brazil. In the latest quarter, Citicorp wrote off $631 million in loans to Brazil, or 20 percent of its loans to that country, as regulatory authorities had recently advised banks to do. For the first six months, Citicorp earned $479 million, or $1.24 a share, down 48 percent from $924 million, or $2.63 a share, a year earlier. The first-half figures for 1989 included a $77 million after-tax gain from the sale of property in Tokyo and $154 million in revenue from Brazilian cash payments that since have been suspended. By the end of the quarter, Citicorp had assets of $227.8 billion, up 3 percent from $221.3 billion a year earlier.
DOC.HEAD: Chemical Banking
DOC.TEXT: Chemical Banking said it earned $113.1 million, or $1.02 per share, in the three months ended June 30 compared with $128.6 million, or $1.65 a share, a year earlier. The company said its results reflected a slight dip in net interest income and a bigger decline in non-interest income, due to lower gains from venture capital activities. But results from the company's Texas Commerce Bancshares subsidiary improved sharply, with earnings up to $24.1 million from $3.2 million. Chemical reported writeoffs on loans to Brazil and Argentina of $268.2 million, citing regulatory directives. For the first half, Chemical earned $264.8 million, up 7.4 percent from $246.5 million a year earlier. But earnings per share fell to $2.57 from $3.14, because more shares were outstanding this year than last.
DOC.HEAD: Manufacturers Hanover
DOC.TEXT: Manufacturers Hanover said it earned $33 million, or 31 cents a share, down from $106 million, or $1.87 a share, a year earlier. The results reflected an after-tax restructuring charge of $60 million, slower corporate finance activity and shaky Third World loans. The company wrote off $450 million in loans to Brazil and Argentina in the quarter. For the first six months, Manufacturers Hanover earned $129 million, or $1.51 a share, down from $209 million, or $3.70 a share, a year earlier.
DOC.HEAD: Wells Fargo
DOC.TEXT: San Francisco-based Wells Fargo said it earned $232.4 million, or $4.40 a share, in the second quarter compared with $147.4 million, or $2.68 a share, a year earlier. It cited a $116.5 million pretax gain from establishment of a joint venture with Nikko Securities Co. Ltd., Wells Fargo-Nikko Investment Advisors. In the first six months, net income was $392.2 million, or $7.45 per share, up 36.5 percent from $288.9 million, or $5.24 per share a year earlier.
DOC.HEAD: Bank of New York
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New York said it earned $70 million, or 90 cents a share, in the three months ended June 30 compared with $114.3 million, or $1.60 a share, a year earlier. Chairman J. Carter Bacot said the economic environmernt prompted the company to increase chargeoffs, write down real estate holdings and boost its allowance for loan losses. But he said net interest income rose 7 percent. For the first half, Bank of New York earned $172.7 million, or $2.28 a share, down 19.8 percent from $215.4 million, or $3.05 a share, a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Du Pont-Kansai Venture Will Supply Paint for Transplant Automakers
DOC.TEXT: The largest U.S. maker of auto finishes and Japan's largest coatings manufacturer said Tuesday they'll launch a joint venture to supply paint to overseas automakers' U.S. plants. Du Pont already supplies finishes for the North American operations of Japanese and Korean automakers and parts suppliers with technical collaboration from Kansai Paint Co., Du Pont spokesman Terrence Q. Cressy said. Effective Aug. 1, the joint venture, Du Pont-Kansai Automotive Coatings Co., will develop and market finishes from primers to topcoats and clearcoats to the transplant automakers. Du Pont will own 60 percent of the company, which will start with about 120 employees. Kansai will own 40 percent and provide marketing and technical support in Japan. The venture will be started with a $5 million investment of capital. It will use existing Du Pont manufacturing plants, offices and laboratories in Troy and Kansai laboratories in Japan, Cressy said. Du Pont Automotive Products markets more than 100 product lines such as finishes, plastics, composites and chemicals and had $3 billion in sales to the auto industry in 1989. Kansai makes automotive finishes as well as coatings for the construction, appliance and marine industries and had 1989 sales of about $1 billion. The joint venture is expected to have sales of $40 million in its first year, Cressy said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar weakened Tuesday on worldwide currency markets after the government reported a widening U.S. trade deficit during May. Gold prices also declined here and abroad. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $362 a troy ounce, down $1.30 from late Monday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $361.40 an ounce, off $1.10. Currency dealers said the dollar was pressured in part by a Commerce Department report Tuesday that showed May's trade deficit jumped to $7.73 billion from a revised $7.31 billion. The increase was due to a big increase in imports of oil and cars. Dealers keep a close watch on trade figures since they often have an impact on the dollar. For instance, dealers worry that a rise in imports will place downward pressure on the dollar in order to enhance the sale of exports. Earl I. Johnson, a trader at Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago, said technical factors also played a role in the dollar's decline Tuesday. ``It just lost the upside momentum,'' he said. Johnson said traders were now awaiting Wednesday's scheduled congressional testimony by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan on monetary policies. In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar closed at 148.20 Japanese yen, down from 148.43 late Monday. It traded at 148.32 yen in London, and at 147.80 yen in New York, down from 148.15 yen. The dollar was weaker against the British pound compared with Monday's levels. Sterling cost $1.8115 in London, up from $1.8040, and $1.8165 in New York, up from $1.8033. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.6440 West German marks, down from 1.6545; 1.4048 Swiss francs, down from 1.4180; 5.5155 French francs, down from 5.5500; 1,204.25 Italian lire, down from 1,211.00; and 1.15295 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15865. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Monday: 1.6455 German marks, down from 1.6535; 1.4065 Swiss francs, down from 1.4165; 5.5210 French francs, down from 5.5460; 1.8552 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8640; 1,205.12 Italian lire, down from 1,210.75; and 1.1562 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1587. The late bid price of gold in London was $361.25 an ounce, down from $362.75 Monday. Gold fell to $361.50 an ounce in Zurich from $362.70. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 75 cents to close at a bid of $361.15 an ounce. Silver prices also weakened. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.814 a troy ounce, down from $4.847 Monday. Silver fell 6 cents in London to $4.83 an ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Highest Closes in Dow Jones Industrials Average
With AM-Wall Street
S&L Figures Agree to Testify
DOC.TEXT: Key figures in a Senate probe of the Bluebonnet Savings bailout have agreed to testify before a Senate committee, Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said Tuesday. James. M. Fail, a Phoenix insurance executive who bought 15 failed Texas savings and loans with $70 million in loans _ putting up just $1,000 of his own money _ dropped his previous objetions to testify, Metzenbaum said. Robert J. Thompson, a former congressional liaison to President Bush when he was vice president, and M. Danny Wall, former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, also dropped previous objections to testify. Metzenbaum, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on antitrust, monopolies and business rights, said they would testify at hearings July 30 and Aug. 6. His panel held a hearing last week into the purchase of the failed thrifts by Fail, who consolidated them into what is now operating as Bluebonnet Savings Bank of Dallas. Metzenbaum said the purchases received an estimated $1.8 billion in federal subsidies. According to documents released by the panel, Thompson borrowed more than $500,000 from Fail thorugh Bluebonnet and Fail's insurance companies. Metzenbaum said last week that a letter from Thompson prompted Wall to arrange a meeting with federal regulators to put together a bailout deal for Fail. He questioned whether Thompson's political connections and friendship influenced the outcome of bidding on the failed thrifts before federal regulators. Metzenbaum had threatened to issue subpoenas for the reluctant witnesses. An attorney for Fail, Stanley M. Brand, last week challenged the jursidiction of the Metzenbaum panel to look into S&L matters. But in announcing the agreement to testify, Metzenbaum said Fail had retained a new lawyer. Metzenbaum said negotiations were under way to obtain the voluntary testimony of another witness, Thomas K. Pennington of Fort Wayne, Ind., a former insurance company president, who may have information about the deal.

DOC.HEAD: Merrill Lynch Reports 2nd Quarter Earnings Gain; PaineWebber Profits Slip
DOC.TEXT: Merrill Lynch & Co. reported Tuesday that its second-quarter earnings rose 13 percent as a restructuring continued to produce positive results. Another investment firm, PaineWebber Group Inc., said its profit fell nearly 3 percent as its investment banking business remained slow. Merrill Lynch said it earned $74.1 million, or 64 cents per share, up from $65.7 million, or 58 cents per share, in the second three months of 1989. Revenue fell 1 percent to $2.87 billion from $2.9 billion a year earlier. However, the company said revenue rose in the latest quarter when compared with first quarter 1990 results. Last year's results were adjusted to delete earnings of the company's real estate subsidiary, which was divested during the third quarter of 1989. PaineWebber said it earned $14.6 million, down from $15.1 million a year earlier. However, quarterly earnings per share rose to 35 cents from 33 cents a year earlier as the investment firm had fewer shares outstanding in the 1990 quarter. Revenue increased 8 percent to $468.2 million from $433 million.

Merrill Lynch said its earnings reflected the results of its restructuring, which was undetaken to lower costs. Operating expenses were down 4 percent, while total expenses were off 2 percent, the company said. The restructuring includes the elimination of 3,000 jobs by the end of this year and the divestiture of several product lines and businesses. Merrill Lynch took a fourth-quarter 1989 charge of $470 million to pay for the restructuring. Other investment firms, hurt by the slowdown on Wall Street since the 1987 crash, have also been cutting back. The company said its investment banking revenue was up 8 percent from the year-earlier period and 31 percent from the first quarter. Corporate underwriting and advisory services revenue offset a decline in revenue from the firm's mergers and acquisitions activities. Revenues from asset management, insurance and custodial activities also increased during the quarter, but revenues from commissions and Merrill Lynch's own transactions declined. For the first half of the year, Merrill Lynch earned $115.4 million, or 98 cents per share, up 14 percent from $101.2 million, or 87 cents a share, in the first half of 1989. Revenue fell 2.9 percent to $5.53 billion from $5.7 billion.
DOC.HEAD: PaineWebber
DOC.TEXT: PaineWebber Chairman Donald Marron said the company's results were hurt by lower earnings from merchant banking investments and the industrywide slowdown in investment banking. He also blamed increased costs from litigation settlements for the decline. PaineWebber reported first-half earnings of $25.4 million, or 55 cents, up 5 percent from $24.3 million, or 44 cents, during the first six months of 1989. First-half revenue totaled $894.3 million, up from $830 million a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Dow Average Finishes Shy of 3000 Again, Unchanged from Monday
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average took a roller-coaster ride Tuesday, careening into the magical 3,000-plus zone for the third straight day and screeching to a halt at exactly the same point of 24 hours earlier: 2,999.75. Wall Street's best-known barometer confounded even the most cynical traders, who have attached little significance to what they call the hype over the Dow index's prolonged flirtation with a 3,000 close. The last time the index finished at exactly the same close for two straight sessions was on June 16 and 17 of 1987, at 2,407.35. There have been numerous other times when it has closed within a point of the previous day's finish. As in the Friday and Monday sessions, the Dow average seesawed at the 3,000 level for part of the day, moving on any big trade involving one or more of the 30 blue-chip stocks that make up the index. In the broader market Tuesday, stock prices finished largely lower in slow trading. Other indices that measure a more expansive range of stocks generally declined. The market had little reaction to two government economic reports this morning, analysts said. The nation's trade deficit climbed to $7.73 billion in May from a revised April imbalance of $7.31 billion. Meanwhile, industrial production rose 0.4 percent in June and plant capacity utilitzation increased 0.2 percentage point to 83.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Court Approves Employment Contract Rejection
DOC.TEXT: Ames Department Stores Inc. won approval from a federal bankruptcy judge on Tuesday to reject employment contracts totaling about $3.3 million for three former executives. The ruling by Judge Howard C. Buschman means the three, who stepped down after the troubled retailer filed for protection from its creditors, will have to line up with other unsecured creditors if they want to collect anything they say is due them under the contracts. They would recover the same percentage of what is owed them as other unsecured creditors when a bankruptcy reorganization plan is approved by the court. The former executives include former chief executive officer Peter Hollis, whose contract guaranteed him a salary of $700,000 a year through Jan. 31, 1993. The others are Leslie Dietzman, former executive vice president of merchandising, whose contract was for $325,000 a year through 1992, and Jeffrey Dentz, former executive vice president of operations, whose contract provides for $200,000 a year through Jan. 31, 1993. Federal law allows a company in bankruptcy to assume or reject any contract it entered into before its bankruptcy filing. The law is intended to help a company reorganize by removing obligations it considers burdensome or no longer appropriate for its ongoing business. Ames, based in Rocky Hill, Conn., filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code on April 25, largely because of problems stemming from its $788 million acquisition of the Zayre discount store chain in 1988. Hollis resigned a few days after the company filed for protection. Dietzman and Dentz resigned their positions but have remained with Ames, said Ames spokesman Doug Ewing. Ames had already stopped making payments to the executives and none received severance payments, said another Ames spokesman, William Roberts. Hollis was replaced by Stephen L. Pistner, a specialist in turning around troubled retail companies who is being paid $1.5 million a year. Last month, Buschman approved the closing of more than 200 stores and authorized the company to pay $24 million to 18,000 workers who will lose their jobs. During Tuesday's hearing, the judge called the Ames case troubling because of the store closings and impending layoffs. Buschman also said the company's unsettled finances have left 38,000 remaining employees with jobs ``dependent upon factors of which they have very little control.'' Ames, the nation's fourth-largest discounter, has 679 stores in the eastern United States and two distribution centers.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Close Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil prices dipped lower and gasoline and heating oil futures closed mixed Tuesday as traders tested the energy market to see if it could hold its recent gains. The August contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of crude oil, fell 2 cents to $18.65 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Later contract months either edged lower or were unchanged. ``Crude is still searching for its level after the big move up,'' said Jim Fiedler, an analyst with E.D. & F. Man International Futures Inc., referring to last week's gains, which were chalked up amid optimism that OPEC would finally curb its runaway production. Tuesday's trading was volatile, with the August contract falling to $18.11 and then surging back. Fiedler said traders were testing the market to see how low it might go, but buyers moved in at the low end of Tuesday's range and moved prices higher. He said the market was unlikely to sell off before next week's full meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. OPEC has made some progress recently toward achieving its goal of an average price for crude of $18 a barrel. Among refined products traded on the mercantile exchange, the August contract for unleaded regular gasoline fell 0.32 cent to 64.12 cents a gallon, but later months advanced. Home heating oil for August delivery fell 0.16 cent to 56.08 cents a gallon, but subsequent months followed the lead of gasoline and also moved higher. In natural gas trading, the August contract closed at $1.462 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.495 Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Crude Oil Prices Expected to Drop on Supply Report
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures prices were expected to retreat Wednesday, bucking the recent trend, after an industry trade group reported an unexpected increase in U.S. crude supplies. Petroleum futures ended mixed Tuesday as late buying offset a wave of profit-taking. On other commodity markets Tuesday, sugar futures tumbled; coffee futures ended mixed on news about the International Coffee Organization; grain futures were mostly lower; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 8 cents lower to 3 cents higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange with the contract for delivery in August at $18.65 a barrel; heating oil was 1.12 cents lower to .37 cent higher with August at 56.08 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .32 cent lower to .98 cent higher with August at 64.12 cents a gallon. Crude prices have climbed about $2 a barrel in the past week amid indications that OPEC members are prepared to reduce their crude output to support prices. The cartel begins its mid-year meeting July 26. After the close, the American Petroleum Institute released weekly supply figures that showed unexpected increases in U.S. stocks of crude and gasoline. Crude oil stocks, which were expected to fall by about 2.8 million barrels, rose by 4.7 million, the API said. Gasoline supplies, which were expected to show little change, rose by about 2 million barrels. Supplies of distillates rose 2.1 million barrels, as expected. James Ritterbusch, an energy analyst for PaineWebber Inc., said crude prices were likely to open 15 to 20 cents lower Wednesday in reaction to the report. But, he said, ``It should be kept in mind that the main fundamental force here is still the willingness on the part of OPEC to curtail output. That still overshadows week-to-week changes in the API numbers.'' Sugar futures tumbled on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange amid heavy commodity-fund selling prompted by bearish technical signals and slack demand for sugar on the world market. Sugar has plunged nearly 5 cents a pound since late April on forecasts for expanding supplies that have not been matched by significant increases in demand. Harry Schwartz, an analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc., said Monday's close below 12 cents a pound sparked computer-driven selling that simply fed on itself. ``Once those machines kick in, they just generate such volume that you can't stand in the way,'' Schwartz said. ``You've just got to step back and let the bulldozer come through.'' Sugar settled .42 cent to .53 cent lower with the contract for delivery in October at 11.19 cents a pound. Coffee futures ended nearly unchanged in New York, erasing moderate gains on news that members of the International Coffee Organization had voted in favor of Brazil's request to cancel a July 23 special meeting. Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer, had asked for the meeting, prompting speculation that Brazil was prepared to support reinstatement of coffee export quotas as a price-support measure. Coffee futures settled .15 cent lower to 1.05 cents higher with July at 84.20 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures ended mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as forecasts for beneficial crop weather outweighed bullish factors that included slow crop development. Wheat futures settled 1} cents lower to { cent higher with July at $3.01} a bushel; corn was unchanged to 3 cents lower with July at $2.73{ a bushel; oats were 1} cents to 2 cents lower with July at $1.19} a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 2{ cents lower with July at $5.95 a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle settled .25 cent lower to .20 cent higher with August at 75.57 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .30 cent lower with August at 87.20 cents a pound; hogs were .15 cent lower to .85 cent higher with July at 63.62 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .20 cent lower to 1.53 cents higher with July at 50.50 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Finish Narrowly Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices finished narrowly mixed Tuesday as the market shrugged off new reports on trade and industrial production and looked toward Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's testimony before Congress. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond lost 1-16 point, or 60 cents per $1,000 face amount. Its yield held at 8.45 percent, the same as Monday. Market watchers said dealings were moderate, but traders appeared hesitant in advance of Greenspan's testimony Wednesday before a congressional committee on the central bank's view of economic conditions. ``People are waiting for Greenspan,'' said Gary Schlossberg, senior economist at Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco. ``They want a better read on what the follow-up to the Fed's recent easing will be.'' Greenspan surprised the markets last week when he told a Senate Banking Committee that the central bank was ready to offset an emerging credit squeeze. Traders widely interpreted Fed actions the next day to inject more reserves into the banking system as a relaxation of its credit policy. The move was followed by a quarter-point decline to 8 percent in the federal funds rate, the interest rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans. The federal funds rate finished at 8 percent, unchanged from late Monday. Also due Wednesday is a report on consumer prices in June with many economists expecting a rise of 0.3 percent. In the first of two economic reports Tuesday, the government said the U.S. trade deficit rose to $7.73 billion in May from a revised $7.31 billion imbalance for April. But analysts said the result had largely been anticipated by the credit markets, and prices failed to respond to the news. In another report, the government said industrial production rose 0.4 percent in June. That was about twice as much as expected, but traders said that report was discounted because the rise was largely due to a heat wave that boosted utility output. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments rose 1-32 point, intermediate maturities were unchanged to up 1-16 point and long-term issues were off as much as 3-32 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index was unavailable. It measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose 3-32 point to 92{. The average yield to maturity slipped to 7.41 percent from 7.42 percent late Monday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills auctioned Monday fell to 7.85 percent as the discount lost 2 basis points to 7.60 percent. Yields on six-month bills auctioned Monday were 7.87 percent as the discount fell 4 basis points to 7.48 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 7.86 percent as the discount lost 2 basis points to 7.34 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 48.5 Percent Profit Increase in 2nd-Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Adolph Coors Co., which is the parent of the company that makes Coors beer, said Tuesday its second quarter profit surged 48.5 percent on an 11.7 percent increase in sales. Net income rose to $25.1 million, or 68 cents share, in the three months ended June 17 compared with $16.9 million, or 46 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales for the quarter rose to $475.4 million from $425.5 million a year ago. For the first half, Coors said its profit jumped to $32.8 million, or 89 cents a share, compared with $12 million, or 33 cents a share, a year ago. First-half sales rose 16 percent to $869.7 million from $749.6 million for the same period in 1989. Coors beer shipments for the second quarter totaled 4.8 million barrels, up 13.6 percent from the 4.2 million barrels shipped in the same period a year ago. For the first half of the year, Coors shipped a record 8.8 million barrels of beer, compared with 7.3 million barrels for the same period in 1989. Coors Brewing Co. recently bought a Stroh brewery in Memphis, Tenn. Coors' subsidiaries include Coors Brewing Co., Golden Aluminum Co. and Graphic Packaging Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Polaroid Earnings Drop Amid Slumping Domestic Sales
DOC.TEXT: Polaroid Corp. said Tuesday that net earnings were down nearly $10 million in the second quarter of 1990 compared with the same period a year ago, in part because of slow domestic sales. Earnings were $32.9 million, or 45 cents a share, on revenue of $475.6 million. For the same period in 1989, the company reported earnings of $42.7 million, or 62 cents a share, on revenue of $486.6. Profits for 1990 to date fell to $64.7 million from $68.6 million in the same period in 1989. U.S. sales were off by 10 percent while international sales increased 8 percent, officials said. ``The continuing uncertainty in the worldwide business climate ... adversely affected second-quarter results,'' said I. MacAllister Booth, Polaroid's CEO and president, in a written statement. ``The continued commitment to invest in Polaroid's future along with the impact of the uncertainty of worldwide economic conditions have led us to lower expectations for the year,'' he said. ``We expect that Polaroid will achieve operating profits that are flat to moderately down from last year's levels.'' The photography giant has been restructuring and trimming operations since successfully fending off a takeover bid by Shamrock Holdings, which cost the company $151.9 million in 1988. Polaroid supplies instant photography, cameras and films, as well as conventional films, videotapes and electronic visual communication products to family, business and technical and industrial markets.

DOC.HEAD: RTC Sold $536 Million in Real Estate in First Five Months of Year
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators sold $536 million of real estate seized from failed thrifts in Texas and Oklahoma in the first five months of this year, but still hold properties worth $7.6 billion. That doesn't include what the government may gain through continued failures. But real estate experts said Tuesday a credit crunch, and the government's reluctance to help finance purchases, are making the thrift bailout effort more difficult. ``We basically have no financing in the real estate market,'' J.R. Kimball, a real estate appraiser from Fort Worth, testified at the first meeting of the Resolution Trust Corp.'s Region 4 Advisory Board. ``Banks don't want to make real estate loans, and the savings and loans are virtually non-existent. ... Everything's still on a downward slope,'' he said. ``Prices are declining ... as the market's continuing to erode with or without financing from the RTC,'' said Elizabeth B. Sink, president of Real Estate-Asset Information Management Systems Inc. in Dallas. ``I don't think we've seen the end of the (downward) spiral,'' she said. The RTC was created last year to oversee the thrift bailout, estimated to cost taxpayers between $300 billion and $500 billion. The advisory boards were designed to provide guidance to the regional RTC offices from industry experts. Tuesday's meeting of the Region 4 board, which oversees Texas and Oklahoma, is the second to be held nationally. Like a previous meeting in New York, few people other than witnesses and RTC officials attended. Carmen Sullivan, the RTC's regional director, told the board the agency now controls 122 thrifts in the two states, including 48 that have been resolved by selling deposits and some assets from the failed institutions. As of May 31, she said, the RTC had retained 17,000 assets in the two states worth $7.6 billion, all but $135 million of it in Texas. Of those properties, 11,000 are single-family residences valued at about $2 billion, 4,400 parcels of vacant land valued at $3.6 billion, and 1,600 commercial properties valued at $2 billion. Of the $536 million sold this year, $248 million was in single-family residences, $98 million in vacant land, and the rest in commercial property, she said. All of last year, government regulators sold off $579 million of thrift real estate, she said. Several board members and witnesses questioned Ms. Sullivan on the problems caused by scant financing, and some board members indicated they backed government guaranteeing of loans. But Ms. Sullivan said, ``I don't believe that we're necessarily turning away any creditworthy purchasers.'' Regulations allow the RTC to finance sales under certain restrictions, and she said the agency provided $16 million in residential financing and $10 million in commercial financing during the first quarter of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Says Budget Talks May Reach Into Farm Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 5-7: ``The administration,'' with Leahy quotes; edits throughout to tighten
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Tuesday that Congress should consider delaying action on the 1990 farm bill until a budget agreement is reached by White House and congressional negotiators. ``Certainly that would be the most propitious way to handle the matter,'' Yeutter told reporters. Otherwise, Congress might have to write two farm bills, he said, indicating an agreement on the overall federal budget may require changes in farm programs not anticipated in the pending legislation. But he said he has not asked any members of Congress directly to delay farm bill action. ``The administration is hiding behind the budget and trying to kill the farm bill,'' said Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt. ``Since the budget summit may take months to complete, the administration's proposal sets the stage from a one-year farm bill extension, so that American farm policy would be written in Geneva.'' Leahy made a similar accusation Monday after Yeutter said he would seek a veto of the bill if its cost isn't reduced. Yeutter is playing a major role in U.S. efforts to get countries participating in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks in Geneva, Switzerland, to reduce trade distorting subsidies. Since discussions on the farm bill began last year, Congress has warned Yeutter that it would not allow agriculture policy in this country to be determined at the international negotiating table. Leahy has said Yeutter wants a one-year bill in order to give U.S. trade negotiators a freer hand at GATT. ``That's nonsense,'' said Yeutter. ``Whether we have a one, three or five-year farm bill is fundamentally irrelevant to the GATT process.'' Though Yeutter has said repeatedly that he would accept a one-year extension of current law if debate bogs down, he said Tuesday that he expects Congress to pass a five-year bill. Senate leaders have said they would like to begin floor debate on the bill this week, probably Thursday. Eighty or 90 possible amendments are being prepared and debate could take more than a week. In the House, the Rules Committee meets that day to determine the procedures for the House debate, which could begin next week. Meanwhile, budget negotiators who have been working since mid-May have apparently made little significant progress toward reaching an agreement. Some have suggested that Congress will have to return after the November election to get a budget passed. The Senate Agriculture Committee says the bill contains $55 billion in price supports, but Yeutter says administration figures show that it would cost $59 billion. ``With the administration announcing yesterday that we're facing a $168 billion deficit, we're not going to have money for that,'' Yeutter said. He said his office also will issue an analysis of the House farm bill. Yeutter said the budget negotiators are trying to work out a five-year economic plan, but until they reveal their proposals the amount allowed for agriculture remains unknown. ``It's totally up in the air because we still do not have a budget agreement with Congress,'' said Yeutter. It is widely accepted that the versions of the farm bill passed by the House and Senate will be significantly changed in conference committee. That committee could wait for an agreement from the budget negotiators before polishing off the farm bill.

DOC.HEAD: United Telecom Reports Big Earnings Drop, Delays Sprint Buyout
DOC.TEXT: United Telecommunications Inc.'s stock plunged Tuesday after it reported a 55 percent drop in second quarter earnings and postponed its purchase of GTE Corp.'s stake in its US Sprint long-distance division. The company also announced it would eliminate 1,000 jobs nationwide and switch more employees to sales and customer service jobs. ``We have determined that, due to the disappointing second-quarter results, this is not the time to complete the buyout,'' the company's chairman and chief executive, William T. Esrey, said in a statement. ``We will continue to evaluate the status on a monthly basis, and the buyout will take place when we determine the timing to be correct,'' Esrey said. Shares of the Kansas City-based telecommunications company dropped $8.75 to $29.50 on the New York Stock Exchange, a 22 percent slide. It was the most heavily traded issue, with 11.8 million shares changing hands. Esrey blamed the earnings drop on high overhead and one-time costs. But William Deatherage, an analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York, said the company wasn't achieving the level of revenue growth it needs to keep pace with costs. ``Not only are they not taking market share from AT&T, they're not even growing at the industry rate, overall,'' Deatherage said. Analysts who had expected slightly lower earnings were surprised by what the company reported, he said. ``They have not communicated to us, over the last few months, that they were having problems of this magnitude. Therefore, it's difficult to pinpoint the exact difficulty,'' Deatherage said. ``But there's no way they can pass off a quarter like this as an aberration.'' Esrey said the company did not meet its revenue goals, particularly in customer segments such as residential and small business. ``In light of increasing competition, we are aggressively refocusing our sales efforts to place our technologically advanced network and innovative telecommunications products and services before potential customers,'' Esrey said. United Telecom had announced with great fanfare three months ago that it would buy the share of US Sprint it did not already own for $500 million and change its name to Sprint Corp. to capitalize on the high profile of the nation's third-largest long-distance company. The transaction and name change had been expected to take place this month. GTE Corp., which formed US Sprint with United Telecom as a joint venture in 1986, still owns 20 percent of the company. US Sprint has 8 percent of the long-distance market and trails only industry leader American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and MCI Communications Corp. The company said it earned $40.6 million, or 18 cents a share, during the quarter ending June 30, compared with $90.5 million, or 43 cents per share, during the same quarter a year earlier. The company said several non-recurring charges totaling $72 million affected the performance of US Sprint. The charges included a reserve for the workforce cuts, a writeoff in the value of non-productive assets and reserves set aside for other unspecified uses. The earnings came on revenue of $2.07 billion, compared with $1.85 billion in the same quarter of 1989. US Sprint's revenue increased 19 percent to $1.24 billion, but after the nonrecurring charges were included, the long-distance unit lost $42 million for the quarter. For the first six-months of the year, United Telecom earned $148.2 million, or 69 cents per share, compared with $166.9 million, or 79 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Syd Courson, a spokesman in Kansas City, said some employees will be laid off when the 1,000 positions are eliminated, but he did not have an exact number. Other job eliminations will come through attrition, he said. The company has been looking for ways to cut costs, he said. In addition, some positions were duplicated when United Telecom and Sprint began consolidating their operations this spring, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Champion Products Named Official NBA Uniform Supplier
DOC.TEXT: Champion Products, supplier of uniforms to seven professional football teams and thousands of college teams, has added the National Basketball Association to its lineup. The athletic wear manufacturer said it has been named official supplier of game uniforms, practice wear and warm-up suits to the NBA, beginning this season. The four-year agreement gives Champion the exclusive right to sell replica NBA uniforms and practice clothes. ``It's the first time we've had a contract that covers an entire league,'' company vice president Ken James said Tuesday. ``It's a tremendous opportunity for the company.'' Champion, a subsidiary of Sara Lee Corp. since February 1989, already supplies uniforms and practice equipment to thousands of high school and college teams as well as a number of NFL teams. Champion also has retail licenses from Major League Baseball and the National Hockey League. Marketing and merchandising manager Mike Merkel would not speculate on how much revenue the NBA agreement could provide, but industry sources said it could generate between $14 million and $20 million in annual sales. Champion had sales of $250 million in 1989, the last year independent sales figures were available.

DOC.HEAD: McGraw-Hill Posts Profit Decline for 2nd Qtr; Scripps Posts Loss
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, Among other ... to include Pulitzer reference. Picks up 4th graf pvs, McGraw-Hill said ... ADDS 7 new grafs with details.
DOC.TEXT: McGraw-Hill Inc. said Tuesday its second-quarter earnings fell 26.7 percent from a year earlier as improved results in financial services were offset by declines in publishing and information services. The lower results also reflected higher interest expenses and the absence of one-time gains reported last year from asset sales, the media company said. Among other media companies reporting results, Park Communications Inc. said its earnings inched higher in the second quarter. E.W. Scripps Co. reported a quarterly loss of $162,000 due in large part to a special charge resulting from the termination of a joint operating agreement involving one of its newspapers. And Pulitzer Publishing Co. said its second quarter profit fell 33.6 percent from a year ago.
DOC.HEAD: McGraw-Hill
DOC.TEXT: McGraw-Hill said it earned $37.2 million, or 76 cents a share, in the three months ended June 30 compared with $50.8 million, or $1.04 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 6.8 percent to $457.8 million from $428.4 million a year earlier. The financial services segment, which includes the Standard & Poor's credit ratings operation, had an operating profit of $27.7 million, up 32 percent from a year earlier. Chairman and Chief Executive Joseph L. Dionne said the segment benefitted from growing international activity, a strong performance in municipal bond business for S&P and the absence of losses from the McGraw-Hill News Service, closed earlier this year, and the Numerax service, which was sold. Operating profit at the information and publications services segmnet fell 20 percent to $30.6 million as gains at the F.W. Dodge and other construction information providers failed to offset advertising declines at Business Week and Aviation Week magazines and other operations. The educational and professional publishing segment posted an operating profit of $3 million, down 55 percent due partly to softness in healthcare magazine advertising. Operating profit in the broadcasting segment was flat at $9.8 million. The company owns four television stations. Dionne said the company should earn $3.50 to $4 a share for the full year despite softness in advertising. For the first six months of the year, McGraw-Hill earned $53.7 million, or $1.10 a share, down 34.5 percent from $81.9 million, or $1.68 a share, a year earlier. First-half revenue rose 7.2 percent to $877.8 million from $818.8 million a year earlier.
DOC.HEAD: Park Communications
DOC.TEXT: Park Communications, based in Ithaca, N.Y., said it earned $5.87 million, or 28 cents a share, for the quarter ended June 30, up from $5.83 million, or 28 cents a share, a year earlier. Second quarter revenue slipped 1 percent to $42.8 million from $43.2 million a year earlier. Chairman Roy H. Park said advertising revenue was down throughout the newspaper business because of problems in the retail industry. ``We are very pleased that we held our own,'' he said. ``We've had to run a pretty tight ship just to stay even.'' For the first half, Park Communications said it earned $8.68 million, or 42 cents a share, compared with $8.67 million, or 42 cents a share, a year earlier. First-half revenue slipped to $78.9 million from $79.8 million a year earlier. Park Communications owns seven television stations, 19 radio stations and 138 newspapers.
DOC.HEAD: E.W. Scripps
DOC.TEXT: In Cincinnati, E.W. Scripps said its $162,000 loss contrasted with net income of $25.2 million, or 31 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1989. The latest results reflected a $36.4 million pretax charge related to payments the company will make to Persis Corp. to terminate a joint operating agreement between Scripps' Knoxville News-Sentinel and The Knoxville Journal, owned by Persis. Under the agreement, which ends in December 1991, The News-Sentinel provides sales, production and distribution for The Journal. It said without the charge, net income for the quarter ended June 30 would have been $23.5 million, or 31 cents per share. Scripps, which publishes 19 daily newspapers, said its revenue for the quarter grew 3.4 percent to $332 million from $321 million last year. ``The soft advertising environment continues to impact revenue growth, particularly in the newspaper group,'' Lawrence A. Leser, Scripps' president and chief executive officer, said in a news release. For the first half, net income declined 76.2 percent to $9.6 million, or 12 cents a share, compared with $40.3 million, or 51 cents a share, a year earlier. First-half revenue rose 2.2 percent to $629.4 million from $615.8 million a year earlier.
DOC.HEAD: Pulitzer Publishing
DOC.TEXT: St. Louis-based Pulitzer Publishing blamed its latest earnings drop on declining newspaper advertising. Net earnings for the quarter, which ended June 30, were $4.59 million, or 44 cents a share, down from $6.92 million, or 66 cents a share, for the same period a year earlier. Revenues rose to $103.8 million from last year's $103.3 million. Along with the soft newspaper advertising conditions, the decreasing earnings reflected increased depreciation and amortization connected with the acquisition of WDSU-TV in New Orleans in December and the sale of WPTA-TV in Ft. Wayne, Ind. For the first half of the year, Pulitzer earned $5.5 million, or 53 cents a share, down 44 percent from $9.96 million, or 95 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues for the first six months increased to $199 million from $197.4 million. Pulitzer's operations include two major metropolitan dailies, the Post-Dispatch and The Arizona Daily Star in Tucson, newspapers and shoppers in the Chicago area and seven network-affiliated television stations.

DOC.HEAD: Upjohn Earnings Up 20 Percent
DOC.TEXT: KALAMAZOO, Mich. _ A pension credit and other non-recurring items helped push Upjohn Co.'s earnings up 20.6 percent in the second quarter, the pharmaceutical company said Tuesday. The pension credit was made possible by lump-sum payments to some Upjohn employees as part of a special early-retirement program. Upjohn reported net income from continuing operations of $114.1 million, or 62 cents a share, for the three months ending June 30. For the April through June period in 1989, the company made $94.6 million, or 51 cents a share. Operating revenue for the quarter rose 10.5 percent to $806.5 million from $730.1 million a year earlier, the company said. For the first six months of the year, Upjohn said it had net income of $228.3 million, or $1.23 a share, on operating revenue of $1.58 billion. That compares with $197.6 million, or $1.06 a share, on operating revenue of $1.48 billion in the first six months of 1989. The pension credit and other non-recurring items increased operating income $38 million in the second quarter, the company said. The oral anti-diabetes mediation Micronase, the anti-anxiety medication Xanax and the male-pattern baldness treatment Rogaine led a 15 percent increase in worldwide sales of human health care products and services, the company said. Upjohn said its U.S. sales rose 9 percent to $487 million for the quarter, and overseas sales rose 13 percent to $318 million, accounting for 39 percent of the company's consolidated sales. Upjohn eliminated several hundred employees last year by holding down on hiring and through the early retirement program accepted by about 600 employees. Upjohn employs about 20,000 people worldwide, including about 8,000 in Kalamazoo.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf to CORRECT date Dow last closed unchanged, Picks up 16th graf, Volume on ...
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices closed mostly lower Tuesday, while for the third session the Dow Jones industrial average gyrated above and below the 3,000 level before closing at 2,999.75 _ unchanged from Monday. In the broader market, prices were hurt by a series of disappointing corporate earnings reports. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 643 up, 877 down and 519 unchanged. The market was unforgiving to several companies that reported lower-than-expected earnings. Among them was United Telecommunications, parent of US Sprint, which fell 8} to 29{ after reporting its second-quarter profit dropped 55.1 percent. United Telecommunications was the most-active NYSE issue, with 11.8 million shares changing hands. GTE, the third most-active NYSE issue, fell } to 28\. The company reported that its second-quarter profit rose 10.6 percent, but the per-share profit of 54 cents was short of analysts' expectations. At the same time, United Telecom said it was postponing until later this year its purchase of the 19.9 percent of Sprint owned by GTE. Steve Shobin, a vice president at Merrill Lynch & Co., said the reaction to the United Telecom report indicated ``the market is walking on very thin ice.'' ``Stocks are responding easily and demonstrably to bad news and, in turn, reinforcing the skepticism of the public,'' he said. The United Telecom earnings report helped send the Dow average down from its morning high of 3,010.64. Traders said the market was looking for an excuse to take profits by selling shares. Later, the Dow retreated further in a wave of selling sparked by computerized trading tied to the index futures market, Shobin said, with the Dow dropping as low as 2,978.71. But in the final half hour of trading, the Dow rebounded more than 20 points as the direction of computer-driven trading changed and buy orders kicked in, he said. The Dow briefly went above 3,000 before closing just under that level. It was the third session the Dow exceeded 3,000, but it never has closed at that figure. The close Monday and Tuesday of 2,999.75 is a record high. Gains in several blue-chip issues helped boost the Dow. Coca-Cola rose 1~ to 47\ after reporting its second-quarter earnings jumped 18.6 percent. Chevron rose 1 to 75~ after Pennzoil said it plans to increase its 8.8 percent Chevron stake to just under 10 percent. Among other blue chips, AT&T fell [ to 37, IBM fell 1| to 120} and Philip Morris rose \ to 50{. The last time the Dow closed unchanged was March 14, 1989, when it ended at 2,306.25. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 176.79 million shares, up from 149.43 million Monday. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 216.40 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $13.690 billion, or 0.39 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 0.64 to 200.49. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 1.79 to 435.58, and S&P's 500-stock composite index fell 1.43 to 367.52. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market closed at 464.48, down 5.12. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index fell 1.19 to 364.39.

DOC.HEAD: American Cyanamid Reports 4 Percent Increase In Second Quarter Profits
DOC.TEXT: American Cyanamid Co. reported Tuesday a 4 percent increase in second quarter profits from continuing operations, despite start-up costs of a titanium dioxide plant and shutdown expenses for an ammonia facility overseas. Net earnings were $111 billion, or $1.13 per share, compared with $107 billion, or $1.05 per share, in the second quarter of 1989. Second quarter earnings came on sales of $1.23 billion, a 6 percent increase over 1989 second-quarter sales of $1.16 billion, the company said. The company incurred one-time costs in the second quarter with the closing of an ammonia facility in Welland, Canada, and the starting of a titanium dioxide plant in Rijswijk, The Netherlands. The titanium dioxide facility is a joint venture with Billiton-Netherlands B.V. Net earnings for the first six months of the year increased 5.3 percent over six months net earnings in 1989, the biotechnology and chemical company said. Six-month net earnings were $202 billion, or $2.14 per share, compared to net earnings for the first half of 1989 of $192 billion, or $1.88 a share. Net sales increased 5.5 percent to $2.4 billion compared with net sales of $2.26 billion for the first six months of 1989. Second-quarter and six-month figures did not include Cyanamid's Shulton Group, which the company announced earlier this year it was selling. The division produces consumer products, including toiletries and fragrances.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Component Manufacturer's Second Quarter Earnings Up
DOC.TEXT: Intel Corp., a manufacturer of microcomputer components, Tuesday reported a 72 percent increase in net income for the second quarter as sales increased 30 percent. Net income was $171 million in the second quarter, which ended June 30, 1990, up from $99 million in the same quarter last year. Revenue was $968 million in the second quarter this year, a 30 percent increase over the $747 million in revenue reported a year ago. Earnings per share increased from 53 cents a year ago to 84 cents in the second quarter of 1990, the company reported. The increased income was attributed to demand for components such as the 32-bit microprocessors, high-density EPROMs and microcontrollers, Intel said. During the second quarter, Intel announced it would open a new chip manufacturing plant in Ireland and keep open its Livermore plant to meet demand for its components.

DOC.HEAD: Telecommunications Products, Services Boost GTE Earnings
DOC.TEXT: GTE Corp.'s earnings increased 11 percent in the second quarter of the year on increased sales of telecommunications products and services, the nation's largest independent telephone company said Tuesday. Second quarter earnings were $364 million, or 54 cents per share, compared with $329 million, or 49 cents per share, for the same quarter last year, the company said in a press release. Revenue rose 6 percent to $4.6 billion, compared with $4.3 billion for the second quarter last year, the company said. GTE's telecommunications products and services business had revenue of $879 million for the second quarter, a 23 percent increase from $716 million for the second quarter of 1989. The increase reflects higher sales of cellular mobile telephone services, government communication systems and directory advertising, the release said. Sales of GTE's electrical products fell to $548 million from $551 million a year ago, primarily because of sluggish sales in the United States, according to the company. Contel Corp., the nation's third-largest independent telephone company, announced July 12 that it had agreed to be taken over by GTE in a stock swap valued at $6 billion. The merger is subject to the approval of both companies' stockholders, and by regulatory agencies. It would result in the country's second-largest cellular phone system operator after McCaw Cellular Communications Inc.

DOC.HEAD: House Defeats Balanced Budget Amendment; Bush Says ``Game Playing'' Over
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; raises Bush quote from penultimate graf to 12th graf: ``Bush on Tuesday,'' ADDS two grafs Sununu comments. Also moving on general news wires. ^By STEVEN KOMAROW
DOC.TEXT: The House narrowly defeated a constitutional amendment Tuesday to balance the budget after opponents said it was a gimmick to hide the failure of Congress and the president to cut the huge federal deficits. The House voted 279-150 in favor of the amendment, but it was seven votes short of the two-thirds required to propose a constitutional change. President Bush, meanwhile, declared that the worsening federal deficit meant ``the time for game-playing is over'' and set a budget meeting with congressional leaders at the White House on Wednesday. Backers of the amendment said they had expected defeat. Rep. Charles Stenholm, D-Texas, said either way, Congress needed to make tough choices to end a decade of huge increases in the national debt, which now tops $3.1 trillion. ``It's up to us folks,'' he said. ``If this amendment passes, it's going to take guts. If it doesn't pass, it's going to take guts.'' ``None of us want to face the tough decisions at hand, but faced they must be,'' said Rep. Larry Craig, R-Idaho, co-sponsor of the amendment. The amendment would, beginning in 1995, prohibit government spending from exceeding revenues, or any increase in government borrowing, unless the requirements are waived by a three-fifths vote of each chamber of Congress. The House defeated, 244-184, a proposal by Rep. Joe Barton, R-Texas, to extend the super-majority threshold to any proposal containing a tax increase. Barton said without his amendment, a balanced budget requirement would create a bias toward raising taxes. The balanced budget amendment would ``send a message to the economic markets of our country that this Congress is serious'' about fiscal responsibility, said Rep. Marilyn Lloyd, D-Tenn. Bush, in a letter Monday, urged support of the amendment along with changes in the budget process to give the president more power, including the line-item veto. ``Together with political courage and discipline, these tools are vital to solving the problem of budget deficits,'' Bush said. Bush on Tuesday told a group of magazine publishers in the White House the ``time for game playing is over'' and he would push harder for a compromise with Congress on a deficit-reduction plan. The House last voted on a balanced budget amendment in 1982, when it fell short by more than 40 votes. Support for the amendment has grown since then, largely because of growing frustration over the deficits and the failure of statutes such as Gramm-Rudman law to solve them. But opponents Tuesday said the amendment was a sham, that its requirements could easily be dodged, and that delaying the effective date to 1995 amounted to passing the buck. ``This so-called balanced budget amendment is the amendment for the truly religious because the balance to which it refers occurs only in the hereafter,'' said Rep. David Obey, D-Wis. ``We get the headlines today, someone else gets the headache of making it work tomorrow,'' said Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill. Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas, said the amendment would solve none of the nations fiscal problems except give the courts an excuse to begin dictating the nation's fiscal policy. ``Judicial tyranny waiting to happen,'' he said. President Bush, like Ronald Reagan before him, has not proposed a balanced budget and has touted the amendment so long as it doesn't take effect too quickly. The White House said it supported the House version, although it objected to language making it harder to raise fees for government services or to increase government borrowing. The delay in the effective date of the House version, until 1995, was in response to concerns expressed by the administration and others that reducing the deficit too quickly would risk damage to the economy. The president's budget office estimated on Monday that the deficit in fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1, would reach $168.8 billion unless spending is cut or taxes raised. That figure would trigger automatic spending cuts under the Gramm-Rudman law of nearly $105 billion. And the new administration estimate does not include the tens of billions of dollars needed for the bailout of the savings and loan industry. White House chief of staff John Sununu said Bush's meeting with congressional leaders on Wednesday afternoon would focus on the budget talks, which have been progressing slowly despite the president's reversal of his ``no new taxes'' pledge. ``The agenda's a very simple one: let's get a solution to the deficit, get a package to come out of the summit and move forward,'' Sununu said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Stock Prices Shed Moderately in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell in early trading against the Japanese yen Wednesday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange dropped moderately. The dollar started trading at 147.56 yen, down 0.64 yen from Tuesday's close of 148.20 yen. It finished at 147.80 yen in New York. Currency dealers said the dollar's slide followed its retreat in New York, partly because of an increase in the U.S. trade deficit in May. The U.S. Commerce Department reported the nation's trade deficit for May increased to $7.73 billion from a revised $7.31 billion in April. The government said increases in oil and auto imports offset the second-highest level of exports on record. A dealer with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank said the dollar's weakness as a whole was in line with trends of declining U.S. interest rates since last week. ``It's somewhat difficult now to buy dollars'' over prospects of further declines in interest rates, said the dealer who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said many market players were awaiting Wednesday's testimony by U.S. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan before Congress. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 91.38 points, or 0.27 percent, to move to 33,080.90 in the first 30 minutes of trading. The index gained 150.55 points on Tuesday. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds edged up to 86.87 points, from Tuesday's close of 86.84. The yield stood at 7.225 percent, down from the previous day's 7.23 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Votes to Cut Short Civil Rights Debate
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 5th graf: ``The sharpest,'' with two new grafs to CORRECT that hiring practices sted work forces subject to challenge; INSERTS grafs 9-10: ``After voting,'' Senate recesses and negotiations continue. Also moving on general news wires. ^By MIKE ROBINSON
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted Tuesday to speed up action on a major job discrimination bill, brushing aside warnings from critics that the measure would lead to minority hiring quotas. The action brought an outcry from Republican Leader Bob Dole that the bill was ``being rammed down our throats'' while White House Chief of Staff John Sununu accused sponsors of backing out on a compromise reached last week. ``If we're going to be treated like a bunch of bums on this side of the aisle, there won't be any agreements on anything,'' said Dole after the 62-38 vote to limit debate to 30 hours. Provisions of the bill sponsored by Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to punitive damages for victims of intentional discrimination. The sharpest clashes have come over a provision that would make it easier to challenge hiring practices of companies whose work forces do not mirror the racial and ethnic makeup of the local labor pool. Such employers, if challenged in court, would have to prove that the hiring practices that led to the composition of the work force were justified by business necessity. That would reverse the most controversial of five 1989 Supreme Court rulings on job bias addressed by the bill. The justices, in a case involving a salmon cannery in Alaska, held that it was up to those who file such lawsuits to prove the practices they objected to were not motivated by business necessity. The Bush administration, business groups and some GOP senators say the bill would lead to employers using hiring quotas to avert any chance they would incur the costs, including damage awards, of job discrimination suits. After voting to set the time limit, the Senate debated an alternative version of the legislation sponsored by Sen. Nancy Landon Kassebaum, R-Kan. But it broke off action for the night with the administration and sponsors agreeing to negotiate some more while still allowing the clock to run on the 30-hour deadline. ``I think everybody agrees its worth one last shot, one last effort,'' Dole said as the Senate recessed. Bush said last week he was encouraged by the negotiations after Kennedy and Sununu appeared to reach a compromise. ``I thought we had an agreement,'' Sununu said. ``The senator came in yesterday after we had an agreement, and then we didn't have it anymore.'' He said President Bush would continue to press for a civil rights agreement but would veto any measure that would lead to hiring quotas. At a photo opportunity session earlier, Sununu said in answer a question on the chances of an agreement: ``We had one Thursday. They reneged on it.'' Kennedy said on the Senate floor, however, the ``president never claimed that there had been a deal and the situation was locked up ... and neither did I.'' If anyone said otherwise, he said, ``They misspoke.'' Kennedy noted the indignation of critics of the bill who argued they needed more than 30 hours to purge it of what they viewed as quota provisions and other objectionable features. ``I wish we could see that kind of indignation about the kind of unfairness that is taking place at job locations all over this country against women and minorities,'' Kennedy said. Dole grimly acknowledged the defection of eight Republicans on the roll call. Raising his voice, he suggested that perhaps someone else should be found to serve as minority leader. ``Some of our Republicans _ they know better than the leadership,'' he grumbled. Dole complained that sponsors were trying to portray Republicans as opposed to civil rights because they voted in large part against limiting debate. He said GOP senators wanted a civil rights bill but remained concerned about the quota issues and other features of the bill. ``To have this rammed down our throats because it didn't please the senator from Massachusetts ... it seems to me that we're going to be in for a long, hot summer,'' Dole said. To drive home the notion that Republicans did not want to stand in the way of civil rights, Dole brought a sudden, stunned silence in the Senate by offering to approve the measure immediately on a voice vote immediately. ``Now we have a chance to pass this historic legislation right now,'' Dole declared. ``We can finish in 20 minutes.'' Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, a proponent of the bill, objected to three separate offers by Dole to pass the measure immediately. Mitchell declared that senators who were scheduled to offer amendments under the 30-hour time limit were entitled to a hearing on them. But Dole said the Democratic reluctance to pass the bill immediately proved that it had some troublesome features that even proponents wanted out before they went home to explain the measure to voters. ``Now we're told we can't vote because we have some fellas stuck out here on a limb and we need some cosmetic surgery,'' Dole said. Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo., one of the Republicans who supported limiting debate, said he didn't believe ``that what we have just done furthers the cause of enacting this into law.'' ``I am satisfied with the bill as is and I will vote for the bill as is, but it is clear that this bill is not going to become law unless the president agrees to it,'' Danforth said. Republicans joining Danforth in the vote to limit debate were: James Jeffords of Vermont, a co-sponsor of the bill; William Cohen of Maine; David Durenberger of Minnesota; Mark Hatfield of Oregon; John Heinz and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania; and Bob Packwood of Oregon. The one Democrat to vote against limiting debate was James Exon, D-Neb.

DOC.HEAD: Great American Bank to Sell Portion of Operations to Wells Fargo
DOC.TEXT: Struggling Great American Bank has agreed to sell its 130 branches in California to Wells Fargo & Co. for $492 million. The San Diego-based thrift, the country's eighth largest savings and loan, has been struggling against a rising tide of losses since the fourth quarter of 1988. Great American acquired a widening loan problem along from an Arizona thrift it bought in 1986. Great American spokesman Brian Luscomb said Tuesday the thrift's employment would drop from 3,563 to about 1,700. It was unclear Tuesday how many of Great American's employees in California would be hired by Wells Fargo. Losses during 1989 hit a staggering $263.4 million and left Great American unable to meet minimum federal capital standards. The thrift must raise $350 million by the end of the year to avoid a government takeover. The proposed deal is subject to approval by shareholders and federal regulators. The California branches have assests of $5.9 billion. The deal with Wells Fargo would pare down Great American's $15.4 billion in assets to between $8 billion and $9 billion. Great American would retain 81 branch offices in Washington, Arizona and Colorado.
